Deflating an Inflation Worry

Author: Walter, Norbert

Publication info: New York Times , Late Edition (East Coast); New York, N.Y. [New York, N.Y]02 Feb 1997: 14.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/430739149?accountid=11752

Abstract: IN testimony before Congress two weeks ago, Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, discussed his worries about the danger of wage inflation. Specifically, Mr. Greenspan is concerned that shortages of qualified people for job openings may lead to excessive wage offers to fill those jobs. Some people take this uneasiness to suggest that a rise in interest rates may be in the offing -- if not at the Federal Open Market Committee meeting starting on Tuesday, then sometime later this year. While German economists like myself are supposedly born with a penchant to worry themselves sick about even the slightest signs of inflation, I cannot quite share Mr. Greenspan's concerns. From my perspective, the most important dimension in evaluating future wage pressures in the United States is regularly overlooked: the increased global outsourcing of services like data processing and computer programming. Computers let American companies tap into a labor pool without national borders -- thus shattering old-school assumptions about tightness in domestic labor markets. If the labor market becomes tight at home, a company can look abroad. In this sense, the United States is again the trailblazer. In the 1970's, big American manufacturers scoured the world to find cheap sources of offshore labor to control production costs. Undoubtedly, the decision to move production abroad not only helped American companies' bottom lines, it was also a crucial factor in keeping the nation's inflation rate in check. Other nations, like Germany and Japan, jumped on the bandwagon only much later.

Links: http://findit.library.jhu.edu/resolve?url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=unknown&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Anytimes&amp;atitle=Deflating+an+Inflation+Worry&amp;title=New+York+Times&amp;issn=03624331&amp;date=1997-02-02&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=3.14&amp;au=Walter%2C+Norbert&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=New+York+Times&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/04424420&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text: AuthorAffiliation Norbert Walter is the chief economist of Deutsche Bank.
IN testimony before Congress two weeks ago, Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, discussed his worries about the danger of wage inflation. Specifically, Mr. Greenspan is concerned that shortages of qualified people for job openings may lead to excessive wage offers to fill those jobs. Some people take this uneasiness to suggest that a rise in interest rates may be in the offing -- if not at the Federal Open Market Committee meeting starting on Tuesday, then sometime later this year.
While German economists like myself are supposedly born with a penchant to worry themselves sick about even the slightest signs of inflation, I cannot quite share Mr. Greenspan's concerns. From my perspective, the most important dimension in evaluating future wage pressures in the United States is regularly overlooked: the increased global outsourcing of services like data processing and computer programming. Computers let American companies tap into a labor pool without national borders -- thus shattering old-school assumptions about tightness in domestic labor markets. If the labor market becomes tight at home, a company can look abroad.
In this sense, the United States is again the trailblazer. In the 1970's, big American manufacturers scoured the world to find cheap sources of offshore labor to control production costs. Undoubtedly, the decision to move production abroad not only helped American companies' bottom lines, it was also a crucial factor in keeping the nation's inflation rate in check. Other nations, like Germany and Japan, jumped on the bandwagon only much later.
United States companies are now repeating this process in the services sector. The global services labor pool, after all, is just a phone call or an E-mail message away. Accordingly, credit card providers, insurance firms, phone companies and technology service concerns are placing crucial business functions all over the world. Even important value-added skills, like software design, are being moved offshore.
This ability to tap into the global labor pool without headaches may well be a special advantage for American corporations. Because English is the second, if not first, language of many people, American companies can readily depend on service providers who speak the same language as headquarters does. Compare that with the problems of, say, a German or Japanese insurance company trying to start a billing department in Barbados or Sri Lanka.
While the effect of global telecommunications and computer networks is increasingly understood, little thought has been given to what it means for the labor-shortage debate in the United States -- specifically, whether inflationary pressures will result.
If the United States economy is supposed to grow faster, signs of inflation from a tight labor market would not be welcome because they would probably lead to higher interest rates. Economists typically refer at this point to a concept called Nairu -- the nonaccelerating inflation rate of unemployment, or the lowest level of unemployment the economy can sustain without setting off inflationary pressures. But we have seen little to no inflation even though the American unemployment rate has fallen below 5.5 percent -- generally seen now as the point at which the labor market supposedly becomes tight enough to become inflationary. Basically, policy makers and analysts have tried to cope with their failure to capture the correlation between unemployment and inflation by lowering the Nairu.
In my view, though, the issue ought to be cast in somewhat starker terms. I wonder whether, instead of fidgeting with numbers, it would not be more appropriate to assume that the Nairu concept may have been destroyed by the creation of global labor pools -- like the one in India generated by Jawaharlal Nehru himself, who, as India's first Prime Minister and a determined modernizer of Indian society, created a work force that is solving many of America's Nairu-related worries from afar.
Such skill pools around the world demonstrate the limitations of any economic model, like Nairu, that does not look beyond national borders. After all, for Nairu to remain a meaningful economic concept, the labor pool must be rather clearly defined on a national, or at least regional, basis. The globalization of services throws this requirement overboard. As a result, it is hard to draw reliable conclusions about slight pickups in wage levels in regions of the United States.
Labor supply is much more elastic today than in the past -- and not only because of old-fashioned (and much debated) immigration. These new forms of ''labor sharing'' provide great flexibility. This not only benefits American companies in their focus on the bottom line, but it also helps the American economy as a whole -- with its overblown inflation worries. And it helps other parts of the world to link into a better division of labor.

Fixing the Falling Greenback

Author: Nasar, Sylvia

Publication info: New York Times , Late Edition (East Coast); New York, N.Y. [New York, N.Y]16 Apr 1995: 3.6.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/430136068?accountid=11752

Abstract: A. I think the Fed should raise interest rates after they make a commitment to gradually reduce inflation in the U.S. I'm talking about a recommitment on the part of the Fed to get inflation down so low that it won't make a difference. If holders of savings believe that the central bank is truly committed to lowering inflation, they don't need as much of an interest rate inducement to make them lend their money. Here's what I'd recommend Chairman Greenspan and the committee do. We know that inflation is going to be rising through 1995. The Fed needs to make a commitment that 1996's inflation rate will not be higher than 1995's, and that 1997's inflation rate will be lower than 1995's. This will help us get back on course to gradual disinflation. I have never been one to argue for dramatic reduction in inflation rates. I've always argued for gradualism. It's not likely that Japan's discount rate move from 1.75 to 1.0 percent will be followed by a big enough drop in interest rates to do the job. If all the interest rates, including the postal savings rate, moved down a full 100 basis points, it would be a very good first step. What's really needed is a follow-up move, which ideally should be a coordinated move between the U.S. and Japan. I'm not sure, but they might need to take the discount rate on down to zero. If the U.S. and Japan both altered rates in opposite directions at the same time, it would make currency markets believe that the two countries are serious.

Links: http://findit.library.jhu.edu/resolve?url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=unknown&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Anytimes&amp;atitle=Fixing+the+Falling+Greenback&amp;title=New+York+Times&amp;issn=03624331&amp;date=1995-04-16&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=3.6&amp;au=Nasar%2C+Sylvia&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=New+York+Times&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text: "YET another postwar low." Even casual followers of finance know this phrase refers to the dollar's continuing fall against the yen. But last Monday's new low was startling even in these days. For a few hours, the dollar hit 80.15 yen -- it was 99.58 in December -- with the one-day fall at one point exceeding 4 percent. The dizzy drop led to sniping among the superpowers. Here are the opinions of Wayne D. Angell, the chief economist at Bear, Stearns and a former Federal Reserve governor. SYLVIA NASAR
Q. Why has the dollar been so weak?
A. The dollar can only weaken against gold, other currencies and commodities when the Fed creates more dollar reserves than the world wishes to hold. The Fed does that if it guesses too low about where the Fed funds rate should be. Then, it is forced to buy T-bills, creating more dollar reserves.
Q. So you see the dollar's weakness as a sign the Fed has been too easy?
A. The strong yen is due 60 percent to overly restrictive monetary policy in Japan and 40 percent to overly accommodative policy in the United States.
It's really kind of sad hearing Treasury Secretary Rubin say that a strong dollar is in the national interest and see him be so unsuccessful.
Q. You don't think that the weak dollar causes inflation, but rather that it is an indication of too much monetary ease. Does a weak dollar pose any danger in and of itself?
A. The danger of continued dollar weakness is that it's a beggar-thy-neighbor policy. It means all major industrial plants get located in the United States as the rate of return on capital in the United States goes up and the rate of return on capital in Europe and Japan goes down.
Q. Has the dollar hit bottom?
A. We don't know that for sure. It did look like something close to a blowout when the dollar got down to only 80 yen in the hours before trading began Monday morning in Tokyo. But it's still a question whether there can be much firming without any action by the Bank of Japan or the Federal Reserve.
Q. Do you expect the Fed to raise rates if the dollar continues to slip?
A. The Fed doesn't want to lose its independence in monetary policy by saying that it is acting primarily on the exchange rate. But the exchange rate is a lot more important to the Fed than they want it to appear.
Q. So you're saying that the Fed should push up rates even though it has raised rates seven times in the past 14 months and even though inflation seems low and the economy is growing more slowly?
A. I think the Fed should raise interest rates after they make a commitment to gradually reduce inflation in the U.S. I'm talking about a recommitment on the part of the Fed to get inflation down so low that it won't make a difference. If holders of savings believe that the central bank is truly committed to lowering inflation, they don't need as much of an interest rate inducement to make them lend their money.
By and large, from 1988 to 1991, the public utterances of individual members of the Fed and statements by the chairman emphasized that commitment. As a result, we ended up two years later with an inflation rate of 2.3 percent, down from 5.5 percent. And the price of gold fell to $330 and yields on two-year Treasuries went down to 3.73 percent.
In other words, the results of this pledge were better inflation performance and lower interest rates. The dollar stayed amazingly strong given that the economy was slowing and rates were falling. But, after the last election, the question asked by capital managers around the world is whether today's Fed has shifted its priorities away from reducing the rate of inflation. Now, the world's perception is that all the Fed cares about is jobs, jobs, jobs.
Here's what I'd recommend Chairman Greenspan and the committee do. We know that inflation is going to be rising through 1995. The Fed needs to make a commitment that 1996's inflation rate will not be higher than 1995's, and that 1997's inflation rate will be lower than 1995's. This will help us get back on course to gradual disinflation. I have never been one to argue for dramatic reduction in inflation rates. I've always argued for gradualism.
Q. Do inflation fears undermine the dollar? Is inflation really picking up?
A. In terms of the dollar, the worst of all worlds is for the Federal Reserve to appear to be complacent as the inflation rate keeps moving up. It has already moved up from a 2.3 percent annual rate last year to a 2.9 percent rate in in the past 12 months.
We're not in the worst situation. So far the acceleration of inflation has not seemed to bother anyone in the U.S. But it has clearly bottomed out. Core inflation -- the Consumer Price Index minus food and energy -- came in at another 0.3 percent in March, which means that the rate over the past three months has been running at 4.1 percent.
The problem is that inflation clearly is going to be higher in 1995. So what happens in 1996?
Q. What about Treasury policy?
A. When President Reagan was elected, he placed a high priority on getting inflation down. That resulted in a stronger dollar. Treasury Under Secretary Beryl Sprinkle criticized the Fed for being too easy, saying the money supply was growing too fast and the dollar was too weak. The way to make the dollar appreciate is to do exactly what Ronald Reagan did. We had tight monetary policy and bigger deficits, and we ended up with the same result as Japan is now seeing because that caused the demand for our currency to increase.
Larry Summers at the Treasury should be calling Paul Volcker on the phone and saying: "Paul, we know the dollar was in weak condition when you became Fed chairman in August 1979. How did you fix this dollar weakness so quickly?" If Bob Rubin says he can't do it, it is a pretty lame explanation for a Secretary of the Treasury to say he wants a strong dollar but doesn't know what to do.
Q. What should United States policy be toward Japan?
A. Japan is on the borderline of zero-growth depression and a bank crisis. Japan's tight money means that the yield on capital in Japan is close to zero, and the private sector can't invest if there's no return.
It's not likely that Japan's discount rate move from 1.75 to 1.0 percent will be followed by a big enough drop in interest rates to do the job. If all the interest rates, including the postal savings rate, moved down a full 100 basis points, it would be a very good first step. What's really needed is a follow-up move, which ideally should be a coordinated move between the U.S. and Japan. I'm not sure, but they might need to take the discount rate on down to zero. If the U.S. and Japan both altered rates in opposite directions at the same time, it would make currency markets believe that the two countries are serious.
Photograph Wayne D. Angell, chief economist at Bear, Stearns. (Edward Keating/The New York Times)

Subject: CURRENCY; CREDIT

Location: JAPAN

People: ANGELL, WAYNE D

Title: Fixing the Falling Greenback

Publication title: New York Times, Late Edition (East Coast); New York, N.Y.

Pages: 3.6

Publication year: 1995

Publication date: Apr 16, 1995

CREDIT MARKETS; Prices of Treasuries Increase A 2d Day on Inflation Data

Author: Hurtado, Robert

Publication info: New York Times , Late Edition (East Coast); New York, N.Y. [New York, N.Y]13 Apr 1995: D.20.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/430135090?accountid=11752

Abstract: Michelle Laughlin, chief economist at Sanwa Securities, said that through the first quarter of this year the inflation rate was running at 4.1 percent on an annualized basis, compared with a 2.6 percent inflation rate for all of 1994. "Last year in the first three months, the inflation rate was 2.9 percent annualized," she said. "This is a confirmation that higher input cost or raw materials gains are coming through to the consumer level." "I do think that the inflation news this week will keep the Fed in play for a tightening on May 23," she said. "The odds are low but not zero. The market has priced in a 30 percent chance of a rate increase, which I think is about appropriate." "Freddie Mac Yields" tracks average weekly yields on Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation 30-year and 15-year participation certificates since December. Yields track changes in fixed-rate mortgages. (Source: Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corp.)

Links: http://findit.library.jhu.edu/resolve?url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Anytimes&amp;atitle=CREDIT+MARKETS%3B+Prices+of+Treasuries+Increase+A+2d+Day+on+Inflation+Data&amp;title=New+York+Times&amp;issn=03624331&amp;date=1995-04-13&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=D.20&amp;au=Hurtado%2C+Robert&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=New+York+Times&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text: Prices of Treasury securities rose for a second consecutive day yesterday, helped by a gain in the Consumer Price Index of only two-tenths of a percent.
Some market participants noted, however, that the market has now seen three good sets of figures -- last Friday's jobs data, Tuesday's Producer Price Index and yesterday's Consumer Price Index -- and has not really taken off. Part of the reason may be that small investors are staying away; another may be that expectations of a slowing economy with little inflation have already been priced into the market.
The 30-year bond rose 8/32 , to 10310/32 ; its yield, which moves in the opposite direction from its price, dropped to 7.35 percent yesterday from 7.37 percent on Tuesday.
Dealers and traders were generally cautious ahead of the short trading week going into the Easter weekend. Reports on industrial production and capacity utilization are scheduled tomorrow -- Good Friday -- when United States markets will be closed.
In another report issued yesterday, the Atlanta Fed said its monthly survey of business activity showed a slower pace of growth in March compared with the previous month. However, market reaction to the report was muted, traders said.
Today investors will get a look at March's retail sales, but trading will be shortened as the Public Securities Association, the main trade group for the public debt industry, has recommended that the Government securities market close at 2 P.M. in observance of Holy Thursday. The recommendation includes money-market and mortgage-backed securities trading.
Yesterday's report on the consumer prices for March showed a gain of two-tenths of a percent, lower than the average forecast of three-tenths of a percent; while the core rate, excluding the more volatile food and energy components, was up three-tenths of a percent, as expected. But some analysts feel that inflation is not as low as it should be.
Michelle Laughlin, chief economist at Sanwa Securities, said that through the first quarter of this year the inflation rate was running at 4.1 percent on an annualized basis, compared with a 2.6 percent inflation rate for all of 1994. "Last year in the first three months, the inflation rate was 2.9 percent annualized," she said. "This is a confirmation that higher input cost or raw materials gains are coming through to the consumer level."
Ms. Laughlin said the market might have been helped later in the morning when a CNW Research and Marketing report on car sales for the first 10 days of April showed considerable weakness. In fact, she said, the report noted that this was the slowest 10-day sales in autos in at least three years.
"I do think that the inflation news this week will keep the Fed in play for a tightening on May 23," she said. "The odds are low but not zero. The market has priced in a 30 percent chance of a rate increase, which I think is about appropriate."
In the municipal bond market, prices were little changed. Some investors were concerned that some housing bond issues could be hurt by proposed government revisions, including last month's plan to reorganize the Department of Housing and Urban Development to consolidate 60 major programs and result in three performance-based funds.
The fear is that many of the tax-exempt securities sold to fund subsidy programs could face potential ratings changes or early redemptions. The restructuring could even even raise the default rate on some housing bonds backed by rental aggreements if there are changes to the rent subsidy programs.
Housing bonds are popular with many investors because they offer higher yields than other tax-exempt securities. Other investors avoid them because they are often redeemed early and tend to lag when interest rates fall. Investors can get as much as 50 basis points more by buying housing bonds instead of similarly rated double-A revenue bonds.
Graph "Freddie Mac Yields" tracks average weekly yields on Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation 30-year and 15-year participation certificates since December. Yields track changes in fixed-rate mortgages. (Source: Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corp.)

CREDIT MARKETS Gains Fade On Fears Of Inflation

Author: Hurtado, Robert

Publication info: New York Times , Late Edition (East Coast); New York, N.Y. [New York, N.Y]16 June 1994: D.8.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/429781667?accountid=11752

Abstract: "Inflation in May was not a problem, but inflation is something to be concerned about," Mr. [Raymond A. Worseck] said. "It is on the mind of the Fed, on the minds of people investing in foreign bonds and on the minds of people watching commodity prices." "Many in the market still live with the memories of 1974, when commodity prices double and tripled," Mr. Worseck said. "But as long as the Fed holds the line, they're making a monetary accommodation that would allow temporary commodity events to spread into general inflation." Inflation fears in the market were heightened after comments by John P. LaWare, a Federal Reserve governor. In an interview with the Market News Service, Mr. LaWare said that although the rate of capacity utilization in American industry fell slightly in May, it had reached potentially inflationary levels. 'Straining the System'

Links: http://findit.library.jhu.edu/resolve?url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Anytimes&amp;atitle=CREDIT+MARKETS+Gains+Fade+On+Fears+Of+Inflation&amp;title=New+York+Times&amp;issn=03624331&amp;date=1994-06-16&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=D.8&amp;au=Hurtado%2C+Robert&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=New+York+Times&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text: Prospects for a rally in the bond market on raised expectations of a slowing economy quickly faded yesterday. A sharp rise in commodity prices, a weak dollar and comments by a Federal Reserve official all helped revive investors' concerns about inflation.
Bond prices initially rose on industrial production and business inventory data that suggested a slowdown in the economy, traders said.
The price of the 30-year bond fell 30/32 , to 8613/32 . Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction from price, rose to 7.39 percent, from 7.30 percent on Tuesday, but still well within the trading range of the last few months. Since April, the yield on the long bond has been as low as 7.10 percent, on April 26, and as high as 7.60 percent, on May 11.
Raymond A. Worseck, chief economist at A. G. Edwards & Sons of St. Louis, said that yesterday's reports were in the range of most economists' expectations. They showed the economy was growing, but at a slower pace, he said. Concern on Inflation
"Inflation in May was not a problem, but inflation is something to be concerned about," Mr. Worseck said. "It is on the mind of the Fed, on the minds of people investing in foreign bonds and on the minds of people watching commodity prices."
The Commodity Research Bureau's index of 21 commodities, a closely watched gauge of inflation, surged 3.31 points yesterday, to 238.61, near a three-and-a-half-year high of 239.20 reached on May 24. The price of oil moved above $19 a barrel yesterday, with the July contract for light crude on the New York Mercantile Exchange settling at $19.86 a barrel.
The gain in the commodities index was led by grains and hogs. Mr. Worseck noted that of the three commodity categories, industrial, agricultural and precious metals, the focus has been on agriculture, where one crop failure can cause turmoil in the market.
"Many in the market still live with the memories of 1974, when commodity prices double and tripled," Mr. Worseck said. "But as long as the Fed holds the line, they're making a monetary accommodation that would allow temporary commodity events to spread into general inflation."
Inflation fears in the market were heightened after comments by John P. LaWare, a Federal Reserve governor. In an interview with the Market News Service, Mr. LaWare said that although the rate of capacity utilization in American industry fell slightly in May, it had reached potentially inflationary levels. 'Straining the System'
The Market News Service reported that Mr. LaWare was more concerned about the relatively high level of capacity utilization. "The estimates are that if you get capacity utilization at 85 percent that you are really kind of straining the system," Mr. LaWare was quoted saying.
Another Fed governor, Lawrence B. Lindsey, told the Market News Service on Tuesday that monetary policy was now "within the neutral range" but that mere neutrality could become inappropriate at some point.
But Mr. LaWare's comments bothered the market more, even though he had made similar comments in the past.
The market was helped by yesterday's report showing the decline in capacity utilization. There is much debate, however, whether industries are at or near the point were they will begin to raise prices.
Industrial production rose two-tenths of 1 percent in May, slightly stronger than expected. Capacity utilization slipped to 83.5 percent, from 83.6 percent, with the market trading up on the decline in capacity usage.
Elsewhere in the market, the Treasury announced that next week it would sell $17 billion of two-year notes on Tuesday and $11 billion of five-year notes on Wednesday. In when-issued trading yesterday, the two-year was being offered at a price to yield 5.92 percent, and the five-year at a price to yield 6.69 percent. Massachusetts Issue
In the municipal market, underwriters, led by Paine Webber Inc., of Massachusetts' $300 million of special-obligation revenue bonds , announced the deal's final pricing. The maximum yield for a bond due in 2014 is 5.90 percent, with shorter-maturity serial bonds priced to yield from 3.40 percent in 1995 to 5.85 percent in 2012.
Moody's Investors Service rated the financing A1. Standard & Poor's gave it a AA- and Fitch Investors Service, A+.

New Governor Named For the Bank of Canada

Author: Farnsworth, Clyde H

Publication info: New York Times , Late Edition (East Coast); New York, N.Y. [New York, N.Y]23 Dec 1993: D.2.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/429398858?accountid=11752

Abstract: Mr. [John Crow]'s tenure recalled a period of the early 1980's when the chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, Paul A. Volcker, throttled inflation in the United States. Yet Mr. Volcker's efforts did not rouse the same political passions as Mr. Crow's did in Canada, possibly because the austerity in the United States was followed by a strong expanson that created millions of jobs. Canada's growth has not made a dent in the jobless rate. Bankers had argued that Mr. Crow was essential to maintain the country's financial credibility abroad and prevent a collapse of the Canadian dollar. Yet many on the left wanted to dump him. A recently formed "Crow To Go" coalition called the policy of fighting inflation with high interest rates "misguided and destructive."

Links: http://findit.library.jhu.edu/resolve?url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=unknown&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Anytimes&amp;atitle=New+Governor+Named+For+the+Bank+of+Canada%3A+%5BBiography%5D&amp;title=New+York+Times&amp;issn=03624331&amp;date=1993-12-23&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=D.2&amp;au=Farnsworth%2C+Clyde+H&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=New+York+Times&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text: Special to The New York Times
John Crow, whose Draconian anti-inflation policies have made him a political target in a period of double-digit Canadian unemployment, is stepping down as the governor of Canada's central bank, the Government announced today.
But he is to be replaced by his deputy, Gordon Thiessen, a longtime Bank of Canada employee, who is expected to keep the same emphasis on price stability.
The announcement by Finance Minister Paul Martin ended one of the biggest guessing games here since the election of the Liberal Government nearly two months ago.
Mr. Crow's policies had been attacked by many Liberals, including the new Prime Minister, Jean Chretien, whose campaign slogan was "jobs, jobs, jobs." But until now the Government had ducked the issue of whether he would be reappointed when his seven-year term expired next month. Policy Called 'Misguided'
Bankers had argued that Mr. Crow was essential to maintain the country's financial credibility abroad and prevent a collapse of the Canadian dollar. Yet many on the left wanted to dump him. A recently formed "Crow To Go" coalition called the policy of fighting inflation with high interest rates "misguided and destructive."
Jeff Rubin, the chief economist at Wood Gundy Inc., a leading brokerage firm, said Mr. Crow "became a sacrificial lamb."
The change in the guard did not fluster the markets. The Canadian dollar, after touching a six-year low, rebounded immediately after the announcement and closed against the American dollar at 74.82 cents, up 0.43 cent.
"The market is taking it as a very positive sign that the new governor is someone so closely identified with the present policies," said Katherine Beattie, an economist at MMS International, a financial information service.
Edward Neufeld, executive vice president and chief economist at the Royal Bank, said he expected a "smooth transition" and little political trouble for Mr. Thiessen. Inflation Less Than 2 Percent
"The new governor is in the fortunate position of not having to drive the inflation rate down any further," he said.
At less than 2 percent, Canada's inflation is about a point lower than that of the United States. But its unemployment, at more than 11 percent, is almost double that of the United States.
Mr. Crow's tenure recalled a period of the early 1980's when the chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, Paul A. Volcker, throttled inflation in the United States. Yet Mr. Volcker's efforts did not rouse the same political passions as Mr. Crow's did in Canada, possibly because the austerity in the United States was followed by a strong expanson that created millions of jobs. Canada's growth has not made a dent in the jobless rate.
Like the man he is succeeding, Mr. Thiessen started at the Bank of Canada on the research staff. Although the two men are roughly the same age -- Mr. Thiessen is 55, and Mr. Crow, 56 -- Mr. Thiessen joined the bank 10 years earler, in 1963. In the 60's Mr. Crow held senior staff positions with the International Monetary Fund in Washington.
Mr. Thiessen, whose appointment is effective Feb. 1, becomes the sixth governor and will earn an initial salary of $224,000 Canadian ($168,000).
Photograph John Crow, who will step down as Canada's central banker.

CREDIT MARKETS; Canada Rate at 20-Year Low

Publication info: New York Times , Late Edition (East Coast); New York, N.Y. [New York, N.Y]23 June 1993: D.15.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/429101519?accountid=11752

Abstract: Andrew Pyle, chief economist for MMS International, said that Canada's leading banks could follow sometime this week with a cut in prime lending rates from 6 percent to their lowest levels since the mid-1960's. Unlike the United States, where interest rates have bottomed, Canada's sluggish recovery and negligible inflation give interest rates further room to ease, economists said. The recession hit Canada twice as hard as the United States, they added.

Links: http://findit.library.jhu.edu/resolve?url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Anytimes&amp;atitle=CREDIT+MARKETS%3B+Canada+Rate+at+20-Year+Low&amp;title=New+York+Times&amp;issn=03624331&amp;date=1993-06-23&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=D.15&amp;au=&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=New+York+Times&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text: Reuters
Canada's official interest rate fell today to a 20-year low, paving the way for prime lending rates to dip below those of the United States for the first time since 1984.
The Bank of Canada rate, which sets the trend for short-term interest rates, dropped to 4.88 percent from 4.94 percent at its weekly setting.
Andrew Pyle, chief economist for MMS International, said that Canada's leading banks could follow sometime this week with a cut in prime lending rates from 6 percent to their lowest levels since the mid-1960's.
United States prime rates are currently at 6 percent as well.
But unlike the United States, where interest rates have bottomed, Canada's sluggish recovery and negligible inflation give interest rates further room to ease, economists said. The recession hit Canada twice as hard as the United States, they added.
Inflation is practically nonexistent in Canada. The country's consumer price index fell by two-tenths of 1 percent in May after rising by the same rate in April.
Mr. Pyle said the Bank of Canada rate could fall another 25 to 50 basis points, or a quarter to half a percentage point, during the summer.
The central bank's anti-inflation policy, worldwide deflationary pressures and the recession have caused the Bank of Canada rate and prime rates to fall sharply from the spring of 1990.
The Bank of Canada has exceeded its tough inflation targets of 3 percent at the end of 1992 and 2.5 percent by mid-1994.

Business Diary/March 15-20

Author: Kurtzman, Joel

Publication info: New York Times , Late Edition (East Coast); New York, N.Y. [New York, N.Y]22 Mar 1992: A.2.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/428417738?accountid=11752

Abstract: The new world order made it to South Africa last week when the white minority electorate gave President F. W. de Klerk an overwhelming mandate to end its monopoly on political power. Mr. de Klerk's ruling National Party has been negotiating with other groups, including the African National Congress, headed by Nelson Mandela, to write a new constitution. After a period of transition "it is a foregone conclusion that Mandela will be South Africa's president," said Prakash Sethi, an adviser to a black South African business group. "The transition is likely to be peaceful," he said. South Africa's economy is in shambles from years of sanctions. Though the United States lifted sanctions last year, many states and cities have kept them in place. "The British and Germans who stayed have a large economic base and will increase investment faster than the Americans can get back in," Mr. Sethi said. Japan's Gesture The offer looked generous enough. Japan, which exports cars to the United States under the 1981 Voluntary Restraint Agreement, said last week it would limit the number of cars going to the United States to 1.65 million, down from 2.3 million, the current limit. That gesture, Japan's Ministry of International Trade and Industry said, would help Detroit's Big Three recover from last year's combined losses of $4.5 billion. But Detroit was skeptical. Since Japan only exported 1.7 million vehicles to the United States last year, its proposal would simply keep the "same volume their auto makers imported into the United States from Japan in 1991," said Harold A. Poling, chairman of the Ford Motor Company. "So, where is the reduction?" he asked. No Compromise on Israel When President Bush rejected Israel's request for loan guarantees last week, he said it was because Israel had refused to stop building settlements in the occupied West Bank and Gaza. Israel wants guarantees so it can borrow $10 billion in the world's capital markets at more favorable rates to build housing for immigrants from the ex-Soviet Union. That is a different matter from settling the West Bank and Gaza, it says. To move beyond the impasse, Congress proposed a compromise. Grant Israel an immediate $1 billion in guarantees, said Senator Patrick J. Leahy, Democrat of Vermont, but keep the remaining $9 billion in reserve, subject to Mr. Bush's approval. Mr. Bush said no. A New Export Champ The figures were cheery last week. The trade deficit narrowed to $5.77 billion, a drop of 3.9 percent, the Commerce Department said. But those numbers may actually signal the end of a trend. It takes two years, economists say, for changes in the value of the dollar to affect the balance of trade. Two years ago the dollar started turning up. "From here on out, exports should be petering out," said Samuel D. Kahan, chief economist at Fuji Securities in Chicago. Losing Money on Herman's Back in 1989, Isosceles P.L.C., the big British buyout firm, snatched up Herman's Sporting Goods when it bought the Gateway Supermarket chain. It made the purchase just in time to see sales drop during the recession. Herman's, which had about $600 million in sales last year, had hefty losses.

Full text: INTERNATIONAL De Klerk's Mandate Frees South Africa for a New Day
The new world order made it to South Africa last week when the white minority electorate gave President F. W. de Klerk an overwhelming mandate to end its monopoly on political power. Mr. de Klerk's ruling National Party has been negotiating with other groups, including the African National Congress, headed by Nelson Mandela, to write a new constitution. After a period of transition "it is a foregone conclusion that Mandela will be South Africa's president," said Prakash Sethi, an adviser to a black South African business group. "The transition is likely to be peaceful," he said. South Africa's economy is in shambles from years of sanctions. Though the United States lifted sanctions last year, many states and cities have kept them in place. "The British and Germans who stayed have a large economic base and will increase investment faster than the Americans can get back in," Mr. Sethi said. Japan's Gesture The offer looked generous enough. Japan, which exports cars to the United States under the 1981 Voluntary Restraint Agreement, said last week it would limit the number of cars going to the United States to 1.65 million, down from 2.3 million, the current limit. That gesture, Japan's Ministry of International Trade and Industry said, would help Detroit's Big Three recover from last year's combined losses of $4.5 billion. But Detroit was skeptical. Since Japan only exported 1.7 million vehicles to the United States last year, its proposal would simply keep the "same volume their auto makers imported into the United States from Japan in 1991," said Harold A. Poling, chairman of the Ford Motor Company. "So, where is the reduction?" he asked. No Compromise on Israel When President Bush rejected Israel's request for loan guarantees last week, he said it was because Israel had refused to stop building settlements in the occupied West Bank and Gaza. Israel wants guarantees so it can borrow $10 billion in the world's capital markets at more favorable rates to build housing for immigrants from the ex-Soviet Union. That is a different matter from settling the West Bank and Gaza, it says. To move beyond the impasse, Congress proposed a compromise. Grant Israel an immediate $1 billion in guarantees, said Senator Patrick J. Leahy, Democrat of Vermont, but keep the remaining $9 billion in reserve, subject to Mr. Bush's approval. Mr. Bush said no. A New Export Champ The figures were cheery last week. The trade deficit narrowed to $5.77 billion, a drop of 3.9 percent, the Commerce Department said. But those numbers may actually signal the end of a trend. It takes two years, economists say, for changes in the value of the dollar to affect the balance of trade. Losing Money on Herman's Back in 1989, Isosceles P.L.C., the big British buyout firm, snatched up Herman's Sporting Goods when it bought the Gateway Supermarket chain. It made the purchase just in time to see sales drop during the recession. Herman's, which had about $600 million in sales last year, had hefty losses. Last week, Isosceles said it was putting Herman's on the block. "In today's market, I can't imagine they would get $200 million for it," said John Horan, the publisher of Sporting Goods Intelligence, a newsletter based in Glen Mills, Pa. That's half of what Herman's was valued at when Gateway was sold. Exhausted Honda Executive For the Honda Motor Company it was a big loss. Shoichiro Irimajiri, one of its most important executives, resigned last week. The timing could not have been worse. Honda is in the midst of reorganizing its operations. Mr. Irimajiri, who brought Honda's manufacturing prowess to Marysville, Ohio, and gave its once-stodgy cars a jazzier look "is in a state of such physical and mental exhaustion that he is unable to continue his work," said Shin Tanaka, a company spokesman. "The whole headquarters is in shock," the company said. What's Slow for Japan . . . Japan is used to loping along at growth rates of 5 percent or more. But last week the Bank of Japan said growth turned negative in the fourth quarter of 1991 -- but barely. Japan's gross national product contracted by 0.2 percent. Over all, growth for the year was still 3.2 percent, slow for the Japanese but a rate the United States still aspires to. "The data indicates growth of just 1 to 2 percent this year," said Carl Weinberg, chief economist at High Frequency Economics, a consulting firm. COMPANIES
Macy's Holiday Letdown R.H. Macy & Company slashed prices during last year's holiday season, hoping to raise enough money to keep creditors at bay. The strategy did not work. Sales tumbled and Macy filed in February for bankruptcy protection under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Code. Last week, citing those holiday season write-offs, Macy reported a loss of $671.6 million in its second quarter. In the same period the year before, Macy earned $78 million. About $606 million of the losses resulted from one-time charges. "I think they will have further restructuring charges and, at least in this quarter, their results are likely to be similar to the second quarter," said Walter F. Loeb, a retail consultant. Retail analysts expect to see Macy close more stores. Dow Gives Up Implants Last week the Dow Corning Corporation said it would no longer make silicone-gel breast implants, but would set up a $10 million fund to pay for research and help some women pay to have implants removed. Though it had 30 percent of the market -- 1 percent of its business -- that 1 percent brought most of its recent headaches. The implants have been implicated in a number of health problems. Making a $2 Million Point How much is an idea for a movie that made $350 million worth? Only $150,000, according to judge Harvey A. Schneider of the Los Angeles Superior Court. That is how much he awarded Art Buchwald for an idea that led to Paramount Pictures' "Coming to America," starring Eddie Murphy. "We won the legal case," said Zazi Pope, Mr. Buchwald's lawyer. The victory was not cheap: legal fees were $2.25 million. Bigger Than a 747 The McDonnell Douglas Corporation is rethinking its next commercial plane. Instead of producing the 375-seat MD-12 tri-jet, McDonnell said last week it is looking into a much larger craft. What it has in mind is a 600-seat, four-engine plane that would compete directly with the Boeing 747. "We have said we are looking at alternatives and we have talked to potential airline customers," said John Thom, a spokesman for the company. Trump's Shrinking Debt In his heyday, Donald Trump bought a lot of snazzy real estate at inflated prices. He paid $409 million for the Plaza Hotel -- all of it borrowed -- which his creditors valued at $260 million. His empire began unraveling two years ago. Last week he agreed to give up 49 percent of the Plaza to a group of banks headed by Citibank; the banks will cancel $125 million of his personally guaranteed debt, plus accrued interest. The deal also offers more favorable terms on the $300 million left on the Plaza's mortgage. In 1990, Mr. Trump was personally liable for $900 million. If this deal goes through, he will owe a mere $115 million. Colt's in Chapter 11 The Colt's Manufacturing Company, whose .45 caliber six-shooter left an indelible impression on the lore of the West, filed for protection under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Code. Colt's, based in Hartford, received a $10 million line of credit from the Connecticut Development Authority and a bank. Colt's lost markets to competitors with more advanced products. Even the Hartford police use Smith & Wesson pistols. ECONOMY
Prices Are Under Control With growth still struggling to get above zero, inflation, at least at the consumer level, remains contained. The Consumer Price Index increased three-tenths of 1 percent in February, the Labor Department said. Which Comes First? It's a case of chicken-and-egg economics. To sustain a recovery, consumers must spend. But before they will, they must have jobs. And companies don't hire until the consumers spend. Too little spending and too little job growth derailed last year's recovery, economists say. Has that changed? "I can't tell you that anyone is suggesting to us that they are in a strong rehiring mode at this moment," said Thomas M. Hoenig, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of Kansas City. "They are hopeful, but they are also cautious." An End To Tsongas Economics When Paul E. Tsongas withdrew from the race for the Democratic Presidential nomination last week, he took his lower-capital-gains, no-tax-cuts-for-the-middle-class strategy with him. What's left for the Democrats to debate is far more populist. Gov. Bill Clinton said he would raise taxes on the rich -- those who earn more than $200,000 a year -- and reduce taxes on the middle class. Former Gov. Jerry Brown -- borrowing an idea once espoused by Ronald Reagan -- said he wants to scrap the system in favor of a 13 percent flat tax. But few give Mr. Brown a chance of capturing the nomination.

CREDIT MARKETS; New Focus On Decline Of Inflation

Author: Nasar, Sylvia

Publication info: New York Times , Late Edition (East Coast); New York, N.Y. [New York, N.Y]07 Oct 1991: D.1.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/428223712?accountid=11752

Abstract: The Blue Chip consensus of 50 economists, compiled by Robert Eggert in Sedona, Ariz., which has been trimming its price forecast for a few months, sees 3.7 percent inflation in 1992. That, incidentally, is just about where the American public feels comfortable. According to a recent report by the Federal Reserve bank of San Francisco analyzing public attitudes toward inflation, Americans are intolerant of inflation when it exceeds 4 percent. New Zealanders, in contrast, grew disturbed when the rate reached 30 percent. A drop in inflation in the first year or so of a recovery, it turns out, is the rule, not the exception. Even after the relatively short and shallow recession of 1969-70, which the recent downturn probably resembles most closely, inflation declined by about 1 percentage point during the recovery. Indeed, lower inflation, which reduces costs and lifts business profits and consumers' purchasing power, is one of the forces that help the economy to recover. Besides, if investors gradually come to believe that the Fed really means what it has been saying about near-zero inflation, even that spread, which reflects the risk that inflation might be higher than expected, could narrow slowly.

Links: http://findit.library.jhu.edu/resolve?url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Anytimes&amp;atitle=CREDIT+MARKETS%3B+New+Focus+On+Decline+Of+Inflation&amp;title=New+York+Times&amp;issn=03624331&amp;date=1991-10-07&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=D.1&amp;au=Nasar%2C+Sylvia&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=New+York+Times&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text: In fretful economic times, people often talk as if the only thing standing between the United States economy and permanent stagnation is the Federal Reserve's next move to trim short-term interest rates. But now, some economists contend, declines in inflation and long-term interest rates may be even more powerful stimulants for growth.
Lower long-term rates reduce the debt burdens of businesses and consumers, making it easier for families to buy homes and allowing companies to invest more in new technology.
"Nothing would be more helpful to the sub-par economic recovery than a sizable reduction in long rates," said Lawrence A. Kudlow, chief economist at Bear, Stearns, the New York investment firm. And nothing, he might have added, would make a reduction in long-term rates more likely than solid prospects for lower inflation. Expectations a Key
Unlike short-term rates, over which the Fed exercises some control, long-term rates rise and fall with investors' expectations of future inflation and future demand for credit.
True, long-term rates can follow short-term rates lower when the Fed eases credit, if only because investors in short-term securities seek higher yields in longer-term maturities. But the extent to which long-term rates actually decline greatly depends on the confidence of savers in the soundness of their money. If people expect inflation to remain low, they are more likely to invest for the long term, helping to push down long-term rates.
The good news, reflected in the current bond rally, is that the United States, which used to have some of the highest long-term interest rates of any industrial country, is now on the low end of the spectrum. Closing the Gap
American rates on 10-year Government bonds -- the usual global yardstick, since many countries do not issue 30-year bonds -- have recently been just over 7 percent, compared with more than 8 percent in Germany and more than 9 percent in Britain.
Although Japan still has lower rates, at around 6 percent, the gap between Japanese and American rates has narrowed from more than 400 basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point, a few years ago.
This welcome decrease in the cost of capital mostly reflects the fact that the United States, once the most notable high-inflation country among the industrial powers, has joined the low-inflation crowd. So far in 1991, the Consumer Price Index has risen at a 2.5 percent annual rate, compared with 4 percent in Germany and around 3.5 percent in Japan.
Granted, a break from lower energy and food prices has pushed this year's actual inflation rate below the long-term trend. Nonetheless, a number of Fed officials, as well as many private forecasters, think the long-term rate is between 3 and 4 percent, compared with 4.5 percent in the five years leading up to the recession.
The Blue Chip consensus of 50 economists, compiled by Robert Eggert in Sedona, Ariz., which has been trimming its price forecast for a few months, sees 3.7 percent inflation in 1992. That, incidentally, is just about where the American public feels comfortable. According to a recent report by the Federal Reserve bank of San Francisco analyzing public attitudes toward inflation, Americans are intolerant of inflation when it exceeds 4 percent. New Zealanders, in contrast, grew disturbed when the rate reached 30 percent.
So far, there are plenty of signs, in addition to the slow money growth of the last four years, that suggest that inflation could remain subdued.
An index of leading inflation indicators from the Columbia University Center for International Business Cycle Research ticked up in September, but is running about 10 points below its level of two years ago. Gains in Productivity
And labor costs remain under control. The restructuring of some service industries, as well as the slow pace of overall hiring, suggest decent gains in productivity and muted pressure to raise wages.
In particular, points out Maury Harris, chief economist at Paine Webber Inc., government workers are no longer getting the higher-than-average pay raises typical of the last few years, because of state and local fiscal crises.
Actual price trends have also been encouraging. Inflation in services, far more persistent than in goods, has lately moderated in everything from rents and other housing costs to medical services.
And, as the bond rally itself suggests, inflation expectations seem on the whole to be improving. Commodity prices remain weak. And in a sign that executives do not see much inflation ahead, business appears to be determined to operate with ever-leaner inventories.
A drop in inflation in the first year or so of a recovery, it turns out, is the rule, not the exception. Even after the relatively short and shallow recession of 1969-70, which the recent downturn probably resembles most closely, inflation declined by about 1 percentage point during the recovery. Indeed, lower inflation, which reduces costs and lifts business profits and consumers' purchasing power, is one of the forces that help the economy to recover.
Should prices really stay well behaved, long-term rates could stay below 8 percent even if the economy is growing at, say, a rate of 2.5 to 3.5 percent next year. Mr. Harris said the spread between inflation and long-term rates was averaging about 400 basis points until the recession.
Besides, if investors gradually come to believe that the Fed really means what it has been saying about near-zero inflation, even that spread, which reflects the risk that inflation might be higher than expected, could narrow slowly.
In all, experts are beginning to conclude, America's improving track record on inflation may now be more important to future economic growth -- and to the bond rally -- than whether the Fed eases credit another quarter point this week.

BUSINESS DIARY/February 10-15

Publication info: New York Times , Late Edition (East Coast); New York, N.Y. [New York, N.Y]17 Feb 1991: A.2.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/427987834?accountid=11752

Abstract: Washington and London, at Odds in the Air All's fair in love, war and international airline negotiations. Disputes over airline rights can divide even friends as close as Britain and the United States. Transportation Secretary Samuel K. Skinner rejected British Airways' proposed fare cuts to the United States last Tuesday. Britain had blocked the sale by Pan Am and Trans World Airlines, both desperate for cash, of several London routes to Heathrow airport that United and American Airlines want to buy. Sir Colin Marshall, chief executive of British Airways, flew into New York himself last week to display solicitude for the ailing airlines. The dispute is "not about knocking Pan Am or T.W.A. out of business altogether," he said. He also urged timid Americans to resume traveling abroad; those who don't risk losing business, he said. What British Airways actually seeks are broader operating rights in the United States, said American analysts. Problem is, that sort of deal might normally take a year to work out; T.W.A. and Pan Am need agreements within a few months. Oddball Salary Inequities When Babe Ruth was asked, about 60 years ago, why he deserved $80,000 when President Hoover only made $75,000, Ruth's legendary response was, "I had a better year than he did." A week ago, Roger Clemens signed a four-year contract giving him a record average of $5.4 million a year; President Bush draws $200,000. Clemens won 21 games, holding opponents to an average of less than two runs a game. George Bush showed quick reflexes in the Persian Gulf but bobbled the tax issue. So Clemens did have the better year. But 27 times better? Enough so that the cost of a single Clemens victory more than covers Bush's salary for an entire season? And the President certainly outplayed, say, Jeff Parrett, the Atlanta Braves pitcher, who recently settled for $855,000 after winning five, losing 10. Memo to team owners wanting to economize: draft George, the former Yale baseball captain, when his Washington contract is up. Alcohol-Fed Inflation Economists have found another fuel to blame for increasing wholesale inflation. A record 5.9 percent jump in alcohol prices raised the core inflation rate in January by five-tenths of 1 percent. Higher alcohol taxes do not figure into producer prices, but many manufacturers took the chance to raise their own prices. Some economists said that, even after accounting for liquor costs, the rising core rate would keep the Federal Reserve from easing further. "The Fed will rest on its oars for at least a couple more weeks," said Irwin L. Kellner of Manufacturers Hanover Trust. The broader inflation rate, including food and energy, fell one-tenth of 1 percent, as oil prices declined. Golden Arch of Catfish? McDonald's believes it has found a recipe for Southern success: The Crispy Catfish Sandwich, a 2.3-ounce patty with lettuce and tangy sauce on a bun. McDonald's plans to sell it at 214 outlets in Alabama, Arkansas, Mississippi, Kentucky and Tennessee. Restaurants that specialize in catfish are hardly trembling.

Links: http://findit.library.jhu.edu/resolve?url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Anytimes&amp;atitle=BUSINESS+DIARY%2FFebruary+10-15%3A+%5BSummary%5D&amp;title=New+York+Times&amp;issn=03624331&amp;date=1991-02-17&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=A.2&amp;au=&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=New+York+Times&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text: THE ECONOMY
Washington and London, at Odds in the Air All's fair in love, war and international airline negotiations. Disputes over airline rights can divide even friends as close as Britain and the United States. Transportation Secretary Samuel K. Skinner rejected British Airways' proposed fare cuts to the United States last Tuesday. Britain had blocked the sale by Pan Am and Trans World Airlines, both desperate for cash, of several London routes to Heathrow airport that United and American Airlines want to buy. Sir Colin Marshall, chief executive of British Airways, flew into New York himself last week to display solicitude for the ailing airlines. The dispute is "not about knocking Pan Am or T.W.A. out of business altogether," he said. He also urged timid Americans to resume traveling abroad; those who don't risk losing business, he said. What British Airways actually seeks are broader operating rights in the United States, said American analysts. Problem is, that sort of deal might normally take a year to work out; T.W.A. and Pan Am need agreements within a few months. Oddball Salary Inequities When Babe Ruth was asked, about 60 years ago, why he deserved $80,000 when President Hoover only made $75,000, Ruth's legendary response was, "I had a better year than he did." A week ago, Roger Clemens signed a four-year contract giving him a record average of $5.4 million a year; President Bush draws $200,000. Clemens won 21 games, holding opponents to an average of less than two runs a game. George Bush showed quick reflexes in the Persian Gulf but bobbled the tax issue. So Clemens did have the better year. But 27 times better? Enough so that the cost of a single Clemens victory more than covers Bush's salary for an entire season? And the President certainly outplayed, say, Jeff Parrett, the Atlanta Braves pitcher, who recently settled for $855,000 after winning five, losing 10. Memo to team owners wanting to economize: draft George, the former Yale baseball captain, when his Washington contract is up. Alcohol-Fed Inflation Economists have found another fuel to blame for increasing wholesale inflation. A record 5.9 percent jump in alcohol prices raised the core inflation rate in January by five-tenths of 1 percent. Higher alcohol taxes do not figure into producer prices, but many manufacturers took the chance to raise their own prices. Some economists said that, even after accounting for liquor costs, the rising core rate would keep the Federal Reserve from easing further. "The Fed will rest on its oars for at least a couple more weeks," said Irwin L. Kellner of Manufacturers Hanover Trust. The broader inflation rate, including food and energy, fell one-tenth of 1 percent, as oil prices declined. Golden Arch of Catfish? McDonald's believes it has found a recipe for Southern success: The Crispy Catfish Sandwich, a 2.3-ounce patty with lettuce and tangy sauce on a bun. McDonald's plans to sell it at 214 outlets in Alabama, Arkansas, Mississippi, Kentucky and Tennessee. Restaurants that specialize in catfish are hardly trembling. Don Buckner, general manager of Hall's on the River in Winchester, Ky., described McDonald's seafood sandwiches as "block pieces of fish" -- suitable for someone who would otherwise have a quarter-pounder. His $9.95 all-you-can-eat catfish dinner includes vegetables and hush puppies, he added. No hush puppies at McDonald's, said a spokeswoman, convinced that Southern customers will accept french fries. Competition for Cellular Lines All that static on the cellular phone lines is coming from aggrieved duopolists. The Federal Communications Commission decided on Wednesday to allow a new form of mobile service in six cities, including New York. Radio dispatch companies for taxis and delivery services will be able to squeeze thousands of other customers into their narrow slices of the radio spectrum. Cellular services that have flourished under rules allowing only two in each city could find competition heating up. Analysts doubt the new service, to be offered initially by Fleet Call Inc. of Bloomfield, N.J., will match cellular's flexibility and features. But the cellular industry called the decision unfair and threatened a fight. Production Declines Ease The slump in industrial output continued for a fourth month in January, but the decline was a moderate four-tenths of 1 percent after much steeper drops in the two previous months. Some economists said the report hints that the worst of the recession is past. But industries used only 79.9 percent of their capacity, the least in four years. In Brief A seven-tenths of 1 percent decline in already lean business inventories in December gave economists hope that any increase in demand would result in higher production. Citibank, long aloof and superior, has decided to join the automated teller machine masses. Its machines will become part of the Cirrus network, sharing access with machines from 7,200 other banks and financial institutions. COMPANIES
George Ball Steps Down When the big boys on Wall Street are suffering, a guy who tried to play with them but failed is truly in trouble. George L. Ball resigned as chairman and chief executive of Prudential-Bach Securities last Wednesday, felled by his loss of $308 million in less than nine years as the firm's chairman and chief executive. Mr. Ball tried to transform a humdrum brokerage firm into a glamorous, global investment bank, throwing around millions to hire star financiers. When the Prudential Insurance Company of America lost patience with his prodigal ways, he responded with what he called a "light cruiser" strategy, fighting only those competitive battles that he believed the firm could win. The losses continued, however, and Mr. Ball finally gave up his command. Carter Hawley Hale Goes Under The real markdowns at Carter Hawley Hale Stores Inc. last week were on "junk bonds" and common stock; the largest department store chain on the West Coast, parent of the Broadway, Weinstocks and Emporium names, filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection. The Carter Hawley Hale story was another 1980's tale of efficient wealth transfer from bondholders, long-term investors and employees -- whose 45 percent stake in the company is now nearly worthless -- to lawyers, investment bankers and the usual short-term profiteers. In its efforts to fight off a takeover attempt led by the Limited Inc. chain in 1987, Carter Hawley Hale had taken on hundreds of millions of dollars in debt. Little was left, therefore, to improve the stores. Competition and a slack American economy did the rest. Auto Makers in Decline The Ford Motor Company has cut back, streamlined production and improved efficiency enough to almost rival the Japanese. But its fourth-quarter loss of $519 million confounded its mission to keep profits flowing even when a recession strikes. The General Motors Corporation lost $1.62 billion, giving the industry its second-worst quarter ever. Analysts were understanding, saying that auto companies can face no worse combination than a recession and higher energy prices. As James P. Womack, an auto industry authority at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, said, "You can't take a 25 percent hit on volume and make much money in any business." In Brief A Federal bankruptcy judge approved the sale of 67 Eastern Airlines takeoff and landing slots and five gates at Washington National Airport to Northwest Airlines for $35.5 million. The Justice Department blocked a bid by United Airlines for antitrust reasons. U S West Inc. agreed to pay $10 million, the largest antitrust fine ever, for violating the agreement that broke up the Bell System. INTERNATIONAL
Germany's High-Cost East One weekend last fall, a carnival on East Berlin's Alexanderplatz was so dreary that visitors had to ask to make sure it was taking place. On the Kurfurstendamm in West Berlin, meanwhile, every evening brought out raucous crowds lingering well past midnight. German officials said last Tuesday that giving eastern Germany much to celebrate will prove far more costly than they had thought. With a turnaround nowhere in sight, the Government approved $3 billion in emergency aid for cities and states. Economists say that rebuilding the eastern regions will cost the Government nearly $100 billion this year, more than $1 trillion over the decade. Traditional Eastern European export markets have evaporated, factories are closing and residents are leaving for the West. Germany's bind might well pinch relations with the United States. The cost of aiding the easterners makes Germans more reluctant to lower interest rates in support of the dollar or finance the war in the Middle East. Trouble With the Trade Deficit The trade deficit is heading in the right direction for the wrong reasons. The gap shrank to $6.3 billion in December, better than most economists had expected. Imports fell 7.9 percent, as the recession curbed America's appetite for foreign goods. But exports slipped also, by 2.1 percent, auguring ill for one of the economy's few healthy areas. "We can't count on that sector as much in the months ahead," said David M. Jones, chief economist at Aubrey G. Lanston & Company. As foreign economies slow, not even a weaker dollar is sufficient to stoke overseas demand.

Mexican Free Trade Pact Pushed

Author: CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH, Special to The New York Times

Publication info: New York Times , Late Edition (East Coast); New York, N.Y. [New York, N.Y]14 Sep 1990: D.1.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/427804929?accountid=11752

Abstract: ''Acting at this time is a way of telling Mexico that we're really serious,'' a senior Administration official said. In late August, President Carlos Salinas de Gortari asked the United States to open the talks. ''The political cost associated with accepting foreign investment in the upstream sector of the petroleum industry would be substantial,'' said Rafael G. Quijano, director of the Petroleum Finance Corporation, a Washington energy consulting group. ''Mexico is a wonderful potential market,'' said Colleen S. Morton, director of the United States Council of the Mexico-United States Business Committee. The council represents key American business groups.

Links: http://findit.library.jhu.edu/resolve?url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Anytimes&amp;atitle=Mexican+Free+Trade+Pact+Pushed&amp;title=New+York+Times&amp;issn=03624331&amp;date=1990-09-14&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=D.1&amp;au=CLYDE+H.+FARNSWORTH%2C+Special+to+The+New+York+Times&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=New+York+Times&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text: LEAD: President Bush, acting more swiftly than expected, will ask Congress next week for authority to negotiate a comprehensive free trade agreement with Mexico, Administration officials said today. Though not the only reason, the Persian Gulf crisis was a factor in the decision, they said.
President Bush, acting more swiftly than expected, will ask Congress next week for authority to negotiate a comprehensive free trade agreement with Mexico, Administration officials said today. Though not the only reason, the Persian Gulf crisis was a factor in the decision, they said.
They also said Canada, already a free trade partner of the United States, was likely to participate, giving an accord hemispheric scope and clearing the way for common standards and trading rules in all three countries by the end of the century.
The integration of economies in North America would follow similar moves in Europe, as the European Community inches toward economic union.
''Acting at this time is a way of telling Mexico that we're really serious,'' a senior Administration official said. In late August, President Carlos Salinas de Gortari asked the United States to open the talks.
Mexico's Oil Reserves

The Middle East crisis has focused the world's attention on global oil supplies. Mexico, with the eighth-largest reserves in the world, would be likely to attract more outside capital with a trade pact to help tap those reserves.
While the United States wants to work with Mexico on increasing oil production, another factor behind the speed-up, officials said, is a desire to accommodate President Salinas, who has seized on free trade to modernize the Mexican economy.
Mexico, which has already cut tariffs from 100 percent or more to less than 10 percent, sees an agreement with the United States attracting foreign capital that would spur modernization.
An economic basket case early in the last decade, Mexico, through deregulation and tax cuts as well as freer trade, has already reduced inflation and interest rates sharply and all but eliminated capital flight.
Cooperation in Energy

Bush Administration officials expect a trade agreement to intensify cooperation in the energy sector, for example, by increasing already robust sales of American oil equipment to Mexico.
One recent sign of cooperation was Mexico's pledge to lift overall oil exports by 100,000 barrels daily to help ease the current pressure on global supplies. Mexico exports about half of its 2.5 million barrels daily. The United States takes about 60 percent of the exports, Japan 15 percent and Europe most of the rest.
Far more controversial is the issue of American participation in Mexican oil and gas exploration, for 50 years the exclusive preserve of the state-owned Petroleos Mexicanos, or Pemex.
Because of political sensitivity about oil, many analysts consider it unlikely that international oil companies would be permitted to operate in Mexico.
''The political cost associated with accepting foreign investment in the upstream sector of the petroleum industry would be substantial,'' said Rafael G. Quijano, director of the Petroleum Finance Corporation, a Washington energy consulting group.
Still Mr. Quijano, a former Pemex executive, suggested that ways might be found to get around the issue.
Foreign Investment Fund

One possible solution, he said, is a financial mechanism, like a trust fund established by foreign investors in a Mexican bank with which Mexican operators would carry out drilling activities.
Decisions on such issues are not likely to be taken before the Salinas Government tests its strength at the polls in 1991 midterm elections.
The Presidents of the United States and Mexico agreed in June to go forward with the pact, but the expectation then was that little progress would be made before yearend.
George W. Grayson, a Mexican oil expert at William and Mary College in Williamsburg, Va., said that Mexico was producing about at capacity and that because of rising domestic use from its rapid industrialization, it badly needed to find new oil.
Immigration is another sensitive issue. Mexico had wanted to take up freer movement of workers as well as goods. Washington had warned that this could doom the talks and won its point. Immigration will not be negotiated, American officials said.
Immigration Issues

But immigration could be affected indirectly. If a free trade pact leads to a more prosperous Mexico, there will be less pressure on workers to come north.
Organized labor in the United States has already signaled its strong opposition to a free trade pact with Mexico. But most industry groups, seeing a large potential for exports, have come out in favor.
''Mexico is a wonderful potential market,'' said Colleen S. Morton, director of the United States Council of the Mexico-United States Business Committee. The council represents key American business groups.
If, as expected, Canada joins the talks, in return for greater access to Mexico, Canada would have to be willing to offer Mexico the same tariff cuts and privileged access to Canada as the United States offers.
The Administration's request to Congress starts a clock in which Congress has 60 legislative days, or at least four months, to determine whether such an agreement would be in the United States' interest.
If Congress gives its assent, which is considered likely, negotiations will probably continue until 1993, officials said. It took about 18 months for Canada and the United States to negotiate a free trade pact in the late 1980's. Though still controversial in Canada, that pact has been so successful that the two nations agreed recently to accelerate scheduled tariff cuts.
Mexico is the third-largest American trading partner after Canada and Japan. In 1989 two-way trade exceeded $51 billion. The United States is Mexico's primary export market.

Subject: INTERNATIONAL TRADE AND WORLD MARKET; FREE PORTS AND TRADING ZONES
