GERMANY AND INTEREST RATES

Author: Wayne, Leslie

Publication info: New York Times , Late Edition (East Coast); New York, N.Y. [New York, N.Y]04 Mar 1990: A.12.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/427590603?accountid=11752

Abstract: ''Domestic economies tend to be the more important influence on interest rates,'' Mr. [Neal Soss] said. He explains the current rise in rates in this country as a ''return to more normal circumstances'' after last summer's startling political developments. Right now, however, he predicts that rates here may fall slightly if the economy continues to weaken. Unlike Mr. Soss, he says the United States is particularly vulnerable to such events because it is so dependent on foreign capital to finance its large trade and budget deficits. ''We're depending on foreign capital inflows of about $10 billion a year to finance our trade balance,'' he said. ''That means we have to pay whatever price is necessary to attract that capital. If interest rates abroad are up, they have to be here.'' ''I still believe the primary factors calling the shots on U.S. interest rates are domestic considerations,'' Mr. Sargen said. ''But going into the 1990's, higher real interest rates abroad become the eventual floor for the U.S. That floor is now being raised. The most difficult question is by how much, and I don't think anyone knows the answer.''

Links: http://findit.library.jhu.edu/resolve?url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Anytimes&amp;atitle=GERMANY+AND+INTEREST+RATES&amp;title=New+York+Times&amp;issn=03624331&amp;date=1990-03-04&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=A.12&amp;au=Wayne%2C+Leslie&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=New+York+Times&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text: LEAD: The meshing of West and East Germany - one a sleek, postwar capitalist engine and the other a shattered, inefficient state-run rowboat with high unemployment - is expected to be a formidable task. While the two halves may some day become a seamless and vibrant economy, the transition is expected to be rough, and unsettling for interest rates around the globe.
The meshing of West and East Germany - one a sleek, postwar capitalist engine and the other a shattered, inefficient state-run rowboat with high unemployment - is expected to be a formidable task. While the two halves may some day become a seamless and vibrant economy, the transition is expected to be rough, and unsettling for interest rates around the globe. There are divergent schools of thought on the subject. One group of economists believes that there is a finite amount of capital in the world. As West Germany seeks to finance the redevelopment of East Germany, so the argument goes, borrowers there will bid up interest rates to attract capital, forcing borrowers in the United States and Japan to raise their rates in a global competition for funds.
But other economists say the matter is not that simple. German reunification, they say, may not affect interest rates elsewhere. And even if it does, the shifts will be subtle and indirect. Besides, some say, the German markets are so much smaller than those in the United States or Japan that their impact, while important, is inherently limited.
Rate Rise, Isolated

Neal Soss, chief economist at the First Boston Corporation, believes that higher German interest rates are inevitable. The most immediate upward pressure will come as East German citizens demand better housing and clothing, even before production in that country rises. This ''demand shock,'' as it is called by economists, represents an inflationary push on interest rates.
Once production in East Germany improves, there will be a second upward force on interest rates as the capital stock of the nation becomes more productive and businesses begin to borrow more money.
Then too, the so-called ''risk premium'' that German borrowers must offer to investors as compensation for investing in such an uncertain economic climate will also cause rates to climb.
Mr. Soss likens the events in Germany to the reunification of the United States following the Civil War - the problems of unifying the currency and organizing a decimated and largely unemployed labor force in the South.
''The restoration of the States was filled with discord and messiness,'' he said. ''And it will be the same in putting West and East Germany together. There will be a lot of new habits that have to be developed with regard to labor and money. That raises the sense of risk and that is the final influence on rising German interest rates.''
Despite this, Mr. Soss believes, there is ''no reason'' that interest rates should go up in the United States or Japan. He says that rates are influenced more by domestic than international issues. In his view, rates in Japan have been going up only because the unification of the Germanys threatens the belief that Japan is about to become the pre-eminent economic power. The 1990's, which have often been billed as the decade of the Pacific Rim, could instead be a time when economic power shifts to a more dynamic Europe, as the Germanys reunify and Eastern Europe re-emerges as an economic force.
To back up his theory that international rates do not march in lock step, Mr. Soss points to last summer, when the United States enjoyed lower interest rates than many of its trading partners. He felt that this came from the notion of the United States as a ''safe haven'' for capital following the death of the Ayatollah in Iran, the supression of the uprising at Tiananmen Square in China and the political scandals in Japan.
''Domestic economies tend to be the more important influence on interest rates,'' Mr. Soss said. He explains the current rise in rates in this country as a ''return to more normal circumstances'' after last summer's startling political developments. Right now, however, he predicts that rates here may fall slightly if the economy continues to weaken.
Rate Rise, International

The opposite view is taken by C. Fred Bergsten, director of the Institute for International Economics, a research institute in Washington. Mr. Bergsten believes that events in East and West Germany will ''drag up interest rates around the world.'' He, too, sees higher German rates as inevitable. They will first come from the inflationary pressures of reunification as the purchasing power of East Germany is mobilzed. Once this happens, he anticipates that the West German central bank, fearful of inflation, will try to tighten monetary policy, which would push up rates.
But unlike Mr. Soss, he says the United States is particularly vulnerable to such events because it is so dependent on foreign capital to finance its large trade and budget deficits. ''We're depending on foreign capital inflows of about $10 billion a year to finance our trade balance,'' he said. ''That means we have to pay whatever price is necessary to attract that capital. If interest rates abroad are up, they have to be here.''
In Mr. Bergsten's view, ''The chickens have come home to roost. Our dependence on foreign capital has made us hostage to economic events abroad.''
Conversely, Japan is less vulnerable because it is an exporter of capital, he said. But he noted that a rapid German reunification would probably push up inflation and interest rates in Japan by several percentage points, while a slower pace would dampen inflation fears and keep rates more stable.
The Rate Floor

Nicholas Sargan, an economist at Salomon Brothers Inc., makes a distinction between different components of interest rates: inflation, real returns and the uncertainty premium. He believes that inflation in a given country directly affects rates within its own borders, but has little impact on global rates. To support this, he points to the decline in United States interest rates last summer as inflation dropped and the economy slowed here. This contrasts with Japan and West Germany, where rising inflation fears pushed up rates.
But he believes that real interest rates - the component that is set by the productive capacity of an economy - equalize across the globe and set an international floor for rates. The risk and inflation premiums are then built on this floor level.
Without the demand for capital in West Germany, rates of different nations moved in different directions last year, depending on internal inflation fears. But with this new element in play, Mr. Sargan says, rates all over the globe will inevitably rise.
''I still believe the primary factors calling the shots on U.S. interest rates are domestic considerations,'' Mr. Sargen said. ''But going into the 1990's, higher real interest rates abroad become the eventual floor for the U.S. That floor is now being raised. The most difficult question is by how much, and I don't think anyone knows the answer.''
An End to Euphoria

Alan Reynolds, chief economist at Polyconomics Inc., an economic consulting firm in Morristown, N.J., believes that the current euphoria about investments in Germany may subside once the difficulties of reunification become clear. For instance, he anticipates that much of the foreign money that surged into West German stock funds could flow out when investors begin to realize that a unified German economic powerhouse will not emerge overnight and that these funds have become overpriced. The deutsche mark will weaken as investors sell and covert the marks used to buy the stocks back into dollars. Interest rates will rise in Germany as money flows back into the United States and Japan and as buyers of German bonds demand higher returns to protect them against a weakening mark.
But over time, he says, interest rates in other nations will react to inflationary pressues in their own borders rather than those abroad. ''To say that all our interest rates have to go in the same direction is to say we all have to raise interest rates to the level of Britain or Australia because they have higher rates,'' Mr. Reynolds said. ''But they have higher rates for a reason - because people there expect inflation.''
The Limited Markets

Besides, noted Robert Brusca, an economist with Nikko Securities Company Ltd., West Germany's role in the world economy is limited by the size of its stock and bond markets relative to those in the United States and Japan. He noted that the German equities market is only one-tenth the size of the Tokyo market and that its bond market is one-third the size of the Japanese bond market, which in turn is half the size of the United States bond market.
This means that only a limited amount of funds can flow into West German securities without driving the deutsche mark, which is needed to buy these securities, to ridiculously high levels, thereby choking off any investment value. As a result, while Germany may indeed play a special role in the European economy because of its strength, that role is inherently limited, as is the upward pressure on its rates.
''Germany is still a small niche market and that means money flows can be deflected away from the U.S. and Japan,'' Mr. Brusca said. ''But if any sizable moves in funds occur, it will be so visible that it will push up rates and prices in Germany and become a self-limiting process.''
In fact, Mr. Brusca said, as oil prices rise, Arab investors may play a more important role than the reunification of Germany in international money flows and interest rates. ''One of the things missed in all this discussion,'' he said, ''is the rise of the Arab investor and the question of where all those dollars flow.''

Brazil's Economic Crossroads

Author: Brooke, James

Publication info: New York Times , Late Edition (East Coast); New York, N.Y. [New York, N.Y]12 Nov 1989: A.1.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/427437306?accountid=11752

Abstract: ''All long-term plans are on hold,'' Timothy A. Durkin, a Citibank vice president, said of the nervous business mood in this city, often known as the ''locomotive'' of Brazil. ''I know of several $100 million-plus projects that are tabled until the situation is defined.'' The surge of manufactured exports and Brazil's barriers against imports have led to conflicts between Brazil and the United States. United States officials last May gave Brazil 18 months to lower its barriers or face retaliatory tariffs. Although some import tariffs have edged down, Brazil remains, in the words of a recent Bank of Boston report, ''very much a closed economy.'' ''We may go with the half-measures of [Leonel Brizola], or with the wrong-headed radicalism of Lula,'' Senator [Roberto Campos] said of the 1990's. ''Then we will have to wait another five years for Brazil to grow again.''

Links: http://findit.library.jhu.edu/resolve?url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Anytimes&amp;atitle=Brazil%27s+Economic+Crossroads&amp;title=New+York+Times&amp;issn=03624331&amp;date=1989-11-12&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=A.1&amp;au=Brooke%2C+James&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=New+York+Times&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text: LEAD: On the eve of its first direct presidential election in nearly 30 years, Brazil, the giant of Latin America, stands frozen at an economic crossroads. Frustrated by a decade of economic stagnation, Brazil's 82 million voters will now decide the path the Western world's eighth-largest economy will take in the 1990's.
On the eve of its first direct presidential election in nearly 30 years, Brazil, the giant of Latin America, stands frozen at an economic crossroads. Frustrated by a decade of economic stagnation, Brazil's 82 million voters will now decide the path the Western world's eighth-largest economy will take in the 1990's.
One school of candidates is offering the classic Western prescription for economic growth in the third world, a path now being followed by Mexico, among others: trade liberalization, more foreign investment and far less state ownership of industry. The other group of candidates in a very crowded field is offering the classic blueprint of Latin American development usually associated with the left: higher wages, land for the landless and at least a temporary moratorium on payments of foreign debt. Brazil has $110 billion in debt, the most in the developing world.
The outcome of the election is impossible to predict. But business leaders say that if the voters choose the pro-Western, free-market course, Brazil will emerge in the next decade with glittering, Pacific Basin-style growth rates. They say that a leftist victory, however, would seriously wound the country, already hobbled by social tension, four-digit inflation and capital flight.
Fueling social combustion, Brazil has one of Latin America's widest gaps between rich and poor. In a nation where three-quarters of the voters earn less than $125 a week, Brazil's conservative military maneuvered for decades to avoid a direct vote for the presidency, fearing a victory for the left. The voting this Wednesday will be the first such election since 1960; since 1964, presidents have been chosen by the military or by a civilian electoral college.
''All long-term plans are on hold,'' Timothy A. Durkin, a Citibank vice president, said of the nervous business mood in this city, often known as the ''locomotive'' of Brazil. ''I know of several $100 million-plus projects that are tabled until the situation is defined.''
With no clear frontrunner in the 22-candidate race, Wednesday's voting is expected merely to clear the field, leaving the two highest vote getters to face each other in a runoff Dec. 17. The winner of the runoff will succeed President Jose Sarney in March.
At stake is the future of Latin America's largest market, with 144 million people. A favorite of American bankers and investors during the high-growth years of the 1960's and 1970's, Brazil lost its allure during the 1980's, when economic growth fell to an average of less than 2.9 percent a year, barely pacing population growth.
Business executives attribute the stagnation to several causes: oil price shocks, a net outflow of capital to service the foreign debt, economic mismanagement that led to gyrating inflation rates and a highly controlled domestic economy that proved increasingly unattractive to investors. Big Trade Surplus
Despite all that, Brazil last year racked up a $19 billion trade surplus, the third-largest in the world after Japan and West Germany. Once largely an exporter of agricultural goods - coffee and the sugar to sweeten it - Brazilian factories now send overseas a panoply of manufactured goods: airplanes, steel, tanks and shoes.
The surge of manufactured exports and Brazil's barriers against imports have led to conflicts between Brazil and the United States. United States officials last May gave Brazil 18 months to lower its barriers or face retaliatory tariffs. Although some import tariffs have edged down, Brazil remains, in the words of a recent Bank of Boston report, ''very much a closed economy.''
Last year, for example, Brazil bought only $4.2 billion worth of American goods, less than what was purchased by Venezuela, which has one-eighth of Brazil's population.
In response, Brazilians say they have to keep import barriers high in order to record a trade surplus that can be used to service the foreign debt. American bankers lead the list of creditors of the $65 billion commercial portion of the debt.
In September, Brazil quietly stopped servicing the foreign debt, in what was seen as a temporary, improvised move. But the debt remains a burning issue in the presidential campaign. Indeed, two strong left-wing contenders have made the debt public enemy No. 1.
Leonel Brizola, a Socialist former governor of Rio de Janeiro state, and Luis Inacio da Silva, a trade unionist known as Lula who has strong Marxist backing, have blamed it for a wide range of ills - from stifling the economy to spurring inflation, now at an annual rate of 1,300 percent.
The two candidates are calling for a formal moratorium on payments while auditors review the debt and far more favorable terms can be negotiated - a process that could easily take a year.
A victory of the left would probably cause further strains with the United States. Dismissing as insufficient Washington's country-by-country debt-relief plan, the leftists say that Brazil should lead a coalition of debtor nations. In the 1980's, such coalitions never got beyond the talking stage. But this could change with an energetic leftist at the head of Brazil.
A milder stance on the debt has come from the frontrunner of the center-right, Fernando Collor de Mello, a former governor of Alagoas state.
But the campaign rhetoric, which is expected to sharpen during the second round of the election, may well force the new president to adopt an unrealistic position on debt negotiations after being inaugurated for a five-year term next March 15.
Many American banks are now in a stronger position to resist Brazil's pressure and to cut off new lending. This year, many banks raised their loan-loss reserves, effectively taking early losses on Brazilian loans.
''We can now be tougher at the negotiating table, because we have very little to lose,'' said one American banker in Rio.
In the third world, the secondary debt market serves as an informal barometer of international assessment of a nation's debt management, political stability and general economic policies.
In Latin America, Chile and Colombia, two careful money managers, score high - their debt securities trade for about 65 percent of face value. Mexico and Venezuela, two countries that this year adopted decisive economic programs featuring free-market reforms, score in the medium range - about 40 percent. Hitting Rock Bottom
Last week, Brazilian debt securities hit their lowest point ever - 21 cents on the dollar. Among the major debtors, only Argentina (at 18 cents) and Peru (6 cents) scored lower.
Meanwhile, confidence in domestic debt securities issued by Brazil has dropped so low that the Government is paying real interest rates of 6 percent a month to attract lenders. Analysts calculate that Brazil's internal debt has increased 50 percent this year, to about $120 billion, roughly a third of the country's gross domestic product. By comparison, Mexico's internal debt has declined as a percentage of G.D.P., to 28.6 percent at the end of 1988, from 33.3 percent the year before.
The lack of confidence reflects the Brazilian Government's increasingly precarious hold on the economy. In the last 15 years, tax collection has dropped from 17 percent of G.D.P. to 9 percent. And with an estimated 90 percent of this year's budget going to pay salaries for the state's 8 million employees, the Government has resorted to printing or borrowing money to pay for nearly everything else, fueling inflation.
It is even unclear whether Brazil's economy can make it to March 15 without disintegrating into the kind of hyperinflation that sparked widespread street rioting in Argentina after presidential elections there last May. With the emergency, Argentina's new President, Carlos Saul Menem, was able to galvanize bipartisan support for a tough anti-inflation program - raising taxes and public utility rates, cutting Government subsidies and selling money-losing state companies. Waiting for a Disaster
''Unlike Argentina, we have not yet had a disaster - only a half-disaster,'' said Roberto Campos, a senator and economist who advocates a similar set of tough measures for Brazil. Under a new Constitution, Brazil's Congress wields strong powers over economic policy. But there is no consensus in Congress for an emergency program, Senator Campos said.
Looking ahead, a diplomat in Brasilia concurred: ''A key issue is whether the next president will be able to mobilize huge sectors of the population and Congress for an economic salvation program.''
In Sao Paulo business circles, there is growing support for cutting the state sector and for opening Brazil to foreign investment and imports.
''The closing of our borders keeps us inefficient,'' said Jose E. Mindlin, president of Metal Leve, a Brazilian-based multinational auto-parts manufacturer.
Antoninho Marmo Trevisan, the president of an economic consulting group here, predicted that the budget shortfall will force the Government to start dismantling the state empire of 230 companies.
''Whoever wins, whether it is Lula or Collor, he will have to privatize if he wants to build schools, roads and health clinics,'' Mr. Trevisan said, advocating selling the money-losing state companies to a mix of foreign and local investors.
But it is unclear whether the voters will follow the recent prescription of a Sao Paulo newspaper: ''Less government, less misery.''
''We may go with the half-measures of Brizola, or with the wrong-headed radicalism of Lula,'' Senator Campos said of the 1990's. ''Then we will have to wait another five years for Brazil to grow again.''

Central Bankers Assail U.S. for Budget Deficit

Author: STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

Publication info: New York Times , Late Edition (East Coast); New York, N.Y. [New York, N.Y]12 June 1989: D.2.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/427245681?accountid=11752

Abstract: LEAD: In unusually harsh language, the world's central bankers said today that the United States' failure to make further progress in reducing its budget deficit was ''deplorable.'' In unusually harsh language, the world's central bankers said today that the United States' failure to make further progress in reducing its budget deficit was ''deplorable.'' ''National control over short-term rates,'' the report stated, can ''pull the exchange market in the opposite direction from that which the fundamentals would warrant.''

Links: http://findit.library.jhu.edu/resolve?url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Anytimes&amp;atitle=Central+Bankers+Assail+U.S.+for+Budget+Deficit&amp;title=New+York+Times&amp;issn=03624331&amp;date=1989-06-12&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=D.2&amp;au=STEVEN+GREENHOUSE%2C+Special+to+The+New+York+Times&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=New+York+Times&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text: LEAD: In unusually harsh language, the world's central bankers said today that the United States' failure to make further progress in reducing its budget deficit was ''deplorable.''
In unusually harsh language, the world's central bankers said today that the United States' failure to make further progress in reducing its budget deficit was ''deplorable.''
In its annual economic report, the Bank for International Settlements, often called the central bankers' central bank, said a reduction in Washington's budget deficit is the most important thing that can be done to bring down worldwide interest rates and reduce the soaring value of the dollar.
''The case for using whatever measures are available to reduce the United States Federal deficit has been made so often and so convincingly that the lack of significant further progress is deplorable,'' said the bank, based in Basel, Switzerland. Sharpness Borders on Bitterness
Central bankers have often criticized governments for being too timid to cut budget deficits to help fight inflation. They have also complained that governments usually let central banks do the hard work, like raising interest rates. Nevertheless, in discussing Washington's budget deficit, the Bank for International Settlements spoke with a sharpness, bordering on bitterness, rarely seen in official economic policy circles.
The bank said the American Government has relied too much on the Federal Reserve Board to raise interest rates to fight inflation, with higher American rates pushing up the dollar's value. The bank said that by making American goods more expensive abroad and foreign goods cheaper, this has undermined efforts to reduce the American trade deficit and cut Japan's and West Germany's trade surplus.
''National control over short-term rates,'' the report stated, can ''pull the exchange market in the opposite direction from that which the fundamentals would warrant.''
In its report, the bank expressed concerns that the process of reducing trade imbalances among the leading industrial nations ''has come to a halt and has in part even been reversed.'' 'Policy of Sustaining'
Speaking about the United States and other countries, the bank said, ''there has been a policy of sustaining rather than reducing'' trade imbalances.
The bankers contended that the process of reducing trade imbalances must be strengthened, expressing fears that nagging imbalances may again threaten the financial markets.
The report said that reducing domestic American consumption, specifically by budget tightening, ''has to take the lead in new efforts to substantially reduce the current-account imbalances among the large industrial countries.''
The report said that by reducing its deficit, Washington would reduce domestic consumption and thus inflation, thereby allowing interest rates to come down.
Two weeks ago in Paris, in a speech to finance ministers of industrial countries, Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady said the Bush Administration had negotiated hard with Congress to bring down the fiscal year 1990 budget deficit to the target of $100 billion set under the Gramm-Rudman balanced-budget law.
Nonetheless, the bank report expressed fears that the American budget deficit would significantly exceed the Gramm-Rudman target as it has in previous years. The bank complained that no progress was made in reducing the underlying deficit last year. It added, ''Nor is any expected in the current financial year.''
The report said the industrial nations ''find ourselves in an exceptional situation in which a major shift in fiscal policy in the largest economy would unambiguously and simultaneously serve'' domestic interests and would help to reduce trade imbalances.
The bank expressed puzzlement as to whether interest rates should be raised or lowered around the world. It said that although there are fears that the tightening of monetary policy may not have succeeded in keeping inflation at bay, there are concerns that further tightening could undermine the boom in capital investment that has helped to increase economic growth.
It said monetary authorities face a difficult choice between further tightening and waiting to see the effectiveness of their earlier actions. ''Should policymakers adopt a 'wait and see' attitude and prove to be wrong, the achievement of bringing inflation down to levels not seen for 20 years will be jeopardized,'' the report said.
The report, written by the bank's general manager, Alexandre Lamfalussy, will be delivered to the central bankers when they hold their annual meeting in Basel on Monday.

Will Reagan's Luck Outlast Reagan?

Publication info: New York Times , Late Edition (East Coast); New York, N.Y. [New York, N.Y]01 Jan 1989: A.11.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/427031061?accountid=11752

Abstract: He regularly mangled facts, and his small talk was the stuff of vaudeville. He once referred to President Samuel Doe of Liberia as ''Chairman Moe.'' He introduced the boxer Sugar Ray Leonard and his wife to Nancy Reagan as ''Sugar Ray and Mrs. Ray.'' He laughed about his work habits. ''It's true hard work never killed anybody,'' he said in 1987, ''but I figure, why take the chance?'' Links: http://findit.library.jhu.edu/resolve?url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=unknown&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Anytimes&amp;atitle=Will+Reagan%27s+Luck+Outlast+Reagan%3F%3A+%5BEditorial%5D&amp;title=New+York+Times&amp;issn=03624331&amp;date=1989-01-01&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=A.11&amp;au=&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=New+York+Times&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text: LEAD: Ronald Reagan, who knows something about scripts, is busily writing one of his own to guide future historians. They are likely to ignore it. His simplistic gloss does little justice to eight years full of contradiction and surprise.
Ronald Reagan, who knows something about scripts, is busily writing one of his own to guide future historians. They are likely to ignore it. His simplistic gloss does little justice to eight years full of contradiction and surprise.
Moreover, while he surely has a right to be proud of much of his legacy, some of his triumphs were achieved at what could be great cost. The tax cuts and defense buildup brought an immediate sense of satisfaction to many people. But they may also have placed painful claims on the future. And many problems were hardly addressed at all.
Ronald Reagan leaves no Vietnam War, no Watergate, no hostage crisis. But he leaves huge question marks - and much to do.
Mr. Reagan made good on his basic agenda -lifting spirits, lowering taxes, improving defenses. Yet his tenure was marked also by discontinuities - promises unmet, achievements few foresaw. Pledging a ''revolution in ideas,'' he hardly disturbed the nation's political or ideological balance. A self-proclaimed fiscal conservative, he presided over a staggering increase in foreign and domestic debt.
A lazy and inattentive man, sometimes dreamily disengaged from reality, he engineered basic changes in domestic and foreign policy. An avowed enemy of the Soviet Union, he left relations with Moscow in much better shape than he found them. An enemy of activist government, he was anything but passive, and may even have left people with a better opinion of government.
His greatest asset was that the country was ready for him, or someone like him. It was, as he correctly noted in the 1980 campaign, down in the mouth, tired of dour Jimmy Carter, wounded by the hostage crisis, dispirited by inflation. Mr. Reagan brought to this yearning for a sturdier society the promise of a ''morning in America,'' an infectious optimism, a sense of humor and a personality remarkably free of meanness or ugliness.
He regularly mangled facts, and his small talk was the stuff of vaudeville. He once referred to President Samuel Doe of Liberia as ''Chairman Moe.'' He introduced the boxer Sugar Ray Leonard and his wife to Nancy Reagan as ''Sugar Ray and Mrs. Ray.'' He laughed about his work habits. ''It's true hard work never killed anybody,'' he said in 1987, ''but I figure, why take the chance?''
But the country laughed with him. It liked him and trusted him. That trust was the basis of his Teflon. It cracked once, when word got out in November 1986 that he had tried to trade arms for hostages, defying all previous pledges. His popularity dropped 20 points overnight. Triumphs and Time Bombs
At home, Mr. Reagan's great achievement was to restore confidence in the economy. He brought inflation down from 13 percent in 1980 to about 4 percent today. The country paid a price: double-digit unemployment and a severe recession. But since then there have been six straight years of recovery and expansion - the most in peacetime history. Employment is the highest ever; unemployment is down to 5.3 percent.
He also cut personal income tax rates and revamped - at a cost of more than $2 trillion - the military. He pretended that his third objective, balancing the budget, would be achieved by cutting domestic spending and by greater growth stimulated by lower taxes. But the supply-side fantasy turned out to be just that. The result was a calamitous rise in the Federal debt from $900 billion to $2.3 trillion, and a concurrent rise in foreign debt to half a trillion dollars.
Some believe that Mr. Reagan's hidden purpose was a ''strategic deficit'' that would slam the door on any future social spending. That's not clear. But whether the deficits arose from a failure to understand economics or, in the words of economist Benjamin Friedman, ''moral irresponsibility on a truly astonishing scale,'' they have left George Bush with a huge problem.
There were other failures. For all the talk about the social ''safety net,'' more families live below the poverty line now than in 1980. Children fared especially badly: nearly one in four live below that line. On drugs, he offered more rhetoric than resources. On the homeless, he repeatedly served up the silly notion that the homeless are homeless by choice. Little was done to protect the environment, much to exploit it for private gain.
On these and other issues Mr. Reagan's mangling of the facts wasn't funny at all, instead betraying a callous indifference.
Remember the vodka story? When Mr. Reagan took heat for his failure to keep the food stamp program apace with the cost of food and the people who needed stamps, he told of the woman who bought an orange with food stamps and a bottle of vodka with the change. Colorful - but wrong. Change from food stamps is limited to 99 cents, which, in any case, is hardly enough for vodka.
Or killer trees? ''Approximately 80 percent of our air pollution stems from hydrocarbons released by vegetation, so let's not go overboard on setting and enforcing tough emission standards from man-made sources,'' he said in 1980. Wrong on at least two counts. Man-made oxides really hurt. Trees actually help clean the atmosphere. Abroad: Staying the Course
Foreign policy produced his most surprising successes. True, his policies in Central America haven't worked. His stubborn insistence on a military solution defied diplomacy. His decision to send Marines to Lebanon was disastrous, his invasion of Grenada melodramatic.
But elsewhere he did well. He punished Colonel Qaddafi, sent arms to the Afghan guerrillas and ships to the Persian Gulf. His measured use of American power arguably contributed to a decline in terrorism, the Soviet decision to withdraw from Afghanistan, and the Iran-Iraq cease-fire in the Gulf.
Similarly, despite nervousness in Europe and at home, he deployed Pershing II missiles aimed at the Soviet Union, and stuck with his so-called ''zero option'' for six years. It worked. The treaty banning intermediate-range missiles - the first arms-control agreement since 1972 - was entirely on Mr. Reagan's terms.
Mr. Reagan was lucky - lucky to survive an assassination attempt, lucky even in his enemies. Much of what he accomplished abroad might not have been possible without the emergence of Mikhail Gorbachev, who for his own reasons chose to seek accommodation. Still, Mr. Reagan's firmness and patience weighed heavily in the scale.
It's too early to judge the consequences of the Reagan era. It's also too early to give it a name, although Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan has taken a look and called it ''this mindless decade.'' It is better than that. Any President would be proud to claim some of Mr. Reagan's major accomplishments: beating inflation, reforming the tax code, controlling arms and muting regional conflicts.
If asked whether they feel better off than they did eight years ago, many Americans would surely say yes. But many would not. Mr. Reagan asked the country to dream dreams, and it has. Yet as Hugh Heclo, a Harvard professor, noted in a recent essay, ''these were necessarily dreams of private advantage, not public accomplishment.''
Just as he promised, Mr. Reagan's social gospel celebrated individualism. At its best, this gospel sought to release private energies; at its worst, it too easily tolerated money-grubbing and, among his own associates, sleazy behavior.
There was virtually no talk about collective purpose, sacrifice, hard choices. The worry, therefore, is that Mr. Reagan may have borrowed too heavily against the future to gratify the present. History may prove him lucky again. But which of us, George Bush included, dares to bet on it?

Full text: LEAD: Following is a transcript of portions of President-elect Bush's news conference yesterday in Washington, as recorded by The New York Times through the facilities of Cable Network News and ABC Radio News: OPENING STATEMENT
Following is a transcript of portions of President-elect Bush's news conference yesterday in Washington, as recorded by The New York Times through the facilities of Cable Network News and ABC Radio News: OPENING STATEMENT
I have several announcements to make and they're part of a [ laughter ] - pay a little attention here - part of a continuing effort to appoint people of talent and distinction to senior positions in Government service. And I said that naming an economic team would be one of the early priorities of my transition and today I want to nominate the remainder of that top team. There are other very important posts to fill but this is the remainder of the very top team.
First I intend to submit the name of Robert Mosbacher, a friend of long standing, a very successful leader in the business community, as my nominee for Secretary of Commerce. I've known Bob for longer than he'd like to admit, but for more than 30 years. He's built a very successful business. He currently serves as the chairman and chief executive officer of the Mosbacher Energy Company of Houston. He is a leader, not only in the energy industry but in the business community nationally. He serves as a director of several companies, nonprofit organizations as well, national business organizations, including the A.P.I., American Petroleum Institute, and the American Business Conference, which brings together a lot of the leaders of the strongest and somewhat newer companies. Also he's been very active in that in terms of the high-growth companies.
Bob's going to bring his tremendous energies to the task of promoting U.S. exports abroad. Another major responsibility will be to carry out the oldest functions of the U.S. Government - that's the administration of the 1990 Census. He'll bring a wealth of experience to the department and I'll be glad to have his wise counsel in my Cabinet and I'm grateful to him for once again responding to the call. Carla Hills as Trade Representative
Carla Hills has already served with distinction in the Cabinet under President Ford and I'm pleased to ask her back to the Cabinet table as the United States Trade Representative. As a member of my Cabinet she'll serve as our trade minister at home and abroad. There are many challenges facing the United States in the trade area. The mid-term review of the current GATT round which Clayton Yeutter is working on as we speak, the implementation of the new trade bill and the great opportunity presented by the Free Trade Agreement that we've signed with our neighbor Canada. Carla's wide experience in Government - she's been Secretary of H.U.D. and Assistant Attorney General; and in law - she's now the co-managing partner of a, of the Weil Gotschal firm here; and in leadership positions in several companies and professional organizations are going to serve us very well. And she's traveled widely abroad. Domestically, she is a tough no-nonsense attorney and Carla and I have spoken about the need to work aggressively to expand trade opportunities for American companies. And she stands for free trade and fair trade. And I'm very very pleased that she will be a part of my Administration.
The third key member of the economic team that I'm announcing today - you might say Carla is a Californian - is another Californian - the Chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers. Dr. Michael Boskin is one of this nation's pre-eminent economists, currently serving as the Wohlford Professor of Economics at Stanford University. Professor Boskin has worked with me in these past few years to formulate a strategy to continue to create economic growth in this country. And I'll be grateful to have his expertise in this Administration. Boskin to Head Economic Council
He is no stranger to Washington - served on several national commissions; testified many times before the Congress. He's also widely published on Government spending and taxing, U.S. saving behavior, capital formation; many other critical subjects. And he's been voted by the students at Stanford as one of the university's outstanding teachers. And so I have great hope that I can learn from him in the future just as I have in the past. And I know he is committed to jobs and opportunity for all Americans through low tax rates and low inflation and I look forward to working with him in charting the courses ahead.
Now there are two other announcements this afternoon that are unrelated or beyond the economic team. And these are in the area of foreign policy and national security.
First I've asked Bill Webster to continue to serve as Director of Central Intelligence. I know this agency well, having served as its director for a short time. I have total confidence that he is the man - the best man - to build and lead our national intelligence community. It's been - what? - 21 months since Bill Webster was appointed by President Reagan to serve in this post. But in that short time period, he's shown his ability to lead, to inspire confidence, to work with the Congress. Prior to that, of course, he served nine years as an outstanding director of the F.B.I. and prior to that as a Federal judge, a judge on the U.S. Court of Appeals and then U.S. District Court as well. My own view is that it is important for there to be some continuity in executing the mission of our intelligence agencies. And Bill Webster's continuing service will help set a healthy precedent. I'm grateful to him for agreeing to stay on.
And my final announcement is about another post that I know well, that I remember fondly, that I, I put as the foremost diplomatic appointment that I have to make. Recent events have made the post of United States Ambassador to the United Nations increasingly important. I believe I know the limitations of the U.N. But I also know of its tremendous potential. And so it's only fitting that my choice for U.N. Ambassador should be an individual with truly exceptional experience. Thomas Pickering, the current United States Ambassador in Israel, has given a lifetime of service to this nation. He served as Ambassador to El Salvador, to Nigeria, Jordan in the past, and as Assistant Secretary of State for Oceans and Environment and Scientific Affairs.
I have a high regard for our nation's Foreign Service. I've worked with Foreign Service Officers when I was - headed the Mission in China and at the United Nations as well and as Vice President. And Tom Pickering is one of our outstanding public servants and very, very top Foreign Service officers. His expertise will serve our nation well at the United Nations and I am delighted that he has agreed to take this post. It symbolizes the importance I place on the United Nations as well as on the Foreign Service.
And so I'd like to ask each of these individuals - four - to just say - have their say and then I'd be glad to take a few questions. And then if you can talk them into taking questions, why they might do the same. QUESTIONS AND ANSWERS Covert Action and Intelligence
Q. Mr. Vice President, do you have a common understanding with Mr. Webster on what is the place of covert action in the intelligence work of the United States? There have been reports that [ unintelligible ] . Can you tell us what your philosophy is?
A. Well, my philosophy is that the law should be meticulously followed. I do believe that from time to time properly found covert actions are essential, and I know Bill feels exactly the same way. And I think that - I don't think there'll be any difference at all. And you notice I said ''properly found.'' I don't know whether I'll promulgate a new executive order on that or not, but we follow the existing executive order to a T. We will -those orders will be properly found and properly reported to the appropriate commission. Jerry, and then you. Membership on the Cabinet
Q. Mr. Vice President, will the U.N. Ambassador and the C.I.A. director be members of your Cabinet? And did you discuss with Mr. Webster any time period under which he should serve?
A. No, they will not be. But both will attend Cabinet meetings as they impact on their fields of interest. There is no point in the United Nations Ambassador sitting around, as I did for a while, talking about ag policy. If there's an N.S.C. meeting or a Cabinet meeting that impacts on the mission at the United Nations, Ambassador Pickering will be at the table.
I like this, because I want to have an orderly flow in foreign policy making - the foreign policy making. And the Ambassador should report, in my view, to the President through the Secretary of State. Bill Webster now is operating in our Administration, President Reagan's and mine, in this manner. I think it's working in effectively. And he will be included in those - in those meetings that affect where, where we have to make decision based on intelligence.
Bill and I are in total accord that this D.C.I. should be - not be in the policy business, but be in the intelligence business. And these lines can be very, very clear. He's in policy when a covert operation is found and he must manage that. But I think that this arrangement is the best in terms of good government.
Q. Mr. Vice President --
A. I didn't answer the last part of his.
Q. Did you discuss how long you want Mr. Webster to serve at any time?
A. Yes. Open-ended. Role at Gorbachev Meeting
Q. On the eve of tomorrow's minisummit, is there a risk because of Gorbachev's aggressiveness and his appeal and his use of propaganda, if you will, in the fact that you are deliberately taking a secondary role and then President Reagan is on the eve of his departure? Is Gorbachev going to be the main player? And is there a down side for you in the policy on that?
A. There's no down side on policy. The Soviets know how our system works, and they know that I become President on Jan. 20. They also know - because you've given me an opportunity to define my expectations for the summit - how I feel on it. And so I will go there as Vice President. I will not be accompanied by members of my own national security team, and I'm confident that the Soviets understand that. And I'm confident they know our system well enough to know that it is only prudent to review foreign policy and to review national security policy and, certainly, to review our relationship with them.
Having said that, I will make clear to the President that we want to go forward. But I'm not going to be pressed into going beyond that prudent approach. Hopes for Soviet Changes
Q. But during the campaign, in fact, you seemed to be a little more cautious about Mr. Gorbachev than President Reagan has been in recent statments. Do you think that perhaps we've invested too much hope in real change in the Soviet Union?
A. No. I want to - I hope that we have a reason to help be a catalyst for real change. To work with - effectively with the Soviets to - to better our relationship and, certainly, to encourage in the field of human rights more openness. That's a policy of the U.S. now and it will be the policy when I become President.
But, no, this doesn't concern me. I think that it - I think it's only prudent to get your own people together; set out your own priorities, and not go off - charging off without the benefit of those to whom I'm going to look for advice. Status of the Cold War
Q. Soviet officials said over the weekend that the cold war may be fading and may be over. You said during the campaign, I believe, that you don't believe the cold war is over. On the eve of Secretary Gorbachev's visit, could you tell us your opinion on the state of the cold war? Is it fading, is it over?
A. I don't, I don't, I'm not going to respond in terms of those words. You have to define for me what you mean by cold war. Do we have any differences with the Soviets? Absolutely. Are they regional? Yeah. Are they on human rights? Yes. Do we have some differences on how we ought to approach the arms control agenda? Certainly. But do I see, am I optimistic about what I see in the Soviet Union? Absolutely.
And you just take a look at the human rights question. There's been some good forward steps there. And I want to see more.
I think that, I think we come into a great period of opportunity in terms of reduction of regional tensions. But there's an awful lot that the Soviets can do to make me feel I'm right in that.
I think that the arms control agenda is one where we have a chance for real progress. But there's some big problems. I keep talking about my commitment on chemical weapons and biological weapons - love to be the one to lead the free world and then work with the Soviets to, and other countries to ban these weapons. But it is an extraordinarily difficult verification problem. So we got to start talking at an appropriate time with them about that kind of thing.
So, I don't like to use these code words because they mean different things to different people. Yeah. Reaction to a Surprise Offer
Q. Mr. Bush, you may be prudent, but if Gorbachev makes a Christmas surprise tomorrow to propose some kind of grandiose, but self-serving, conventional arms reduction, for example, Congress may not be prudent. The public opinion may not be prudent and in fact, may try to pre-empt an orderly negotiating process by even beginning in January to discuss troop reductions in response to that proposal. What would you do to prevent that kind of --
A. I would make clear to the Soviets that it's the President of the United States that is going to set the foreign policy and the national security of the policy of this country, working with the Congress. And I see no likelihood of that. That is so hypothetical that I see no likelihood of that happening whatsoever. Yeah. Selection of Defense Secretary
Q. Sir, is it true what I read in the paper about you? That you have surveyed the reports given you about Senator Tower's womanizing and alcoholism and about his representing foreign and domestic defense contractors, and you don't think that's any deterrent in his being made Secretary of Defense?
A. I'm not sure you were at the last one of these minipress conferences we had. But I said then that I wasn't prepared to discuss the, the, who might be Secretary of Defense or anything about that until it got a little further along. And I'm in the same mode today. So I would prefer not to respond.
Q. -- but I want to know if what I read in the paper, that you've already surveyed these reports and that they mean nothing to you. That you have said, in the paper today you were quoted as saying that doesn't impress me at all. I still think he ought to be the Secretary of Defense.
A. You have to - Look, I don't want to go into this, because I don't know which reports you're talking about. There's so many out there, but I just will leave it that way. I have a great, high regard for Senator Tower. And so if you're talking about negative reports, I'm disinclined to believe anything of that nature. Yeah. Dealing With the Deficit
Q. There's considerable debate over how much time you have, sir, to come up with a serious and definitive plan for dealing with the deficit once you take office. Do you feel that you have to go in with both guns blazing? Or do you have some time to deal with it.
A. I have some time, but I have to take the offense. And I've made clear to the Speaker and to Senator Dole and to Senator Mitchell that it is my responsibility to do that. And how, what that means in terms of form I'm not quite sure yet, haven't defined it. We haven't, we're just fleshing out our economic team here today. And I'd like to keep in a self-serving sense pointing out, I think we're quite a bit ahead of where previous President-elects have been in the selection of these teams.
So, but in terms of the urgency of the problem, I do feel the urgency of getting something moving on the deficit front. And I'll do my level best to do that early on and take the offense. What I think they're concerned about is that I'll turn to the Congress and say this is your problem. I will not do that. I'm going to lead. Yes, Jerry. Need for a Tax Increase
Q. You had a chance to discuss the budget with Congressman Rostenkowski today. He apparently suggested a gasoline tax might be a good idea and has said in the last few days that he might feel compelled to try to raise marginal tax rates if you proceed with a capital gains tax reduction. Do you want to respond to the chairman?
A. Well, only that we didn't go into that detail with him, but having known him a long time and him having known me a long time, he knows my position. And I pointed out to him out there, I don't remember Congressmen, a lot of your colleagues on either side of the aisle running on the necessity of a tax increase. Maybe I'm missing something. Give me a few names. And look, he's a very experienced chairman of that tax-writing committee. And I know him well. And I can work with him. But I'm go out there and do what I said I'd do. And I think he understands that. Now, does he differ with it in some ways? I'm sure he does. Yeah. Minorities in Leadership
Q. A few weeks ago, you said that you had a good list of very talented minorities for consideration in your administration. If the list is so good, if the minorities on the list are so talented, why haven't we seen them?
A. You've seen one. If you call - if you consider Hispanics minorities, you've seen my pledge fulfilled. And I'd like to get more. But stay tuned; we're only about halfway through this act.
Yeah, two more and then I'm going get - one, two. Then I quit. Cutbacks and the Deficit
Q. Mr. Vice President, you have talked about your flexible freeze as a way of dealing with the budget deficit, and it seems that boils down to a call for Congress to give you the ball in what cuts they make. And yet you have been unwilling to suggest to us what programs might be restrained. Are you willing to take that now, since obviously you have seen enough in programs that you feel you might be able to restrain to balance the --the get rid of the budget deficit?
A. Absolutely. When I'm President of the United States, I'll do that. Yes. Speculation About Tower
Q. On the Tower question, would you at least endorse Craig Fuller's statement that nothing has come to the transition team that would indicate that Senator Tower in any way would be disqualfied from serving?
A. Sure, I'd say that. But I don't want to get into the speculation that I'm trying to stay out of. But in fairness to the man, I'd say that, absolutely. All right, that's it.
Q. Thank you, Mr. Vice President.

Experts Divided on Benefits Of a Further Drop in Dollar

Author: FUERBRINGER, JONATHAN

Publication info: New York Times , Late Edition (East Coast); New York, N.Y. [New York, N.Y]16 Nov 1988: D.1.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/426989074?accountid=11752

Abstract: ''If it is slow and gradual and not too drastic, it will not have a whole lot of impact, said Richard W. Rahn, vice president and chief economist of the Chamber of Commerce of the United States. ''I wouldn't lose any sleep over it.'' ''There is a dream scenario,'' said Rudiger Dornbush, a professor of economics at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, speaking of a decline in the dollar coupled with a decline in the budget deficit. ''But if the fiscal adjustment does not come, the dream scenario turns into a nightmare. It becomes inflation.'' Some economists do not believe that the dollar needs to decline at all. ''If you have an economy growing at a good rate with inflation at low levels, these problems are largely self-correcting,'' he said, referring to the trade deficit.

Links: http://findit.library.jhu.edu/resolve?url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=unknown&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Anytimes&amp;atitle=Experts+Divided+on+Benefits+Of+a+Further+Drop+in+Dollar%3A+%5BNews+Analysis%5D&amp;title=New+York+Times&amp;issn=03624331&amp;date=1988-11-16&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=D.1&amp;au=FUERBRINGER%2C+JONATHAN&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=New+York+Times&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text: LEAD: The sharp decline of the dollar last week and the effort by President-elect Bush to stabilize it this week are only the latest round in a long-running debate about the proper level of the dollar.
The sharp decline of the dollar last week and the effort by President-elect Bush to stabilize it this week are only the latest round in a long-running debate about the proper level of the dollar.
The dollar declined slightly yesterday, after rising Monday in response to supportive comments by Mr. Bush, Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady, Japanese and West German officials and the intervention of central banks.
The dollar debate has raged through most of the Reagan Presidency, involving politicians, central bankers, business people and economists from the major industrialized nations. Ultimately the level of the dollar affects the trade deficit, interest rates and inflation.
The dollar rose through much of the early 1980's, hitting a peak against other major currencies in February 1985.
But the strong dollar had several troublesome consequences. It was widely blamed for damaging American exports of agricultural and manufactured goods. And by lowering the price of imported products, it encouraged American consumers to go on a buying binge that led to an enormous increase in the nation's trade deficit.
Since September 1985, the Administration, in cooperation with its economic allies, has worked to bring the dollar down, and it has fallen about 50 percent from its highs.
Now the markets are looking for signals on what the Bush Administration's dollar policy will be.
Many economists and foreign-exchange traders are convinced that the dollar must fall still further to reduce the persistent United States trade deficit, which has not shrunk as fast as many anticipated when the dollar began to decline.
This view has become so widely held that many traders are predicting that the dollar will continue to decline just because they think that it is the right economic policy and that the Bush Administration will have to follow it. A lower dollar helps to reduce the deficit by making United States products less expensive abroad while imports become more costly for Americans to buy.
Mr. Bush seemed to say the opposite - that a weaker dollar is not a desirable goal - with his effort on Monday to calm the markets, an effort that was joined by Japanese and West German officials and supported by central banks' market intervention to bolster the dollar.
But Mr. Bush spoke only of ''exchange market stability,'' which does not necessarily mean that the Administration wants to keep the dollar at its present level. Rather, it means that he wants to avoid a sharp, fast drop in the dollar that could create uncertainty, spilling over into the stock and bond markets and shaking investor confidence in the American economy.
Even some economists who favor a stronger dollar believe that an orderly and moderate decline will not have a major impact on the economy.
''If it is slow and gradual and not too drastic, it will not have a whole lot of impact, said Richard W. Rahn, vice president and chief economist of the Chamber of Commerce of the United States. ''I wouldn't lose any sleep over it.''
But while the further, gradual decline of the dollar should help improve the trade deficit, it would pose other problems. The main danger is inflation. First, a lower dollar raises prices in the United States by making imports more expensive. It also can create price pressure if it spurs export production at a time when factories are operating at or near full capacity and unemployment is low, as is the case now.
Also, if the dollar falls foreign investors may be reluctant to invest in Treasury securities unless interest rates rise. Investment by foreigners in Treasury securities is considered crucial to financing the Federal budget deficit.
In light of those concerns, some economists believe that if the dollar continues to decline without action by the White House and Congress to reduce the Federal trade deficit, the economy will be harmed.
''There is a dream scenario,'' said Rudiger Dornbush, a professor of economics at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, speaking of a decline in the dollar coupled with a decline in the budget deficit. ''But if the fiscal adjustment does not come, the dream scenario turns into a nightmare. It becomes inflation.''
Some economists believe the dollar must decline substantially. Martin S. Feldstein, a former chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers in the Reagan Administration and an adviser to the Bush campaign, has said many times that the dollar has to fall as much as 20 percent over the next several years or the trade deficit will not narrow. He repeated these comments just after the election and the dollar declined, although he said he was speaking for himself. Later in the week, Bush advisers said his remarks were not a statement of Bush policy.
One of the main reasons Mr. Feldstein is calling for such a steep decline is that he expects inflation to be higher in the United States over the next few years than in Europe or Japan. Thus, he wants the dollar to drop to offset the increased prices of American goods caused by inflation.
Some economists do not believe that the dollar needs to decline at all. Mr. Rahn of the Chamber of Commerce is betting that inflation in the United States will be lower over the next several years than in Europe and Japan. ''If you have an economy growing at a good rate with inflation at low levels, these problems are largely self-correcting,'' he said, referring to the trade deficit.
John Lipsky, director of bond market research at Salomon Brothers, also believes that the dollar does not need to decline more. He said there are indications that the dollar is not significantly overvalued at this time and is not hurting the competitiveness of American exports. Price is only one factor in determining whether American goods sell overseas.
Mr. Lipsky believes that a significant decline would not be much of a help to exports but would still increase inflation. Last May Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, made this argument in saying that a further significant decline of the dollar was not called for. The dollar, which rallied this summer before its autumn decline, was at about the same level as it is now.
As the debate continues, uncertainty itself becomes a problem. A declining dollar, even one that is dropping slowly, can create uncertainity because investors do not know when the decline is going to stop. This can discourage investment from abroad and lead foreigners to sell their dollar holdings. The dollar selling by itself could precipitate a sharper decline in the dollar than was wanted.
''The prospective fear of a decline can discourage investment flows,'' said David C. Munro, senior corporate forecaster at the General Motors Corporation.

Shultz Calls for Free Trade in Asia

Author: ELAINE SCIOLINO, Special to the New York Times

Publication info: New York Times , Late Edition (East Coast); New York, N.Y. [New York, N.Y]12 July 1988: D.6.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/426874007?accountid=11752

Abstract: In an effort to dispel a growing perception in Asia that the United States is a great power in decline while nations like Japan are on the rise, Mr. [George P. Shultz] said the United States was ''doing just fine'' in adapting to change and was enjoying ''unprecedented growth and prosperity.'' ''Such trade barriers in Asia provide a rallying point for those in the United States who wish to increase protectionism and, from an Asian point of view, also reduce competition and consumer choice at home,'' Mr. Shultz said. ''To this I can only say that protectionism is arson that eventually burns down everyone's house.'' Rigid Policies Criticized

Links: http://findit.library.jhu.edu/resolve?url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Anytimes&amp;atitle=Shultz+Calls+for+Free+Trade+in+Asia&amp;title=New+York+Times&amp;issn=03624331&amp;date=1988-07-12&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=D.6&amp;au=ELAINE+SCIOLINO%2C+Special+to+the+New+York+Times&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=New+York+Times&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text: LEAD: Secretary of State George P. Shultz urged Asian nations today to resist trade protectionism and keep their markets open.
Secretary of State George P. Shultz urged Asian nations today to resist trade protectionism and keep their markets open.
In what was described as a major economic policy speech to the Indonesian Economist Association, Mr. Shultz praised Japan for making structural reforms to encourage growth at home, expand world trade and prevent a global recession, and he faulted West Germany as not taking enough steps in that direction.
He criticized the members of the Association of South East Asian Nations for retaining high tariffs, often with import licensing and other non-tariff constraints.
''Such trade barriers in Asia provide a rallying point for those in the United States who wish to increase protectionism and, from an Asian point of view, also reduce competition and consumer choice at home,'' Mr. Shultz said. ''To this I can only say that protectionism is arson that eventually burns down everyone's house.'' Rigid Policies Criticized
The Secretary said Asian countries should abandon rigid structural policies because, he said, they prop up inefficient industries, subsidize exports and restrict foreign investment. The Association of South East Asian Nations consists of Brunei, Indonesia, Malaysia, the Philippines, Singapore and Thailand.
As for the United States, Mr. Shultz portrayed its economy mainly in terms of achievement. He surprised some people in the audience by praising the American trade deficit.
He said that when the history of the 1980's is written ''it will be recognized that the growth of the United States trade deficit, with all of its potentially troublesome implications, was a mutually beneficial development, enabling world trade to expand while helping our own economic growth to proceed without inflation.'' A sentence acknowledging that this trend could not be indefinitely sustained was deleted from the final draft of the speech, an American official said.
Mr. Shultz also proposed the creation of an intergovernmental group in Asia that could be modeled on the Paris-based Organization of Economic Cooperation and Development. Functions of a Forum
An Asian organization, he said, would offer a forum ''where like-minded countries could compare experiences, discuss ideas and prepare analyses on subjects that are of interest to most countries in the region,'' he said. Mr. Shultz cited problems that such a forum could deal with, including investment policy, deregulation, tax revision and privatization.
Japan favors the idea. In a San Francisco speech last March, Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone called for an Asian version of the O.E.C.D.
But other Asian countries have expressed concern that Japan - with its sophisticated economic structure, its extraordinary prosperity and its status as the only Asian partner in the Group of Seven industrial democracies - would try to dictate policies to its Asian trading partners.
In an effort to dispel a growing perception in Asia that the United States is a great power in decline while nations like Japan are on the rise, Mr. Shultz said the United States was ''doing just fine'' in adapting to change and was enjoying ''unprecedented growth and prosperity.''

Tokyo and Bonn at Odds on Dollar

Author: FUERBRINGER, JONATHAN

Publication info: New York Times , Late Edition (East Coast); New York, N.Y. [New York, N.Y]07 July 1988: D.1.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/426902579?accountid=11752

Abstract: ''The changes are not enough yet for major tensions,'' said John Williamson, a senior fellow at the Institute for International Economics in Washington. ''But if the Europeans think the Japanese are too willing to take a mark appreciation, that could lead to tension. I can see the possibility that something might emerge.'' ''This is asymmetrical,'' said Horst Schulmann, managing director of the Institute of International Finance in Washington and a one-time adviser to the former German Chancellor, Helmut Schmidt. ''In the short run it is good for the United States. But in the short run and the long run it is not good for the Germans.'' 'Cool Reaction' From Japan In Japan, the situation is different. Links: http://findit.library.jhu.edu/resolve?url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Anytimes&amp;atitle=Tokyo+and+Bonn+at+Odds+on+Dollar&amp;title=New+York+Times&amp;issn=03624331&amp;date=1988-07-07&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=D.1&amp;au=FUERBRINGER%2C+JONATHAN&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=New+York+Times&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text: LEAD: The dollar's recent rally has exposed a rift in the worldwide policy coordination that has governed the currency markets since 1985, when the United States and its allies agreed to force a big decline in the dollar.
The dollar's recent rally has exposed a rift in the worldwide policy coordination that has governed the currency markets since 1985, when the United States and its allies agreed to force a big decline in the dollar.
For political and economic reasons, the Japanese are now cooperating with the Americans in allowing the dollar to rise against the yen and other currencies. But the West Germans have been resisting the two-week-old rally at every turn.
The rift shows how hard it is to coordinate world economic policy when individual domestic concerns conflict, and it could be a lesson for the United States and European nations that are moving toward a more unified economic system in the 1990's. Confusion and Volatility
The opposite moves being made daily in the currency markets by the Germans and the Japanese have created confusion, added volatility to the dollar's movements and fostered the suspicion that the harmonious dollar policy of the United States and its industrial allies that has been followed for the last two and a half years may be in jeopardy.
While there is no open break, something could be brewing. The cooperation between the United States and Japan during the dollar's rise has been so unusual that it has even led to speculation in the markets that Treasury Secretary James A. Baker 3d, a close ally of Vice President Bush, and the Japanese Finance Minister, Kiichi Miyazawa, have reached a private agreement on the dollar.
''The changes are not enough yet for major tensions,'' said John Williamson, a senior fellow at the Institute for International Economics in Washington. ''But if the Europeans think the Japanese are too willing to take a mark appreciation, that could lead to tension. I can see the possibility that something might emerge.''
''It's a difference of where they put their priorities,'' added Stephen H. Axilrod of Nikko Securities.
A rising dollar is good economics and politics for the Reagan Administration and Vice President Bush in this election year. It reduces the prospects of rising inflation because it lowers the cost of imports. It could make the trade-deficit figures look better in the short run because the total value of imports will decline. And it reduces the pressure on the Federal Reserve to raise interest rates to curb inflation.
Japan seems willing to support the United States for several reasons. One is diplomatic. Given the strained relations between the two countries over Japan's trade surplus, the Japanese Government apparently wants to take this opportunity to cooperate. In addition, Japanese officials have said that so far they are not worried about the immediate inflationary consequences of a run-up of the dollar. The reason, said one Japanese analyst, was that the Government expects the dollar to fall back from the current 133-yen level to around 125. Germans Feel Threatened
But the West Germans feel threatened by the rising dollar. Because a higher dollar increases the cost of imports, it raises the fear of inflation, the prospect for higher interest rates and the chances of a less competitive stance abroad - particularly in competition with the Japanese.
For Germany, the rise in the dollar presents both short-term and long-term problems - a double whammy that has forced the Government to try to stop the rise with both large dollar sales and increases in interest rates.
In the short term, the lower mark means that commodities, like oil, are more expensive for the Germans because they are priced in dollars.
''They have a tremendous fear of inflation,'' said Craig S. Shular, manager of foreign exchange risk at Union Carbide. For Germany, which was ravaged by inflation after World War I, even small rises create political and economic problems. Raising Interest Rates
The threat of inflation and the depreciating mark have already forced the Germans to raise key interest rates to defend the mark. And if the dollar continues to rise, another increase is likely.
The global split also means the yen is falling against the dollar faster than the mark, which means the yen is also falling against the mark. That results in lower import costs for Japanese goods - a worrisome trend for German manufacturers.
In addition, the Germans worry that in the long term, an appreciating dollar will slow or stop the shrinking of the United States trade deficit. All the major industrial nations agree that this would be damaging because it could spur protectionism and set off a sharp drop in the dollar that could push the world economy into recession.
''This is asymmetrical,'' said Horst Schulmann, managing director of the Institute of International Finance in Washington and a one-time adviser to the former German Chancellor, Helmut Schmidt. ''In the short run it is good for the United States. But in the short run and the long run it is not good for the Germans.'' 'Cool Reaction' From Japan
He added, ''I was a little bit surprised by the cool reaction of the Japanese authorities.''
In Japan, the situation is different. ''One mystery is what the Japanese attitude is,'' said Frank Watson, vice president of the Swiss Bank Corporation. The split reflects ''a different political situation in Japan,'' he said.
''The yen has been extremely strong, which hurts export industries. I think it's much more difficult for the Japanese to be seen to keep the dollar down as long as Baker does not mind the dollar going up,'' he added.
C. Fred Bergsten, director of the Institute for International Economics, suggested that the Japanese willingness to cooperate with the Reagan Administration may be in partial repayment for the cooperation Mr. Baker showed in 1986 to help then-Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone politically.
Beyond the diplomatic and political reasons, there is less fear of inflation in Japan because prices are stable and the overall health of the economy gives Japan more flexibility than West Germany. In addition, the economy is less open than West Germany's, which means the yen depreciation has less impact on prices. Dazzling Adjustment
The economic strength is a product of Japan's rapid and dazzling adjustment in the last two years to a stronger yen, a weaker dollar and the need to curb exports. This was done by stimulating domestic demand by encouraging the Japanese to buy.
''Their concern is to restructure their economy, and a small depreciation in the yen will not hurt that,'' said Mr. Williamson of the economics institute.
Yoshindo Takahashi, president of the Nomura Research Institute of Technology in New York, said, ''Basically, the Japanese are less worried about inflation.''
Economists, including some working for Japan's central bank, have indicated that a yen between 130 and 135 to the dollar will not have a major impact on prices.
Mr. Takahashi also said the Japanese have flexibility because he thinks they believe the dollar will fall again and the yen will recover. Since the lows reached in December, the dollar is up about 16 percent against the mark but about 10 percent against the yen. Doubts on Letting Yen Fall
But despite the apparent harmony with the United States, there are emerging doubts in Japan over how far to allow the yen to fall.
The key problem is that Japan has been able to adjust to a strong yen. Even at 120 yen to the dollar - the year's low - the Japanese seem able to remain competitive. This means a weakening yen could stimulate their exports even more. The level that some Japanese officials worry about is 135 to 140, not far from yesterday's 133 level in New York.
The higher level would increase the Japanese trade surplus and quickly aggravate its trade problems with the United States. Such a development would raise the possibility of retaliatory action in the new Administration, especially if it is Democratic. And this is what the Japanese appear to be trying to avoid by cooperating with the United States now.
