IMMIGRATION LAW IS FAILING TO CUT FLOW FROM MEXICO

Author: LARRY ROHTER, Special to the New York Times

Publication info: New York Times , Late Edition (East Coast); New York, N.Y. [New York, N.Y]24 June 1988: A.1.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/426848315?accountid=11752

Abstract: ''There's thousands and thousands of people in Mexico City looking for jobs that just don't exist,'' said Emiliano Benitez, a 37-year-old farm worker from the state of Morelos, just south of Mexico City, who was traveling with his 16-year-old son, Esteban. ''With the dollar worth 2,300 pesos and jobs available for the asking, look how much you can earn in the United States.'' As a result, men who in the past came up north alone in the spring and returned to Mexico for the Christmas and New Year holidays now appear to be sending for their wives and children. Dr. [Wayne Cornelius] said his researchers had observed that ''housing densities in California neighborhoods where undocumented migrants live are increasing'' at the same time that some sending areas in Mexico ''are being turned into ghost towns.'' #47 Percent of Houses Closed ''In one village in Michoacan I recently visited, 47 percent of the houses were closed, some locked up with chains, because everybody in the household is in the United States,'' he said. ''The neighbors who have stayed behind told us that more wives and children have gone up this year than ever before.'' ''It's harder to cross, but we do get across, if not on the first try, then on the second, third or fourth,'' said Manuel Mendez Roldan, a 40-year-old who has been coming to work in the United States every summer since 1970. ''They can't close the border to us, no matter how hard they try.''

Links: http://findit.library.jhu.edu/resolve?url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Anytimes&amp;atitle=IMMIGRATION+LAW+IS+FAILING+TO+CUT+FLOW+FROM+MEXICO&amp;title=New+York+Times&amp;issn=03624331&amp;date=1988-06-24&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=A.1&amp;au=LARRY+ROHTER%2C+Special+to+the+New+York+Times&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=New+York+Times&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text: LEAD: The 1986 immigration law is failing to stem the illegal flow of Mexicans into the United States and may be creating new problems on both sides of the border by distorting traditional immigration patterns, Mexican and American researchers say.
The 1986 immigration law is failing to stem the illegal flow of Mexicans into the United States and may be creating new problems on both sides of the border by distorting traditional immigration patterns, Mexican and American researchers say.
Studies by immigration specialists at the College of the Northern Border in Tijuana and the Center for United States-Mexican Studies at the University of California, San Diego, indicate that the number of Mexicans illegally seeking work in the United States has actually increased in recent months.
The data also show that these illegal immigrants are staying in the United States longer, are increasingly arriving in family groups and are coming in growing numbers from parts of Mexico that have not sent many migrants in the past. No Effect on Flow Seen
''There is no sign the legislation has had any impact on the flows,'' said Jorge Bustamante, director of the College of the Northern Border, a Mexican research institute that studies immigration and other social issues. ''The basic, underlying pattern has not changed in any significant way.''
Wayne Cornelius, director of the Center for United States-Mexican Studies at the University of California, San Diego, offered a similar picture.
''Clearly, we have reached the end of the period of fear, uncertainty and confusion about the 1986 law among workers still based in Mexico,'' he said. ''Those who delayed migration to the U.S. during 1987 are now coming, having observed that work is still available even for new arrivals lacking papers.'' Enforcement Stepped Up
The 1986 immigration law is intended to discourage illegal immigration while providing amnesty to undocumented foreign workers able to demonstrate they entered the United States before Jan. 1, 1982, and have lived there continuously since that date. The application period for the amnesty expired May 4, and the United States Immigration and Naturalization Service is both stepping up enforcement along the border and carrying out a program of sanctions against those who employ illegal immigrants.
The sanctions include fines of $250 to $10,000. Employers who engage in a ''pattern and practice'' of violations also face a prison sentence of up to six months. In the first phase of enforcement, the authorities familiarized employers with the law and issued warnings rather than fines in most cases, but since June 1 immigration officials have been empowered to seek fines for first offenses under the new law.
That system of employer sanctions was intended to make the law more effective. But in interviews with 100 California employers, the University of California study found that employers were resorting to a variety of subterfuges, including subcontracting work, accepting documents they know to be forged and hiring workers for fewer than 72 hours, in which case they are exempt from the paperwork the law requires.
According to statistics compiled by the immigration service, there were 494,144 apprehensions of illegal immigrants along the border during the first five months of this year. That figure represents a 11.9 percent increase over the comparable period in 1987, when the immigration legislation was gradually being put into effect. The law is formally known as the Immigration Reform and Control Act and popularly known as the Simpson-Rodino bill after its sponsors, Senator Alan K. Simpson, Republican of Wyoming, and Representative Peter W. Rodino, Democrat of New Jersey.
Information gathered by Dr. Bustamante's researchers shows an even larger increase. According to their observations at Canon Zapata, the busiest illegal crossing point on the 1,952-mile border, the flow of illegal immigrants from Mexico to the United States is up 15 percent during the last six months and is now approaching the record numbers recorded just before the law went into effect in November 1986. Apprehensions Are Down
In a panel discussion in San Diego this month, the I.N.S. Commissioner, Alan C. Nelson, said that though apprehensions were up this year compared with last, ''they are still down from before the Immigration Reform and Control Act, So there has been a net reduction.'' He said that indicated the law was, in fact, working as intended.
Research on both the Mexican and American sides of the border suggests, however, that the pressures generated by Mexico's economic crisis have been stronger than the sanctions of the law and the new manpower provided to enforce it. Inflation in Mexico last year hit an all-time high of 160 percent, and although the Government has a new anti-inflation program, unemployment continues to be high and real wages are still declining.
Traditionally, Mexicans reluctant to risk their luck at the border have sought a better future by going to Mexico City, the country's industrial center. But the research, supplemented by a reporter's interviews with Mexican migrants waiting to cross into the United States here, indicates that the economic crisis has increasingly made internal migration less attractive.
''There's thousands and thousands of people in Mexico City looking for jobs that just don't exist,'' said Emiliano Benitez, a 37-year-old farm worker from the state of Morelos, just south of Mexico City, who was traveling with his 16-year-old son, Esteban. ''With the dollar worth 2,300 pesos and jobs available for the asking, look how much you can earn in the United States.''
Facundo Roldan, a 37-year-old farm worker who said he was crossing the border for the first time, said: ''Even when there is work available back home, you're only making $2.25 for nine hours of work. You're working six days a week just to buy a pair of shoes. Compare that to the stupendous money you can make working in the United States, and you'll know why I am here.'' More From Urban Areas
In fact, more than 20 percent of the newly arrived immigrants interviewed in the University of California survey were from Mexico City or its neighboring states, areas that in the past have not sent large numbers of workers to the United States. Dr. Bustamante, broadening the focus, said migration from large cities across Mexico was increasing in general.
''We're seeing less people coming from the countryside and more from urban areas,'' he said. ''That pattern is related to inflation, the rate of devaluation of the peso versus the dollar, and the fact that Mexico's economic crisis has made it too expensive for the very poor to consider outmigration.''
The Mexican research group obtains some of its data from photographs taken three times a day at the staging field at Canon Zapata. Other information comes from the 75 interviews it has conducted every weekend here since April 1987 and from weekly interviews with Mexican migrants at five other points on the border.
The University of California survey is based on 670 detailed interviews with Mexican workers and American employers in Southern California during the last year. The institute also draws on field research being conducted in three towns in the Mexican states of Jalisco, Michoacan and Zacatecas.
Dr. Cornelius said that in another striking departure from the norm, nearly two-thirds of the illegal immigrants his institution had interviewed in California over the last year were in the United States for the first time. Workers who whiled away their time jeering the Border Patrol as they waited for darkness to fall at Canon Zapata said that trend, too, was a consequence of Mexico's worsening economic situation. Joined by Eight Friends
Efrain Garcia, a 22-year-old from Acapulco, said that when he announced a few weeks ago that he was heading north to pick cherries and apples in Washington State, eight friends who had never before crossed the border suddenly asked to join him. All eight men, who ranged in age from 19 to 24, said they had decided to seek their fortunes in the United States after being unable to find jobs at home. ''You fill out applications, and nothing happens,'' one said.
''We all recognize the immigration push-and-pull factors at work here,'' Mr. Nelson said when asked to account for the increase in apprehensions along the border. ''If Mexico's economic problems increase, then the push factor grows.''
While the Simpson-Rodino law does not seem to have deterred immigration from Mexico, it does appear to have encouraged those Mexicans already in the United States illegally to relinquish their habit of spending part of the year at home. That is partly a result of the ''grandfather clause'' that allows migrants without papers to keep jobs they held before November 1986 and also of their fears that it will be too difficult and costly to come back and find regular employment.
As a result, men who in the past came up north alone in the spring and returned to Mexico for the Christmas and New Year holidays now appear to be sending for their wives and children. Dr. Cornelius said his researchers had observed that ''housing densities in California neighborhoods where undocumented migrants live are increasing'' at the same time that some sending areas in Mexico ''are being turned into ghost towns.'' #47 Percent of Houses Closed ''In one village in Michoacan I recently visited, 47 percent of the houses were closed, some locked up with chains, because everybody in the household is in the United States,'' he said. ''The neighbors who have stayed behind told us that more wives and children have gone up this year than ever before.''
Mr. Benitez said that in the past he had shuttled back and forth between Mexico and California. But this time, he said, ''if I get across, I plan to stay at least three or four years.''
Mr. Benitez and other would-be immigrants interviewed at Canon Zapata said that they were well aware of the provisions of the law, but that it was possible to get around it by buying fake qualifying documents in the United States. They also acknowledged that the American enforcement effort had become more visible in the last year, but argued that their own persistence and need made the law meaningless.
''It's harder to cross, but we do get across, if not on the first try, then on the second, third or fourth,'' said Manuel Mendez Roldan, a 40-year-old who has been coming to work in the United States every summer since 1970. ''They can't close the border to us, no matter how hard they try.''

INTERNATIONAL REPORT; In the Dance of the Two Dollars, Canada Seems to Be Taking the Lead

Author: JOHN F. BURNS, Special to the New York Times

Publication info: New York Times , Late Edition (East Coast); New York, N.Y. [New York, N.Y]28 Mar 1988: D.10.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/426761325?accountid=11752

Abstract: Among Canadians, opinions on the strengthening of the currency depend on where one stands. In recent years, the streets of this city's downtown shopping district have often been dotted with American couples shopping for bargains at furriers like Paul Magder on Spadina Avenue. The rise of the Canadian dollar threatens to depress this retail business, because goods are becoming more expensive in terms of the American dollar. But the millions of Canadians who head to Florida and California as tourists every winter are realizing substantial savings from their dollar's gains. Links: http://findit.library.jhu.edu/resolve?url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Anytimes&amp;atitle=INTERNATIONAL+REPORT%3B+In+the+Dance+of+the+Two+Dollars%2C+Canada+Seems+to+Be+Taking+the+Lead&amp;title=New+York+Times&amp;issn=03624331&amp;date=1988-03-28&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=D.10&amp;au=JOHN+F.+BURNS%2C+Special+to+the+New+York+Times&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=New+York+Times&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text: LEAD: After 12 years of trading their currency at a discount to the United States dollar, Canadians have watched recently with a mixture of satisfaction and concern as the Canadian unit has bumped progressively upward, passing the 80-cent (United States) level last recorded in February 1984.
After 12 years of trading their currency at a discount to the United States dollar, Canadians have watched recently with a mixture of satisfaction and concern as the Canadian unit has bumped progressively upward, passing the 80-cent (United States) level last recorded in February 1984.
At the close of the financial markets in Toronto on Friday the Canadian dollar was at 80.51 cents (United States), up more than 3 cents this year and more than 11 cents - 16.5 percent - from the low of 69.13 cents recorded in February 1986. Many Canadian analysts think that the rate could rise to 85 cents by midyear, and some even think that the two currencies could be at par in the early 1990's.
Among Canadians, opinions on the strengthening of the currency depend on where one stands. In recent years, the streets of this city's downtown shopping district have often been dotted with American couples shopping for bargains at furriers like Paul Magder on Spadina Avenue. The rise of the Canadian dollar threatens to depress this retail business, because goods are becoming more expensive in terms of the American dollar. But the millions of Canadians who head to Florida and California as tourists every winter are realizing substantial savings from their dollar's gains. As for exporters - and close to 80 percent of all Canada's exports go to the United States - the stronger currency can be a serious problem. Opposing Political Views
Politicians, too, have differences of view. Prime Minister Brian Mulroney, facing a general election within 18 months, greeted the dollar's push through the 80-cent barrier earlier this month as an endorsement of the economic policies of his Government, which has begun to rise in opinion polls after a year of recording some of the most dismal ratings in Canadian history. The opposition has been warning that failure to halt the dollar's rise could choke off the country's impressive economic growth.
Arguments over the rising dollar turn quickly into debate about the monetary policies of the Bank of Canada, the country's central bank. In pursuit of a low inflation rate, currently 4 percent, the bank has persisted in setting stiff interest rates that act as a magnet to international currency flows, and thus bolster the value of the Canadian dollar. Last week, despite the dollar's continuing rise, the bank set its bellwether rate on 91-day Treasury bills at 8.75 percent.
For months, Canadian rates have averaged about 2.5 percentage points higher than the rate on equivalent United States Treasury notes; the spread between Canadian and United States rates for commercial loans and mortgages is about the same. Although Canadian rates have usually run higher than those in the United States, the current policy has provoked widespread criticism of John Crow, the English-born economist who took over as Governor of the Bank of Canada last year. Anti-Inflation Policy
One critic has been George Saba, chief economist with the Montreal Trust Company, who has urged an easing of monetary policy.
''Crow wants to make it abundantly clear that he's not going to cut interest rates, risk overheating the economy and rekindling inflationary forces,'' Mr. Saba said. But he added that keeping borrowing costs high -and pushing the dollar up with them - posed a threat to exporters who have had to trim profit margins to maintain United States markets. ''It's creating a lot of hardship,'' he said.
A surge in exports to the United States has been an important factor in the Canadian economy's strong growth in the last five years. Last year, the Government measured the growth at 5.7 percent after inflation, and the official forecast for this year is 3.7 percent. The figures mean Canada has one of the fastest-growing economies among industrialized nations, accompanied by an impressive number of jobs being created. Last month, unemployment was officially recorded at 7.9 percent of the work force, the lowest level in seven years.
But with the Canadian dollar riding high, economists, bankers and others have begun to worry that United States markets could shrink, choking off the growth.
As one example, they cite exports of Canadian automobiles and trucks, which account for as much as 40 percent of all Canada's exports to the United States. Since 1985, when these exports reached a record $20.5 billion (Canadian), the drop in auto and truck sales has closely followed the rising unit costs of the vehicles in United States dollars. In the first nine months of 1987, as the Canadian dollar strengthened against the United States unit by about 5 percent, vehicle sales fell by 7.5 percent, to $2.4 billion (Canadian). Anxiety Over Rising Dollar
Anxiety over the rising dollar has also been expressed by the oil and gas industry, centered in Alberta, whose exports to the United States totaled more than $8.2 billion in 1986.
In a statement after the dollar rose above 80 United States cents, the Canadian Petroleum Association calculated that the industry, whose export prices are denominated in United States currency, loses $10.5 million (Canadian) with every increase of one United States penny in the value of the Canadian dollar.
Some say that the dangers of a rising dollar have been exaggerated. They point to other factors that, they say, should offset whatever losses Canadian exporters have had in the United States. Among these are the gradual improvement in commodity prices - for lumber, minerals, fish and other products - that constitute a major part of Canadian exports. Combined with this, the Canadian dollar, along with the United States currency, has declined by 30 percent to 40 percent against the major European currencies and the Japanese yen.
Together, the weakening of the Canadian currency against these currencies and improving commodity prices have bolstered Canada's trade balance with the rest of the world, so much so that Canada's overall trade deficit has been falling.
While exports to the United States have been declining, from $20.5 billion (Canadian) in 1985, to $17.4 billion in 1986 and $16.7 billion in 1987, the country's overall trade deficit has shrunk, falling from $7 billion in 1986, to $6.4 billion in 1987, and dropping still further this year.

Economic Scene; Electoral Politics Dictates the Script

Author: Silk, Leonard

Publication info: New York Times , Late Edition (East Coast); New York, N.Y. [New York, N.Y]20 Jan 1988: D.2.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/426720346?accountid=11752

Abstract: LEAD: FOR Americans traveling or residing abroad, the shrunken value of the dollar is felt not only as a strain on the pocketbook but as a personal insult. Feeling overcharged, overspent and over there, Americans ask: ''Is this what we're worth now - half what we were a few years ago?'' Feeling overcharged, overspent and over there, Americans ask: ''Is this what we're worth now - half what we were a few years ago?'' Links: http://findit.library.jhu.edu/resolve?url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Anytimes&amp;atitle=Economic+Scene%3B+Electoral+Politics+Dictates+the+Script&amp;title=New+York+Times&amp;issn=03624331&amp;date=1988-01-20&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=D.2&amp;au=Silk%2C+Leonard&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=New+York+Times&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text: LEAD: FOR Americans traveling or residing abroad, the shrunken value of the dollar is felt not only as a strain on the pocketbook but as a personal insult. Feeling overcharged, overspent and over there, Americans ask: ''Is this what we're worth now - half what we were a few years ago?''
FOR Americans traveling or residing abroad, the shrunken value of the dollar is felt not only as a strain on the pocketbook but as a personal insult. Feeling overcharged, overspent and over there, Americans ask: ''Is this what we're worth now - half what we were a few years ago?''
For the professional economist, the value of the dollar is an abstraction, a function of supply and demand in the foreign exchange market, as affected by a host of factors: the flows of imports and exports, disbursements of interest and dividends, capital movements, the relative level of American and foreign interest rates, events in the securities markets, the intervention of central banks, relative levels of private savings and investment here and abroad, the Federal budget deficit, productivity changes and inflation, the growth of United States gross national product relative to growth abroad and, as economists now have learned to say, ''expectations.''
For the economist, the falling dollar may seem a very good thing for restoring eqilibrium to the current balance of payments, but for the innocent abroad, the shrunken dollar is a blow to his purse, ego and national pride. The depreciation of his currency makes him angry, and he searches for villains - foreigners who are ripping him off or his own politicians who are doing the same.
Dollar depreciation is a kind of inflation. It not only erodes the value of money but undermines confidence in its reliability, the most important attribute of money. That makes the individual feel part of a crowd - the crowd of the cheated and humiliated. As Elias Canetti, winner of the Nobel Prize in Literature in 1981, put it, ''Inflation is a crowd phenomenon in the strictest and most concrete sense of the word.'' It drives those who think they have been cheated together, and unites them against those who they think have cheated them. And, in the case of a runaway inflation, such as Germany experienced after World War I, they never forget it.
Canetti called inflation ''a witches' sabbath of devaluation where men and the units of their money have the strangest effects on each other. The one stands for the other, men feeling themselves as 'bad' as their money; and this becomes worse and worse. Together they are all at its mercy and all feel equally worthless.'' They seek vengeance on those who they think did this to them.
Thus, Canetti warned, inflation causes something to happen that is so dangerous that anyone charged with public responsibility who is capable of foreseeing it must fear it: It is a ''double devaluation'' originating in a double identification - the identification of the individual with his money, and the identification of the individual with the crowd of the dispossessed, hostile to those who have dispossessed them.
The devaluation of the dollar against foreign currencies does not affect the entire population of the United States with the same force as a domestic inflation. Nevertheless, the inflationary impact on American prices of more expensive imports is significant not only for Americans traveling or living abroad but on all Americans purchasing goods from abroad or from domestic producers feeling less pressure from their foreign competitors. In the last 12 months, inflation, as measured by consumer prices, has averaged 4.5 percent in the United States, compared with less than 1 percent in West Germany and Japan, and this trend is likely to continue, or rise, in the coming year, largely because of the dollar devaluation.
Rejecting the advice of those economists who have urged the Administration to let the dollar float lower as a means of reducing the trade deficit, President Reagan has declared that the United States wants stability of the dollar and is working for that with its trading partners. The Administration does not want to risk a further plunge in the dollar this election year, which could be both economically and psychologically disturbing to the electorate and to foreign governments.
The stock market has also tended to react negatively to the falling dollar, and the last thing the Administration wants is another shock like ''Black Monday'' before the election.
At the same time, the Administration does not want to see the Federal Reserve raise interest rates to defend the dollar, lest higher rates choke the slowly growing economy into recession. It believes that the dollar can be defended at about its current level by a combination of intervention by central banks in the market and ''open mouth'' policy - warnings to currency speculators that they are running the risk of being beaten by the central banks if they bet against the dollar.
To avoid the need for the Federal Reserve to raise interest rates, the Administration is putting pressure on foreign governments to reduce their own rates. This would help keep the world economy expanding and ease the debt repayment burdens of the hard-pressed developing countries. Thus electoral politics is dictating the script of a more stable dollar, steady or lower interest rates and a continuing expansion in 1988.

The Theory Gap on the Trade Gap

Author: Kuttner, Robert; Robert Kuttner is economics correspondent of The New Republic. His latest book is "The Life of the Party."

Publication info: New York Times , Late Edition (East Coast); New York, N.Y. [New York, N.Y]17 Jan 1988: A.1.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/426720684?accountid=11752

Abstract: ''The United States trade balance has shown less turnaround than anyone expected, or than any of the models predicted,'' Paul Krugman, an economist at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology said at a recent conference of international economists on ''The Economics of the Dollar Cycle'' at Brandeis. In standard economic theory, if the yen appreciates by 50 percent against the dollar, that exchange rate shift should be largely ''passed through'' in the form of a 50 percent price increase on Japanese products. That should increase sales of domestic products, which are now cheaper, and depress sales of imports. By the same token, a cheaper dollar also ought to make United States products more attractively priced in foreign markets. According to Professor Krugman, formerly a trade specialist on the staff of the Reagan Council of Economic Advisers, foreign companies, especially Japanese, are adept at ''pricing to market'' - they adjust prices to fit competitive conditions in different markets. American companies, though, characteristically don't. ''Pricing to market is not symmetric,'' Professor Krugman said. ''The United States is a market that is priced to, but United States firms do not correspondingly price to other markets.'' Harvard economist Lawrence Summers, arguing for a cheaper dollar rather than a ''competitiveness agenda,'' recently wrote that ''A 10 percent decline in the dollar exchange rate is equivalent to a 10 percent tariff on all imported goods and a 10 percent subsidy on all exported goods. Its short-run impact on the trade balance dwarfs anything that can be done to improve productivity.'' But evidence presented at the Brandeis Conference suggests that such standard assumptions have been overtaken by events. Since 1985, a 10 percent decline in the dollar exchange rate in fact does not produce a 10 percent increase in the price of imports.

Links: http://findit.library.jhu.edu/resolve?url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Anytimes&amp;atitle=The+Theory+Gap+on+the+Trade+Gap&amp;title=New+York+Times&amp;issn=03624331&amp;date=1988-01-17&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=A.1&amp;au=Kuttner%2C+Robert%3BRobert+Kuttner+is+economics+correspondent+of+The+New+Republic.+His+latest+book+is+%22The+Life+of+the+Party.%22&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=New+York+Times&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text: LEAD: THE persistent failure of the cheaper dollar to significantly improve the United States trade balance not only signals problems for Administration economic policy. It is a puzzle - and increasingly an embarrassment - for an economics profession that predicted almost unanimously that a cheap dollar would bring dramatic trade improvement.
THE persistent failure of the cheaper dollar to significantly improve the United States trade balance not only signals problems for Administration economic policy. It is a puzzle - and increasingly an embarrassment - for an economics profession that predicted almost unanimously that a cheap dollar would bring dramatic trade improvement.
Despite the good news in the November trade statistics, the improvement in the balance of trade resulting from the cheaper dollar has been a far slower and less reliable process than expected. Even the improved November deficit of $13.3 billion still represents an annual imbalance of more than $159 billion, which exceeds the 1986 trade deficit.
''The United States trade balance has shown less turnaround than anyone expected, or than any of the models predicted,'' Paul Krugman, an economist at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology said at a recent conference of international economists on ''The Economics of the Dollar Cycle'' at Brandeis. In standard economic theory, if the yen appreciates by 50 percent against the dollar, that exchange rate shift should be largely ''passed through'' in the form of a 50 percent price increase on Japanese products. That should increase sales of domestic products, which are now cheaper, and depress sales of imports. By the same token, a cheaper dollar also ought to make United States products more attractively priced in foreign markets.
When the dollar was undervalued in the late 1970's and then overvalued in the early 1980's, prices responded pretty much the way economists expected. ''In the past, 100 percent of exchange rate changes were passed through to price changes within two years,'' according to Catherine Mann, a World Bank economist who has done extensive research on how actual prices respond to currency swings.
But during the long slide of the dollar that began in early 1985, the predicted shift in prices has largely failed to materialize. Though a strong dollar in the early 1980's caused prices of American products to rise steeply on world markets, a cheap dollar has not reversed the damage.
FAR less of the higher yen or Deutschmark has been passed through to American consumer markets in the form of higher import prices. As a result, consumers have continued to buy imports, and the trade deficit has only worsened.
At first, most economists assumed that the failure of the deficit to improve simply reflected a time lag - the oft-mentioned ''J-curve.'' A decline in the dollar makes imports more expensive, but consumers change their buying habits in response to the new prices only gradually. Thus, in dollar terms, the trade deficit gets worse before it gets better. Supposedly, the picture eventually improves.
But in the mid-1980's, something fundamental changed. Foreign producers managed to hold down their export prices despite enormous changes in currency values. And if relative prices of imports and domestic products fail to change, then the predicted benefits of a cheaper dollar fail to materialize.
According to Professor Krugman, formerly a trade specialist on the staff of the Reagan Council of Economic Advisers, foreign companies, especially Japanese, are adept at ''pricing to market'' - they adjust prices to fit competitive conditions in different markets. American companies, though, characteristically don't. ''Pricing to market is not symmetric,'' Professor Krugman said. ''The United States is a market that is priced to, but United States firms do not correspondingly price to other markets.''
Some American companies, like Ford and I.B.M., have been very successful at operating overseas. But unlike their Japanese competitors, much of their production is also located abroad. If Fords sold in Europe are produced primarily in Europe, the cheaper dollar does not increase exports of made-in-U.S.A. cars. Because capital investments are expensive, major manufacturing companies do not suddenly relocate billion-dollar operations in response to short-term currency swings. Over the long term, a cheaper dollar may induce American manufacturers to move some production back to the United States (this has already begun in some industries like electronics), but not nearly enough to make a major dent in the overall trade imbalance.
So far, much of the trade debate has centered on the dollar's value. Because the trade accounts have not improved, most economists think the dollar must continue to fall. Other economists believe the dangers of imported inflation outweigh the dangers of the trade deficit; they want to stabilize the dollar.
But by focusing on the dollar, economists may be missing a large part of the problem. By and large, economists have not examined in detail the dynamics of how foreign companies manage to hold down their export prices in the face of a declining dollar, and why United States companies apparently are less tenacious at pricing to hold market share.
''That question,'' said Ms. Mann of the World Bank, ''is viewed by most economists as a black box.''
Instead, most economists have investigated what went wrong with the predictive power of their equations. Part of the reason the equations have not worked, according to Harvard economist Jeffrey Sachs, is that the Administration chose to drive down the value of the dollar by lowering interest rates rather than by cutting the Federal budget deficit. The mix of relatively low interest rates and a big public sector deficit, he says, has perpetuated a consumer spending boom, which continues to pull in imports. In addition, Professor Sachs believes the period of adjustment to currency swings may be lengthening.
BUT, he concedes, that still does not tell the whole story. And even fairly mainstream macroeconomists like Professor Sachs are beginning to look harder at the ''structural'' issues of competitiveness that modern macroeconomic analysis has avoided as old-fashioned.
''We need more industry-by-industry examination of why American producers are failing to compete despite the cheaper dollar, and that has to be integrated with the macroeconomic analysis,'' Professor Sachs said.
This is a task that modern economics has on the whole disdained as hopelessly ''anecdotal'' and imprecise. There is no significant economics literature on how individual foreign industries or companies have altered their marketing strategies to compensate for exchange rate shifts, for example. Most of the studies that do exist try to infer corporate strategies from aggregate statistics, rather than examining them directly.
One statistical study, by Japanese economist Ruyhei Wakasugi of Shinshu University, found that the cost of raw materials, capital and labor fell in many Japanese industries, allowing them to hold down prices with only a moderate decline in profits.
According to research by Federal Reserve Board economists Bonnie Lupescu and Robert Johnson, increases in Japanese export prices have varied dramatically among industries. In chemicals, for example, where competition is fierce, Japanese producers have taken advantage of the drop in the yen price of oil, and have held price increases to an estimated 9 percent. In precision instruments, where some specialized products are made only in Japan, dollar export prices rose about as much as the value of the yen, without hurting sales.
Economists baffled by the failure of trade balances to follow predictions have even borrowed a term from physics, ''hysteresis,'' to express their puzzlement. Hysteresis, as used in physics, simply means the failure of an object to return to its previous equilibrium path once a disturbance is removed. As used in economics, hysteresis means that if the dollar rises by 50 percent and then drops back to where it was, trade flows might not return to their previous levels. That is because the rise might have led to some structural change, such as an American producer being pushed out of a market, say color televisions, while a foreign competitor gains a commanding position. A reversal of currency misalignments would not necessarily reverse the situation. If it is defined as continuing structural change, ''hysteresis'' would seem to be a normal condition of modern industrial life.
In general, however, macroeconomists, who have been the dominant voices in the debate about trade and the dollar, have been extremely skeptical about the role of structural factors in the trade deficit. On the whole, the economics profession tends to believe that if the cheaper dollar has not reversed the trade imbalance, it must be because the dollar simply has not fallen far enough. In standard economic analysis, where markets are assumed to equilibrate on the basis of price, structural change is seen as a puzzling and untrustworthy special case. Moreover, in the words of Jeffrey Sachs, ''Most economic analyses do not allow for it mathematically.''
''Anecdotal'' evidence, of the sort that formal economic analysis generally mistrusts, suggests a variety of reasons why prices of foreign goods have not followed the yen and the Deutschmark skyward.
* Most raw materials are priced in dollars. In Japan, a 70 percent decline in the dollar means a 70 percent decline in the cost of oil, iron ore, chemical feedstocks, and so on, which substantially offsets the effect of the higher exchange rate on the finished product.
* All currencies have not appreciated against the dollar. Both American and Japanese producers have increasingly moved production to cheap-currency, low-wage countries like Korea, Taiwan, Singapore, China and Mexico.
* Capital costs are far lower in Japan and Germany. This means that a Japanese company can shave profit margins to hold the line on prices, and still make an acceptable return.
* Many foreign producers did not pass along the full savings to United States customers when the dollar was expensive, so they had a substantial cushion to absorb anticipated price increases as the dollar got cheaper.
In addition, a large share of imports today are marketed in the United States by American retailers or wholesalers, who share the foreign producer's interest in holding down the price. Big American retailers like Sears, Roebuck, who attach their own brand names to imported products, or makers of designer apparel who license the use of their labels to foreign producers, are able to shift purchases to the lower-wage, cheaper-currency countries if they encounter price increases from Japanese sources; that, in turn, intensifies the pressure on Japan to hold the line on prices in the United States.
For example, the Tandy Corporation, maker of Radio-Shack electronics products, gets about 50 percent of its products - including disk drives, laptop computers, and printers - from the Orient, especially Japan. Despite the dramatic decline in the dollar, though, only 4 percent of the products in Tandy's 1988 catalogue increased in price. According to Bernard Appel, Tandy's president, both Radio Shack, and some of its Japanese suppliers, have held down price increases by moving some production to lower- cost producers.
JAPAN'S trade surplus with the United States in manufacturing did not decline in 1987, but Japan did increase its imports from other Asian nations by about 30 percent, much of that in component parts for re-export. Interestingly, this shift is not captured by the official United States trade statistics, which are based on information from customs receipts. If a computer imported from Japan contains chips made in Korea, 100 percent of the cost nonetheless shows up in the trade accounts as an import from Japan.
In many other cases, Japanese producers have held the line on prices by trimming profit margins on their sales to the United States. But this factor is often exaggerated. In the first year of the cheap dollar, many economists assumed that Japan was restraining export prices by undergoing a significant profit squeeze, which could not continue over time. But more recent research by a number of American and Japanese economists indicates that Japan's ability to hold the line on prices has more to do with the decline in prices of raw materials, productivity improvements, and Japan's own selective relocation of production offshore. Over all, major companies traded on the Tokyo stock exchange reported only a slight drop in their earnings per share between 1985 and 1987.
IN theory, if Japanese companies are artificially holding down their United States prices, even in part by taking lower profit margins on those sales, they are ''dumping.'' But United States law only holds that products may not be sold below their cost or their home-market price. In practice, pricing decisions of big conglomerates give Japanese companies ample latitude to use domestic profits to shave United States profit margins without violating the letter of the anti-dumping law.
Late last year, Du Pont persuaded the United States International Trade Commission that a Japanese competitor was dumping granular teflon, a product widely used in compression-molded plastics. As evidence, Du Pont, apparently breaking legal ground, contrasted the rise in the yen with the decline in the United States price of the Japanese product. But few industries have been able to meet the standard of proof necessary to demonstrate Japanese dumping.
According to Paula Stern, a former commissioner of the International Trade Commission, the number of anti-dumping cases filed in 1987 actually declined by 42 percent. Moreover, in many situations, such as the purchase of Japanese products for sale under the label of an American company (like Tandy or Sears), the dumping issue is moot because the American company is happy to get the lower price and there is no complaining party to file suit.
The policy implications of these developments suggest a paradox: The dollar may have to become even cheaper just to compensate for the relative decline in the competitivness of American companies that has already occurred. But at the same time an ever cheaper dollar by itself may not be sufficient to produce a tolerable trade balance. All the factors that allowed America's competitors to adjust to a declining dollar would continue to operate.
In the view of a minority of economists who emphasize structural factors, such as M.I.T.'s Lester Thurow, the danger is that an ever cheaper dollar will only make the United States a relatively poorer country, without making American products fully competitive. Even at 100 yen to the dollar, it is questionable how many American-made Chevrolets would be sold in Japan, or how many VCR's will be made in America.
Despite the puzzlement of an increasing number of economists, the academic debate about the dollar continues to be cast primarily in terms of whether the dollar should be allowed to fall even more, or whether it should be stabilized, and not whether currency manipulation is a sufficient means of repairing United States competitiveness. But because most economists still tend to focus on statistical aggregates, rather than observing what companies actually do, much of the debate fails to shed light on why foreign producers seem to operate more adaptively than American ones, despite swings in exchange rates.
Harvard economist Lawrence Summers, arguing for a cheaper dollar rather than a ''competitiveness agenda,'' recently wrote that ''A 10 percent decline in the dollar exchange rate is equivalent to a 10 percent tariff on all imported goods and a 10 percent subsidy on all exported goods. Its short-run impact on the trade balance dwarfs anything that can be done to improve productivity.'' But evidence presented at the Brandeis Conference suggests that such standard assumptions have been overtaken by events. Since 1985, a 10 percent decline in the dollar exchange rate in fact does not produce a 10 percent increase in the price of imports.
And Germany and Japan have continued to enjoy both strong currencies and trade surpluses precisely because they continue to show impressive gains in productivity. In Germany and Japan a strong currency is the accurate measure of high real wages and a strong economy; in the United States, a steadily weakening currency is the measure of a steadily weakening economy.
ACCORDING to the structuralists, like Mr. Thurow and Harvard's Robert Reich, America may well need not only a relatively cheap dollar, but also heroic efforts to improve competitiveness. Their agenda would include a better educated work force, lower capital costs, a reduced public deficit, strategic investment in key industries, and a new marketing outlook appropriate to an open global economy, as well as more effective diplomatic efforts to get Germany and Japan to accept responsibility for overall balance in the trading system.
In this view, if America relies only on an ever cheaper currency, and productivity growth continues to lag behind that of major competitors, at some point - perhaps an exchange rate of 50 yen or one Mark to the dollar - our trade accounts will formally balance. But by then America will be a much poorer country.
Until lately, most macroeconomists largely wrote off the structuralist view. But the limits of the cheap dollar solution may force the economics profession to put aside the equations and adopt more empirical methods to learn what is inside the black box of actual companies, technologies and marketing strategies. ECONOMIC SCENE; The Outlook For Inflation

Author: Silk, Leonard

Publication info: New York Times , Late Edition (East Coast); New York, N.Y. [New York, N.Y]19 Aug 1987: D.2.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/426587204?accountid=11752

Abstract: To be sure, nobody really knows the state of oil inventories. Prof. Maurice Adelman of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, who has been studying the oil industry for 35 years, says inventories in the hands of companies are not well known and those downstream are ''a statistical black hole.'' With heightened competition among oil producers for market share, and continued consumer investment in equipment to economize on energy, the danger of another steep inflation in oil, which was a critical factor in the global inflation in the 1970's, looks far-fetched in the years immediately ahead. The quick end to the current flap over Iran's threat is evidence of that. The widespread anxieties about worsening inflation that have been troubling the stock market this week do not rest only on oil prices. The inflationary case, as spelled out by such analysts as Henry Kaufman, Richard Berner and Jerry Pegden of Salomon Brothers, is this: Higher import and energy prices have been the driving force behind higher inflation this year. Now, renewed concern about the dollar, which was manifest in the stock and foreign-exchange markets yesterday, could cause a spillover of ''import inflation'' into next year. But the major impetus to inflation in 1988, which the Salomon economists expect to hit a 6 to 6.5 percent rate, will be ''home grown,'' in the form of a quickening in the rise of wages, emerging bottlenecks in several product markets and prospectively higher Federal excise taxes.

Full text: LEAD: WITH the economic news full of surprises -most strikingly the jump in the United States trade deficit to a record level in June, when it was supposed to shrink - the stock market has become extremely nervous.
WITH the economic news full of surprises -most strikingly the jump in the United States trade deficit to a record level in June, when it was supposed to shrink - the stock market has become extremely nervous.
After closing above 2,700 for an all-time high Monday, the Dow industrials yesterday fell 45.91 points. Anxiety about the plunge in the dollar set off the stock market's fall. Underlying its anxieties about both the trade deficit and the dollar are the market's fears of inflation.
But, just as expectations are congealing around the idea that a sharp step-up in inflation is in the works, a critical factor - the oil price - has taken a dive. Contracts for West Texas Intermediate, the benchmark United States crude, which had climbed above $22 in early August following the American reflagging of Kuwaiti tankers, have fallen $2.33, or 11 percent, from their peak. West Texas Intermediate dropped 76 cents Monday, to $19.83 a barrel, the first time it had been below $20 since June 25.
That drop stemmed from the market's realization that Iran, heavily dependent on oil exports to sustain its economy and its seven-year war with Iraq, wants a closing of shipping through the Persian Gulf like a hole in the head. Even more fundamentally, the market recognizes that world oil inventories are swollen beyond current demand.
To be sure, nobody really knows the state of oil inventories. Prof. Maurice Adelman of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, who has been studying the oil industry for 35 years, says inventories in the hands of companies are not well known and those downstream are ''a statistical black hole.''
Data on current production are also murky, with suspicions of a lot of cheating by members of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries. Oil prices are likely to remain unstable in the months ahead, but not go much higher. Even though Saudi Arabia has re-established itself as the swing producer, after baring its fangs by letting the oil price fall below $10 a barrel, OPEC itself has very shaky control over the world oil price.
Yet, flying blind, it will struggle to hold the price fairly high and steady. But it may not succeed. What Mr. Adelman foresees is a continuation of the cycle of meetings, firming prices, cheating, price declines, threats and promises, more cheating and more meetings.
These cycles will be punctuated by outbreaks of war and revolution, periodically thrusting oil prices up. It is impossible to systematize the oil cycle of wars and revolutions, but one could make a case for a six- or seven-year cycle - roughly the interval between the Arab-Israeli war of 1973, the Iranian revolution of 1979 and the seven-year Iran-Iraq war, followed this year by the increase of Iranian revolutionary fervor and threats to other states in the region, as well as to the United States and other Western powers.
But this latest Iranian threat has been a fizzle, most clearly in its lack of lasting effect on the oil price. The oil market has apparently concluded that the underlying supply-and-demand conditions for another oil price explosion are simply not there.
The debate now is whether those fundamental conditions for a renewed oil inflation will be there even in a few years. The consensus, looking toward rising prices in the coming decade, is that the current oil glut will be dried up by growing world demand and limited resources. But some experts, including Mr. Adelman, insist that the probability of a continuing world surplus of oil is strong, because virtually every producer, whether in OPEC or outside it, has been struggling to maintain surplus capacity to strengthen its bargaining position, and is likely to continue to do so.
Even falling oil prices after 1981 did not check the growth of oil capacity; indeed, the 50 percent price decline after 1981 acted like a needle in the arm to both OPEC producers and others, inducing them to raise production in an effort to sustain their net income.
With heightened competition among oil producers for market share, and continued consumer investment in equipment to economize on energy, the danger of another steep inflation in oil, which was a critical factor in the global inflation in the 1970's, looks far-fetched in the years immediately ahead. The quick end to the current flap over Iran's threat is evidence of that.
However, the widespread anxieties about worsening inflation that have been troubling the stock market this week do not rest only on oil prices. The inflationary case, as spelled out by such analysts as Henry Kaufman, Richard Berner and Jerry Pegden of Salomon Brothers, is this: Higher import and energy prices have been the driving force behind higher inflation this year. Now, renewed concern about the dollar, which was manifest in the stock and foreign-exchange markets yesterday, could cause a spillover of ''import inflation'' into next year. But the major impetus to inflation in 1988, which the Salomon economists expect to hit a 6 to 6.5 percent rate, will be ''home grown,'' in the form of a quickening in the rise of wages, emerging bottlenecks in several product markets and prospectively higher Federal excise taxes.
The decline of unemployment to 5.9 percent in July, the lowest rate in the last eight years, and the just-announced July rise of the rate of operation of American factories, mines and utilities to 80.5 percent of capacity, the highest in 18 months, have added to the case for inflation in 1988.

THE NATION; Stocks Zoom, But Economy Is Dwadlinge

Author: Silk, Leonard

Publication info: New York Times , Late Edition (East Coast); New York, N.Y. [New York, N.Y]16 Aug 1987: A.4.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/426584550?accountid=11752

Abstract: Are these forces likely to bring a speed-up in inflation as the year wears on? ''Concerns about a continuing reacceleration of inflation are exaggerated,'' said Beryl W. Sprinkel, chairman of the President's Council of Economic Advisers. He said the inflation rate was already moving down to the 4 percent range. The Labor Department said last week that the producer price index in July rose a modest two-tenths of 1 percent, providing evidence of slowing inflation. ''We must face reality,'' he said. ''The only force strong enough to stop this nation's massive, runaway budget is the Constitution.''

Links: http://findit.library.jhu.edu/resolve?url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Anytimes&amp;atitle=THE+NATION%3B+Stocks+Zoom%2C+But+Economy+Is+Dwadlinge&amp;title=New+York+Times&amp;issn=03624331&amp;date=1987-08-16&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=A.4&amp;au=Silk%2C+Leonard&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=New+York+Times&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text: LEAD: WHILE Wall Street was cheering the fifth anniversary of the big bull market that had carried the Dow Jones industrial average from 776.92 on Aug. 12, 1982, to a record close of 2,691.49 Thursday, some experts were worrying that the economy was ready to throw the stock market a curve.
WHILE Wall Street was cheering the fifth anniversary of the big bull market that had carried the Dow Jones industrial average from 776.92 on Aug. 12, 1982, to a record close of 2,691.49 Thursday, some experts were worrying that the economy was ready to throw the stock market a curve.
A Phillips curve, to be exact. Named for the British economist A. W. Phillips, the theory holds that when the unemployment rate falls, the inflation rate moves upward. The logic is that when labor markets tighten, wages rise, pushing up prices.
In July the nation's unemployment rate fell to 5.9 percent, an eight-year low and a full percentage point below its level a year ago.
Even more striking has been employment growth: The number of jobs has increased by 12 million since President Reagan took office. Though the service sector has provided the bulk of the growth, with manufacturing jobs falling a million overall, last month there was a 70,000-job spurt in manufacturing.
At the same time, inflation has been rising in recent months. Where the Consumer Price Index went up by a mere 1.1 percent in 1986, so far this year it has risen at a rate of 5.4 percent. The producer price index, measuring the wholesale prices that businesses pay for finished goods and raw materials, has turned around even more sharply. After dropping 1.7 percent last year, producer prices rose at an annual rate of 2.9 percent in the first quarter and 5.4 percent in the second quarter this year.
Is all this an ominous indication of an unemployment-inflation trade-off? Are threats of labor shortages and wage escalation so great that the Federal Reserve will be forced to tighten money, driving up interest rates and knocking down the stock market and the economy?
In fact, the economy, unlike the stock market, has not been booming. After growing at a rate of 2.9 percent last year, the real gross national product, the total output adjusted for inflation, stepped up to 4.6 percent in the first quarter, then fell to a 2.6 percent growth rate in the second quarter. Disposable Income Drops
The rates were slower than they looked, because much of the gain came from the piling up of inventories that did not move off warehouse shelves - or were not driven away from the auto dealers' lots. Final sales -total national output minus the increase of inventories - scarcely grew in the first half of 1987.
Consumers have simply not had enough money to spend on cars, housing and other items to send the economy spiraling upward. Disposable personal income - the amount of money consumers have available to spend or save after deducting taxes - has been rising slowly, but, after adjusting for inflation, it actually dropped 4 percent in the second quarter of this year.
As yet, there is no evidence that the drop in unemployment is causing wages to start climbing faster, putting the inflationary heat on prices. In 1986, hourly earnings in nonagricultural jobs rose by only 2.5 percent. In the first half of 1987, the rate of increase in hourly earnings had been averaging only 2.2 percent over last year's, measured in current dollars. When measured in constant dollars, wages have fallen 1 percent below last year.
The upturn in inflation appears to be the result of international factors, not increasing wages. Oil prices have been rising, and markets for metals and other raw materials have recovered. The dollar is cheaper, causing import prices to rise and giving American producers greater leeway to raise their prices.
Are these forces likely to bring a speed-up in inflation as the year wears on? ''Concerns about a continuing reacceleration of inflation are exaggerated,'' said Beryl W. Sprinkel, chairman of the President's Council of Economic Advisers. He said the inflation rate was already moving down to the 4 percent range. The Labor Department said last week that the producer price index in July rose a modest two-tenths of 1 percent, providing evidence of slowing inflation.
Meanwhile, the international forces that have caused higher inflation now seem to be ebbing. Oil prices were given a sharp push upward immediately after the American reflagging of Kuwaiti oil tankers, but have since fallen again as the threat of the closing of the Persian Gulf has receded. Sluggish growth in the world economy is not putting much pressure on commodity prices. And, after its steep fall in 1985 and 1986, the dollar has stabilized and even risen again.
With the big United States trade deficit still dogging not only producers but politicians, the country has been pressing foreign central banks to intervene in exchange markets to prevent the dollar from rising further and inflicting new damage on American exports. The Commerce Department reported Friday that the trade deficit was $15.71 billion in June, an all-time monthly high.
The danger remains that the chronic budget deficit could be the undoing of the American economy and securities markets. Last week, in his televised address, President Reagan renewed his request for a constitutional amendment requiring a balanced budget.
''We must face reality,'' he said. ''The only force strong enough to stop this nation's massive, runaway budget is the Constitution.''
This could become an issue in the election campaign. Vice President Bush has indicated his strong support for such an amendment. But the Democrats, who point to the huge growth in the debt during the Reagan Administration, are likely to brush off the President's proposed constitutional solution as a political red herring that might have a perverse effect in a recession by forcing steep spending cuts or tax increases when the economy is already falling.
In the end, the job of economic management is likely to depend not on the fiscal actions by a divided Republican White House and Democrat-dominated Congress but on the monetary policies pursued by Alan Greenspan, sworn in last week as the Chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, and his colleagues. The Fed seems sure to lean against the wind of inflation in the coming year, but not too hard, since pressure coming from the other axis of the Phillips curve, falling unemployment and tightening labor markets, does not yet seem excessive.
Mr. Greenspan may get the honeymoon any new Fed chairman would like in an election year. If so, the stock market, ever fearful of rising inflation and interest rates, can relax for a while.

No, Inflation Isn't the Fed's Top Priority

Author: Association., Robert Eisner; Robert Eisner, professor of economics at Northwestern University, is president-elect of the American Economic

Publication info: New York Times , Late Edition (East Coast); New York, N.Y. [New York, N.Y]15 June 1987: A.17.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/426525862?accountid=11752

Abstract: LEAD: Fight inflation, fight inflation and fight inflation! That's the advice Alan Greenspan, chairman-designate of the Federal Reserve Board, is getting from many of his fellow economists. It's bad advice. Fight inflation, fight inflation and fight inflation! That's the advice Alan Greenspan, chairman-designate of the Federal Reserve Board, is getting from many of his fellow economists. It's bad advice. One source of inflation is excess demand caused when Government and the private economy attempt to buy more than we are capable of producing - hence, the aphorism, ''Too much money chasing too few goods.'' But that is clearly not the case now, with unemployment still persistently over 6 percent, much of industry operating well under capacity and economic growth sluggish. Reducing demand and purchasing power by denying people money and credit may well keep inflation in check, or even drive prices downward. But to restrict purchasing power when there is no excess to begin with could easily lead to a reduction in real output. There is, at the moment, no compelling reason why the Fed should choose to refight the last war - the war against the double-digit inflation of 1979 and 1980. Even that inflation stemmed largely from soaring petroleum prices rather than excess purchasing power.

Links: http://findit.library.jhu.edu/resolve?url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=unknown&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Anytimes&amp;atitle=No%2C+Inflation+Isn%27t+the+Fed%27s+Top+Priority%3A+%5BLetter%5D&amp;title=New+York+Times&amp;issn=03624331&amp;date=1987-06-15&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=A.17&amp;au=Association.%2C+Robert+Eisner%3BRobert+Eisner%2C+professor+of+economics+at+Northwestern+University%2C+is+president-elect+of+the+American+Economic&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=New+York+Times&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text: LEAD: Fight inflation, fight inflation and fight inflation! That's the advice Alan Greenspan, chairman-designate of the Federal Reserve Board, is getting from many of his fellow economists. It's bad advice.
Fight inflation, fight inflation and fight inflation! That's the advice Alan Greenspan, chairman-designate of the Federal Reserve Board, is getting from many of his fellow economists. It's bad advice.
Not that inflation is a good thing. But it must be resisted prudently, at the right time and with the right tools. Moreover, the Fed has other goals besides limiting inflation, not the least of which is achieving high employment and maximizing the real volume of goods and services available to the American people. A mistimed assault on inflation could ruin our chances of meeting these goals.
One source of inflation is excess demand caused when Government and the private economy attempt to buy more than we are capable of producing - hence, the aphorism, ''Too much money chasing too few goods.'' But that is clearly not the case now, with unemployment still persistently over 6 percent, much of industry operating well under capacity and economic growth sluggish. Reducing demand and purchasing power by denying people money and credit may well keep inflation in check, or even drive prices downward. But to restrict purchasing power when there is no excess to begin with could easily lead to a reduction in real output. There is, at the moment, no compelling reason why the Fed should choose to refight the last war - the war against the double-digit inflation of 1979 and 1980. Even that inflation stemmed largely from soaring petroleum prices rather than excess purchasing power.
Our current problems arise, rather, from an economy that is out of joint. Large Federal budget deficits accompanied by an excessively restrictive monetary policy have contributed to high real interest rates and a dollar so expensive on world markets that we have been exporting far less than we import. The result has been sluggish business investment and a misguided lurch toward protectionism.
The obvious solution is not, as some advise, to keep money tight - but to do just the opposite. The Fed should see to it that the money supply is fully adequate to finance all the activity our economy is capable of.
Increasing the money supply would, first of all, make it cheaper to borrow. Lower interest rates would then encourage private investment and, by lowering the interest burdens on the Treasury, reduce the budget deficit. This in turn would relieve the political pressure to cut public investment in the physical and human capital on which the nation and its future depend.
Second, the dollar would be cheaper in terms of foreign currencies. A lower dollar would bring major progress toward genuinely ''fair'' trade and a better balance between exports and imports. Along with appropriate stimulative policies abroad, easier money in the United States would thus help move the world to higher levels of prosperity and growth.
Yet the siren songs of those who insist that inflation must always be our first and dominant concern continue to inhibit effective policy. This misplaced concern stems in part from exaggerated fears about inflation, which, after all, has been very modest over the past 12 months and is not expected to go much higher. But it also stems from the failure of the public, the politicians and some of our economists to find the real bottom line. That is and should be the goods and services that we as a people enjoy, and not the prices we pay for them.
To be sure, inflation can get so bad that the economy becomes disorganized and production suffers. Inflation falsifies expectations and changes the distribution of income in capricious and unfair ways. But what matters is how we fight inflation. Inflation can be fought efficiently by promoting competition at home and abroad, eliminating ineffective and costly regulations and ridding ourselves of Government programs, including those in the agricultural sector, that are aimed at propping up prices.
Inflation-fighting of this sort would help increase productivity and improve the bottom line. But those things are not under the control of the Federal Reserve. What the Fed should be doing with the tools at its disposal is leading the nation toward higher levels of prosperity and growth.

WHY THE LID IS ON PRICES, AT LAST

Author: Popkin, Joel; Joel Popkin is president of Joel Popkin Company, economic consultants who specialize in price and wage analysis and forecasting.

Publication info: New York Times , Late Edition (East Coast); New York, N.Y. [New York, N.Y]01 Dec 1985: A.2.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/425737868?accountid=11752

Abstract: EACH month's inflation news suggests our new environment of low inflation has staying power. But how long can it continue? Right now, the dollar's decline since last winter is causing concern that inflation may reignite - a lower dollar could mean a rise in the price of imported raw materials and finished goods, and corresponding price increases in similar domestic products. This concern assumes that the dollar will continue to fall and that the inflationary response will be symmetrical to its response when the dollar was rising. Such symmetry has occurred in the past. But a symmetrical response is not likely this time, nor is the dollar likely to retrace its rise and give up the 87 percent it gained over the five-year period that ended last winter. The remaining question is how far the dollar will fall from its present level. The agreement reached on Sept. 22, by the Group of Five - the United States, Japan, Great Britain, West Germany and France - stated that ''some further appreciation of the main non-dollar currencies against the dollar is desirable.'' But there is reason to believe that the practical intent of that statement was to raise the value of the yen against the major non-yen currencies. SINCE the September 22 agreement, the dollar has depreciated 17 percent against the yen, compared with depreciation of 7 percent to 10 percent against the currencies of the three European countries. Prior to Sept. 22, the dollar had depreciated only 8 percent from its high against the yen, compared with a 14 percent to 20 percent depreciation against the currencies of the three other countries. Now the dollar shows about the same total decline -24 percent - from its peak against each of the four currencies. So, the yen has been put in line with the three European currencies without pushing the dollar down too much farther on average.

Links: http://findit.library.jhu.edu/resolve?url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Anytimes&amp;atitle=WHY+THE+LID+IS+ON+PRICES%2C+AT+LAST&amp;title=New+York+Times&amp;issn=03624331&amp;date=1985-12-01&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=A.2&amp;au=Popkin%2C+Joel%3BJoel+Popkin+is+president+of+Joel+Popkin+Company%2C+economic+consultants+who+specialize+in+price+and+wage+analysis+and+forecasting.&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=New+York+Times&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text: EACH month's inflation news suggests our new environment of low inflation has staying power. But how long can it continue? Right now, the dollar's decline since last winter is causing concern that inflation may reignite - a lower dollar could mean a rise in the price of imported raw materials and finished goods, and corresponding price increases in similar domestic products. This concern assumes that the dollar will continue to fall and that the inflationary response will be symmetrical to its response when the dollar was rising. Such symmetry has occurred in the past. But a symmetrical response is not likely this time, nor is the dollar likely to retrace its rise and give up the 87 percent it gained over the five-year period that ended last winter.
The world economy differs from that of five years ago in two important respects. First, there is a surfeit of agricultural, energy and other industrial commodities. Second, the strong dollar promoted the development of substantial manufacturing capacity in the Far East, particularly among the newly industrialized countries of Hong Kong, Singapore, South Korea and Taiwan. As a result, these exporters have an excess supply of commodities and, thus, are not likely to risk losing their market shares in the United States by raising prices.
The widespread availability of crude oil and natural gas has been apparent for some time. Oil prices have fallen by almost a third from their peak. The combination of declining consumption, plentiful reserves (30 years at current production rates) and the increasing availability of those reserves outside of the volatile Middle East, suggests that the prices of crude oil and petroleum products sold to the United States will not rise to offset the decline in the dollar's value.
Similar excess-supply conditions exist for other industrial materials, largely because deeply indebted third world countries are important suppliers - and they are flooding the market in an effort to get dollars needed to service their debts.
The picture is much the same in agriculture and manufacturing. Over the last decade, world consumption of grains has grown about 2.25 percent annually, the same rate as the yield per acre. Grain inventories at the end of this crop year should be about one-third higher than they were 10 years ago, when shortages were widespread and farmers were getting record prices. And with capacity utilization of manufacturing in both Europe and the United States hovering at around 80 percent, there is a substantial margin for capacity to rise before bottlenecks appear.
Beyond that, there has been substantial growth of capacity in the newly industrialized countries in the past several years, prompted in large part by the outsourcing and direct investment of American manufacturers seeking relief from the intense competitive pressures placed on them by the strong dollar. The slow growth - 2 percent - in the United States economy from the middle of last year to the middle of this one, has hurt the newly industrialized countries. It has created the excess capacity that will prevent those countries from raising prices on goods they sell to the United States.
This worldwide picture of excess manufacturing capacity and raw material abundance means this year's decline in the value of the dollar is unlikely to add much if anything to the inflation rate next year.
The remaining question is how far the dollar will fall from its present level. The agreement reached on Sept. 22, by the Group of Five - the United States, Japan, Great Britain, West Germany and France - stated that ''some further appreciation of the main non-dollar currencies against the dollar is desirable.'' But there is reason to believe that the practical intent of that statement was to raise the value of the yen against the major non-yen currencies. SINCE the September 22 agreement, the dollar has depreciated 17 percent against the yen, compared with depreciation of 7 percent to 10 percent against the currencies of the three European countries. Prior to Sept. 22, the dollar had depreciated only 8 percent from its high against the yen, compared with a 14 percent to 20 percent depreciation against the currencies of the three other countries. Now the dollar shows about the same total decline -24 percent - from its peak against each of the four currencies. So, the yen has been put in line with the three European currencies without pushing the dollar down too much farther on average.
That the objective of the Group of Five was to raise the value of the yen against all four currencies rather than to lower the dollar is very plausible. Their public claims notwithstanding, the Europeans know they need a strong dollar and yen. Before the worldwide recession of 1981 and 1982, Europe paid for its trade deficit with the United States by exporting to the OPEC countries and to other developing nations. But those markets dried up with the fall-off in prices of oil and other industrial and agricultural commodities. Europe needed markets in the United States, Canada and the Far East to compensate. But its ability to increase penetration in those markets was limited by its labor costs; the rise in the dollar facilitated that penetration.
Unit labor costs in all three countries were well above those of the United States in 1980. Now they are well below. So the strong dollar provided the impetus for a swing in Europe's trade with the United States, from a deficit of $20 billion in 1980 to a surplus of about $15 billion in 1984.
Thus, the European economies are not yet ready to bear the consequences of further dollar depreciation. They must await the reopening of new markets. How soon that occurs depends on whether the Soviet leader, Mikhail S. Gorbachev, really does want to pursue policies that will increase trade between Western Europe and the Eastern bloc countries.
For now, the dollar appears to have fallen about as much as it will for the next several years. And the decline to date is unlikely to result in a rebound of United States inflation that is symmetrical to that which occurred when the dollar rose.
Surely inflation will creep up, as long as our economic expansion coontinues. But international currency developments are not a threat to the low inflation rate over the next 12 to 18 months. And the strengthening of price stability stemming from worldwide abundance should keep inflation far from double digits for the rest of the decade.
