WHY THE DATA MAY BE OFF

Author: Glyn, Andrew; Andrew Glyn is a fellow in economics at Corpus Christi College, Oxford.

Publication info: New York Times , Late Edition (East Coast); New York, N.Y. [New York, N.Y]22 Sep 1985: A.2.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/425516312?accountid=11752

Abstract: The results are rather dramatic. In the first three quarters of 1984, United States earnings on direct investment abroad were about $28 billion. In contrast, the profits on overseas investments in the United States were only about $7.5 billion. Thus, while the book value of American direct investment abroad was only half again as much as direct investment in the United States, its earnings were four times as much. From this figure, we can establish a net capital value for American overseas investment of about $350 billion (against a net book value of $77 billion).

Links: http://findit.library.jhu.edu/resolve?url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Anytimes&amp;atitle=WHY+THE+DATA+MAY+BE+OFF&amp;title=New+York+Times&amp;issn=03624331&amp;date=1985-09-22&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=A.2&amp;au=Glyn%2C+Andrew%3BAndrew+Glyn+is+a+fellow+in+economics+at+Corpus+Christi+College%2C+Oxford.&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=New+York+Times&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text: Is the United States truly a debtor nation, as the Commerce Department reported last week? I think not. While there is no disputing that America's international investment position has fallen dramatically, the official figures give a highly misleading impression. The reason lies in a failure to properly allow for inflation.
The total of international assets is a hodgepodge of shares, government bonds, bank deposits and overseas assets. Shares, bonds and bank deposits have a market value that is readily determined. The stock of direct investment, however, is the cumulative book value of investments. As any book-value calculation, it understates the replacement value of the assets. The older the investment, the greater the understatement, especially in an inflationary time.
United States direct investment abroad is greater in book value terms (around $226 billion in October 1984) than direct investment in America (about $149 billion). It is also older; about one-half of direct investment in the United States took place over the last five years, while only one-fifth of American direct investment abroad was added in those years.
What is the true replacement value of American direct investment overseas? Data that would allow a direct calculation are not available. But the earnings from direct investment can be capitalized to give a rough market evaluation, on a par with that of shares and bonds.
The results are rather dramatic. In the first three quarters of 1984, United States earnings on direct investment abroad were about $28 billion. In contrast, the profits on overseas investments in the United States were only about $7.5 billion. Thus, while the book value of American direct investment abroad was only half again as much as direct investment in the United States, its earnings were four times as much. From this figure, we can establish a net capital value for American overseas investment of about $350 billion (against a net book value of $77 billion).
Thus, the United States is not a net international debtor, and will not be for another couple of years, even if trade deficits turn out as high as forecast. However, this should not disguise or minimize the fact that the pattern of international direct investment has drastically changed.

PROTECTIONIST MOOD: MOUNTING PRESSURE SMOOT AND HAWLEY

Author: Silk, Leonard

Publication info: New York Times , Late Edition (East Coast); New York, N.Y. [New York, N.Y]17 Sep 1985: D.1.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/425514498?accountid=11752

Abstract: After Herbert Hoover was elected, Congress wrote a trade bill that steeply increased tariffs not only on farm imports but also on virtually all other imports. When Smoot-Hawley reached the President's desk 1,038 American economists - including just about every reputable economist of whatever political view - signed a petition urging him to veto the bill. They warned that it would ''inevitably provoke others to pay us back in kind,'' damaging the United States economy. But President Hoover, who felt bound by his party's platform pledge, signed the Smoot-Hawley legislation. The real pressure for protection has little to do with the balance of trade, according to Lionel W. McKenzie, professor of economics at the University of Rochester. Instead, he said, it stems from ''particular industries which can benefit from excluding Japanese products.'' In his view, these are ''rich industries which pay high wages and salaries and have a corresponding political clout.'' President Reagan, seeking to undercut Congressional pressure for protectionism, has introduced a more aggressive policy to open foreign markets to American goods. He has said he would initiate a series of investigations into ''unfair trading practices'' of Japan, the European Economic Community, South Korea and Brazil. And it now seems likely that additional tough measures, intended to impress and appease Congress, will follow. Outcome Is Unknown On President's Efforts It is too early to know whether the President's efforts to stanch protectionism, possibly reinforced by his veto power, will prevail - or whether his efforts to use tough means to redress the American trade position will themselves become a form of protectionism.

Links: http://findit.library.jhu.edu/resolve?url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Anytimes&amp;atitle=PROTECTIONIST+MOOD%3A+MOUNTING+PRESSURE+SMOOT+AND+HAWLEY%3A+%5BANALYSIS%5D&amp;title=New+York+Times&amp;issn=03624331&amp;date=1985-09-17&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=D.1&amp;au=Silk%2C+Leonard&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=New+York+Times&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text: After pursuing a free-trade policy for the past 50 years, the United States Congress is seriously considering protectionist measures of the sort contained in the damaging Smoot-Hawley tariff act of 1930, which many economists believe helped to create the Great Depression.
There is much perplexity about the strength of protectionist sentiment in Congress - and much anxiety over the danger that, if it prevails, the United States would again provoke retaliation and start a trade war that would inflict grave damage on the economy of America and the world.
Could this happen again, or has the danger been greatly overblown?
Supporters of restrictive trade legislation today insist that they are not trying to start a trade war but seek only to protect American labor, industry and agriculture from unfair competition.
What their intentions are and what the results would be, however, may be two different things. Most trade experts believe that the danger of serious protective measures taken by the United States is a real danger and that such measures could indeed spark some kind of trade war. But they add that its disastrous economic effects could be tempered if the United States and other countries undertake strong spending programs or other expansionary moves.
In 1930 the supporters of Smoot-Hawley intended merely to help some injured Americans - especially the farmers. The Republican Party had promised in its 1928 platform to relieve the agricultural depression, which had already begun.
After Herbert Hoover was elected, Congress wrote a trade bill that steeply increased tariffs not only on farm imports but also on virtually all other imports. When Smoot-Hawley reached the President's desk 1,038 American economists - including just about every reputable economist of whatever political view - signed a petition urging him to veto the bill. They warned that it would ''inevitably provoke others to pay us back in kind,'' damaging the United States economy. But President Hoover, who felt bound by his party's platform pledge, signed the Smoot-Hawley legislation.
The economists were right about retaliation from America's trading partners. Britain, France, Italy and other nations raised tariffs or introduced quotas. Switzerland boycotted American products. Canada raised its tariff walls to the highest in history. International conferences were held in 1931, 1932 and 1933 in an effort to work out a truce in the trade war. All those talks failed. The higher American trade barriers frustrated Tokyo's efforts to improve the economic conditions of the Japanese people through expanding trade. Japan turned to a more nationalistic and militant foreign policy.
The United States was worse off after Smoot-Hawley than it had been before. This country's exports plunged because of the higher trade barriers and because of the spreading world depression, which was aggravated by the collapse of trade. By 1932 American exports had plummeted to about one-fourth of their 1929 level. Agriculture, the sector President Hoover had tried to help, suffered the most. Wheat exports, which had totaled $200 million 10 years earlier, slumped to $5 million in 1932. Auto exports fell from $541 million in 1929 to $76 million in 1932.
In retrospect, Smoot-Hawley was worse than futile. It failed to solve unemployment and other problems of American labor, industry and agriculture; instead it aggravated the problems. And it contributed to the deepening political and economic crisis and the bitter nationalism that helped to bring on World War II.
In light of these past events, why are serious people in Congress and their supporters now contemplating setting off the biggest wave of restrictive trade legislation since the Depression? Industry and Labor Put Pressure on Congress For one thing, the pressure on legislators has been mounting as the nation's trade deficit swells. The pressure comes from affected industrial and labor groups demanding a more restrictive and aggressive American trade policy. Administration officials and private economists have forecast that the trade deficit will widen to between $140 billion and $160 billion this year, compared with $123 billion last year, and there is no turnaround in sight.
No nation, whether the United States or Brazil or Argentina, can expect foreigners to finance its deficits indefinitely. ''Such a gigantic imbalance is simply not sustainable,'' said Lawrence A. Krause, an international economist at the Brookings Institution in Washington, voicing a widely shared sentiment.
Another major reason for the buildup of protectionist pressure -despite the benefits in lower prices or better quality that imports can bring to consumers - is the fact that specific industries and groups of workers suffer an immediate loss of income or jobs. This means losses that they consider unacceptable, regardless of the long-run effect on the nation's trade.
The real pressure for protection has little to do with the balance of trade, according to Lionel W. McKenzie, professor of economics at the University of Rochester. Instead, he said, it stems from ''particular industries which can benefit from excluding Japanese products.'' In his view, these are ''rich industries which pay high wages and salaries and have a corresponding political clout.''
But if some high-wage industries, such as steel and autos, are pressing for protection from imports, so are some low-wage industries such as textiles and shoes. What all these manufacturers have in common is a loss of ground in both foreign and domestic markets. American Resentment Against the Japanese Particularly vexatious is the loss of position in areas where the United States has considered itself the world leader: high technology and capital goods. While the United States still ran trade surpluses in these categories in 1984, the surpluses have shrunk considerably.
Unquestionably, a significant factor in the upward surge of protectionist spirit among many Americans is that the losses to the Japanese have been both large and growing, and they feel that the Japanese have not played fair but instead have discriminated against or excluded American goods from their market through a variety of methods. At the same time, however, American consumers have continued to buy Japanese goods heavily.
Last year the United States ran its biggest bilateral deficit in trade with Japan - more than $37 billion, compared with a bilateral trade deficit against West Germany of just $8 billion.
Yet the threat to American dominance in manufactured goods is by no means limited to Japan. It comes from the newly industrialized nations of Asia - South Korea, Hong Kong, Singapore and Taiwan. And as technology is rapidly diffused throughout the world, the threat also comes from many developing countries as well, ranging from Brazil to China, which is now making an enormous bid to take its place among the industrial nations.
It is these strains that are now weighing on American trade policy. Since the Reciprocal Trade Act of 1935, that policy has been based on the proposition that free and open trade is the best means of promoting the development of both the United States economy and the world economy.
Although economists still generally support free trade, they are beginning to take a more skeptical look at the doctrine in the light of present conditions. The Present Problem: Economists' Viewpoint Stephen V. O. Clarke, an economist who has served in senior positions at the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, suggests, ''Free trade is designed to serve the self-interest of the nation that is industrially dominant.'' In his view, Britain swung from mercantilism to free trade when it became industrially dominant early in the 19th century, and the United States followed a similar course in the earlier part of the 20th century.
One way of regarding the present surge of protectionist spirit, not only in Congress but also in American industry, is that the United States has lost confidence that it is the industrial leader and needs to revert to a more aggressive and nationalistic trade policy. Under this theory, Japan, as the emerging world leader, ought to embrace free trade. And indeed there are some signs that it is doing so, although some critics of Japan believe it has waited too long and has endangered an open world trading system by provoking American resentment and protectionist spirit.
How great is the danger that the mood of protectionism will prevail in the United States? And, if it does, how great is the danger that the world economy would suffer the kind of shock that followed Smoot-Hawley? Bob Dole of Kansas, the Senate majority leader, says he has ''never seen stronger sentiment'' in Congress for restrictive trade legislation.
But President Reagan, seeking to undercut Congressional pressure for protectionism, has introduced a more aggressive policy to open foreign markets to American goods. He has said he would initiate a series of investigations into ''unfair trading practices'' of Japan, the European Economic Community, South Korea and Brazil. And it now seems likely that additional tough measures, intended to impress and appease Congress, will follow. Outcome Is Unknown On President's Efforts It is too early to know whether the President's efforts to stanch protectionism, possibly reinforced by his veto power, will prevail - or whether his efforts to use tough means to redress the American trade position will themselves become a form of protectionism.
If, in fact, protectionism does win out in the United States, either with Mr. Reagan's acceptance or despite his resistance, would it provoke retaliation and unleash the depressive forces that swept the world economy in the wake of Smoot-Hawley?
The disastrous effect last time of a worldwide trade war would probably have a considerable effect in causing many nations to try to scale down their counterattack on the American measures. The existence of international agreements - especially the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, past resolutions on open trade reached at economic summit conferences of leaders of the industrial countries and the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development - would act to check a trade war.
Geoffrey Bell, president of Geoffrey Bell & Company, a New York consulting firm that advises Venezuela and other countries on their economic policies, believes that the response of foreign countries to restrictive American measures would also be muted because of their strong interest in keeping a stake in the huge United States market, by far the biggest in the world. But Teh Kok Peng, chief economist for the Monetary Authority of Singapore, fears that many countries would be driven to respond to American protectionism because of domestic political reasons as well as economic reasons.
Even if trade barriers proliferated, however, they might not touch off the same kind of downward economic spiral into industrial stagnation and unemployment as happened in the 1930's. Since the Depression, nations have learned a great deal about how to use fiscal and monetary policy to maintain a high enough level of aggregate demand for goods and services to prevent a plunge into mass unemployment. In the United States 25 percent of the labor force was unemployed in 1933. Role of Central Banks In Counteracting Slump Last time many governments and monetary authorities raised taxes, cut spending and choked off demand, thereby aggravating the Depression, Next time - if there is one - both the governments and central banks of the industrial nations would almost certainly use monetary and fiscal policy to counteract the depressive forces as much as possible.
What could inhibit stimulative governmental measures, however, are the huge budget deficits in many countries, including the United States, and fears of inflation.
But if the potential for problems seems reduced now, the stakes are greater than they were in the 1930's. Nations have grown far more dependent on foreign trade as the world economy has become increasingly integrated. Just in the past two decades, total world exports and imports have each risen from 9 percent of gross domestic product to 17 percent.
Also, the developing countries have piled up enormous debts, which now exceed $800 billion. An outbreak of protectionism could gravely aggravate the world's precarious financial web. The developing countries, seeking to cope with their debt burdens, have been restraining imports and stimulating exports. A wave of protectionism, hitting the Brazils and Argentinas and Mexicos of this world by shutting out their exports, would make it impossible for them to service their debt, which would affect the banks in the industrial world that have lent heavily to them, threatening a financial disaster.
Thus, the policy issue confronting the United States today is not whether it will correct its gigantic trade deficit but how - whether by measures aimed at reducing imports or by measures aimed at expanding exports. A Different Strategy: Expansion of Exports Protectionist measures aimed at restricting imports, on the Smoot-Hawley model, run the danger of causing world trade to deteriorate and world depression to emerge. Measures to expand exports, on the contrary, can be made consistent with an open world trading system, encouraging efficiency and stimulating the growth of output, income and jobs.
Pursuing the latter course of expansion for the United States will involve reducing what the vast majority of economists regard as the overvaluation of the dollar. They do not think it is a coincidence that the rapid appreciation of the dollar since 1980 occurred at the same time as the worsening of the American trade deficit. Some economists attribute as much as two-thirds of the trade deficit to the overvalued dollar, which raises the prices of a broad range of American-made products abroad and cuts the prices of a broad range of foreign goods imported into the United States.
Restoring the dollar to a better alignment with other currencies involves several elements. Foreign countries might accelerate the growth of their economies or the United States could reduce its own growth or go into recession. This is likely to be a major issue at the coming meetings of the International Monetary Fund next month in Seoul, South Korea.
The United States might also seek to reduce its level of interest rates as a way of helping to bring down the foreign-exchange value of the dollar. But to reduce ''real'' interest rates -the nominal rates, adjusted for inflation - the United States would have to change its mix of fiscal and monetary policy. That would require, first of all, a major reduction in the Federal budget deficit, thereby reducing the Government's demand for funds, including foreign savings, to make way for an easier monetary policy by the Federal Reserve System, aimed at bringing down interest rates. Fed Remains Cautious On Specter of Inflation Some economists believe that the Federal Reserve could and should take more risks to bring down interest rates and the dollar's value, even in the absence of major budget-shrinking actions by Congress.
But Paul A. Volcker, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, and his colleagues remain cautious about reigniting inflation by such measures in the absence of a less stimulative fiscal policy.
The dollar has fallen about 10 percent since its peak in late February, but its decline seems to have stalled. And with the macroeconomic factors that have aggravated the United States trade deficit still uncorrected, Congress and the affected industrial and labor interests are focusing their efforts on dealing directly with the problem of import. The Jenkins bill, for example, would roll back textile imports by about 30 percent, and even stiffer measures than that have been proposed.
The President, having sought to stop the protectionist attack frontally - by vetoing a bill to cut shoe imports, for instance - now appears to be preparing a more aggressive line to accommodate Congressional pressures. His actions on the trade front are apparently aimed at heading off even tougher action by Congress. He is still hoping to deal with the trade problem mainly by opening foreign markets wider to American goods.
As long as the macroeconomic conditions making for an overvalued dollar and a huge trade surplus prevail, however, the trade issue (as Senator Dole has said) is likely to endure through the 1986 Congressional and 1988 Presidential elections, producing great political heat and increasing the risks of retaliation and a contraction in trade and the world economy.
Representative Willis Hawley, Republican of Oregon, and Senator Reed Smoot, Republican of Utah, co-authors of the tariff act of 1930 that bears their names, were Congressional leaders who made their mark as experts on taxation and finance.
Willis Hawley came to Congress in 1906 after having taught economics and constituitonal law at Willamette University, where he had earned bachelor of science and law degrees and also served as its president. In Congress, Mr. Hawley was named chairman of the Ways and Means Committee in 1928.
Mr. Hawley was one of many Republicans who lost his seat in the Democratic landslide of 1932, during the Great Depression, when Franklin D. Roosevelt won election to the White House. Many people believed the trade war that followed adoption of the Smoot-Hawley legislation aggravated the Depression. President Roosevelt, who had attacked the tariff act in his 1932 campaign, subsequently dismantled it. Mr. Hawley died in 1941 at the age of 77.
Reed Smoot, elected to the Senate in 1902, was an expert on tariff taxation and a champion of government economy. He became chairman of the Finance Committee, where he worked 17 months for passage of the tariff bill.
Mr. Smoot grew up in Salt Lake City and graduated from Brigham Young Academy (now Brigham Young University). In Utah he gained prominance in banking, mining, livestock raising and the manufacture of woolen goods. He was a delegate to the Republican National Convention five times.
A well-known Mormon leader, Mr. Smoot was named president of the Utah Stake of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints and became one of the 12 apostles of the church in 1900. His election to the Senate was contested on the ground that, as a high Mormon official, he sanctioned polygamy in violation of the laws of Utah.
Like Mr. Hawley, he lost his Congressional seat in 1932. Mr. Smoot continued to serve in the church until his death in 1941.

Economic Scene; If the Dollar Lands Hard

Author: Silk, Leonard

Publication info: New York Times , Late Edition (East Coast); New York, N.Y. [New York, N.Y]24 July 1985: D.2.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/425457298?accountid=11752

Abstract: This outcome is not inevitable. Paul A. Volcker, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, during his Congressional testimony last week, warned that ''we are piling up debts abroad in amounts unparalleled in our history,'' and said, ''When we are living on this much borrowed money, we are also living on borrowed time.'' But faced with the threat of a hard landing, Mr. Volcker gave the impression that the Fed would fight to halt the dollar's decline and capital outflow, even if it meant tighter money and higher interest rates. Preston Martin, vice chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, said in an interview yesterday that he believed the Group of 10 leading industrial countries was starting to come to grips with the need for cooperative action. ''This country can't go it alone,'' he said. ''Our partners in Europe and Japan have a bigger G.N.P. than the United States, and they must come forth with more stimulative policies.'' He said Treasury Secretary James A. Baker 3d was ''a skilled negotiator'' and would make them see the importance of expanding their economies and their imports as a contribution to restoring balance to the American trade position. At the same time, Mr. Martin said the United States needed to take a ''tougher line'' against foreign trade barriers and was sure that the new United States trade negotiator, Clayton K. Yeutter, would do so.

Links: http://findit.library.jhu.edu/resolve?url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Anytimes&amp;atitle=Economic+Scene%3B+If+the+Dollar+Lands+Hard&amp;title=New+York+Times&amp;issn=03624331&amp;date=1985-07-24&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=D.2&amp;au=Silk%2C+Leonard&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=New+York+Times&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text: IS a soft landing for the dollar - a gradual decline that would reduce the United States trade deficit - feasible or has a hard landing, or a crash landing, now become virtually inescapable?
Stephen N. Marris of the Institute of International Economics finds a soft landing highly implausible as a matter of ''simple arithmetic.''
In the current issue of Brookings Papers on Economic Activity, Mr. Marris calculates that if the dollar were to depreciate by 5 percent a year, it would take 14 years to eliminate the United States current account deficit, by which time the American external indebtedness would have risen to more than $2.3 trillion.
Such an external debt, he suggests, is nonsensical. But even if one could conceive of borrowing that much money, the real interest rates in this country would have to be so high - at least 5 percent above the potential United States growth rate - as to stifle economic growth. Alternatively, he calculates, real interest rates in other countries would have to be so low - 5 percent below their potential growth rates - as to breed virulent inflation.
Another version of the soft-landing scenario envisions capital inflows to the United States gradually slowing down to, say, 1 to 2 percent of gross national product by 1990. But, if the American economy were to maintain a moderate growth rate while gradually reducing its trade deficit, Mr. Marris estimates that this would require a 35 percent drop in the dollar by 1990 - by which time the United States net external debt would have risen to about $800 billion.
''In other words,'' he writes in the current Brookings Papers, ''some asset holders, somewhere, would have to be induced to increase their exposure in dollars by about $800 billion at a time when, for example, the German mark would be appreciating against the dollar by about 75 percent.''
That he finds unbelievable. Rather, he expects that for a period of a year to a year and a half, people's willingness to increase their dollar exposure will fall faster than the United States economy's need for capital inflows to make up for its deficiency of domestic savings.
The result is likely to be a financial ''crunch'' and a hard landing for the dollar, Mr. Marris says, with a shooting up of interest rates by at least five percentage points above what they otherwise would have been. That hard landing, he says, would cause a recession, rising unemployment and accelerating inflation in the United States, with fallout on other countries.
However, this outcome is not inevitable. Paul A. Volcker, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, during his Congressional testimony last week, warned that ''we are piling up debts abroad in amounts unparalleled in our history,'' and said, ''When we are living on this much borrowed money, we are also living on borrowed time.'' But faced with the threat of a hard landing, Mr. Volcker gave the impression that the Fed would fight to halt the dollar's decline and capital outflow, even if it meant tighter money and higher interest rates.
Yet, despite Mr. Volcker's efforts to quiet what was in danger of becoming a ''disorderly'' market, the Fed's true aim appears to be to permit or even engineer a gradual decline in the dollar. Yet, along the way, it means to keep speculators from running wild.
Many academic economists, and some central bankers as well, believe that the United States cannot solve the problems of an overvalued dollar and a widening trade deficit on its own.
Preston Martin, vice chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, said in an interview yesterday that he believed the Group of 10 leading industrial countries was starting to come to grips with the need for cooperative action. ''This country can't go it alone,'' he said. ''Our partners in Europe and Japan have a bigger G.N.P. than the United States, and they must come forth with more stimulative policies.''
He said Treasury Secretary James A. Baker 3d was ''a skilled negotiator'' and would make them see the importance of expanding their economies and their imports as a contribution to restoring balance to the American trade position. At the same time, Mr. Martin said the United States needed to take a ''tougher line'' against foreign trade barriers and was sure that the new United States trade negotiator, Clayton K. Yeutter, would do so.
But thus far the response from America's trade partners has been sluggish at best. ''There is at present absolutely no sign that Japan, West Germany or the United Kingdom would be prepared to take expansionary action of the required order of magnitude,'' Mr. Marris said.
In a time of growing world deflationary pressure - most notably in the area of oil prices, with the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries near the point of cracking - the European countries and Japan remain most afraid of inflation. They fear that a decline in the value of the dollar would exacerbate that problem. Besides, they do not want to give up the advantage to their own export-oriented economies that an overvalued dollar conveys.
So the United States trade deficit continues to worsen, and the danger of a hard landing for the dollar increases. The question now is whether the Western allies can move ahead of an economic crisis, or whether, however risky, a crisis has become crucial to a solution.

An Oil Surplus - for Now

Author: Industry.'', Daniel Yergin; Daniel Yergin, president of Cambridge Energy Research Associates, is editor of ''Just Another Commodity? The Reshaping of the Oil

Publication info: New York Times , Late Edition (East Coast); New York, N.Y. [New York, N.Y]08 July 1985: A.17.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/425475403?accountid=11752

Abstract: To be sure, what is true for the United States is emphatically not true for other parts of the world. Oil prices, for the most part, are denominated in dollars, and the strengthening dollar has overwhelmed falling oil prices for Western Europe. The result is that in real terms the Europeans are paying more than they ever have in the past - the effects of the strong dollar on their prices are rightly referred to as the ''third oil shock.'' If the United States were only a consumer of energy, all this would be enough. The United States is also a producer, and falling oil prices trouble and threaten ''good faith'' energy investment. This applies right across the spectrum - making allies, ironically, of people who have seen themselves in competition with each other - from those involved in alternatives and conservation to those in domestic oil and gas. Many banks, looking at their energy portfolios, will share that distress. These are the groups that will seek a tariff to protect the domestic energy economy.

Links: http://findit.library.jhu.edu/resolve?url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=unknown&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Anytimes&amp;atitle=An+Oil+Surplus+-+for+Now%3A+%5BOP-ED%5D&amp;title=New+York+Times&amp;issn=03624331&amp;date=1985-07-08&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=A.17&amp;au=Industry.%27%27%2C+Daniel+Yergin%3BDaniel+Yergin%2C+president+of+Cambridge+Energy+Research+Associates%2C+is+editor+of+%27%27Just+Another+Commodity%3F+The+Reshaping+of+the+Oil&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=New+York+Times&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text: The crisis in the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries is clear to everyone. Hardly recognized, however, is the extent to which the second oil price shock - the rapid rise in prices between 1979 and 1981 - is almost over, at least for the American consumer.
The price of oil has been falling for four years. Since 1981, it has dropped more than 25 percent. The drop is even sharper if we take inflation into account. In real terms, oil prices have fallen 40 percent since 1981.Yet even this does not capture the full extent of the drop. When corrected for inflation, United States oil prices in 1985 are just about back to where they were in 1975 - $27.66 per barrel in April versus $27.07 in 1975.
The change is even more striking if we turn to the price at the gasoline pump. If you put 1975 prices into 1985 dollars, the American motorist was paying only a dime less then than now - $1.12 in 1975, compared to today's $1.22.
Four factors have been responsible for this: conservation, the recession, weak economic activity and the growth of alternative, non-OPEC supplies. All of this has put us in an era of surplus in which prices have nowhere to go but down.
To be sure, what is true for the United States is emphatically not true for other parts of the world. Oil prices, for the most part, are denominated in dollars, and the strengthening dollar has overwhelmed falling oil prices for Western Europe. The result is that in real terms the Europeans are paying more than they ever have in the past - the effects of the strong dollar on their prices are rightly referred to as the ''third oil shock.''
The forces that brought oil prices down continue to work. World oil demand is proving very slow to recover, even with renewed economic growth. Many markets for oil have permanently shrunk. Coal and nuclear power have taken over much electricity production from oil - to such an extent that France, for instance, is now trying to sell its nuclear-generated electricity - once a program of national survival - to its neighbors at bargain rates! Other markets will be constricted. Americans will continue to replace cars that get 12 miles to the gallon with cars that get 26 and 27 miles to the gallon.
American consumers are winners from falling oil prices. Less of their budgets will go to paying for energy, meaning that they will have more money to spend for other purposes. The non-oil developing world is also a big winner.
Another winner is the Reagan Administration. Falling oil prices provide a stimulus to economic growth and a most welcome antidote to inflation. Both are very valuable in a time of huge and intractable budget deficits and uncertain economic performance.
If the United States were only a consumer of energy, all this would be enough. The United States is also a producer, and falling oil prices trouble and threaten ''good faith'' energy investment. This applies right across the spectrum - making allies, ironically, of people who have seen themselves in competition with each other - from those involved in alternatives and conservation to those in domestic oil and gas. Many banks, looking at their energy portfolios, will share that distress. These are the groups that will seek a tariff to protect the domestic energy economy.
Further weakness in price will undermine the rationale for a great deal of existing and new investment in energy. Energy consumers will conclude that conservation investment is less important. Oil companies will reduce their efforts to develop new oil fields in frontier regions.
Does this mean that the world will again face a difficult energy situation in the future? Not for several years, at least. The surplus of oil and energy worldwide is very large - so large that tankers and oil installations in the Persian Gulf can be attacked and the price of oil goes down, not up. That cushion will be quite a number of years in eroding. Oil will beome more like other commodities, with volatile prices.
But unless there is a major technological development, at some point the reduction in energy investment will come back to haunt us, and market realities will again give way to geological realities - the concentration of oil reserves in OPEC and in the Middle East. And that will eventually put the era of surplus behind us.

PRACTICAL TRAVELER: WHEN PAYING WITH DOLLARS COSTS MORE

Author: Grimes, Paul

Publication info: New York Times , Late Edition (East Coast); New York, N.Y. [New York, N.Y]26 May 1985: A.3.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/425426087?accountid=11752

Abstract: A notable exception, however, is the QE2. ''You can buy in pounds in London only if you are a U.K. resident - if your passport is British,'' said Alice Marshall, Cunard's assistant vice president for public relations in New York. ''If we charged U.K. residents the same price we charged others,'' she added, ''there wouldn't be any U.K. business because it would be priced out of the market.'' Under ''Tour Conditions'' on page 82 of its 1985 ''Europe's Best Bargains'' brochure, distributed in the United States, Cosmos Tourama states that its dollar prices were set in August 1984 and are subject to increase without notice if rates change substantially. ''In converting all the European currencies which make up the Cosmos tour prices to U.S. dollars,'' the company says, ''it has been necessary to use a rate approximately 5 percent higher than the current (August 1984) bank rates of exchange to cover the higher cost involved in making reservations in Europe available in the United States.'' Here is one of the results, based on a comparison of this brochure, obtained in New York, with one obtained from Cosmos in London. A 14-day ''Grand European Folklore'' tour, beginning and ending in London, is priced at $549 a person in the United States and $:389 ($486) in Britain. Can an American pay in pounds in London? ''We don't care what they are,'' said Jeffrey Joseph, executive vice president, sales and marketing, for Cosmos in New York. ''They can be green, yellow, Americans, Britons -it doesn't make any difference.''

Links: http://findit.library.jhu.edu/resolve?url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Anytimes&amp;atitle=PRACTICAL+TRAVELER%3A+WHEN+PAYING+WITH+DOLLARS+COSTS+MORE&amp;title=New+York+Times&amp;issn=03624331&amp;date=1985-05-26&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=A.3&amp;au=Grimes%2C+Paul&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=New+York+Times&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text: They have never met, but Robert B. Turner and Sol Chazin have something in common. Each of them has taken an escorted tour conducted by a London-based company called Voyages Jules Verne and each has been disturbed by what happened. Among their principal complaints was that Americans paid substantially more than Europeans on the same tours.
Mr. Turner, who lives in Manhattan Beach, Minn., paid $9,310 for his wife and himself to travel by air and rail from London to Hong Kong along what the company calls ''The Golden Road to Far Cathay.'' The journey began Sept. 19 and ended Oct. 28. In a recent letter to The New York Times, Mr. Turner said, ''During the trip we discovered that Jules Verne had a dual pricing policy. North Americans paid 57 percent more!''
Mr. Chazin, a mechanical engineer from Tenafly, N.J., traveled through India, Pakistan and Sri Lanka, mostly by rail, on a tour called ''The Raj Express.'' The trip began in London on Feb. 5 and ended there March 13. ''To start with,'' Mr. Chazin complained in early April, ''I paid $4,100 for the excursion. The rest of the 22 tour members - mostly British -had booked the trip in London for $:2,500. I'm no mathematician, but the exchange rate seems a little off there. Considering that the British pound is worth $1.05 or so, I overpaid by roughly 45 percent.''
By mid-May, the pound had strengthened and was running about $1.25. Even so, there were substantial disparities between what some of the same trips cost in London and in the United States. Voyages Jules Verne was hardly alone in dual pricing; such policies extended to much larger operations, including Cosmos Tourama and Trafalgar Tours, both based in London, and trans-Atlantic sailings of Cunard Line's Queen Elizabeth 2.
In some cases, there are ways to get around this. Most tours out of London can be bought there in pounds. You usually have to be there, however, and identify yourself as the actual passenger. This could mean that if a tour is popular and you do not arrive until shortly before departure, it might be sold out.
A notable exception, however, is the QE2. ''You can buy in pounds in London only if you are a U.K. resident - if your passport is British,'' said Alice Marshall, Cunard's assistant vice president for public relations in New York. ''If we charged U.K. residents the same price we charged others,'' she added, ''there wouldn't be any U.K. business because it would be priced out of the market.''
So, according to Miss Marshall, an inside cabin in trans-Atlantic class, the lower of the two classes on the ship, with upper and lower berths, on a sailing from Southampton to New York, costs Americans $1,510 a person, based on two in a cabin, but it costs Britons $:855. The British price amounts to $1,067, or $443 less, computed on the recent rate of $1.25 to a pound. A first-class cabin with two lower beds costs Americans $2,720 and Britons $:1,540 ($1,925). A deluxe cabin with two lower berths (and dining in the choice Princess Grill) costs Americans $3,440 a person and Britons $:1,945 ($2,431).
To take advantage of the favorable pound rate, a Briton who planned to sail from New York to Southampton would have to buy his ticket in Britain before leaving home. ''We don't sell in pounds in the United States,'' Miss Marshall said.
Tour operators defend dual pricing on the ground that they have to establish rates up to a year in advance. Said Philip Morrell, managing director of Travel Promotions Ltd., which owns Voyages Jules Verne: ''Trying to anticipate what will happen between the dollar and the pound is like trying to hit a moving target.''
Operators say it costs more to market tours in the United States than in Europe. They cite higher costs for advertising and handling reservations. Reached in London, Mr. Morrell said commissions to travel agents run about 15 percent higher in the United States than in Britain because the rate is higher here and because all his American sales are through agents while half his British sales are direct to travelers.
Should the dollar weaken, it could work to Americans' advantage on European travel for which prices are guaranteed in dollars. Americans would find, however, that shopping and any accommodations and meals not included in a tour package would cost much more than they do now.
Miss Marshall of Cunard said, however, that the company's price structure was based primarily on local conditions rather than on currency fluctuations. ''Prices are raised or lowered according to inflation in local markets,'' she said. ''Prices have been sort of steady for the past few years. But if the inflation rate in the United States was 5 percent, that's about how much rates would go up in the United States. If inflation in the U.K. was 15 percent, that's about how much rates would go up in the U.K.''
Under ''Tour Conditions'' on page 82 of its 1985 ''Europe's Best Bargains'' brochure, distributed in the United States, Cosmos Tourama states that its dollar prices were set in August 1984 and are subject to increase without notice if rates change substantially. ''In converting all the European currencies which make up the Cosmos tour prices to U.S. dollars,'' the company says, ''it has been necessary to use a rate approximately 5 percent higher than the current (August 1984) bank rates of exchange to cover the higher cost involved in making reservations in Europe available in the United States.''
Here is one of the results, based on a comparison of this brochure, obtained in New York, with one obtained from Cosmos in London. A 14-day ''Grand European Folklore'' tour, beginning and ending in London, is priced at $549 a person in the United States and $:389 ($486) in Britain. Can an American pay in pounds in London? ''We don't care what they are,'' said Jeffrey Joseph, executive vice president, sales and marketing, for Cosmos in New York. ''They can be green, yellow, Americans, Britons -it doesn't make any difference.''
Similarly, the same ''Scenic Europe'' itinerary of Trafalgar Tours is priced at $775 in the United States and $:420 ($525) in London. For Americans, however, the price includes three nights in London hotels, which are not part of the British offering. So if you subtract $99 for those nights (at Trafalgar's listed rate of $33 a night), the comparable American price drops to $676. (In its British brochure, however, Trafalgar offers, as an optional extra, the same accommodations at $:22 - $27.50 - a night.) Asked to comment, Nigel Osborne, vice president, sales and marketing, for Trafalgar in New York, said, ''We don't specifically market those tours in the U.K. The brochures are there in our London reception center in case somebody returning from one of our tours wants to buy another one.''
With American Express, the policy is different, according to Miriam Trokan, manager of business support communications. She said that most of its European tours were priced in dollars and a European who paid in local currency would do so at the then-current exchange rate. The company's short tours and villa vacations - priced in pounds - could be bought by anyone at that rate, she said.
Explaining Jules Verne's dual pricing, Mr. Morrell said that many of the company's expenses were incurred in Communist or developing countries where they had to be paid in dollars or at rates set in relation to the dollar. He said that few Britons took his tours anyway (a point that some travelers have disputed) and that, because trade regulations limited the surcharges that could be imposed on them, they were in effect being subsidized by non-Britons. He said, however, that if an American in London insisted on paying the pound price, he could do so, but that in mid-May the rates in the 1985 brochure were subject to a 9.9 percent surcharge and that prices for 1986 would be up to 20 percent higher than those advertised for this year.
Once an American has paid in dollars - as Mr. Turner of Minnesota and Mr. Chazin of New Jersey learned after substantial correspondence - seeking a refund is likely to be futile.

Subject: TRAVEL AND VACATIONS; PRICES

Location: UNITED STATES EUROPE

People: GRIMES, PAUL

Company / organization: Name: Cunard Line Ltd; NAICS: 721110, 483112; SIC: 4481, 7011; DUNS: 61-856-7358

Title: PRACTICAL TRAVELER: WHEN PAYING WITH DOLLARS COSTS MORE

Publication title: New York Times, Late Edition (East Coast); New York, N.Y.

REAGAN'S NEW DOLLAR STRATEGY

Author: Kilborn, Peter F

Publication info: New York Times , Late Edition (East Coast); New York, N.Y. [New York, N.Y]03 Mar 1985: A.1.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/425362646?accountid=11752

Abstract: * The Measurex Corporation in Cupertino, Calif., makes computerized manufacturing systems, mostly for the paper industry. Ten years ago, well before the rise of the dollar, Measurex opened a factory in Waterford, Ireland, where it assembles its systems for sale to the European market. But in January, because of the dollar, the company switched to ''local currency pricing'' - quoting its prices in foreign currencies rather than dollars, to remain competitive, even though that means lower earnings in terms of dollars. ''We can't demand a fixed dollar price any more,'' said Robert McAdams Jr., senior vice president for finance. ''The competition won't allow us to do that.'' * The Brunswick Corporation in Skokie, Ill., is a diversified manufacturer whose products include the Mercury and Mariner brands of outboard motors. ''Over the past four years, our motor sales have declined, mostly because of the dollar,'' said Max E. McGrath, vice president for finance. Japanese competitors - Honda, Suzuki, Yamaha - have captured much of Brunswick's market. ''We're dealing with it,'' he said, ''primarily with an extensive cost-reduction program, so when we deliver our engines our goal is to meet their price.'' Brunswick is also importing more engines from Japan under its own label. * The Briggs & Stratton Corporation in St. Paul is one of the nation's best-known makers of gasoline and diesel engines. ''We get pretty emotional about the dollar,'' said L. William Dewey, executive vice president. ''We used to have 26 percent of our sales outside the United States. Right now, it's less than half that. We attribute it almost totally to the dollar.'' Briggs & Stratton's strategy for dealing with Japanese competitors in America is ''zero pricing,'' which means the company does not raise prices. Overseas, the company, like Measurex, has switched to ''local currency pricing.'' In the 1960's, Mr. Dewey said, the company considered opening a manufacturing plant abroad and decided not to. ''It's a strategy we have to seriously consider again,'' he said.

Links: http://findit.library.jhu.edu/resolve?url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Anytimes&amp;atitle=REAGAN%27S+NEW+DOLLAR+STRATEGY&amp;title=New+York+Times&amp;issn=03624331&amp;date=1985-03-03&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=A.1&amp;au=Kilborn%2C+Peter+F&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=New+York+Times&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text: WASHINGTON THE week of the dollar is over.
And in the immediate aftermath, it is clear that the world's leading industrial powers have quietly agreed that the dollar must be stopped.
Their strategy showed itself with a vengeance in midweek after the dollar had registered one of its biggest one-day gains in history - reflecting a marketplace view that President Reagan would do nothing to bring it down. The Western nations sold dollars from their reserves - more than one billion by most accounts - and with that, it was evident that the Administration and its Western allies were trying to move toward a common economic policy that would eventually bring the dollar into check.
The scale of the governments' intervention Wednesday appeared to come partly in response to the statement of Paul A. Volcker, chairman of the Federal Reserve, that interventions to date had been too small to make a difference. With the Germans in the lead, the countries stunned the market with an overflow of dollars and provoked one of the dollar's sharpest one-day declines in history.
It looked like a bold move, and indeed it was compared with the rare and tentative interventions of the last few years. But $50 billion to $100 billion washes through the currency markets each day, and to many of the market's experts, the intervention last week - by itself - could do little more than discourage another rise like Monday's. ''It would take $10 billion to $15 billion to count as a substantial amount,'' said Roger Kubarych, chief economist at the Federal Reserve Bank of New York until January and now at the Conference Board.
More significant than the size of last week's intervention was the signal it sent of the changing official attitudes toward the dollar and the future roles of the economies that underlie major currencies. The dollar, the intervention said, has become politically untenable, especially for the Reagan Administration. Damage to such sensitive constituencies as farmers and numerous manufacturers is finally forcing the President to modify his long-held view that the dollar should ride with the tides of the open market.
''One could make the argument until the middle of last year that the rise of the dollar was beneficial in forcing companies to operate more efficiently,'' said Robert D. Hormats, an economist at Goldman Sachs and formerly a top State Department economist in the Nixon, Ford, Carter and Reagan Administrations. ''But industries are now getting hurt by imports through no fault of their own, like Caterpillar Tractor and DuPont. The question is, what pace of this adjustment is acceptable. That's where we are today.''
The new Reagan strategy is likely to include a major intervention, in cooperation with its partners, to derail any sharp, future ascent of the dollar. It appears also to incorporate a new willingness to slow the American economy, should it show signs of growing faster than the 4 percent annual rate that the Administration has set as its goal for the years ahead. Faster growth would intensify credit demand, pushing up interest rates and, presumably, demand for dollars to invest in United States securities at the higher rates.
And finally, the new Reagan approach officially acknowledges, for the first time, a link between Federal budget deficits and the might of the dollar. To get one down, the other must come down, James A. Baker 3d, the new Treasury Secretary, said a few days ago.
Nothing, of course, says that such an ambitious policy will work. Previous efforts among the industrialized nations to synchronize their economies have failed. Over the next year or two, inflation could reappear in Europe as the new economic growth there reduces the 10-percent unemployment level and factories begin to push the limits of their capacity. The United States could dip into a recession next year, as many economists expect. Inflation in Europe and flagging growth in the United States would force unwanted shifts in currency values that the countries would be hard put to prevent.
Still, the message coming from the Reagan Administration and its Western allies last week was that they seek only a modest decline in the dollar's value - certainly nothing more than 5 or 10 percent over the next year, a drop that would barely erase the dollar's 9 percent rise since December alone. The reluctance to allow a precipitous fall stems from the realization that the accelerating recovery in Europe and in the developing world has come to depend on the profits earned from exports to the United States.
''It would be a mistake to believe that the rest of the world can afford a dollar that comes down too much,'' said Rudiger Dornbusch, an economist at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. ''Europe would lose jobs if the dollar were to collapse.'' Adds James T. McGroarty, vice president for foreign exchange at the Discount Corporation of New York: ''Everyone fears a major intervention package. I don't see the ingredients there. I don't think the political will is there.''
THE new Reagan dollar strategy
falls into line with the views of
Mr. Volcker, who said twice in Congressional testimony last week that intervention can be useful as one of several tools to bring down the dollar.
From mid-January through the third week of February, the major Western nations intervened several times, but in small amounts, totaling about $4.5 billion, without noticeable affect, a Treasury official said. ''It was eaten up,'' he said. ''Baker thinks it's absurd. He saw it didn't do anything.'' Last week's intervention, however, was different.
Mr. Volcker and Reagan officials hold that the real way to bring foreign currencies into a better alignment with the dollar is by improving the balance of the economies behind the currencies.
That's also the view in Europe. Until a few months ago, the governments of Europe assailed and even ridiculed the contentions of the Reagan Administration that its economic policies - even with their associated budget deficits - were beneficial for the world. Reagan officials argued that their policies brought on the American recovery and thereby created markets for foreign manufacturers.
The Europeans, however, had argued that the explosion of Government borrowing that the deficits required pushed up interest rates and those high rates in turn lured capital from Europe, stifling investment there and driving up the dollar. They wanted the deficit cut and the dollar driven down. They did not want to raise their own interest rates and thus risk slower growth.
But now European officials are talking of the extent to which their export industries have benefited from the mighty dollar. With their production costs declining in dollar terms, European companies were able to undersell their American competitors, both in world markets and the United States. Their soaring profits have washed through the economies of Europe, pulling all from the prolonged recession of the early 1980's. In short, their recovery is export- driven, with the help of a strong dollar.
The countries' stock markets have been rising, signalling resurgent investment, and their interest rates now are close to the levels of the United States. That has made European governments less critical of Reagan Administration economic policies. Their attitudes vary now, but in general their intervention shows that they want the dollar down - but not by too much.
MEANWHILE, a Reagan Administration that stood back and cheered the rise of the dollar as validation of its economic policies is having second thoughts of its own, mostly because the strong dollar is rousing such political unrest in the United States.
Farmers are mounting marches on Washington, appealing for Federal aid and vigorous action to bring down the dollar. It has been so strong that a grain company decided recently that it could ship Argentine wheat half- way around the world and sell it at a profit to a Louisiana flour mill, for less than wheat purchased in Kansas. The angry outcry of farmer organizations stopped that deal.
The aging behemoths of steel, shoes and textiles, at the same time, stepped up their demands for protection against the rush of foreign imports, and they are no longer alone. For otherwise healthy, growing industries, even the thriving computer industry, the rising value of the dollar has been overwhelming.
Robert W. Galvin, chairman of Motorola, one of the giants of American technology, has called for a temporary, 20-percent tax on imports of foreign goods. ''Kellogg will still make cereal in Battle Creek,'' he says. ''But we see a grave injury to American manufacturing taking place under our nose.''
Under this sort of pressure, the first sign of the shift in the Administration's attitude turns out to have been the meeting here last Jan. 17 of the top economic officials of the five leading industrial countries - the United States, Japan, Germany, Britain and France. It was to have been a routine meeting without public coverage. But the ministers released a communique, restating their commitment to joint intervention in the currency markets when they became ''disorderly,'' and Donald T. Regan, then the Treasury Secretary, added that the disorderly criterion had been broadened to cover intervention when it would be ''helpful.''
It wasn't clear then what helpful meant. It seemed to reflect a desire to placate Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher, who had written to President Reagan just days before the meeting. ''She said 'give me a hand with the pound,' '' a Treasury official recalled, ''and you don't want to be unkind to your best friend.'' With the small interventions that followed the meeting, however, it became evident that help for Mrs. Thatcher would also help the United States.
Acontinually rising dollar could
pose even greater risks to the
Administration's fervent commitment to open markets, both for currency and trade. The President's first-term agreements to set up protectionist trade barriers for such industries as steel, textiles and motorcycles were compromises enough, Administration officials say.
To stem the dollar-driven domestic demand for protectionism, then, the Administration is redoubling its efforts to force the rest of the world, and Japan and Europe in particular, to drop their barriers to imports of American goods.
Just last week, the Secretary of Commerce, Malcolm Baldrige, demonstrated the point at an unusual news conference. He announced that to persuade the Japanese to talk ''nitty-gritty'' about opening their markets to American goods, he had canceled the Tokyo visit of a senior trade negotiator because the Japanese, Mr. Baldrige said, only wanted to discuss ''generalities.''
At the same time, he said, he urged repeal of Section 7 of the Clayton Antitrust Act to allow American companies to merge and to cut costs so that they could compete more effectively against foreign competitors - a drastic step that found a chilly reception in Congress.
For all the political concern over the impact of the dollar, economists disagree over the damage it has wrought to the American economy by opening the nation to such an influx of foreign goods and cutting so deeply into exports.
Certainly farming has been hurt. ''Harvested acreage is coming down from its peak of the early 80's,'' said Robbin Johnson, a vice president of Cargill Inc. of Minneapolis, the company that pondered shipping the Argentine wheat to the United States. ''We are slowly but surely shrinking the acreage devoted to wheat.'' Big grain companies like Cargill, too, are losing ground because their vast investment in storage and shipping facilities in the United States are operating far below capacity.
MANY of the jobs in the automobile, steel and leather goods industries that were lost in the last recession are gone for good, partly because of the dollar. But companies in healthier industries have relinquished American jobs as well, moving operations abroad because of the pressure of the dollar, and buying materials and parts abroad that they previously bought from American manufacturers.
Anthony M. Solomon, who recently retired as president of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, suspects that the jobs that have been lost to the dollar will be a long time coming home. ''My guess would be that if the dollar were to decline,'' he said, ''it would be somewhat easier for us to regain a significant part of those export markets that have recently been lost, especially in the agricultural commodities, than it will be to erase the increase in the import share of manufactured goods.''
Employment in manufacturing has fallen 6 percent since 1979, according to Mr. Dornbusch, the M.I.T. economist. ''When the dollar comes down, those firms aren't going to be there,'' he said.
The country's huge machine tools business is one of the biggest victims of the strong dollar. Imports accounted for 8 percent of all domestic business spending for machine tools in 1970. Ten years later their share of the market had doubled. By 1983, it was 20 percent, and last year, with the dollar taking an ever-bigger toll, it was 26 percent.
Economists, however, also look at American business in another context. In the aggregate, more new businesses have been formed since the recession ended than in any simliar period, business investment in new domestic factories and cost-reduction equipment has been uncommonly strong, and employment has climbed all through the economy's recovery and subsequent expansion. Many are service jobs that on average pay less than manufacturing jobs, but still, there are more jobs.
''Some people say the trade deficit costs 3 million jobs - that's preposterous,'' said Robert Z. Lawrence, economist at the Brookings Institution. ''The same process that has given us the trade deficit has given us economic growth. Many of the jobs that are lost are really hypothetical. Not adding hypothetical jobs is quite a difference from actually losing jobs.''
ECONOMISTS are also uncertain
how the dollar might behave
once it starts to decline in value. In the conventional view, born of historical precedent, a lower dollar could mean somewhat higher inflation in the United States, but it could also mean a reduction in the trade deficit and, over- all, a healthier, more balanced economy.
Little in the behavior of the dollar of the 1980's, however, has much precedent in history. In rising more than 70 percent since the middle of 1980, the dollar has climbed far beyond the boundaries of normal currency behavior, defying one nugget of conventional wisdom after another.
Currencies are supposed to fall when the trade of the economies behind them fall into deficit, but the United States has recorded two consecutive years of record trade deficits, and still the dollar rose. Currencies are supposed to fall when the economies behind them are more inflationary than others, but inflation in the United States, although low, exceeds that of Japan, and yet the dollar kept rising against the yen.
Most orthodox economists, including Mr. Volcker, say repeatedly that a sharp fall of the dollar means rising domestic inflation. But David C. Lund, a Commerce Department economist, has produced a study arguing that there would be far less inflation than most economists have promised. Commodity prices could quickly rebound, he said, but the prices of European and manufactured goods might not change.
Those prices never went down. They merely stabilized, and as the dollar rose, the foreign manufacturers reaped fatter profits. Once the dollar declines and American prices become more competitive, there's room in the foreigners' profits to hold prices down. ''It's Newton's other law,'' Mr. Lund said. ''What didn't go down won't go back up.''
It could even turn out that all the efforts of Europe, Japan, the Reagan Administration and Mr. Volcker to move the dollar will be for naught. A sounder worldwide economy would mean lower budget deficits, and lower budget deficits could prove just the recipe for another ascent of the dollar.
''The United States would be in such a strong position without that last black cloud hanging over it,'' said Edward L. Hudgins, economist at the conservative Heritage Foundation. ''If the deficit went down, all other things being equal, the exchange rate of the dollar would go up.''
STRUGGLINGTO LIVE WITH A MUSCULAR DOLLAR
The strong dollar has changed the way American companies do business:
* The Huffy Corporation in Miamisburg, Ohio, is the country's largest maker of bicycles, and it has a peculiar problem with the dollar. The currency of its chief competitor, Taiwan, is tied to the dollar, so both rise and fall together. Thus Taiwan faces the same difficulty in selling to foreign markets that American companies do, and it concentrates its efforts on the United States. ''Four or five years ago, we built a plant in Ponca City, Okla.,'' said the chairman of Huffy, Stuart J. Northrop. ''We've had to close that facility, and it's up for sale.''
* Cincinnati Milacron Inc. is one of the world's leading producers of machine tools. To keep its domestic costs down, a spokesman said, ''we're increasing our worldwide sourcing'' - buying the materials and components the company needs from abroad, rather than from American manufacturers. In addition, it has hired subcontractors in Japan to make its robots for the Far Eastern market. ''That market is virtually closed to us because of the yen-dollar gap,'' the spokesman said. The company has also licensed a major Japanese company, Fanuc, to make its injecting-molding machine, used to make plastics.
* The Measurex Corporation in Cupertino, Calif., makes computerized manufacturing systems, mostly for the paper industry. Ten years ago, well before the rise of the dollar, Measurex opened a factory in Waterford, Ireland, where it assembles its systems for sale to the European market. But in January, because of the dollar, the company switched to ''local currency pricing'' - quoting its prices in foreign currencies rather than dollars, to remain competitive, even though that means lower earnings in terms of dollars. ''We can't demand a fixed dollar price any more,'' said Robert McAdams Jr., senior vice president for finance. ''The competition won't allow us to do that.''
* The Brunswick Corporation in Skokie, Ill., is a diversified manufacturer whose products include the Mercury and Mariner brands of outboard motors. ''Over the past four years, our motor sales have declined, mostly because of the dollar,'' said Max E. McGrath, vice president for finance. Japanese competitors - Honda, Suzuki, Yamaha - have captured much of Brunswick's market. ''We're dealing with it,'' he said, ''primarily with an extensive cost-reduction program, so when we deliver our engines our goal is to meet their price.'' Brunswick is also importing more engines from Japan under its own label.
* The U.S. Shoe Corporation in Cincinnati is the country's No. 2 supplier of shoes, the producer of such brands as Red Cross Papagallo, Capezio and Liz Claiborne. Its competition with imports predates the rise of the dollar. It has been manufacturing overseas for more than 20 years, and imports account for 65 to 70 percent of the women's shoes it sells in the United States. With the rise of the dollar, a spokesman said, its import business has been thriving, and its domestic manufacturing waning. It has laid off workers in Ohio, Indiana and Kentucky.
* The Briggs & Stratton Corporation in St. Paul is one of the nation's best-known makers of gasoline and diesel engines. ''We get pretty emotional about the dollar,'' said L. William Dewey, executive vice president. ''We used to have 26 percent of our sales outside the United States. Right now, it's less than half that. We attribute it almost totally to the dollar.'' Briggs & Stratton's strategy for dealing with Japanese competitors in America is ''zero pricing,'' which means the company does not raise prices. Overseas, the company, like Measurex, has switched to ''local currency pricing.'' In the 1960's, Mr. Dewey said, the company considered opening a manufacturing plant abroad and decided not to. ''It's a strategy we have to seriously consider again,'' he said.
