DEBTS OF THE FEW PROMPT GLOBAL FEARS

Author: Silk, Leonard

Publication info: New York Times , Late Edition (East Coast); New York, N.Y. [New York, N.Y]02 Oct 1983: A.2.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/424799335?accountid=11752

Abstract: ''Our monetary system is in a rather frightening state,'' H. Johannes Witteveen, the former managing director of the International Monetary Fund, said at the start of last week's annual meetings of the I.M.F. and the World Bank. Most of the world's money men assembled in Washington share his anxiety. President Reagan's speech to the conference, acknowledging as it did the possibility of ''an economic nightmare that could plague generations to come,'' was not just a more realistic appraisal than the White House has hitherto expressed. Because the United States is crucial to any solution, Mr. Reagan's reaffirmation of his commitment to both the Fund and the Bank was the week's most important positive development. The crisis itself produced the change in rhetoric. The question is whether that presages a change in policy. Mr. Reagan sought to dispel doubts that Congress would back him on a no- strings $8.4 billion share in a $42 billion international package to increase the Fund's lending capacity by declaring his ''unbreakable commitment.'' But Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan gave a flat ''no'' to more extended United States emergency support. When asked why, he curtly said, ''No money.'' When the Fund's managing director, Jacques de Larosi ere was asked to comment, he said drily, ''Well, everybody has his difficulties.'' The United States also wants to cut World Bank loans to poor countries.

Links: http://findit.library.jhu.edu/resolve?url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Anytimes&amp;atitle=DEBTS+OF+THE+FEW+PROMPT+GLOBAL+FEARS&amp;title=New+York+Times&amp;issn=03624331&amp;date=1983-10-02&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=A.2&amp;au=Silk%2C+Leonard&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=New+York+Times&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text: ''Our monetary system is in a rather frightening state,'' H. Johannes Witteveen, the former managing director of the International Monetary Fund, said at the start of last week's annual meetings of the I.M.F. and the World Bank. Most of the world's money men assembled in Washington share his anxiety.
In ordinary times, the fact that outstanding loans to just five Latin American countries exceeds 150 percent of the capital of the nine largest American banks would be nothing to worry about. Loans to those five debtors account for just 10 percent of the banks' total assets. But these are not ordinary times. Because of depressed exports and high interest rates, the five and scores of other countries in the third world and in the Communist bloc are having trouble just servicing their debt. If more money is not made available to bail them out, the international monetary system could collapse.
President Reagan's speech to the conference, acknowledging as it did the possibility of ''an economic nightmare that could plague generations to come,'' was not just a more realistic appraisal than the White House has hitherto expressed. Because the United States is crucial to any solution, Mr. Reagan's reaffirmation of his commitment to both the Fund and the Bank was the week's most important positive development.
The crisis itself produced the change in rhetoric. The question is whether that presages a change in policy. Mr. Reagan sought to dispel doubts that Congress would back him on a no- strings $8.4 billion share in a $42 billion international package to increase the Fund's lending capacity by declaring his ''unbreakable commitment.'' But Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan gave a flat ''no'' to more extended United States emergency support. When asked why, he curtly said, ''No money.'' When the Fund's managing director, Jacques de Larosi ere was asked to comment, he said drily, ''Well, everybody has his difficulties.'' The United States also wants to cut World Bank loans to poor countries.
Ideological Keys
The Administration's efforts to cut back are based not only on reluctance to go to Congress for more money but also on its conservative ideology. Too great a bailout, it believes, will exacerbate the world's monetary problems by making it easier for debtor countries to avoid making necessary adjustments, such as closing their budget gaps and ending the balance-of-payments deficits that have caused heavy borrowing.
The Americans drew criticism last week from British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher, who said they should practice what they preach. Representatives of other countries, including the conservative West Germans and the Socialist French, also accused the United States of purusing ''Keynesian'' big-deficit fiscal policies to stimulate economic advance while practicing a restrictive monetary policy to curb inflation, thus producing high interest rates that impede investment and a stronger world recovery.
President Reagan and Mr. Regan countered that tax increases to narrow the United States deficit would arrest the American expansion which is helping to pull the world out of the slump. Mr. Reagan also made a case for greater security, and hence his military budget increases, as the foundation of economic prosperity. Despite such disagreements, there is a real consensus among the United States, West Germany, Japan and other creditor countries on the need for borrowing countries to put their economic and financial houses in order. Mr. de Larosi ere stressed that loans would be wasted unless the borrowers ended the loose fiscal and monetary policies that produced inflation and sucked in imports from abroad. A.W. Clausen, the head of the World Bank, regretted so much emphasis in the press on ''conditionality,'' as though it were something that the rich imposed on the poor. The poor accepted it, he said, because it was in their best interests. Nations can always create more money, in effect, by printing it. The I.M.F. could print up a batch of Special Drawing Rights - international paper currency - after member countries vote to do so. But there is intense debate on how much more money to create.
Opponents contend that more money, whether in national or international form, would be inflationary because there is still a hangover of excess credit expansion from the past and because it would relieve debtor countries of making those necessary adjustments. Proponents, especially among developing countries, feel they need more resources to give them time to adjust. Some, including economists from developed countries, argue that the persistence of high unemployment and excess capacity minimize the inflation risk. In this argument, the advantage is with the givers. But with the conservative Reagan Administration backed by the conservative British, German and Japanese Governments, the nongivers are likely to prevail.
The immediate crisis centers on Brazil, which cannot service its $90 billion in postponed debts unless it gets a quick infusion of cash. The heaviest work last week was in putting together a rescue package of $11 billion for Brazil - though it is still far from clear that the bankers on a steering committee can get their own nervous boards of directors and those of hundreds of other banks not represented at last week's meeting to deliver.
More fundamentally, the short-run crises dominating official attention mean little thought has been given to how to reform the monetary system to establish more control over it. Mr. Witteveen crushingly said in his Per Jacobbson Lecture in Washington last week: ''The monetary authorities seem powerless to counter or manage the massive capital flows which have come to dominate foreign exchange markets.'' That is the fundamental reason for the lack of confidence in the system.

EUROPEANS DEBATE WAYS TO SPUR THEIR LAGGING ECONOMIC UPTURN

Author: PAUL LEWIS, Special to the New York Times

Publication info: New York Times , Late Edition (East Coast); New York, N.Y. [New York, N.Y]17 Sep 1983: 1.1.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/424773140?accountid=11752

Abstract: The contrast between Europe's disappointing prospects and the more encouraging outlook in the United States is adding fuel to the fierce controversy between ''Keynesian'' economists and those of the ''monetarist'' or neo-classical school. Continuing Economic Arguments ''We're facing a crisis in economics as well as an economic crisis - there's absolutely no consensus over what to do,'' said Sylvia Ostry, who watched Europe's economic fortunes closely for four years as chief economist at the Paris-based O.E.C.D. before resigning last summer to return to her native Canada. ''The key question is whether economies are self- levitating or not,'' she said. Continuing high interest rates are the most obvious brake on new investment, as European governments find themselves forced to match the high United States rates to keep their currencies from taking an inflationary plunge against the dollar. In Britain and Germany, long-term bonds currently yield more than the average return on industrial investment. ''Investment isn't profitable,'' warns Klaus Wiener, chief economist at the Westdeutsche Landesbank in D"usseldorf.

Links: http://findit.library.jhu.edu/resolve?url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Anytimes&amp;atitle=EUROPEANS+DEBATE+WAYS+TO+SPUR+THEIR+LAGGING+ECONOMIC+UPTURN&amp;title=New+York+Times&amp;issn=03624331&amp;date=1983-09-17&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=1.1&amp;au=PAUL+LEWIS%2C+Special+to+the+New+York+Times&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=New+York+Times&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text: Helped by declining inflation and the strength of the American recovery, the economies of Western Europe are finally starting to pick up after the deepest recession since the 1930's, but only slightly.
Indeed, the European upturn, retarded by high interest rates and lagging demand for exports everywhere except in the United States, is feeble and patchy so far. And economists and policy makers are sharply divided over whether even this weak upswing will last and what, if anything, can be done to strengthen it.
In the 1972-73 recovery, Western European economies were growing by almost 6 percent when the first oil price shock punctured the boom. And during the next upswing, in 1976, Europe registered 4.6 percent annual growth.
But today, as Western Europe starts to climb up out of the trough caused by the second oil price shock, the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development expects growth of a mere five- tenths of 1 percent this year, with 1.5 percent next year, and a continuing increase in unemployment.
The contrast between Europe's disappointing prospects and the more encouraging outlook in the United States is adding fuel to the fierce controversy between ''Keynesian'' economists and those of the ''monetarist'' or neo-classical school. Continuing Economic Arguments
For the Keynesians, who believe governments can and should intervene to speed recovery, the time is ripe for countries with low inflation, such as West Germany and Britain, to adopt more stimulative policies, increasing public spending or cutting taxes to increase growth. In their view, the strength of the American recovery stems mainly from the Reagan Administration's highly stimulative fiscal policy, based on one of the biggest budget deficits in American history.
But economic policy in Europe's low- inflation countries is dominated by monetarists, who fear that more stimulative policies would revive inflation. They believe that Western economies will take off on their own again if governments keep inflation low and allow market forces to operate freely.
In any event, the monetarists observe, European governments have been running high budget deficits for a number of years without producing a convincing recovery. Only in Britain will the deficit be smaller in proportion to economic output this year than in 1979.
''We're facing a crisis in economics as well as an economic crisis - there's absolutely no consensus over what to do,'' said Sylvia Ostry, who watched Europe's economic fortunes closely for four years as chief economist at the Paris-based O.E.C.D. before resigning last summer to return to her native Canada. ''The key question is whether economies are self- levitating or not,'' she said.
A snapshot of Europe's leading economies around midyear discloses flashes of strength against a generally somber background:
WEST GERMANY: Europe's economic workhorse is gloomy, with growth of 1 percent forecast for this year and perhaps 2.5 percent next, coupled with a further rise in unemployment, which is already up two points over last year at 9.4 percent. Yet industrial output has climbed 13.7 percent at annual rates over the last three months and retail sales are up a healthy 8.1 percent. Inflation remains low, averaging 2.5 percent over the last year. But it has edged up to a 4.4 percent annual rate over the last three months, spurred by an acceleration in wage settlements.
BRITAIN: Inflation should also be in the 4 percent range this year. The economy is expected to grow about 2 percent, but then shrink back to a 1.7 percent rate in 1984, according to the latest forecast by the National Institute for Economic and Social Research. Industrial production is growing more slowly than in West Germany, up only four-tenths of 1 percent in the last three months, and the trade balance has slipped into the red again, despite the benefits of North Sea oil. Also, unemployment - at 12.8 percent the highest among the major European economies - is still rising, though at a slower pace.
FRANCE AND ITALY: Both have been left out of Europe's mini-recovery and expect stagnant or contracting economies this year with only a marginal improvement next year. They are trying to curtail high rates of inflation - 9 percent and 17 percent, respectively - that are badly out of line with their neighbors.' They also want to reduce huge payment deficits. Unemployment - at 8.3 percent and 11.6 percent, respectively - is expected to edge higher in both countries.
THE NETHERLANDS: Despite having Europe's lowest inflation rate, under 3 percent a year, the Dutch are wrestling with the highest unemployment rate in the European Economic Community - 17.3 percent by the latest figures. The expectation is for stagnant growth this year and next as the country seeks to extricate itself from a fiscal crisis attributed to runaway welfare spending.
BELGIUM: Caught in a similar crisis of high unemployment, which is running at 14.8 percent, and out-of- control Government spending, it is trying to reduce a huge budget deficit through a tight austerity program. Curiously, however, industrial production has surged to an annual rate of almost 13 percent over the last three months.
In the smaller Common Market economies, Ireland and Greece both face stagnant growth and rising unemployment, attributable to continuing high inflation and their neighbors' disappointing performance. In Ireland, unemployment is expected to rise to nearly 16 percent next year, while in Greece, which has little industry and poor statistics, it is expected to climb to 7 percent. Only in tiny Luxembourg is unemployment remaining around the 2 percent level, once the norm for all the Western industrial nations. Outlook Remains Pessimistic
In Western Europe, despite the signs of a mild upturn, the prevailing view among economists, government officials and business leaders remains profoundly pessimistic.
The O.E.C.D., a group that promotes the economic growth of its 24 member nations and the development of emerging countries, warned not long ago that the robust recovery in the United States would not be shared by Western Europe. It predicts that unemployment in Europe will rise from more than 10 percent of the work force to almost 12 percent next year. The Common Market's Executive Commission says unemployment could climb to almost 14 percent by 1988, even if overall growth accelerates to 2.3 percent a year on average.
Europe's recovery is being held back by a combination of factors. In addition to high interest rates and weak demand for exports in most areas, economists agree, the widespread belief that consumer spending will soon falter weakens business confidence, and the rigidity of the European economies makes them less able to adapt to change.
Where recovery signs are strongest, they mainly reflect a consumer spending spree as individuals find that their wages will buy more with inflation falling, and feel less need to save. This, combined with some industrial restocking after the recession and the surging American demand for imports brought on by the strong dollar, is what is pushing European economies modestly upward. A Lack of Investment
What is lacking is the investment boom that monetarist economists believe will materialize on its own once business is confident inflation is under control. After the 1973 recession, investment in Europe turned sharply upward, but not this time. The latest European Economic Commission survey shows industrial investment stagnating in Germany this year and falling in Britain and France, although in Italy it is expected to rise.
Continuing high interest rates are the most obvious brake on new investment, as European governments find themselves forced to match the high United States rates to keep their currencies from taking an inflationary plunge against the dollar. In Britain and Germany, long-term bonds currently yield more than the average return on industrial investment. ''Investment isn't profitable,'' warns Klaus Wiener, chief economist at the Westdeutsche Landesbank in D"usseldorf.
Under Dr. Ostry's leadership, the traditionally Keynesian O.E.C.D. has spent the last couple of years quietly urging Germany, Britain and other low-inflation countries to strengthen Europe's recovery by switching over to more stimulative policies. The effort got nowhere, however, except perhaps intellectually.
Among the converts is Prof. Wynn Godley of Cambridge University, leader of the so-called New Cambridge School. He no longer believes Britain can restore full employment by adopting a stimulative policy behind protectionist barriers. He now advocates an international meeting - similar to the call by President Francois Mitterrand of France for a new Bretton Woods conference - to plan a coordinated economic stimulus combined with new measures to stabilize exchange rates. In 1944, an international monetary conference attended by 44 nations was held at Bretton Woods, N.H., at which the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank were created. Ossified Systems Blamed
For the neoclassicists, growth is sluggish and unemployment obstinately high because European economies have become ossified through elaborate social security systems, high taxes and complex regulations.
In a report to the European Parliament, Prof. James Ball of the London Business School and Michel Albert, former head of the French Economic Planning Commission, gave strong support to this view.
The European and American economies both grew by about 2.2 percent a year between 1974 and 1980, they observed. But while European wages increased 2.3 percent a year, adjusted for inflation, and employment stagnated, they said, in the United States real wages were stagnant and employment rose 2 percent a year. ''Europe gave priority to individual income over employment,'' the report says.
The neo-classicists hope this process will go into reverse, as low inflation and high unemployment encourage workers to price themselves back into jobs by accepting less generous wages and governments act to make employing labor more profitable.

Economic Scene; Deficits' Effect On Growth

Author: Silk, Leonard

Publication info: New York Times , Late Edition (East Coast); New York, N.Y. [New York, N.Y]20 July 1983: D.2.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/424670709?accountid=11752

Abstract: MARTIN FELDSTEIN, the chairman of President Reagan's Council of Economic Advisers, has told the nation's county governments, meeting in Milwaukee this week, that they should expect not more but less Federal help because it is essential to shrink the share of gross national product going to domestic spending ''if we are to avoid perpetual deficits or unacceptable tax increases.'' That proposal included a complex ''contingency tax plan'' that Congress has shown no inclination to accept and the President appears just as willing to avoid. Without those contingency tax rises, the President's budget plan, if fully enacted by Congress, would yield deficits averaging some $200 billion a year from 1984 through 1988. Not only domestic but international debt as well can be a drag on United States output and employment. To prevent defaults by foreign debtors, the United States has been running a huge deficit in its foreign trade account. Prof. Hyman Minsky of Washington University in St. Louis notes that a little understood ''basic fact of life in the 1980's'' makes it hard for the United States to achieve full employment as the trade deficit hurts profits and employment.

Links: http://findit.library.jhu.edu/resolve?url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Anytimes&amp;atitle=Economic+Scene%3B+Deficits%27+Effect+On+Growth&amp;title=New+York+Times&amp;issn=03624331&amp;date=1983-07-20&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=D.2&amp;au=Silk%2C+Leonard&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=New+York+Times&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text: MARTIN FELDSTEIN, the chairman of President Reagan's Council of Economic Advisers, has told the nation's county governments, meeting in Milwaukee this week, that they should expect not more but less Federal help because it is essential to shrink the share of gross national product going to domestic spending ''if we are to avoid perpetual deficits or unacceptable tax increases.''
Meanwhile, President Reagan went to Hollywood, Fla., to tell the International Longshoremen's Association that, while he was waiting for his new bipartisan commission, headed by former Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger, to forge a long-term United States policy for Central America he would not yield on his requests for military and economic aid for the area, including $362 million this year for El Salvador alone.
And despite reports of waste at the Pentagon, which Defense Secretary Caspar Weinberger has vowed to halt by making heads roll, Mr. Reagan plans to raise military outlays by $30 billion, to $245 billion in the 1984 fiscal year, and onward and upward to more than $400 billion by 1988.
Even if the economy keeps rising at a 4 percent clip or more year after year, the budget deficits threaten to keep rising. On a current-services basis, the Administration projects that the deficits would rise from $225 billion in the 1983 fiscal year to $284 billion in 1986 and on up to $315 billion in 1988. The Reagan plan incorporated in the 1984 budget proposal calls for chopping those deficits down to $203 billion next year and on down to $126 billion by 1988.
But that proposal included a complex ''contingency tax plan'' that Congress has shown no inclination to accept and the President appears just as willing to avoid. Without those contingency tax rises, the President's budget plan, if fully enacted by Congress, would yield deficits averaging some $200 billion a year from 1984 through 1988.
How will the soaring public debt affect the nation's economic growth? Prof. Benjamin Friedman of Harvard, in a study of the obstacles to growth, notes that, historically, a rising ratio of public debt has meant a falling ratio of private capital formation. During periods of slump, a rising Federal debt acts as a cushion for the national economy and even a spur for recovery. But as the recovery continues and the economy approaches full employment, the clash between public and private demands for capital intensifies, increasing pressure on interest rates.
The United States economy is now heading into that crucial period of transition. If the recovery continues and the Federal Reserve pursues a noninflationary monetary policy, the rising proportion of public debt to gross national product will at some point mean a falling proportion of private debt and capital formation. Climbing interest rates will do the rationing, driving down private investment. If the Fed were to seek to avoid that clash between public and private borrowing by increasing the money supply enough to accommodate both, it would regenerate inflation - but without solving the problem. For as experience in the 1970's made clear, inflation drags down capital formation, impairs productivity and weakens the United States in world markets.
Not only domestic but international debt as well can be a drag on United States output and employment. To prevent defaults by foreign debtors, the United States has been running a huge deficit in its foreign trade account. Prof. Hyman Minsky of Washington University in St. Louis notes that a little understood ''basic fact of life in the 1980's'' makes it hard for the United States to achieve full employment as the trade deficit hurts profits and employment.
One step for breaking the obstacles to steady growth would be for the United States to cut and stabilize the budget deficits it would incur even at high employment - defining high employment today as equivalent to 6 percent unemployment.
But that will not be easy. Professor Friedman estimates that stabilizing the Federal debt-to-G.N.P. ratio at 34 percent, where it will be at the end of the current fiscal year, would mean reducing the deficit to an average of $122 billion a year from 1984 through 1988 - about $80 billion a year less than the deficits now in prospect. A more ambitious effort to stabilize the national debt at 30 percent of G.N.P., where it was at the end of the 1982 fiscal year, would require cutting the deficit to an average of $74 billion a year for the next four years - $130 billion below the Reagan plan without the contingency tax increases.
But the Administration appears to have put aside any effort to shrink the high-employment deficits until after the 1984 election. It hopes to get by without much rise in interest rates or inflation, thanks to the hangover of unemployed resources. But the operating rate at the nation's factories, utilities and mines rose in June to 74.5 percent, the highest rate in 16 months.
The financial markets are already worrying about the coming clash between the Government and private borrowers, and the growtharresting effects that would produce through rising interest rates. The Administration's political anxiety must be that market expectations will force interest rates up enough to hurt the recovery before 1984 is over. But its attack on the deficit problem remains limited and highly selective, pointed at efforts to keep the Federal Reserve from tightening monetary policy too soon and to curb social spending.

EXCERPTS FROM PRESIDENT'S INTERVIEW ON MEETING

Author: Special to the New York Times

Publication info: New York Times , Late Edition (East Coast); New York, N.Y. [New York, N.Y]27 May 1983: D.14.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/424626401?accountid=11752

Abstract: Q. Since this is, after all, an economic summit, let's start with the economy. There's good news there; the economy is picking up. But if the leaders whom you'll be dealing with have one thing in common, it's that they're worried about the size of the budget deficits that your Administration is running up. They're afraid that it will abort the recovery. What is your reaction, sir, to this, especially since you're an old foe of deficit financing? A. Well, first of all, there seems to be a misperception that we're interested in some kind of a trade war with the Soviet Union, and we're not at all. The very fact that we have told the Soviets that we're willing to sit down and negotiate a long-term grain agreement is evidence of that. We're also - we don't believe that while they're devoting so much of their resource to this military buildup that we should engage in trade in which we, in a sense, subsidize our exports to the Soviet Union, or give them favored treatment with regard to low interest rates on long-time credit. Scope of Recovery

Links: http://findit.library.jhu.edu/resolve?url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Anytimes&amp;atitle=EXCERPTS+FROM+PRESIDENT%27S+INTERVIEW+ON+MEETING%3A+%5BTEXT%5D&amp;title=New+York+Times&amp;issn=03624331&amp;date=1983-05-27&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=D.14&amp;au=Special+to+the+New+York+Times&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=New+York+Times&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text: President Reagan was interviewed today by correspondents from Canada, West Germany, France, Britain, Japan and Italy. Following are excerpts from the White House transcript. Concern Over Deficits
Q. Since this is, after all, an economic summit, let's start with the economy. There's good news there; the economy is picking up. But if the leaders whom you'll be dealing with have one thing in common, it's that they're worried about the size of the budget deficits that your Administration is running up. They're afraid that it will abort the recovery. What is your reaction, sir, to this, especially since you're an old foe of deficit financing?
A. Yes, I am, and I think about half of our deficit is due to the recession, which, as we know, is worldwide. And the other half I think is structural.
But the main way that we can handle the deficit, I think, is the program that we have under way right now. And that is to restore the economy. There's a limit to how much you can achieve in reducing spending. There's a limit to how much you could achieve if you try to do it with taxes, in addition to which you are threatening then the recovery, by removing the incentives that I think have brought about the start of the recovery.
The answer does lie in economic growth. If we, for example, could for the next few years - if we were one percentage point higher than our estimate in the growth of the economy, it would reduce the deficit by a hundred billion dollars a few years from now.
So we're proceeding, and we think that our program is right. Because we started with interest rates that were more than twice as high as they are now. We started with an inflation rate that was more than three times as great as we've brought it down to. And of course, it is the inflation which contributes to the high interest rate.
And we have a plan that I submitted to the Congress with regard to our budget and contingency taxes for the out-years, once we have established the recovery as definite, that we would be willing to assume, which would lead to a declining pattern of deficits in the out-years and down the line, a balanced budget.
Q. But to follow up, sir, right now the way the deficits are structured, they may soak up as much as 70 percent of all the net savings in the United States. In other words, $7 out of $10, instead of going into the investments that you're talking about, to create jobs, are going to go to service that deficit.
A. On the other hand, maybe not that much, because we have, with our - the tax programs that we've put into effect - we have seen an increase in the percentage of personal savings of billions of dollars that over these same next few years, I think are being underestimated as to what they will contribute to the pool of capital. East-West Relations
Q. Your Government is taking a much stricter anti-Soviet line compared to other allies. And recent news reports said you are not going to meet Mr. Andropov this year. My question is, how do you plan to present this problem to the leaders at the summit.
A. Well, first of all, there seems to be a misperception that we're interested in some kind of a trade war with the Soviet Union, and we're not at all. The very fact that we have told the Soviets that we're willing to sit down and negotiate a long-term grain agreement is evidence of that.
But what we are concerned about is the Soviet expansionism, and particularly when it comes into the Western Hemisphere. There have been several Soviet vessels recently unloading weaponry in Nicaragua and for the use in the effort to overthrow the Government of Salvador. We don't look upon those as friendly acts.
But the East-West trade, I think we and our allies are in very much agreement on that. There have been constant consultations in which we have come to agreements. On the trade that we don't want to extend to the Soviet Union is high technology that can contribute to their further military buildup. And, as I say, we're in great agreement on things of that kind.
We're also - we don't believe that while they're devoting so much of their resource to this military buildup that we should engage in trade in which we, in a sense, subsidize our exports to the Soviet Union, or give them favored treatment with regard to low interest rates on long-time credit. Scope of Recovery
Q. Mr. President, the scenario for recovery is not uniform at all. The American engine is going strong; the Italian economy is not moving yet. Do you expect the recovery will benefit all our nations?
A. Yes, I think it will. I do believe that - I don't believe, I have been told by leaders of our allied states - that recovery must begin in the United States. Evidently we are that much of a factor in world commerce, and they are pleased to see it beginning here and believe that it is aiding their own recovery. For example, the United States will be importing to such an extent that we will have a $55 billion-$60 billion trade imbalance, that we will be buying that much more than we are selling, which should be of benefit to our trading allies. Seeking Coordination
Q. Less optimistic forecasts of a short recovery - do you plan to coordinate it at Williamsburg with the other leaders all the necessary measures to remove the obstacles to a strong recovery?
A. This will be one of the principal subjects, discussing how we can bring convergence of policies together, because all of us need a long-term recovery, and that is what our plan is aimed at, not the what I call quick fix that has been tried in the past, since World War II, and each time has only been temporary and results in a worse recession a few years later. And I think this means all of us doing a job together to reduce inflation worldwide.
The very fact of our success in bringing inflation down as rapidly as we have is going to be helpful in the other countries as well. And, as long as we can stay on that path, not of quick fixes, but all of us seeking long-term, solid economic recovery -sadly enough, the last thing ever to recover from a recession is in the unemployment situation. But even there, there are beginning signs. And that is the ultimate goal of all of us - is to put our people back to work. U.S. 'Responsibilities'
Q. Mr. President, you have repeatedly stated that France is your best ally, at least on defense issues. Why, then, respond with indifference or benign neglect to French and European alarm over the rise of the dollar and the interest rates? Isn't it time the United States realized they cannot pretend to political leadership of the West if they do ignore their economic responsibilities?
A. Well, we are not ignoring our economic responsibilities. We didn't ask for the strong dollar. The strong dollar came about because of our success, so far, in reducing inflation in our country in comparison to the decline in inflation in other countries.
But the figure that I just used a moment ago, the fact that we will have a $55 billion to $60 billion imbalance in trade this year, is an indication of the penalty that we suffer from a strong dollar. It makes our exports higher priced and, therefore, not as desirable. And it also is beneficial to the other countries that are selling to us. Mitterrand's Position
Q. Do you believe you are going to have a direct confrontation over these issues with President Mitterrand?
A. No. I don't really expect confrontation there. We are, pretty much, all agreed upon our participation in the international funding group such as the International Monetary Fund, the World Bank and so forth. And I think we honestly are going to come together in effort to find ways that we can have that convergence I mentioned, where we can try to go forward together in the policies that we're following to get over inflation.

Links: http://findit.library.jhu.edu/resolve?url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Anytimes&amp;atitle=TRANSCRIPT+OF+PRESIDENT%27S+NEWS+CONFERENCE+ON+FOREIGN+AND+DOMESTIC+MATTERS%3A+%5BTEXT%5D&amp;title=New+York+Times&amp;issn=03624331&amp;date=1983-04-23&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=1.9&amp;au=&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=New+York+Times&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text: Following is a transcript of President Reagan's news conference yesterday at the White House, as recorded by The New York Times: OPENING STATEMENT
Good afternoon. I'd like to begin with a few words about the Middle East. The tragic and brutal attack on our embassy in Beirut has shocked us all and filled us with grief. Yet, because of this latest crime we are more resolved than ever to help achieve the urgent and total withdrawal of all American forces from Lebanon, or I should say, all foreign forces. I'm sorry. Mistake.
With this in mind, I've asked the Secretary of State to visit the Middle East next week. His primary purpose will be to bring to a successful conclusion the negotiations in Lebanon.
We are hopeful that an agreement between Lebanon and Israel can soon be concluded under terms which provide for the security of the borders.
I must stress that until all foreign forces are out of Lebanon, that country cannot assert its sovereignty and begin real reconstruction. These are basic goals of our Middle East policy. Outlook on Inflation
I have a second subject. Economic recovery received a big push forward in March, thanks to our continued progress against inflation. Prices rose by only onetenth of 1 percent last month and by only 3.6 percent over the last year. We've had virtually no inflation in America for the last six months. And that's welcome relief for every American family after the double-digit inflation and record interest rates of 1980. We know that zero inflation cannot last forever. Energy prices have firmed a bit in recent weeks.
Nevertheless, evidence indicates that the underlying rate of inflation has fallen below 5 percent, something the experts said couldn't be done. With inflation down, interest rates down and workers being called back, this is no time to sabotage the recovery we've worked so hard for with a quick political fix.
The battle over the budget now moves to the arena of the Senate floor, and I intend to marshal every resource of our Administration to protect the interests of the American people. We're determined to fight unfair and unwise tax increases on the people, to restore defense spending to a level that insures U.S. security and to reduce inflationary domestic spending. QUESTIONS AND ANSWERS Talks in Middle East
Q. Mr. President, recent public reports indicate that King Hussein apparently views the Mideast peace process as just about collapsed. Can you offer us today any concrete indications that there is still some chance to save your peace plan in the Middle East?
A. Yes. That's why George Shultz is going there. But that statement with regard to King Hussein - I've been in communication with him both by phone and by cable, and that hasn't been the position he expressed to me.
All that really happened was that the effort to persuade Arafat, as a representative of the P.L.O., to allow Jordan to represent the P.L.O. in the negotiations that will follow the removal of forces from Lebanon. He came in with an amendment to what had looked like his willingness to do this, calling for measures that Hussein could not agree to, I could not agree to, none of the other moderate Arab states could agree to. And so they told him that until and unless they came up with something different than what they had proposed - this came from the radical element of the P.L.O. -why we would, all of us, just have to go our own way.
Q. But since it seems unlikely that the P.L.O. will go along with Hussein, how can you pull it out? A. Well, maybe we're making the P.L.O. more important than they are. The negotiations don't have to hinge on the P.L.O. being present. Senate Vote on Budget
Q. Mr. President, if I can return to the last part of your opening statement, what you were referring to is the fact that the Senate Budget Committee yesterday voted against your programs on taxes, on defense and on domestic spending. How do you explain the rejection of really a total program by a Republican-controlled committee, and don't you really have to compromise more than you have so far on the budget?
A. No, the, what actually happened there was that the only way we could've been victorious in that committee was to get every one of the 12 Republican votes. Even one defector and we could not have won out. So it was simply decided to put it out on the floor and take the matter to the floor. And that's what happened.
Q. And as for compromise?
A. What?
Q. As for compromise? Aren't you going to have to compromise more on defense and taxes and domestic spending?
A. We have proposed a compromise, but certainly not to the extent that the committee turned out. Because that would be very irresponsible and it would be irresponsible on my part to not call it irresponsible. Defense and Tax Cuts
Q. Mr. President, are you willing to accept, ah, are you willing to accept that your, the third year of your tax cut might not be put in place? Or are you willing to accept a smaller increase in the defense spending than what you've proposed?
A. I believe that, well we're going to, we're going to seek an increase over the figure that came out of that committee, obviously. We have announced in the beginning that there is a willingness, we have found that we can go somewhat below the original figure that we first introduced in the budget. This has come about through the change brought about by the committee on the MX and all, on better progress in inflation, some things of that kind. So we are, there is a compromise figure on that, but it has been presented to the chairman of the committee. He knows about it.
With regard to the taxes, no, there's no way that we can give up on this third year of the tax increase. Nor can we give up on the indexing, which is strictly for the benefit of those in lower-and middle-income ranges because they're the only ones who can be shoved into higher tax brackets by cost-of-living pay increases.
Q. Mr. President, the Republican Senate voted overwhelmingly yesterday to reject the Administration's plan on withholding, to delay it for four years, which amounts to killing it. And with Senator Armstrong, we understand, who prevented the members of the budget committee - the Republican members of the budget committee - from being unanimous. What has happened to Republican unity? Why is, why are you having so much trouble with your own people in the Senate?
A. Well, this particular issue here, I thought that yesterday's vote in the Senate on the withholding was quite a triumph for the people who were not paying the taxes they fairly owe. And we'll see what happens in the other house, when it goes to the other house. But it seemed a little strange to me, in this great revved-up effort that happened, that that bill was passed without any problem or any protest by both houses of the Congress to have withholding of interest and dividend income. It is not a new tax. Went through the '82 election and it wasn't even mentioned, or was an issue or not.
And then suddenly a very successful lobbying effort went forward and the simple fact is that what was voted in the Senate was to allow people to go on cheating on their income tax rather than making them pay their fair share. Support for Programs
Q. But sir, your own strongest conservative partisans, such as Senator Kasten and Senator Armstrong, are not backing you on these important measures. My question was, what has happened to the united front that you used in '81 and '82?
A. Well, in this particular instance they went their own way. We'll see what happens on some other episodes.
Q.. Mr. President, with that overwhelming Senate vote and the likelihood of a House vote, perhaps of similar proportion, are you still planning to veto that bill in light of perhaps a veto-proof vote by the Congress?
A. The, as I've said many times before, in this case, I've said an apple can be an orange, in this case a bad apple might turn out yet to be an orange. We'll just wait and see. And I'll make up my mind on that when I see what hapens in the House. It might not get through the House.
Q. One last question. But are you predisposed at this time, because it is, they're trying to give you, as they said, wiggle room to get out of this thing because it's veto-proof, would you, in light of the overwhelming vote of both houses, if it should happen, would you veto it? Do you feel that strongly about it?
A. I feel strongly about it. That's all I'll say in advance. P.L.O. Role in Nicaragua
Q. Mr. President, you mentioned a few moments ago about the radical elements of the P.L.O. We understand that the White House now has intelligence information that not only the Libyans but also the P.L.O. have been aiding the Nicaraguan Government and the Salvadoran leftist guerrillas. Can you tell us more about what the P.L.O. is doing - I understand there's some 50 P.L.O. pilots down there -and what you're going to do about it?
A. I can tell you that the report is true. They, like others from the Communist states, have been in there, and are in there. And the episode with the Brazilian halting of the planes from Libya the other day, when the aspirin they were supposed to be carrying turned out to be hand grenades and things, is just further evidence of what we've said all the time - that there are outside forces, all of them principally aligned with or sympathetic to the Communist bloc, who are in there and intervening in the legitimate affairs of those countries.
Q. But if the P.L.O. is doing this, should we be dealing with them or trying to bring them into the peace process?
A. The, there has to be a solution to the problem of the Palestinians. Now, no one ever elected the P.L.O. among the Palestinians. I don't think that what an element of that group is doing should turn us away from trying to find a solution to the problem of hundreds of thousands, millions in fact, of Palestinians, who aren't radicals and who simply want something of a homeland. Vote on Arms Spending
Q. Back on the defense budget, if I might. Do you, you asked Senator Domenici to postpone his, his markup for three weeks and I'm wondering if you feel, in retrospect, that if you and your advisers had gone to the Senators in that period of time, you might now be in a different position, that you might not have been able to get the, the cooperation in those 12 votes you need?
A. It just wasn't that easy. You, as I said before about a defense budget, they're talking dollars. They're looking at it and wanting to simply cut dollars. We have to look at things. What do we feel we need to meet our defense strategy worldwide? And if they want to cut money, we have to look and say, 'Where can we responsibly eliminate one of these factors or more that we think are necessary for our national security?' And so all we asked for time was to study and see. Could we cooperate with them? Could we meet some of their demands on this without setting back the progress that we've made in closing that window of vulnerability? And it's just a different way of looking at things. Up there they simply looked at the money as if you could make a percentage cut across the board and it wouldn't have any effect on your military capability.
Q. Do you still think you're going to be able to put it back together again on the floor to get the defense budget somewhere near what you think it should be?
A. Yeah.
Q. Mr. President
A. Wait a minute. I've got to go back farther. I'm staying down front here too long. Arms Treaty Violations
Q. Mr. President, are you going to be speaking out publicly soon about alleged Soviet violations of current treaties? And if the United States does believe that the Soviets are now violating treaties we have with them, does that make it very difficult to reach agreement on any new treaties?
A. No, but it imposes a responsibility on us to be more careful in a new treaty than we've been in the past. Whether I'll be speaking out or not depends on a study that is going on right now on the most recent testing of a missile.
There have been evidences in the past when we have had indications that we thought possibly meant a violation of previous agreements. Unfortunately, those previous treatments, ah, treaties, are so ambiguous that it amounts to loopholes. And when, as in this most recent case, we feel that there is possible evidence that there was a violation, an interagency task force of experts reviews all the findings that we have. And then they report to my own advisers and then to the National Security Council, all of them looking at this. If there is then further evidence that we believe can be obtained from the Soviet Union, and asking them directly the answer to some questions, that enters into it. And that's all before it gets to me.
And the problem is trying, it is so ambiguous that it is difficult to establish, and have hard and fast evidence, that a treaty has been violated. This most recent case, for example, is one in which the Soviet Union says that they were testing an improved version of a missile that is already proper under the treaty. The evidence that we thought we had indicated that very possibly this was a new missile, which would be in violation.
Now, all I can tell you about this is, if this is like the past ones have been, if you can't get that kind of courtroom evidence you need, then you can't make the charge of violation. But what I've said is we've learned enough since we've been here, to know that any treaties that we arrive at with regard to arms limitation or reductions with the Soviets, we're going to make sure they are not ambiguous, that the the thing, the clauses that are in there are hard and fast.
Q. Are you concerned if you do speak out about possible violations, that this will set back the effort to, for our negotiations with the Soviets?
A. No. No. Not really, no.
Q. Thank you, Mr. President.
A. Well, I still never got beyond the third row.
A. Drop by whenever you're in the neighborhood.
A. All right. I will. I will. O.K. Thank you.

INDUSTRIAL NATIONS SHOW LOW INFLATION

Author: PAUL LEWIS, Special to the New York Times

Publication info: New York Times , Late Edition (East Coast); New York, N.Y. [New York, N.Y]16 Apr 1983: 1.31.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/424607280?accountid=11752

Abstract: In the United States, long-term Government bonds offered an average yield of 10.58 percent in February, according to Morgan Guaranty's World Finance Markets newsletter, although consumer prices were rising at an annual rate of only 3.5 percent. This gave such bonds what economists call a ''real'' rate of return, calculated by substracting inflation from the yield, of nearly 7 percent, or close to the peak yields recorded in 1982, when inflation was stronger. ''High real rates show people don't believe the present disinflation will continue for the next five years,'' said Paul Nield, chief economist at the London stock brokerage firm of Phillips & Drew. The new inflation figures point up another paradox about the present state of the industrial economies. Although many economists fear persistent high real interest rates could abort the emerging recovery in the United States, Japan and West Germany, stock markets everywhere are booming, suggesting that investors believe corporate profits are now firmly back on an upward track. ''The only explanation is that high real rates will not be such a deterrent to growth as we once thought,'' Mr. Nield argued. Decline Accelerating

Links: http://findit.library.jhu.edu/resolve?url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Anytimes&amp;atitle=INDUSTRIAL+NATIONS+SHOW+LOW+INFLATION&amp;title=New+York+Times&amp;issn=03624331&amp;date=1983-04-16&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=1.31&amp;au=PAUL+LEWIS%2C+Special+to+the+New+York+Times&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=New+York+Times&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text: The rate of inflation in the non-Communist industrial world has fallen to its lowest level in 10 years, pushed down by a global recession that has left more than 30 million people unemployed, the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development reported today.
Consumer prices in the 24 industrial member countries climbed by only two-tenths of 1 percent, on average, during February following a rise of five-tenths of 1 percent in January, the organization said in its latest monthly inflation survey.
As a result, the average inflation rate over the 12 months through February dropped to 5.7 percent, compared with 5.9 percent in the 12 months ended last January. These are the first inflation figures at an annual rate below 6 percent since February 1973, the organization said.
High Interest Rates Cited
However, the economic picture is not wholly favorable, some economists noted. In addition to the problem of high unemployment, interest rates remain obstinately high in the United States and most other major industrial countries.
In the United States, long-term Government bonds offered an average yield of 10.58 percent in February, according to Morgan Guaranty's World Finance Markets newsletter, although consumer prices were rising at an annual rate of only 3.5 percent. This gave such bonds what economists call a ''real'' rate of return, calculated by substracting inflation from the yield, of nearly 7 percent, or close to the peak yields recorded in 1982, when inflation was stronger.
''High real rates show people don't believe the present disinflation will continue for the next five years,'' said Paul Nield, chief economist at the London stock brokerage firm of Phillips & Drew.
The new inflation figures point up another paradox about the present state of the industrial economies. Although many economists fear persistent high real interest rates could abort the emerging recovery in the United States, Japan and West Germany, stock markets everywhere are booming, suggesting that investors believe corporate profits are now firmly back on an upward track. ''The only explanation is that high real rates will not be such a deterrent to growth as we once thought,'' Mr. Nield argued. Decline Accelerating
The new O.E.C.D. figures show that the decline in inflation is accelerating. While the annual rate during the 12 months through February was down to 5.7 percent, compared with an average of 7.8 percent during the 1982 calendar year and 10.5 percent in 1981, the rate during the six-month period through February was only 2 percent.
Staff economists at the O.E.C.D. said that slowing world inflation was aided in February by the second consecutive monthly fall in retail energy prices and by the general weakness of other commodity and food prices, brought about by the global recession. As a result, the average rate of inflation in the industrial nations has now tumbled to under half the record level of 12.8 percent it reached during 1980.
The fall in the inflation rate is most striking in the seven major O.E.C.D. countries - the United States, Japan, West Germany, France, Britain, Italy and Canada. During the 12 months through February, it was down to 4.8 percent in these countries, compared with 7.1 percent during 1982. But the rate during the six-month period through February was a mere 1.3 percent, or 2.6 percent on an annualized basis, which is below the average inflation rate these countries experienced between 1961 and 1970.
However, not all countries have made equal progress in the fight against inflation, the new figures show. In February, consumer prices were still climbing at an annual rate of 12 percent in Ireland, 13.4 percent in Spain, 16.1 percent in Italy, 18.8 percent in Ireland and 21.3 percent in Greece. Iceland, as usual, held the O.E.C.D. inflation record with a rate of 68.1 percent, while Turkey's was 29.6 percent.

HOW FAR YOUR DOLLAR CAN GO

Author: Dionne, E J, Jr; E.J. DIONNE Jr. is a correspondent in the Paris bureau of The New York Times

Publication info: New York Times , Late Edition (East Coast); New York, N.Y. [New York, N.Y]10 Apr 1983: A.22.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/424621934?accountid=11752

Abstract: Now, the low rates of American inflation, combined with the continuing high rates of interest paid to holders of dollars, are attracting currency buyers back to the dollar. And they've been selling other currencies, notably the French franc. Dollars cost more -are ''worth'' more - because they're in demand; francs cost less because they're not. An orchestra seat for Agatha Christie's ''The Mousetrap,'' London's longest-running play, would have cost 1.75 pounds in 1972. It was up to 6.50 pounds in 1980 and 1981, and was up again to 7.50 pounds in 1983. Every month, the State Department publishes per diem allowances for cities all over the world. They're based on the cost of lodging, food and miscellaneous expenses for one person at ''adequate, suitable and moderately priced facilities.'' The numbers don't necessarily correspond to what you'll actually spend, but taken together, they're a fairly good index of where you can travel cheaply, and where you can't.

Links: http://findit.library.jhu.edu/resolve?url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Anytimes&amp;atitle=HOW+FAR+YOUR+DOLLAR+CAN+GO&amp;title=New+York+Times&amp;issn=03624331&amp;date=1983-04-10&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=A.22&amp;au=Dionne%2C+E+J%2C+Jr%3BE.J.+DIONNE+Jr.+is+a+correspondent+in+the+Paris+bureau+of+The+New+York+Times&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=New+York+Times&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text: The dollar is king again, and traveling to Europe is cheaper than it ever was, right? Not exactly. In fact, if your memory goes back to the time before Jimmy Carter's inauguration or to the Watergate period, not at all. Had you gone to Paris in 1972, you could have rented a single room at the Ritz for about $42, had the Tour d'Argent's duck for just under $12, and enjoyed a cup of coffee at the Cafe de la Paix for 69 cents.
If you were on a tight budget then, you might have stayed at the Hotel Henri IV for $2.78 a night and had a burger-fries-and-Coke dinner at McDonald's for $2.08.
The great inflation spurred by the oil crisis has wiped out such bargains - and in many European countries that inflation was greater than in the United States. The same room at the Ritz would now cost $151, the duck $24 and the coffee more than $1. Even the bargain tour has gone up: You would now pay about $7.15 at the Henri IV, and $2.63 for McDinner.
But while the stronger dollar can't wipe out all the effects of inflation, it helps. If things aren't as good for American tourists as they were in 1972, they are much better than they were three years ago.
Go back to 1980, when the dollar was being battered on currency markets all over the world. Even though the cost of the room at the Ritz has almost doubled since 1980 when calculated in French francs, its actual cost to an American has gone up by a grand total of $5.
And - again, thinking in dollars - the price of the room at the Henri IV, the duck or McDonald's meal has actually gone down. In 1980, the Henri IV room would have cost $1 more, the duck almost $6 more, and the meal at McDonald's 58 cents more. Even the cup of coffee was 30 cents more then.
It's not magic; it's the strange sort of economics that has governed the world for the last decade. Of course, a dollar won't buy what it used to buy, even for Americans within the United States, but it really is stronger than it has been in a long time. Still, that can't make up for the waves of inflation that affected almost everyone in the 1970's.
How does it work? Tomes have been written on this subject, but from the traveler's point of view there are two things that count: How much local currency does your dollar buy, and then how much can the local currency you just purchased bring in meals, hotel rooms, postcards or whatever?
The value of the dollar is set essentially by the world's currency traders and - to a lesser degree - by currency agreements among countries. Currency traders are looking for the best deal. When inflation was especially high in the United States, the currency market didn't have much confidence in the dollar and exchanged it for other currencies, notably the German mark, the Japanese yen or the Swiss franc. These currencies promised to be worth more over time than the dollar.
Now, the low rates of American inflation, combined with the continuing high rates of interest paid to holders of dollars, are attracting currency buyers back to the dollar. And they've been selling other currencies, notably the French franc. Dollars cost more -are ''worth'' more - because they're in demand; francs cost less because they're not.
In 1980, a hundred American dollars could buy 423 French francs or about 43 British pounds. Today, those hundred dollars would buy 725 francs or 68 pounds - if you had a way of getting them at the official exchange rates. In fact, most tourists are condemned to getting inferior rates and paying bank charges, so those 725 francs per hundred dollars come out closer to 700 or 710.
All other things being equal, that means you could walk into a flea market in the Paris suburbs with almost twice as much money in your pocket.
But all other things are seldom equal. In the same period that the dollar's value went up, so did prices. Given the inflation rate, something that costs 725 francs today - say, an expensive meal for two - would have cost only about 500 francs in 1980.
Thus, your hundred dollars still buy more today than in 1980, but not quite as much as you might have hoped. Taking prices into account, today's dollar can buy, very roughly, about a fifth more in French goods than it did in 1980. What it comes down to is that the increased value of the dollar abroad allows you to wipe out the effect of inflation - something you can't do at home - and then save a little more over that.
This also explains why things are still far more expensive than they were in 1972. The increase in the value of the dollar in francs is big enough to make up for the last three years of inflation, but not for the last 11.
There are other factors to take into account. For one thing, not all prices go up at the same time, or at the same speed. Since 1980, for example, the cost of the room at the Ritz has gone up $5, because the dollar's value didn't go up fast enough to wipe out the price increases that hotel has levied over the years. But the cost of getting a shirt done by the Ritz's laundry service has gone down, from $4.50 in 1980 to $3.45 now. Laundry prices - at least at the Ritz - went up slower than room rates.
By this standard, one of the great bargains is sauerkraut at Paris's Lipp bistro, where many of France's most important people get together. The price of sauerkraut there has gone down from $9.45 in 1980 to $7.85 today. That's true for an American thinking in dollars; for France's elite, paying in francs, the actual price has gone up, from 40 francs to 57 francs.
The other factor you have to take into account is that prices have gone up much faster in some places than in others and the dollar, while generally strong these days, is not equally strong against every currency.
In France and Britain, for example, the dollar is at its highest point in decades; in Britain, it has never been worth more. But in other places, notably Germany and Switzerland, the dollar - though worth more now than it was a few years ago - is far less valuable than it was a decade or two ago.
To take the happy example first: Everyone raves about the wonderful bargain London theater is compared to Broadway. It used to be, and then prices went through the ceiling, but thanks to the dollar, it's a pretty good deal again.
An orchestra seat for Agatha Christie's ''The Mousetrap,'' London's longest-running play, would have cost 1.75 pounds in 1972. It was up to 6.50 pounds in 1980 and 1981, and was up again to 7.50 pounds in 1983.
But the pound is now at its lowest level in history compared to the dollar. A pound cost $2.50 in 1972; it had dropped to $2.32 by 1980 and now stands at about $1.46. So, the ''Mousetrap'' ticket that went from about $4.35 in 1972 and $15 in 1980, is down to just under $12 now.
In Germany, on the other hand, the long-term trend is not nearly as good. In 1972, a dollar bought 3.19 marks. By 1980, the value of the dollar had fallen to 1.82; it's now back up again, but has recovered only part of the loss, and now stands at about 2.42 marks to the dollar.
What does this mean in what you pay? At the Hotel Drei Loewen in Munich, a double room facing the courtyard (with breakfast) cost 79 marks in 1972, 136 marks in 1980 and 166 marks now. With the decline in the dollar, this meant that, for an American, the price of the room tripled between 1972 and 1980, going from just under $25 to just under $75. The improvement in the dollar has brought the price down to $68 - still a long way from 1972.
The story is similar in Switzerland. The dollar is now worth substantially more than it was in 1979 and 1980, but it still buys less than half the Swiss francs it did in 1970 or 1971. In those days, you could get more than four Swiss francs to the dollar; now, even with the recent improvements, you get just over two.
Then there are the countries in Southern Europe that have been the traditional bargain spots for tourists: Spain, Portugal and Greece in particular. In fact, the dollar buys more than three times as many Portuguese escudos now as it did in 1972; two-and-a-half times as many Greek drachmas, and more than twice as many Spanish pesetas.
But such changes don't happen by accident. One of the reasons for the big increase in the dollar's value is that inflation ran in the high teens or twenties in all three places for most of the last decade. Even taking all that into account, though, these countries are still a good deal for tourists.
And so, the ultimate question: If your budget is tight, and you want to go somewhere relatively inexpensive, where do you go?
There is no definitive answer to a question like that - you may despise mountains, or the shore. Or you may want to go to Scandinavia, no matter how much it costs. But if you're willing to look for bargains, you can find help from the United States State Department.
Every month, the State Department publishes per diem allowances for cities all over the world. They're based on the cost of lodging, food and miscellaneous expenses for one person at ''adequate, suitable and moderately priced facilities.'' The numbers don't necessarily correspond to what you'll actually spend, but taken together, they're a fairly good index of where you can travel cheaply, and where you can't.
In Europe, Greece remains one of the best deals available. The per diem allowance in Athens for last January was only $48. That was down $11 from last year - a clear indication of the dollar's new strength - and up only $7 from six years ago. Lisbon at $64 a day is also a relative bargain, and Madrid at $71 is not terribly expensive either.
At the upper end of the scale, Ireland has become vastly more expensive over the years - $124 a day is the allowance there -as has Israel at $100 a day.
The Scandinavian countries are also very expensive. But there's been a substantial improvement for dollar holders over the last couple of years. Oslo, according to the State Department, is now about 12 percent cheaper for travelers who spend dollars than it was last year, and Stockholm is somewhat less expensive. But these things are relative: Sweden and Norway are still two of the most costly places in Europe. Among the Scandinavian countries, the State Department figures suggest that Denmark is the bargain.
The figures show that Britain, France and Italy - the more popular tourist countries -are in the middle price ranges. Britain and France are, generally speaking, as inexpensive as they've ever been in the last five years, but, as we have seen, still more expensive than they were before that. The same, roughly speaking, is true in Italy, though in Venice, a favorite tourist stop, prices continue to climb. Germany continues to be quite expensive.
Note, too, that it is often a lot cheaper to travel the hinterlands. Edinburgh, one of Great Britain's most beautiful cities, is about $21 cheaper a day than London. Siena, a pretty and peaceful Italian town, is less expensive than Rome and Venice.
As for Eastern Europe, it's hard to say anything definitive because the official exchange rates often bear no relation to what currency trades for in the much-trafficked black markets.
Having said all of this, what can you do to make your dollar go farther? Generally speaking, unless you plan to spend tens of thousands of dollars, you should not become obsessed with exchange rates. Banks usually offer better deals than hotels, some banks are better than others, and the places that are open over the weekends often take advantage of your urgent need for cash by giving you a bad rate.
But don't waste hours to try to save $2 on a $500 exchange. Exchange rates are usually posted in the windows of banks and you can get a good sense quite quickly of what constitutes a fair rate. Travelers checks usually bring a premium. And don't change such small amounts of money that you keep having to go back to the bank and pay a lot of unnecessary charges.
Can you make money on currency speculation? You are, after all, buying and selling money just like the traders. Don't expect to make much - most of your gains would be wiped out by the bank charges anyway - but it doesn't hurt to keep an eye on the newspapers.
Last month, France devalued its currency 2.5 percent, and Germany upgraded its currency by 5.5 percent. That meant that a mark suddenly bought 8 percent more francs than it did before. If you were traveling from Germany to France and had a lot of marks left over, you could have saved a small bundle by holding on to your marks for a few days. But such situations are rare.
Finally, How long will the strong dollar last? Those who play the currency markets pay a lot of money trying to figure out precise answers to such questions. There is much talk now that the dollar is overvalued and that it could drop back. That would change many of the numbers and, depending on which other currencies rose and fell, almost all of the calculations could go out the window. On the other hand, few people think the dollar is in for anything like the beating it took in the late 1970's.
Among the uncertainties facing travelers going abroad is what to do about money. As you plan your trip, it is worth examining the alternatives. For guidance, ask a travel agent, a major bank or foreign-exchange dealer, an international airline that flies where you are going or perhaps the appropriate government tourist offices in New York. To find them, ask your agent or check the Manhattan Consumer Yellow Pages under ''Tourist Information.''
Cash - Carrying large amounts of money is always risky. For a twoweek trip, I generally carry about $50 in United States currency, mostly in one- and five-dollar bills. I use this for such incidentals as porter tips upon leaving and returning to the United States, buying drinks on a plane or to help pay a local departure tax or unexpected airport expenses.
Foreign-exchange dealers in the United States often encourage travelers to buy enough foreign currency to pay for tips and transportation to town from the airport of arrival, or to cover them for weekend arrivals. These days, however, most major foreign airports have foreign-exchange kiosks (often run by local banks) that are open for all flights from abroad, regardless of day or time, and that will give you as good a conversion rate as anywhere.
Major banks or foreign-exchange dealers in the United States will sometimes offer foreign currencies at far better than the official rate in the issuing country. Before you plunge, however, be sure that it is legal to take that money into the country. Even if it is legal, there may be an officially recognized unofficial rate within the country that is better.
Traveler's Checks - If lost or stolen, they can be replaced (although not always as easily as advertised) providing you have a record of the serial numbers of those you have not spent. Their principal disadvantage is that you must pay for them up front, which means that the company is getting interest on your money until you use the checks. Some companies, notably American Express and Thomas Cook, market traveler's checks in the United States in a number of major foreign currencies. So consider buying traveler's checks in French francs, for example, if you plan an extended stay in France: They will usually be easier to use than dollars. But be aware that if the franc falls in value - as happened when France recently devalued it - your franc traveler's checks will suddenly be worth substantially less than when you bought them.
Changing Money Abroad - You generally get the best rate at banks, except where, as in Brazil and the Dominican Republic, there is an unofficial rate at which you can trade legally elsewhere, such as in hotels and shops. But always avoid money-changers who approach you furtively in building lobbies or on the street. Keep invoices covering all exchanges at official rates; you may need them to change money back into dollars when you leave the country.
Credit Cards - Their principal advantage - and it is a big one - is that your money can keep drawing interest in your bank until you are billed by the card company, which may be several months after you charged something abroad. However, different companies use different methods of converting foreign charges into dollars, and the benefit or disadvantage to you can vary according to the rates on the day of conversion.
If you plan to use a credit card heavily, make sure that it is readily acceptable where you are going. Be aware, also, that while you usually have 30 interest-free days to pay bills for purchases, interest begins accruing on the very day you use a credit card for a cash advance. Also, since credit-card conversions are usually at the official exchange rate, you will do much better in Brazil and the Dominican Republic, for example, to use cash or traveler's checks.Paul Grimes
