SPRINKEL'S REMARKS STARTLE REGAN

Author: CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH, Special to the New York Times

Publication info: New York Times , Late Edition (East Coast); New York, N.Y. [New York, N.Y]20 Jan 1983: D.1.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/424533470?accountid=11752

Abstract: According to the sources, Mr. [Donald T. Regan] was furious - not at Mr. de Larosiere but at Mr. [Beryl Sprinkel]. The Under Secretary was ''speaking for himself,'' Mr. Regan told aides to say. Mr. Regan also told them to stress that there had been no change in policy. Mr. Regan declined to respond today to questions about the possible existence of rifts in the Treasury, but pointedly stated at a news conference that it was necessary to achieve world growth ''in a more stable fashion,'' without ''massive doses of inflation.'' ''Speaking for the United States,'' Mr. Regan added, ''we would not want to return to above 5 and 6 percent inflation.'' That rate is about the current annual rate of price increases in the United States.

Links: http://findit.library.jhu.edu/resolve?url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Anytimes&amp;atitle=SPRINKEL%27S+REMARKS+STARTLE+REGAN&amp;title=New+York+Times&amp;issn=03624331&amp;date=1983-01-20&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=D.1&amp;au=CLYDE+H.+FARNSWORTH%2C+Special+to+the+New+York+Times&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=New+York+Times&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text: The first that Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan knew about the comments of his errant Under Secretary was early Monday, when Jacques de Larosiere, the managing director of the 146-nation International Monetary Fund, telephoned from Paris.
Mr. de Larosiere wanted to know whether the remarks of Beryl Sprinkel, the Under Secretary of the Treasury for Monetary Affairs, signified a major change in American policy - from one of emphasis on controlling inflation to one that gave priority to economic growth, even if such a policy ignited inflationary forces again.
Mr. Sprinkel made his comments at a news conference in Paris on Sunday. Official sources here, who declined to be identified, recounted the story, which sheds some light on relationships in high places in the Treasury at a time of policy ferment in the Reagan Administration.
According to the sources, Mr. Regan was furious - not at Mr. de Larosiere but at Mr. Sprinkel. The Under Secretary was ''speaking for himself,'' Mr. Regan told aides to say. Mr. Regan also told them to stress that there had been no change in policy.
The Treasury chief was miffed because he was about to get on a plane himself - and go without sleep that night in the process - to lead the American delegation in Paris at a meeting of finance ministers from the 10 largest industrial nations. The Secretary saw it as his job, not Mr. Sprinkel's, to speak for the United States.
Mr. Sprinkel, the sources said, had not informed the Treasury Department's press office that he was meeting with reporters. The sources added that Mr. Regan was much more distressed, however, over the misunderstanding that apparently had been caused by the Under Secretary's remarks.
The question raised by Mr. de Larosiere, and apparently others in Europe, was whether the United States was now about to initiate a much more expansionary set of policies domestically and press other nations on a similar course.
If this were true, it would require a new global economic strategy, one that the officials of the 10 industrial nations, gathered in Paris Monday and Tuesday, were unprepared to address. The meeting was called mainly to negotiate a substantial increase in the lendable resources of the International Monetary Fund, so that the I.M.F. would be better able to help developing nations deeply in debt. Mr. Sprin-kel had warned that attempts to solve the international debt crisis will fail unless other Western nations and Japan joined the United States in adopting policies to stimulate their economies out of recession. The emphasis that he put on getting faster growth suggested to some people that the Treasury Department was putting its top priority on growth, rather than on the fight against inflation.
Mr. Regan declined to respond today to questions about the possible existence of rifts in the Treasury, but pointedly stated at a news conference that it was necessary to achieve world growth ''in a more stable fashion,'' without ''massive doses of inflation.''
''Speaking for the United States,'' Mr. Regan added, ''we would not want to return to above 5 and 6 percent inflation.'' That rate is about the current annual rate of price increases in the United States.

REAGANOMICS AND THE PRESIDENTS MEN

Author: Weisman, Steven R; Steven R. Weisman is The Times's White House correspondent.

Publication info: New York Times , Late Edition (East Coast); New York, N.Y. [New York, N.Y]24 Oct 1982: A.26.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/424447052?accountid=11752

Abstract: Mr. [Dan Rostenkowski] had a talk with Vice President [George Bush], an old friend. ''I told him, 'George, if you want a vote on the floor on the third year, I'll give it to you,' '' the Congressman recalls today. In other words, he would not use parliamentary tactics to prevent the House from voting on the three-year tax cut. ''But I said, 'Let's stay out of oil and gas and the estate and gift taxes. Because if it gets to be a bidding war, George, I'll bid.' '' In fact, the President apparently remained personally aloof from the day-to-day details of the process even as he insisted that his overall principles could not be compromised. At one meeting in the Roosevelt Room of the White House between a group of Presidential aides and a collection of Congressmen of both parties, Secretary [Donald T. Regan] beckoned the President to sit down and join the horse-trading - votes for tax breaks. ''Heck, no,'' the President replied. ''I'm going to leave this to you experts.'' The Power of an Image On the evening of Feb. 5, 1981, seated at his desk in the Oval Office, [Ronald Reagan] delivered his maiden television address as President and offered a fresh pitch for his program of tax cuts. ''Over the past decades,'' he said, ''we've talked of curtailing Government spending so that we can then lower the tax burden. Sometimes we've even taken a run at doing that. But there were always those who told us that taxes couldn't be cut until spending was reduced. Well, you know we can lecture our children about extravagance until we run out of voice and breath. Or we can cure their extravagance simply by reducing their allowance.'' In December and January, the White House staff launched yet another ''offensive'' - a proposal to raise perhaps $45 billion in new taxes in 1983-85. Newspapers came to be filled with items about these plans. Finally, at a staff economic meeting in the Cabinet Room, Mr. Reagan began the session by announcing, ''You know, everybody in the press says that you guys have a conspiracy to talk me into a tax increase.'' By the time the session was over, Mr. Reagan found himself declaring: ''By God, they're right!'' There were still many people close to Mr. Reagan who felt that the supply-side tax cuts had not been given time to have their energizing effect, and, not surprisingly, Representative [Jack F. Kemp] was in that group. He led a counteroffensive that convinced the President to reject his aides' advice.

Links: http://findit.library.jhu.edu/resolve?url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Anytimes&amp;atitle=REAGANOMICS+AND+THE+PRESIDENTS+MEN&amp;title=New+York+Times&amp;issn=03624331&amp;date=1982-10-24&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=A.26&amp;au=Weisman%2C+Steven+R%3BSteven+R.+Weisman+is+The+Times%27s+White+House+correspondent.&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=New+York+Times&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text: It was like a rerun from the 1980 Reagan campaign: The tall, athletic figure standing beside a huge cargo vessel, face wreathed in a characteristic lopsided grin as he placed a hard hat on his head and waved to a crowd of longshoremen. ''America's economy is ready to lead the world out of recession and into recovery,'' he declared as the workers cheered.
But President Reagan on the campaign stump in the port of Long Beach, Calif., earlier this month was, in fact, very different from Candidate Reagan of two years ago. Back then, he joyously lashed President Carter and the Democrats for causing the nation's economic stagnation. Now, with the economy still floundering, Mr. Reagan finds his own policies under attack. The very day of his appearance at the shipyard, the Labor Department reported that unemployment had reached 10.1 percent, the highest level since the Great Depression. Republican Congressmen fear that the economic malaise will drag them down to a crushing defeat in the election next month, threatening the future viability of the Reagan Administration itself.
No economist lays the entire blame for the current recession at the doorstep of Reaganomics. But judged on its own terms, Mr. Reagan's allegedly painless means to economic recovery has failed to deliver on its promise of simultaneous low inflation, robust growth and a balanced budget.
How could the nation have gone from hope to gloom in less than two years? It is a critical question as the 1982 election approaches. Yet there is another, possibly more significant question to be asked: How could Mr. Reagan's economic plan have been enacted in the first place? For it was a program that lacked any sort of traditional constituency in Congress or in the Government, a program whose premises were challenged by conservative and liberal economists alike and that was widely characterized as a risky gamble with the nation's future.
This question hovers over much of the current debate about Reaganomics, just as it hovered, unasked, over a somber meeting in the White House just two months ago. There, as the sun streamed in through the French doors of the Cabinet room, a combative President was pressing 25 Republican Congressmen to support a measure he himself would have ridiculed earlier, a $98 billion tax increase. Many in the room opposed the measure, including Representative Jack F. Kemp of suburban Buffalo, an early advocate of the so-called ''supply-side'' theory that deep tax cuts by themselves would spur economic recovery.
The room fell silent as Paul Laxalt, the rangy, silver-haired Senator from Nevada, spoke up. Mr. Reagan's closest friend on Capitol Hill, Mr. Laxalt not surprisingly supported the President in seeking the tax in-Page 28 crease. But it was a poignant moment. The three-year tax cut, which had been at the heart of Mr. Reagan's economic program, and which had been enacted amid such promise the previous summer, had been a mistake, Mr. Laxalt said, and now it was time to take corrective action. After all, he reminded listeners, it wasn't as if they had all been true believers in supply-side economics. ''If there had been a secret ballot in the Senate last year,'' he said, ''there wouldn't have been more than 12 votes for the tax cut.''
The Senator's astonishing statement passed without comment at the Cabinet Room, even from Mr. Reagan. But viewed in the light of the past year, given the staggering political and economic impact, now and for the future, of the biggest tax cut in the nation's history, his words are worth pondering. Given all those misgivings about the program, how could it have happened?
Recently, in dozens of interviews with The New York Times, central figures in the Administration and Congress have explored that question. Their observations - offered on the condition that the sources not be identified - shed new light on the first six months of the Reagan Presidency, on the personal and institutional forces that combined to produce a remarkable episode in modern American history.
Some Republicans in Congress and members of the President's own team set aside their reservations out of loyalty and, in some instances, because they were not sure they were right. Others hoped that the system of checks and balances would lead to a compromise. But there were also Congressmen who yielded because of Administration promises, which were not kept, and newcomers to Republican leadership posts who didn't want to rock the boat. There were miscalculations by Senators about the House, by Reagan staffers about the power of the Pentagon and by almost everybody about the difficulty of cutting the Federal budget.
The most dramatic revelation, however, concerns those White House aides who, one by one, as the economic news worsened, began to fear that the tax-cut program would not work - and failed to alert the President. David A. Stockman, the budget director who told of his early doubts about the program in a magazine article, was but one among many. After the law was passed, Mr. Reagan's men set about a series of sometimes desperate efforts to undo what had been done. And running through all the comments of those interviewed was the image of a charming, insistent President - politically skilled, ideologically stubborn, a man who defied the odds and bent the public and the Government to his will. Riding Two Horses Economically speaking, Ronald Reagan rode two horses to victory in the election of 1980, and they corresponded to the two chief problems he promised to solve. The large tax cuts, as espoused by the supplysiders, were designed to energize the economy. The reining in of the nation's money supply, as called for by the monetarists and endorsed by Mr. Reagan, was aimed at controlling inflation. In the first six months of 1981, those two horses went dashing off in different directions. At first, those in charge seemed not to recognize the crisis in the making; then, as some now admit, they fell prey to self-deception and political expediency. One of the first orders of business for any new Administration is to produce a projection of the economic future. Within days of the Inauguration, the optimistic supply-siders at the Treasury Department were ready, predicting an economic growth of more than 5 percent for each of the next two years - compared with 3.2 percent growth in 1979 and a small decline in 1980. Meanwhile, the monetarists in the Administration were sure their tight-money policy would bring inflation down from its double-digit levels of 1980 to 7 percent in 1982 and even 2 percent by 1984. (When Murray Weidenbaum, then chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers, was presented the 2 percent figure on a working paper, he refused to sign his name to it.)
Before they became official, the predictions were leaked to the press, which carried articles about the Administration's ''rosy scenario.'' Some quick, minor adjustments in the figures were made. The incident was an early demonstration of the White House's diverging policies.
What was most significant about the statistics was the way they ignored economic realities. There had been a surge in the money supply toward the end of 1980, with inflation still raging out of control; in the first months of '81 the economy showed signs of improvement. Under the leadership of Paul A. Volcker, and with the blessing of the new Administration, the Federal Reserve Board was moving in traditional monetarist fashion to restrict the quantity of money flowing through the nation's economic system. Inflation was the chief enemy, and the Fed seemed ready to do battle, even if the price of victory was a minor recession.
Given the Administration's expectation that the Volcker campaign would succeed, the likelihood of a spurt in economic growth was virtually nil. How could the Administration have ended up with an official projection that still called for a growth rate of 4.2 percent in 1982 and 5 percent in 1983?
''We took a given high level of growth, and the lowest level of inflation we thought we could get away with,'' a White House official now admits, ''and we added the two together. The issue didn't get settled. It just got added up.'' In order to justify the tax-cut program to which the President and his Administration were committed, the economic experts failed to see - or, seeing, decided to ignore - the program's all-but-inevitable impact on the economy. Page 29 As the first months of the Administration passed, the restrictive policies of the Fed started to take hold, with the supply of money actually falling below some of the Fed's own targets. The bond markets were watching. They knew that a sudden drop in the money supply would restrict the pool of funds available for borrowing, and they were convinced that the proposed three-year tax cut would produce giant budget deficits. That meant the Federal Government would be forced to compete with the private sector in the already tight money marketplace, and the cost of borrowing would soar.
In April and May, the markets moved to beat the clock, finally pushing the prime rate for borrowing up to more than 20 percent. That rate made it prohibitively expensive for corporations to borrow to finance expansion or for individual citizens to borrow to buy automobiles or homes. The chances that a rush of new investment would rejuvenate the economy were clearly in jeopardy.
At the White House, the dangers of the soaring interest rate had become apparent to a handful of economic aides. Mr. Stockman began prodding the Cabinet for more budget cuts to reduce the Federal deficit. He and other aides finally won Mr. Reagan's approval of a package of reductions in Social Security benefits. But after the package was made public, it was resoundingly rejected by Congress and then disavowed by the President himself.
Meanwhile, as the bond-market interest rates were reaching historic highs, Mr. Reagan and some of his West Coast entrepreneurial colleagues seemed baffled and angry. ''I have never found Wall Street a source of good economic advice,'' Mr. Reagan commented.
In July, the recession that had always been a probable result of the Fed's tight-money policy began, and along with it came a reduction in Federal tax revenues. Suddenly, what had been a budgetdeficit problem was a budget-deficit crisis.
As the economy went into its nose dive, Secretary of the Treasury Donald T. Regan publicly questioned the wisdom of the Federal Reserve Board's tight-money actions; perhaps Chairman Volcker had overdone things, he said. Yet it was an awkward position to take. From the start, Mr. Volcker had the President's blessing for his tight-money policy, and the Fed chairman had frequently made clear his conviction that the Administration should do its part in combatting inflation by curbing the deficit. This the President had failed to do. Mr. Volcker told an associate that he found Secretary Regan's criticism ''astounding.''
Today, economists have other questions. They wonder how the Administration could have dreamed that a tight-money, monetarist policy would be compatible with the giant, supply-side tax cut. And some wonder how, after interest rates topped 20 percent in May, the Congress could have gone on to vote for the tax-cut measure.
The President's Men Ronald Reagan's unwavering personal faith in the economic theories of the supply-siders plus his superb capacity to frame and present those theories to the American public and Congress thrust his untried tax-cut program toward enactment in 1981. But Mr. Reagan and his program benefited as well from the services of a brilliant, dedicated - and unquestioning - staff.
In most Administrations, there comes a time when advisers prevail, when the weight of their arguments and their unanimity persuade a President to alter his course. Jimmy Carter, for example, promised during his election campaign to undertake a vast governmental reorganization in the interest of efficiency, abolishing several Federal agencies along the way. After the election, his aides convinced him to drop the plan.
Mr. Reagan also campaigned with the promise of making a sweeping economic change if elected, and during of the first six months of 1981, his aides also harbored ever greater doubts about the wisdom of actually pursuing their boss's plan. But interviews with White House officials and aides show that the President was basically not informed of their reservations until after his program was enacted in July. Loyalty, uncertainty, timidity, miscalculation, expedience and general weariness combined to bring about their silence.
The doubts about Reaganomics among Mr. Reagan's staff actually had their seeds in the 1980 Presidential campaign when he became the first nationally recognized Republican to campaign for the threeyear, 30 percent supply-side tax cut. It had an appealing premise - the tax cuts would quickly spur such an increase in investment and thus in economic growth that the Government would soon be raking in more tax revenues than had been cut in the first place.
But during the primaries, Mr. Reagan's opponents ridiculed the scheme. George Bush called it ''voodoo economics.'' Representative John B. Anderson of Illinois said that the only way Mr. Reagan was going to fulfill his promises to cut taxes, balance the budget and increase defense spending was with mirrors. And economists of both parties, including some who were to join Mr. Reagan's staff, expressed strong reservations.
In September 1980, the decision was made to confront the doubters, and a major speech was scheduled for Sept. 9 in Chicago. Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers under President Ford, was asked to work with Martin Anderson, a Stanford University economist who was a longtime Reagan adviser, to patch together a more credible program. It was known within the staff as the ''mirrors'' speech.
For the first time, in that address, Mr. Reagan modified his supply-side stance and promised to cut spending as well as taxes. No spending cuts were specified, though, and in the following months many Republicans remained skeptical. A few, like former President Ford, continued to express their distrust of the whole supply-side approach, but most leaders and aides kept their silence in the interest of party unity. Another explanation has since been offered by a campaign adviser: ''Nobody thought it was even remotely possible that the whole tax cut could be enacted.''
Once in office, Mr. Reagan continued his supply-side rhetoric. A day after outlining his budget to a joint sesthe White House East Room that every other modern tax cut had resulted in the Government ending up with more revenues than it started out with, and that ''we're just convinced'' it would happen again. It was an amazing statement in light of the official Administration budget projections released at the time. They indicated that there would be sizable budget deficits as a result of the massive tax cuts.
When aides are asked to explain the discrepancy, they tend to shrug their shoulders and offer comments like, ''He really does believe it.'' Several aides quoted the President as saying that he had never put much faith in economic projections anyway. Yet for all Mr. Reagan's certainty, his staff was getting nervous.
The first to worry about deficits, according to insiders, was Martin Anderson, the bookish, self-effacing domestic policy adviser. He counseled his colleagues to work out a compromise with the Democrats in Congress on a two-year tax cut. But Mr. Anderson never told the President of his feelings -for a variety of reasons. As a veteran of the bitter arguments over the program during the campaign, for example, he shared with some other Reagan old-timers a reluctance to reopen those wounds. He also believed in the customary procedures of the Reagan office whereby the staff reached a consensus on a major issue before going to the President with it - and that point never seemed to arrive.
The next aides to become upset were Mr. Stockman, the 34-year-old budget direc-tor, and Richard G. Darman, then 37, a White House aide in the policy and legislative areas. Mr. Darman, a former protege of Elliott Richardson, a pillar of the Republican establishment, forged a crucial early alliance with Mr. Stockman.
Mr. Stockman sent discreet signals to his friends among the Democrats in Congress of his hope for a tax-cut compromise, but he was outside the direct negotiations. The two men were supervised by James A. Baker 3d, the shrewd, affable White House chief of staff, along with Treasury Secretary Regan.
The budget director also began warning his White House colleagues about the burgeoning deficit. A sophisticated reader of Mr. Reagan's first budget submissions, for example, would have noticed that between Feb. 18 and March 10 of 1981 the 1984 projected deficit, accounting tricks aside, grew from $30 billion to $44 billion - $14 billion in 20 days. ''There was a sinking feeling that every time we went into a meeting with Stockman, his numbers got worse,'' recalls a White House official. ''What we looked at in June was far different from what we looked at in February or March.''
Another of the President's men troubled by the deficit figures was Murray Weidenbaum, but he too failed to convey his concern to the President. He saw his role more as a mediator between optimists and alarmists.
Then the doubts reached James Baker. He had been told by Mr. Darman in March that the Administration's deficit forecasts were too low. He later heard the same thing from Mr. Stockman and from budget experts in Congress. He responded by trying to achieve a compromise with the Democrats on the Administration's tax bill, an effort supported by his colleagues, Edwin Meese 3d, the White House counselor, and Michael K. Deaver, the deputy chief of staff. Mr. Baker was wary of pushing too hard for compromise, however, because of his former role as campaign manager for George Bush, the man who coined the ''voodoo economics'' phrase.
In the spring and early summer, the aides came to the President with possible concessions that could be made to move along the negotiations with the Democrats. Mr. Reagan did accept a reduction of the tax cut in the first year from 10 percent to 5 percent, his only major concession. And once it became clear that the President did not intend further compromise, Mr. Baker went all out for the man to whom he now owed his loyalty.
By all accounts, Secretary Regan was the last supply-side dropout in the President's inner circle - and his loss of faith came only in the fall of 1981, well after the tax program was in place. Mr. Regan's tenacity was nothing if not ironic. During his confirmation hearings, he had said that ''the more important parts'' of the Reagan program were the spending cuts - not the tax cuts. Then Mr. Regan was converted by Norman B. Ture and Paul Craig Roberts, the leading supply-siders at Treasury.
All the doubts came to a head at a crucial strategy meeting on June 5. The prime rates had moved beyond 20 percent only days earlier. White House aides crowded around a mahogany conference table in James Baker's spacious West Wing office to discuss whether to issue a new, less optimistic economic forecast. The case for the new forecast was made by Lawrence Kudlow, the senior economist in the budget office.
Secretary Regan told colleagues that he remained optimistic about the economy. He pointed to certain signs of growth in the first quarter of the year, and suggested that an even rosier scenario might be in order. Finally, he said that, as a practical matter, a less optimistic forecast at that point would derail the chances of the Administration's tax bill.
But the Administration's economic goals were inherently contradictory, Mr. Kudlow insisted. Then Mr. Baker spoke up: ''You mean it really is voodoo economics after all?'' The room erupted in laughter. Later, Mr. Baker told an associate that he saw no reason to change the forecast and jeopardize the chances of the Reagan program.
The unwillingness of the Reagan staff to challenge the President's deeply held beliefs can be explained, in part, by their relationship with the man himself. As a newcomer to Washington and the Federal bureaucracy, Mr. Reagan depended heav-ily on his staff to help translate his themes into political and legislative realities. In return, he offered these younger men an unusually large share of the limelight. A sign near his desk in the Oval Office reads: ''There's no limit to what a man can do or where he can go if he doesn't mind who gets the credit.'' Moreover, Mr. Reagan, as a man of genuine warmth and generosity, earned his staff's loyalty on a personal level.
At the same time, the President was supremely confident in himself and his ideas. He came to the Presidency convinced he had been given a mandate by the voters to carry out his program, and his staff by and large agreed. That was another reason why they hesitated in bringing doubts to him.
'It was not our role to go in there and try to reshape the President's policies,'' said a senior White House official. ''To rewrite the Reagan agenda was just not appropriate.'' Billions for Defense Ronald Reagan's call for a cutback in Federal spending had always left room for new Pentagon programs, but the military expenditures he sought after taking office far exceeded any of his campaign promises. That commitment to the largest peacetime military buildup in history made it all the more difficult to keep the budget within bounds. And according to interviews with participants, the decision was made by officials who avoided customary review procedures and mistakenly assumed that agreements, once reached, could be rescinded.
During the campaign of 1980, Mr. Reagan first laid out his military spending projections in the Sept. 9 ''mirrors'' speech. The figures had been set the evening before his talk in an angry meeting in a Chicago hotel room among Mr. Greenspan, Mr. Anderson and William R. Van Cleave, a University of Southern California professor who was serving as the candidate's defense consultant. The two economists, already nervous about the budget outlook, favored an annual spending increase of 5 percent, after allowing for inflation. Mr. Van Cleave, a longtime critic of detente and the nuclear-arms treaties with the Soviet Union, insisted on 7 percent.
''It was a hell of a battle,'' said a campaign official. The struggle came to an abrupt halt minutes before a news conference called to brief reporters on the speech. Mr. Anderson simply grabbed a piece of paper, typed a set of numbers on it and passed it on to an aide to be distributed to the press.
During the two previous years, the Carter Administration had increased defense spending 3 percent, after inflation, and Mr. Carter had called for a 4 percent annual growth through 1985. Mr. Anderson was willing to raise the ante, but not by much, and the annual projection he typed out was for 5 percent. Mr. Van Cleave was not pleased.
On Jan. 15, 1981, Jimmy Carter of-fered up some of the same kind of valedictory one-upmanship that had distinguished President Ford's last days in office four years earlier. He called for defense spending to increase annually at 5 percent.
The Carter recommendation was contained in a proposed budget for the 1982 fiscal year that had no legal force. But for Mr. Van Cleave, who had been named the Reagan transition team's director of defense planning, it had a large political and strategic significance. It was now essential, he told Caspar W. Weinberger, the incoming Secretary of Defense, that Mr. Reagan send a ''signal'' to the Soviet Union of his determination to spend more for military preparedness than his predecessor. As Mr. Van Cleave saw it, the appropriate signal would be a 7 percent annual increase in defense spending.
On the face of it, Mr. Weinberger seemed an unlikely convert. A former director of the Federal budget office, where he was known as ''Cap the Knife,'' he had been chosen Defense Secretary in part because he was thought likely to find ways to cut spending. Soon after he started on the job, he let it be known that he, not Mr. Van Cleave, would direct defense planning for the Administration. Yet for all his bureaucratic expertise and independence, Mr. Weinberger had little background in military strategy and spending. The new Defense Secretary passed a necessarily unseasoned eye over money requests presented by the Joint Chiefs of Staff -what one Administration official called a ''wish list'' - and concluded that nothing less than 7 percent would meet the Soviet threat as he perceived it.
In February, at a one-hour meeting in the Pentagon, Secretary Weinberger won Mr. Stockman's agreement. But Mr. Stockman, who was frantically churning through endless budget meetings day and night, thought he was looking at tentative figures. Others in the Administration felt the same way. ''A lot of us weren't paying much attention to defense spending,'' one White House official recently acknowledged.
The figures were discussed, for example, at a meeting later that month attended by Messrs. Stockman, Baker, Meese, Anderson, Weidenbaum and Darman. Little attention was paid to details - one official there recalled wondering out loud whether it would be physically possible for the Pentagon to spend that much money. Among those attending, it was ''mostly assumed,'' another participant said, that defense spending would be reduced when the budget office and the Pentagon got down to figuring out exactly how the money was going to be spent over the next several years. In other words, Mr. Stockman and the others would get a ''second crack'' at defense spending.
Pushing to meet the March 10 deadline for the submission of the overall budget to Congress, the White House staff agreed to the 7 percent figure. President Reagan went along. The decision was made.
The determination of how much money an Administration wants to devote to military spending is usually made after a lengthy and intensive review of the proposed programs and in the light of the nation's strategic needs. But no such procedure was followed by Mr. Reagan in 1981 until after the overall budget had been sub-Page 85 mitted and the Administration was publicly committed to a course. It is possible that an earlier, in-depth review might have led the Administration to recognize just how enormous the defense proposal really was. Mr. Reagan's original 1980 pledge to increase defense spending by 5 percent a year had been based on a defense budget of $158 billion for the fiscal year 1981. But Mr. Weinberger's 7 percent solution was based on the 1982 defense budget, which in the meantime had ballooned to $222 billion. Reckoned on the basis of the 1981 budget, the new growth rate was actually 11 percent after inflation, more than twice what Mr. Reagan had promised.
The malfunction of the system of planning and review, under deadline pressure, thus led to a decision many Administration officials now regret. And their hopes of getting a second chance to trim the Pentagon budget have proved to be what one Presidential aide now calls ''naive.'' He added: ''What happened was that the Pentagon bureaucracy just dug in on those numbers. Any retreat was considered a great threat to United States security.'' The Highest Bidder In February 1981, Secretary Regan invited the senior Congressmen concerned with tax legislation to join him for breakfast at a private Treasury Department dining room. He told his guests that he hoped for what he called a ''clean bill,'' a measure limited to President Reagan's campaign promises - the personal tax cut of 10 percent a year over three years and a program to ease depreciation formulas for businesses to encourage investment in new plants and equipment.
Representative Dan Rostenkowski, an Illinois Democrat who is chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, interrupted. ''Mr. Secretary,'' he said, ''you know there might be only one train going to Peoria this year. And if there is, everybody is going to want to get on it.''
The others around the table laughed, but the point was serious. The chances were that there would, indeed, be only one tax bill passed that year, and it wasn't likely to be ''clean.'' Every special interest and constituent group in Washington would besiege Congress, demanding special tax breaks, and some of them inevitably would be part of the final package. Responsibility for balancing the competing demands for tax relief rested with Mr. Rostenkowski and his counterpart in the Senate, Bob Dole, chairman of the Finance Committee.
Of course, there were Congressional traditions that would help in the process. Democrats and Republicans on each of the two committees had a history of working hand in hand on tax matters to sort through the competing proposals. Even after agreements had been worked out with colleagues or lobbyists, there was a fail-safe mechanism: The House com-mittee knew that the worst of its deals would be eliminated by the Senate committee, and vice versa. Tax issues, in other words, were so sensitive that compromise was all but mandatory. In fact, as they sat around Secretary Regan's table, both Mr. Rostenkowski and Mr. Dole assumed privately that a deal could be made on the new President's three-year proposal itself, leading to a one-or two-year tax bill.
Since most members of both houses of Congress were unenthusiastic about the Reagan tax-cut measure, how could it have passed? One central reason was the breakdown of traditional procedures and relationships between the Senate and the House. In the face of a tenacious, resourceful President, compromise turned into a pitched battle of tax-cut giveaways, and the fail-safe mechanism failed.
In the Senate, the Majority Leader, Howard H. Baker Jr. of Tennessee, and most of his Republican colleagues had no taste for the three-year tax-cut measure. But they were convinced at strategy sessions with White House officials that the measure should be left intact. This would leave room for the usual compromise solution, a scaling down of the bill to gain Democratic votes in the House.
''Compromise'' was not, however, a word to be bandied about. Nervous White House aides rebuked Senators who spoke publicly of concessions. Senator Dole received the ultimate reprimand after suggesting casually to a reporter that some compromise might eventually be needed. The next day he received a tart, hand-written note from the President, who was recovering from surgery following the attempt on his life in March.
That kind of White House pressure was particularly effective with Mr. Dole, Mr. Baker and other Republican Senate leaders. They were new in their jobs - the party had not controlled the Senate since 1955 - and they were uncertain to what degree they could assert their independence of the President. Moreover, few senior Republican Senators had been great political supporters of Mr. Reagan; Mr. Dole and Mr. Baker, in particular, had actually run against him in 1980 and lost. They were all mindful of the need to prove their loyalty.
''I had to subordinate my own feelings,'' says one Republican Senator. ''I figured, Ronald Reagan was elected the Republican President. That was always in the back of my mind. I'm not here to pick a fight with a brand new President.''
Meanwhile, in the House of Representatives, the Democratic leaders disliked Mr. Reagan's approach to tax cutting and geared up to prepare a bill of their own. Democrats charged that the President's bill, with its across-the-board income-tax reduction, favored the wealthy. Moreover, they felt it would produce giant deficits, forcing Congress to cut social programs. It fell to Dan Rostenkowski, a gregarious and combative protege of the late Mayor Richard J. Daley of Chicago, to seek an alternative.
Mr. Rostenkowski started out with compromise in mind. He and the Democrats at first offered a one-year tax cut but assumed that a compromise on a two-year bill was possible. He knew that Senator Dole was privately ready to deal, and he knew that some in the Administration had begun thinking in terms of compromise. Then Secretary Regan gave the Congressman a sheet of paper containing the outlines of a two-year tax cut, which Mr. Rostenkowski took back to his colleagues for further study.
In early May, though, there was a change in the wind, after Mr. Reagan's preliminary budget cuts came up for a vote in Congress - and sailed right through. Mr. Rostenkowski recalls that he first encountered the change at a secret meeting with Secretary Regan. Mr. Rostenkowski was told that the two-year bill was no longer on the bargaining table. Then he was presented with some new Administration tax ''ideas,'' as they were labeled. They included reductions in estate and gift taxes and in the tax on oil royalties. Unbeknownst to him, while he had been making his rounds of meetings with Secretary Regan and Treasury aides, talking about a tax-cut compromise, another set of aides at the White House had been dangling special tax breaks to win the votes of conservative Democrats from the South and Middle West, the so-called ''boll weevils.'' The White House had suddenly come to the conclusion that it might be possible to win it all.
''You could just feel it in the air,'' says a White House Congressional strategist. ''There was such a feeling of elation over what we had been able to get out of Congress that everybody just wanted to try again and get more.''
Mr. Rostenkowski had a talk with Vice President Bush, an old friend. ''I told him, 'George, if you want a vote on the floor on the third year, I'll give it to you,' '' the Congressman recalls today. In other words, he would not use parliamentary tactics to prevent the House from voting on the three-year tax cut. ''But I said, 'Let's stay out of oil and gas and the estate and gift taxes. Because if it gets to be a bidding war, George, I'll bid.' ''
An Administration official tells of a moment just before the bidding war broke out at the end of May: ''I remember Jim Baker looking tremendously downcast and saying, 'Well, Rosty's dug in and the President's dug in, and we're not going to get the President to change his mind.' Jim said, 'We're going to have to go the other way.' The question none of us knew the answer to was: What would it cost?''
There were two tax-cut bills in the House at this point -the Administration version and the Rostenkowski version, and they were both getting fatter as new tax-cut provisions were piled on in a frantic bid to attract the vote of individual Representatives. Ironically, in the course of the free-for-all, the two bills became more and more alike, offering concessions to many of the same special interests.
As the bidding war got under way, Senator Dole, who had earlier held the loyalist line for a ''clean'' tax bill, returned to the forefront of the battle. He proposed adoption of a so-called ''indexing'' provision, under which an individual's tax rate would be calculated to remove the impact of inflation. Since inflation pushes taxpayers into higher brackets, thereby increasing Federal tax revenues, indexing would cost the Government hundreds of billions of dollars in lost receipts over the next two decades.
When the Senator first sought the indexing provision, White House aides opposed it, but they yielded in the face of his insistence that he needed the measure to win votes. Mr. Dole's fellow Senators, having watched the bidding war in the House, wanted their own chance to earn points with constituents by attaching ''goodies'' to the tax bill. A politician who knows the Senator well offers another explanation: ''Dole figured there was so much junk being put in the tax bill that there might as well be some real tax reform, too.''
The final measure, signed into law on Aug. 13, 1981, contained a three-year, 25 percent tax cut; indexing; new business depreciation allowances, and a dazzling array of tax breaks on oil production, estates, charitable contributions, interest income, deposits into retirement accounts, income from new tax-exempt savings certficiates and other items. A measure intended to encourage investment and spur economic growth had become the biggest, most expensive tax-cut grab bag in history.
There had been some second thoughts. During the spring, Pete V. Domenici of New Mexico, the chairman of the Senate Budget Committee, had received a memorandum from his aide Stephen E. Bell, warning that the budget outlook was ''considerably worse'' than the Administration claimed, with huge deficits looming. A chain-smoking workaholic, Mr. Domenici found himself losing sleep over the prospect. Finally, as the vote neared, he informed Senator Baker that he intended to lead a revolt against the Administration bill.
That rang alarms. Mr. Domenici was called to meetings at the White House with Jim Baker and Dick Darman. They promised they would seek more spending cuts later in the year, including military budget trims, if only he would stay in line now. He was then called to meet with Senator Baker and President Reagan. Finally, Mr. Domenici relented.
Had Mr. Domenici gone ahead with his revolt, he might have affected the outcome, and to this day he remains tortured about his decision. ''I think it'll haunt him for the next 10 years,'' said one of his aides.
The second thoughts about the tax-cut bill have come thick and fast, and there seems more than enough blame to go around. Some Senators have wondered whether Howard Baker and Bob Dole might not have fought for a compromise bill if they had not been so new in their posts. Others have insisted that they were caught by surprise by the Administration's hard-line approach. ''We assumed the House would bail us out on the tax bill,'' said a key Republican Senator's aide. ''Well, we never got bailed out.''
Some White House officials feel that Mr. Rostenkowski was too inflexible in his initial bargaining over the form of the tax cut, that he missed an opportunity to settle on a two-year 20 percent bill when the White House hinted its willingness to compromise. Some Congressional Democrats say that Mr. Rostenkowski was too generous with the tax ''goodies,'' thereby helping to raise the ante of the bidding battle without managing to win the war.
At the Treasury, there are aides who claim that Jim Baker and the White House gave too many concessions too easily. At the White House, there are officials who complain that Secretary Regan failed to drive a hard enough bargain. And in Congress, there are aides and officials who blame both Mr. Regan and Jim Baker, aided and abetted by Ronald Reagan himself.
In fact, the President apparently remained personally aloof from the day-to-day details of the process even as he insisted that his overall principles could not be compromised. At one meeting in the Roosevelt Room of the White House between a group of Presidential aides and a collection of Congressmen of both parties, Secretary Regan beckoned the President to sit down and join the horse-trading - votes for tax breaks. ''Heck, no,'' the President replied. ''I'm going to leave this to you experts.'' The Power of an Image On the evening of Feb. 5, 1981, seated at his desk in the Oval Office, Ronald Reagan delivered his maiden television address as President and offered a fresh pitch for his program of tax cuts. ''Over the past decades,'' he said, ''we've talked of curtailing Government spending so that we can then lower the tax burden. Sometimes we've even taken a run at doing that. But there were always those who told us that taxes couldn't be cut until spending was reduced. Well, you know we can lecture our children about extravagance until we run out of voice and breath. Or we can cure their extravagance simply by reducing their allowance.''
The message was clear: Since the ''children'' who run the Congress lack the discipline to cut Federal spending on their own, and thereby make lower taxes possible, Mr. Reagan would force their hand. He would simply cut the taxes, and the Congressmen would have no choice -they would have to spend less as their allowance of Federal tax revenues dwindled.
It was a strange kind of argument for an advocate of supply-side economics, which holds that major tax cuts quickly spur economic growth, which in turn makes budget trims unnecessary. But this Children's Allowance Theory had a seductive simplicity, a quality that has often distinguished Ronald Reagan's presentation of public issues.
During the weeks following his television appearance, the new President used this theory to good effect to sell his program. At the same time, in a significant supporting role, David Stockman was brought on stage as the compleat budget cutter; he would prove to any doubters that a strong Administration could keep Government extravagance down.
The Children's Allowance Theory, brilliantly framed and enthusiastically presented by the President, helped overcome skepticism among economic traditionalists - Congressional conservatives, for example, who for years had worshiped at the altar of a balanced Federal budget.
One such skeptic was Representative Barber B. Conable Jr., the senior Republican on the House Ways and Means Committee and an upstate New York neighbor -though no fan - of Jack Kemp and supplyside economics. Another was Representative Trent Lott of Mississippi, the minority whip in the House, whose overriding political goal was to reduce the size and scope of the Government.
Scores of prominent businessmen were also shepherded through the White House to hear President Reagan argue his Children's Allowance Theory. Many recalled later that their fears about tax cuts had been dispelled by the President's assurances that they would lead to budget cuts. (Of course, many of these visitors already liked a tax bill so generous toward business.) One of the most important corporate conversions made with the help of the Children's Allowance Theory was that of Donald T. Regan, the former chairman of Merrill Lynch & Company. He yielded his budget-cut-before-tax-cut beliefs, and as Secretary of the Treasury he became the Administration's chief emissary to the business community, assuring skeptics that tax cuts and a balanced budget were not mutually exclusive. When pressed, Mr. Regan hastened to explain that budget cutting was not in his domain, but the responsibility of David Stockman. (It was many months later that Mr. Regan would admit to an associate that he had been ''naive'' about the budget.)
For Secretary Regan, then, as it was for President Reagan, Mr. Stockman provided the tangible evidence of the Administration's commitment to budget cutting. With his graying hair and boy-wonder mastery of the bureaucracy, learned during six years as a Capitol Hill aide and four years as a Michigan Congressman, the 34-year-old Mr. Stockman captured the public's imagination. His ''black books'' were filled with the names of programs to be trimmed, such once-sacred cows as highways, dairy price supports, student loans, job training, public-service jobs, low-income housing, school aid.
So dazzling was his performance that several things went unappreciated. One: The degree to which the plans to increase military spending, which comprises 30 percent of the total budget, would overwhelm the struggle to cut spending elsewhere. Another: the President's decision to leave several sacred cows untouched, such as Social Security, Medicare, civil-service pensions and veterans' benefits. Nearly half the Federal budget consisted of these and other programs that provide open-ended payments to individuals - the socalled ''entitlements'' - and Mr. Reagan knew that Congress was not ready to dismantle the welfare state, as middle-class Americans have come to enjoy it. ''Ronald Reagan was looking for something that would pass,'' says one White House official. ''He was willing to take risks, but not on a sure loser.''
That left Mr. Stockman a problem: With the military and entitlement programs exempted, along with the mandatory costs of servicing the Federal debt, he was forced to seek most of his 1981 savings from less than 20 percent of the budget.
In July, the Congress approved a $700 billion budget incorporating a $35 billion package of Stockman-initiated spending trims. But as budget officials now admit, some $8 billion of that total consisted of accounting gimmicks and phony savings. And before the year was over, even the remaining $27 billion had been wiped out by cost overruns in interest charges on the Federal debt, farm price supports, unemployment compensation and other items.
The tax cuts had trimmed the Children's Allowance, all right, but they ended up spending more than before. Patchwork President Reagan's mountaintop California ranch was shrouded in fog, that day in August 1981, when he proudly signed his program of tax cuts and budget cuts into law. Yet, behind the scenes, Mr. Reagan's advisers were already quietly plotting a series of ''offensives,'' as they called them, to counter the program's effects. Although they could not know until months later that a recession had, statistically speaking, begun the previous month, they knew the economy was faltering as interest rates continued to rise. They and their President would spend the next year trying to extricate themselves.
The first ''offensive'' came just days after the signing when David Stockman, in a private memorandum to the President, called for a cut in the Defense Department budget. Military spending was now growing faster than anyone had anticipated, Mr. Stockman wrote, and to say it could not be trimmed for security reasons was just ''Pentagon blue smoke.''
The President's other immediate aides, impressed by the argument, felt certain Mr. Reagan would go along, and their sentiment was shared with reporters. The President was said not to be pleased to read that he was expected to go along with his staff on the issue.
Whatever the effect of the press reports, Defense Secretary Weinberger mounted a strong attack on the proposed cuts, with a full and elaborate presentation for the President, insisting upon the validity of the Pentagon's security claims. And preparedness won the day: Mr. Reagan sided with his Defense Secretary.
The White House staff, undaunted, scheduled another offensive. Jim Baker, David Stockman and Dick Darman knew they had a kindred spirit in Senator Domenici, chairman of the Senate Budget Committee - who had been stung once before by a Presidential decision to keep the Pentagon budget high. Mr. Domenici worked behind the scenes in the fall to devise a parliamentary scheme whereby a series of new spending cuts, including changes in the entitlement programs, would be incorporated in a single, catch-all resolution. All told, the offensive sought budget savings of more than $40 billion spread over three years.
In September, Mr. Reagan appealed on television for public support of his new package. But it was not to be. Eventually, Congress adopted a resolution that embodied cuts of only $4 billion in one year alone. Mr. Domenici's Republican colleagues on Capitol Hill had grown weary of budget cutting and were inclined to give the supplyside magic some time to work.
According to a White House official, there was also another, lesser reason for the result: the appearance of the article ''The Education of David Stockman'' in the Atlantic Monthly. The suggestion that the budget director had lost faith in supply-side economics and misled Congress doomed the chances of another Stockman-led charge on the budget.
In December and January, the White House staff launched yet another ''offensive'' - a proposal to raise perhaps $45 billion in new taxes in 1983-85. Newspapers came to be filled with items about these plans. Finally, at a staff economic meeting in the Cabinet Room, Mr. Reagan began the session by announcing, ''You know, everybody in the press says that you guys have a conspiracy to talk me into a tax increase.'' By the time the session was over, Mr. Reagan found himself declaring: ''By God, they're right!'' There were still many people close to Mr. Reagan who felt that the supply-side tax cuts had not been given time to have their energizing effect, and, not surprisingly, Representative Jack Kemp was in that group. He led a counteroffensive that convinced the President to reject his aides' advice.
It was not until the spring of 1982 that Republican leaders in Congress, alarmed and emboldened by soaring deficits, joined with the White House staff to persuade Mr. Reagan to accept, in principle, cuts in military spending and new taxes. And it took weeks of haggling and recriminations before the Congress arrived at a package of $98 billion in tax increases for 1983-85 and defense spending cuts worth $30 billion for the same three-year period.
The President plugged for passage of the bill, which he said was needed to eliminate ''unintended'' tax benefits of the earlier taxcut measure - what he later called the ''Christmas tree ornaments that were hung on our program.'' But a few days before its passage in August, he told a news conference that he did not feel bound by the second and third years of the Pentagon spending cuts, which took care of $23 billion of the $30 billion saving.
That backtracking enraged the President's Congressional partners, who had painfully put together the deal making the tax measure possible. And it set the stage for a return performance by those members of Congress like Senator Domenici who believe the Pentagon budget is for cutting. The issue will be raised, most directly, in the review of the Administration's 1984 budget by the budget director and the Secretary of Defense and their staffs. Such discussions usually begin in the early fall, but Mr. Stockman has postponed them until after next month's elections.
The legacy of the Fed's tight-money policies, the three-year tax cut, the defense spending increases and the resulting budget deficits, as most economists view it, has been a recession deeper and longer than might have otherwise occurred. The defense spending and entitlement programs are still growing at several times the rate that tax revenues can possibly be expected to grow. By some estimates, the Federal deficit in the next few years could exceed 5 percent of the gross national product, a level unprecedented in peacetime, sending interest rates soaring again. In 1980 and 1981, the deficit was only about 2 percent of the G.N.P.
Some Reagan advisers say privately that further tax increases might be necessary. And the new Congress will inevitably be asked, once again, to examine such ''sacred cows'' as Social Security to look for trims.
President Reagan has said that it would take a ''palace coup'' to get him to agree to new taxes. Indeed, there is no indication that the President has departed from his belief in the supply-side theory. During the first six months of 1981, Mr. Reagan succeeded in convincing his staff, Congress and the public that this untried approach to energizing the economy should be put into effect. The odds against that achievement were imponderable. Who is to say that he will be unable to withstand the growing pressures to meet the deepening recession with a new economic policy? AFTERWORD Presidents before Ronald Reagan have thought they could defy the odds. Presidents before Ronald Reagan have embarked on programs that had unintended results. But in the case of Reaganomics, the risks and the possibility that the program could backfire were widely recognized, even by members of his own party, and yet the program was enacted into law.
Why? For one thing, the events of 1981 were a triumph of human factors over the inbred conservatism of government institutions. The usual safeguards - the party system in Congress, the independent Federal Reserve, the business community, the Cabinet and the press - all were bypassed or overcome by Mr. Reagan's political skills.
According to James David Barber, a Duke University professor and author of several books on the Presidency, Mr. Reagan was also helped in putting across his program by the average American's attitude toward economics. ''To the public,'' he said, ''economics is like magic, and one economic plan is as plausible as another.''
Surely the timing of the 1980 election was also a decisive factor in 1981. Battered by inflation and confused by such national traumas as the Iran hostage crisis, the voters had grown weary of a President who lectured them about the complexity of their woes. They turned to the man who said he wanted to lead, and who seemed to know where he wanted to go. He interpreted his election victory as a mandate, and many voters felt he should be given a free hand. That has happened before in American history, but seldom has a new President used it to apply so radical a treatment to an ailing body politic.
What happened in 1981 takes on particular importance today. The United States is in the throes of profound economic change. Whole sections of the country are in depression as old industries are phased out. The advent of new technologies is bringing prosperity to some Americans, but poverty to others. And experts have come to recognize that the government machinery to cope with these problems is in need of drastic overhaul.
Reaganomics has deepened the urgency of the crisis. Yet, as the nation moves to find new solutions to its economic woes, the experiences of 1981 may provide an object lesson. Given the manner in which Mr. Reagan's untested program won enactment, Americans may feel that a re-examination of their political system should be their first order of business.

LOANS FOR SOUTH AFRICA ASSAILED IN U.N. REPORT

Author: Bonner, Raymond

Publication info: New York Times , Late Edition (East Coast); New York, N.Y. [New York, N.Y]21 Oct 1982: D.1.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/424445393?accountid=11752

Abstract: Joan Dickie, an information officer at the United States Mission to the United Nations, rejected the idea that the United States had influenced any decision not to publish the report. ''We are not members of the Committee of 24,'' she said. ''We have no power to influence what the committee publishes or does not publish.'' ''Defense expenditures leading to budget deficits, budget deficits leading to inflation, inflation leading to balance-of-payments problems - that is the indirect path by which South Africa arrived at the I.M.F.'s door,'' the report said. ''In addition there was the direct increment to the balance-of-payments deficit caused by rising arms imports.'' The report was sharply critical of the monetary fund's agreement in 1969 to buy gold from South Africa at the official price of $35 an ounce. The report said this decision was ''ostensibly'' for the purpose of stabilizing the world price of gold, but it added, ''In practice, the decision worked to aid South Africa and to destabilize world gold markets.''

Links: http://findit.library.jhu.edu/resolve?url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Anytimes&amp;atitle=LOANS+FOR+SOUTH+AFRICA+ASSAILED+IN+U.N.+REPORT&amp;title=New+York+Times&amp;issn=03624331&amp;date=1982-10-21&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=D.1&amp;au=Bonner%2C+Raymond&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=New+York+Times&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text: A United Nations study sharply critical of the International Monetary Fund's loans to South Africa has languished unpublished for more than a year, according to U.N. officials.
The study charges that loans from the monetary fund have helped South Africa maintain its system of apartheid and have contributed to that country's military buildup. In addition it concludes that the I.M.F. has treated South Africa more favorably than other African countries and has ignored declarations by the General Assembly and Security Council that South Africa's occupation of Namibia is illegal.
Jean Gazarian, director of General Assembly Affairs in the office of the Secretariat, said he could recall no other instances in which a United Nations report of this nature was not published as an official document and translated into the U.N.'s official languages. He called the treatment of this report ''very strange'' but said he did not know what had happened.
Special Panel's Project
The study was commissioned by the Secretariat at the request of the Special Committee of 24. Its jurisdiction includes overseeing the carrying out of United Nations declarations on decolonization.
Frank Abdulah, chairman of the Special Committee of 24, declined to say why the report had not been translated and disseminated like other U.N. studies.
''I think you had better ask the United States Government that,'' said Mr. Abdulah, who is the chief representative to the United Nations from Trinidad and Tobago.
The Reagan Administration, seeking to improve relations with South Africa, has allowed high-ranking South African military officers to come to the United States and has adopted a more flexible policy regarding sales of nuclear materials to South Africa.
But Joan Dickie, an information officer at the United States Mission to the United Nations, rejected the idea that the United States had influenced any decision not to publish the report. ''We are not members of the Committee of 24,'' she said. ''We have no power to influence what the committee publishes or does not publish.''
The I.M.F.'s representative to the United Nations declined to make any public comment. Request for a New Loan
The study has acquired new significance because South Africa recently requested a $1.1 billion loan from the monetary fund. A resolution opposing the loan was introduced by Guinea in the General Assembly yesterday.
According to the study, some $543 million in South African drawings from the I.M.F. from 1975 to 1977 ''helped to pay increases in South African defense expenditures.'' During that period, South Africa's military outlays increased by $450 million, the study found.
''Defense expenditures leading to budget deficits, budget deficits leading to inflation, inflation leading to balance-of-payments problems - that is the indirect path by which South Africa arrived at the I.M.F.'s door,'' the report said. ''In addition there was the direct increment to the balance-of-payments deficit caused by rising arms imports.''
The study charged that I.M.F. loans to South Africa have ''demonstrated to the world financial community that, despite increasingly violent confrontations between the majority black populations and the white minority Government in South Africa, the I.M.F. would continue to support the status quo and the white authorities.'' Share of Credits Analyzed
Without I.M.F. loans, and the potential for future loans, the report continued, South Africa would be faced with the ''domestic financial and political costs of its controversial racial policies and of its illegal occupation of Namibia.''
During recent years, the report charged, South Africa received a ''disproportionate share'' of I.M.F. credits that went to African nations. As an example, the study noted that Nigeria, a nation of comparable economic stature, was a current net contributor of $592 million to the I.M.F. last year while South Africa had a net debt of $10 million.
The report was sharply critical of the monetary fund's agreement in 1969 to buy gold from South Africa at the official price of $35 an ounce. The report said this decision was ''ostensibly'' for the purpose of stabilizing the world price of gold, but it added, ''In practice, the decision worked to aid South Africa and to destabilize world gold markets.''

Playing Games With Real Money

Publication info: New York Times , Late Edition (East Coast); New York, N.Y. [New York, N.Y]10 Sep 1982: A.22.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/424429134?accountid=11752

Abstract: Present law does not presume to tell the Fed what measures or targets it should use, or how high or low to set its objectives. The two Democratic proposals would demand a single rigid approach. Senator [Robert Byrd] would require the Fed to maintain ''real'' short-term interest rates - the difference between actual rates and the level of inflation - at ''historic levels.'' In recent years that would have meant increasing the money supply, on the dubious theory that more money always results in lower interest rates. Even if it worked, the rule could easily sap confidence in the currency and drive inflation higher.

Links: http://findit.library.jhu.edu/resolve?url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=unknown&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Anytimes&amp;atitle=Playing+Games+With+Real+Money%3A+%5BEditorial%5D&amp;title=New+York+Times&amp;issn=03624331&amp;date=1982-09-10&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=A.22&amp;au=&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=New+York+Times&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text: Not to be outdone by the Administration's crowd-pleasing campaign to balance the budget by constitutional amendment, top Democrats in Congress propose now to lower interest rates by legislation. They, too, are being hypocritical and wrong-headed.
With a posse of co-sponsors, the Senate Democratic leader, Robert Byrd, and the House majority leader, Jim Wright, offer bills that would require the Federal Reserve system to focus its operations on the level of interest rates - forevermore. Either bill would be an unprecedented restriction on the management of monetary policy. The Wright bill would go further by directing the President to declare his opinion on every policy move the Fed makes. It would institutionalize blatant political intrusion in a process that is already delicate.
Officially, our central banking system is ''independent'' of White House influence. In practice, it trims its sails to accommodate the policies of the President in power. It would be reckless to do otherwise.
Within this framework, however, the Fed has been free to design and redesign its methods, as it did three years ago in shifting its focus from interest rates to broad aggregates of the money supply. This monetarist approach may not be the best answer to current problems, but it is certainly preferable to political dictation from Capitol Hill.
The itch to curb the Fed at a time like this is understandable. The tightness of monetary policy has riled conservative Republicans as well as liberal Democrats. But why were these radical bills introduced just before the summer recess of a Congressional election year? Are they anything more than campaign fodder?
Present law does not presume to tell the Fed what measures or targets it should use, or how high or low to set its objectives. The two Democratic proposals would demand a single rigid approach. Senator Byrd would require the Fed to maintain ''real'' short-term interest rates - the difference between actual rates and the level of inflation - at ''historic levels.'' In recent years that would have meant increasing the money supply, on the dubious theory that more money always results in lower interest rates. Even if it worked, the rule could easily sap confidence in the currency and drive inflation higher.
The Wright bill would force the Fed to aim instead at long-term rates, an even more difficult technical assignment. Both bills commit the same basic error: they would restrict the Fed's flexibility to adjust to circumstances and give all its work an inflationary bias.
The bill's critics may find it perversely comforting that the House Banking Committee plans only a single day of hearings on the Wright bill. Remember, though, that the House recently approved a major tax increase after no hearings at all. Under the deceptive slogan of ''Balanced Monetary Policy'' - the title of Senator Byrd's bill - this assault on flexibility might be tacked onto other legislation that is guaranteed passage.
If there really oughta be a law, which is doubtful, let it be decently considered.

WORK FORCE SHIFT TIED TO GRIMMER JOBLESS IMPACT

Author: AP

Publication info: New York Times , Late Edition (East Coast); New York, N.Y. [New York, N.Y]13 Aug 1982: A.10.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/424403020?accountid=11752

Abstract: She added that an ''unusual combination of tight monetary policy and expansionary fiscal policy means that there is considerable uncertainty'' about whether an economic recovery can be sustained, and said: ''Without a strong and sustained economic recovery, significant reductions in unemployment will not occur.'' Fauntroy], a Democrat, said lawmakers ''must weigh the benefits of reduced inflation against the costs of increased unemployment that has resulted from an exclusively monetarist anti-inflation policy.'' Links: http://findit.library.jhu.edu/resolve?url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Anytimes&amp;atitle=WORK+FORCE+SHIFT+TIED+TO+GRIMMER+JOBLESS+IMPACT&amp;title=New+York+Times&amp;issn=03624331&amp;date=1982-08-13&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=A.10&amp;au=AP&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=New+York+Times&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text: The effects of unemployment in this recession will probably be more serious than those in other recessions since World War II because of a shift in the kinds of jobs available, a House subcommittee was told today.
''The most important difference between this recession and most others is that it reflects structural change in the economy,'' said M. Harvey Brenner, professor of operations research at Johns Hopkins University in Baltimore.
''Many workers in the extractive and manufacturing sectors are not going to find re-employment at their old jobs, nor are their sons and daughters or younger brothers and sisters going to find work careers in these stable and contracting industries,'' he said, noting that unemployment was highest in the automobile, steel and other high-wage durable goods industries.
''Training for services and communications-sector jobs, and for lighter industrial work, is necessary to bring these displaced workers back into productive roles,'' Professor Brenner said. Unemployment Patterns Studied
He made his comments at the first of two hearings in which the House Banking Committee's Subcommittee on Domestic Monetary Policy is studying how the distribution of unemployment has changed in the current recession and whether the changing work force has affected the lengths and patterns of unemployment.
The subcommittee, under the chairmanship of Walter E. Fauntroy, the District of Columbia Delegate, is also looking at how the budget is affecting unemployment.
Alice M. Rivlin, director of the Congressional Budget Office, said that the jobless rate ''is projected to decline slowly, but to remain above 8.5 percent in the final quarter of 1983.''
But she added that an ''unusual combination of tight monetary policy and expansionary fiscal policy means that there is considerable uncertainty'' about whether an economic recovery can be sustained, and said: ''Without a strong and sustained economic recovery, significant reductions in unemployment will not occur.'' Emphasis on Reducing Inflation
Noting that for the past two years the primary emphasis of monetary policy had been on reducing inflation, Mr. Fauntroy, a Democrat, said lawmakers ''must weigh the benefits of reduced inflation against the costs of increased unemployment that has resulted from an exclusively monetarist anti-inflation policy.''
''If the social, economic and human costs of our present levels of unemployment are relatively small,'' he said, ''we will judge the course of current monetary and economic policies to be correct.''
But he added that ''if, as I believe to be the case, the unemployment rate of 9.8 percent in July understates and conceals the actual degree of suffering and hardship, we need to change our policies so that the road to lower inflation does not leave so much pain and suffering in its wake.''
