DISARMAMENT PANEL WORRIES ABOUT REAGAN POLICY

Author: PAUL LEWIS, Special to the New York Times

Publication info: New York Times , Late Edition (East Coast); New York, N.Y. [New York, N.Y]26 Oct 1981: A.14.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/424212194?accountid=11752

Abstract: Speaking at the end of the session, Mr. [Olof Palme] said there had been ''a general consensus that there is now a strong economic case for disarmament.'' The $500 billion a year spent on weapons, he said, is ''tying up resources and skilled manpower that can be more profitably used in other ways.'' In addition, Mr. Palme said the commission generally agreed that ''the beneficial effects of defense spending on employment and technological development tend to be exaggerated and will become more so in future.'' Prof. Emma Rothschild of M.I.T. told the commission that military spending created ''relatively little employment'' because of the increasing sophistication of modern weapons and that it tended to promote inflation by creating shortages of raw materials and skilled labor.

Links: http://findit.library.jhu.edu/resolve?url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Anytimes&amp;atitle=DISARMAMENT+PANEL+WORRIES+ABOUT+REAGAN+POLICY&amp;title=New+York+Times&amp;issn=03624331&amp;date=1981-10-26&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=A.14&amp;au=PAUL+LEWIS%2C+Special+to+the+New+York+Times&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=New+York+Times&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text: An international panel on disarmament agreed this weekend that the increased military spending that President Reagan is advocating to match Soviet spending risked making the world's economy worse rather than better.
The panel, known as the Independent Commission on Disarmament and Security Issues, was created last year under the chairmanship of former Prime Minister Olof Palme of Sweden to act as a high-level pressure group for world disarmanent.
It took as its model the Brandt Commission on development problems, a group headed by former Chancellor Willy Brandt of West Germany. The commission achieved a major success last week when 22 leaders of industrialized and developing nations held a meeting in Cancun, Mexico. The meeting had been organized at the Brandt Commission's suggestion.
Prominent members of the disarmament commission, which was holding its seventh meeting, include former Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance; Dr. David Owen, former Foreign Secretary of Britain; Georgi A. Arbatov, a member of the Soviet Central Committee; Lieut. Gen. Olusegun Obasanjo, a former Nigerian head of state, and former Prime Minister Mustafa Khalil of Egypt.
Speaking at the end of the session, Mr. Palme said there had been ''a general consensus that there is now a strong economic case for disarmament.'' The $500 billion a year spent on weapons, he said, is ''tying up resources and skilled manpower that can be more profitably used in other ways.''
In addition, Mr. Palme said the commission generally agreed that ''the beneficial effects of defense spending on employment and technological development tend to be exaggerated and will become more so in future.''
At previous meetings, the commission has supported the creation of nuclear-free zones as a concrete step toward more effective arms control; urged the United States and the Soviet Union to preserve their treaty limiting deployment of antiballistic missile systems, and called on Washington and Moscow to negotiate reductions in their European nuclear arsenals, as they have now agreed to do at talks that are to begin in Geneva on Nov. 30.
At closed sessions this weekend, participants said the commission examined studies by outside experts that argued that higher arms spending was more likely to promote inflation and unemployment today than stimulate economic recovery, unlike the situation in World War II, when heavy military spending helped pull the industrial world out of the Depression.
Prof. Lester C. Thurow of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology said the American economy could safely afford any level of military spending considered necessary for national security, provided it was financed properly.
In the Korean War, he said, the United States Government wisely raised taxes and imposed controls on the economy to limit the inflationary impact of higher military spending. But, Mr. Thurow said, President Johnson tried to pay for the Vietnam War while also increasing social spending, leading to inflation and recession.
In Professor Thurow's view, President Reagan is in danger of repeating this mistake by combining an increase in military spending and lower taxes. Already, the professor said, the result is high United States interest rates that are depressing the world economy.
Prof. Emma Rothschild of M.I.T. told the commission that military spending created ''relatively little employment'' because of the increasing sophistication of modern weapons and that it tended to promote inflation by creating shortages of raw materials and skilled labor.
Another study, which was written by a Soviet specialist who was not identified and submitted by the Soviet representatives, blamed the United States and its European allies for the arms race. But what interested Western participants was the study's plea for disarmament on the ground that high military spending is absorbing scarce resources badly needed by civil industry in the Soviet Union as well as in the West.

WALL STREET, FEARING DEFICITS, FINDS REAGAN MIXED BLESSING

Author: Silk, Leonard

Publication info: New York Times , Late Edition (East Coast); New York, N.Y. [New York, N.Y]13 Sep 1981: A.1.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/424186965?accountid=11752

Abstract: Not everyone on Wall Street is critical of the President. Morris Cohen, an economic consultant, describes Mr. [Ronald Reagan]'s leadership as ''almost breathtaking'' and predicts that his program ''should prove highly benefici al to the economy in the next 12 to 18 months.'' ''The big concern is insuring that the President's program doesn't result in a massive budget deficit,'' John K. Castle, president of Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Inc., said last Thursday. ''If in fact the outcome were a larger debt and larger deficit, there is no doubt it would continue to have an adverse impact on the securities markets.'' ''I don't believe the market is rejecting the Reagan program, per se'' Thomas Johnson, executive vice president of Chemical Bank's Treasury group, agreed. ''It is saying that the increases being proposed in defense spending, combined with the size of the budget so far and the prospect of zero cutbacks in Social Security, can only mean a deficit that will put continued pressure on interest rates.''

Links: http://findit.library.jhu.edu/resolve?url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Anytimes&amp;atitle=WALL+STREET%2C+FEARING+DEFICITS%2C+FINDS+REAGAN+MIXED+BLESSING&amp;title=New+York+Times&amp;issn=03624331&amp;date=1981-09-13&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=A.1&amp;au=Silk%2C+Leonard&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=New+York+Times&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text: The Reagan Administration is struggling to decipher an apparent and annoying contradiction: Why, if Mr. Reagan has done so much for business, isn't its applause rolling in? Why, if Wall Street supported his tax cuts, budget cuts and restrictive monetary policies, is the Street now so critical of the Reagan program and driving down the values of stocks and bonds?
Part of the explanation emerges from comments by a broad range of Wall Street figures. This is that the Reagan program did in fact give most of what it wanted to Wall Street - that assemblage of stockbrokers and bond dealers, bankers, investment counselors, financial economists, investors, traders, speculators, corporate treasurers and chief executives who buy and sell securities. But the comments show that Wall Street also woke up with more than it expected, and that ''extra'' has revived fears of Federal deficits running out of control.
Wall Street supported the tax program, including 25 percent in cuts in personal income taxes over three years, cuts in the top income tax rate to 50 percent from 70, cuts in estate and gift taxes, accelerated depreciation, tax breaks for savers and investors and much else. But then it took fright when it saw tax cuts totaling $750 billion over the next five years, plus climbing military and nonmilitary spending, even after the Reagan trims in social programs. In Wall Street's view, that all means a string of budget deficits as far as the eye can see.
''Clearly, the budget is heading in a trend toward a larger deficit, rather than less,'' Michel David-Weill, senior partner of Lazard Freres & Company, the investment house, said. ''This is inflationary in and of itself.''
Not everyone on Wall Street is critical of the President. Morris Cohen, an economic consultant, describes Mr. Reagan's leadership as ''almost breathtaking'' and predicts that his program ''should prove highly benefici al to the economy in the next 12 to 18 months.''
But Mr. Cohen is an exception on the Street. The thinking of many of those who have put their remarks on the record is that budget deficits mean heavy Government demands on the credit markets, and that means trouble. With the Federal Reserve holding a tight rein on money and credit, it means persistently high interest rates. That is bad news for stocks and bonds, and bad news, too, for autos, housing, state and local governments, small businesses and all others dependent on credit and the price of money. 'Adverse Impact' on Markets
''The big concern is insuring that the President's program doesn't result in a massive budget deficit,'' John K. Castle, president of Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Inc., said last Thursday. ''If in fact the outcome were a larger debt and larger deficit, there is no doubt it would continue to have an adverse impact on the securities markets.''
''I don't believe the market is rejecting the Reagan program, per se'' Thomas Johnson, executive vice president of Chemical Bank's Treasury group, agreed. ''It is saying that the increases being proposed in defense spending, combined with the size of the budget so far and the prospect of zero cutbacks in Social Security, can only mean a deficit that will put continued pressure on interest rates.''
The Reagan White House has reacted with increasing exasperation - and Republican leaders in Congress with increasing anger - to Wall Street's negative reaction, as though the financial community had let down its man. Senator Howard H. Baker of Tennessee, the majority leader, even warned Wall Street of reprisals in the form of ''credit controls, reorganizing the Federal Reserve, a windfall-profits tax on interest income, and wage and price controls.''
But if Washington's Reagan supporters were disappointed in Wall Street, they should not have been surprised. Connally Had Most Support
Ronald Reagan was not Wall Street's first choice for President, most importantly because it feared the risks of his proposals for large tax cuts in the face of high inflation. If anyone, John B. Connally, Secretary of the Treasury in the Nixon Administration, commanded most support from the business and financial establishment. And it was George Bush, another establishment Republican candidate for President, who called Mr. Reagan's proposed economic program, especially the huge tax cuts, ' 'voodoo economics.''
According to the supply-side school of economics, the Reagan tax cuts would give business and investors new incentives and thereby touch off a burst of economic activity that would more than make up for the lost tax revenues. This expectation has required a leap of faith that conservative Wall Street has been unwilling to venture.
Most recently Wall Street's alarm was intensified by analyses of the budget for fiscal 1982, which begins only two weeks from now on Oct. 1, showing that the Reagan Administration's forecast of a deficit of $42.8 billion was too optimistic. The Congressional Budget Office estimated that the deficit would be about $65 billion in the new fiscal year.
Wall Street's most respected economists generally agreed with the Congressional estimate. The mounting cost of interest payments by Government would alone account for most of the underestimate by the Reagan Administration. Large Fiscal Impact Seen
The Conference Board, a nonpartisan business research body, placed the deficit for fiscal 1982 in a range of $57.5 billion to $62.5 billion, but said the true picture was far more stimulative than such figures implied. It predicted that large increases in military expenditures and tax cuts would give the economy a ''massive'' fiscal thrust of $107.3 billion, or 3.33 percent of gross national product, in fiscal 1982. That compared with only $34.6 billion in fiscal 1981, or 1.25 percent of gross national product.
Beyond fiscal 1982, analysts warned that the Reagan program was highly unlikely to produce the balanced budget the President had advertised for fiscal 1984. Data Resources, Inc. estimated that the budget deficit would climb from $62.5 billion in 1981 to $75.7 billion in 1984 - and that it would continue to climb, reaching $90.8 billion in fiscal 1986.
''They are trying to turn around overnight a system and spending patterns we have lived with for decades,'' said Seth Glickenhaus, director of Glickenhaus & Company, a Wall Street investment advisory firm. ''It's just not that simple.''
As painful as such appraisals were to the stock market, which tends to look only months, or maybe minutes, ahead, they were lethal to the long-term bond market. That market, already sinking before Wall Street analysts had added up the budgetary implications of the Reagan tax cuts and the military buildup, sank to record lows. Bond Yields Soar
Yields on bonds soared to record levels, as did interest rates on long-term mortgages. Unless something was done to bring down those rates, the implications for both capital investment and housing construction would be severe.
''In 1979, when all the investors were promised a balanced budget, a $1,000 Treasury bond came out at 9 1/8 maturing in the year 2009,'' Robert L. Shoemaker, manager of the Government trading department of Paine, Webber, Jackson & Curtis Inc., said last week. ''Today that same bond is selling for $635. This market is going to seek a level to hide at until it has some proof positive that inflationary deficits are not going to continue to eat away at the value of bond coupons.''
Wall Street's doubts did come as something of a surprise in Washington. For one thing, very few Wall Street leaders criticized the President publicly. Some swallowed doubts because they sought favors - in the tax legislation, for instance - but also they were plainly reluctant to attack a President they like and heartily agree with on many issues.
It is also true that the White House has not been especially attentive to Wall Street or to big business. According to one of the President's long-time business friends from California, Mr. Reagan has yet to develop close new ties to leading business figures. He still listens to old friends, who typically are self-made entrepreneurs, not from the Wall Street or corporate establishment. Appointments by Reagan
During his campaign, in an effort to forestall criticism from the financial establishment, Mr. Reagan gave influential roles to such economists as Alan Greenspan, the Wall Street economist and chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers under President Ford, and George P. Shultz, president of Bechtel, the big international construction firm and Secretary of the Treasury under President Nixon.
The effort to reconcile the views of these traditional conservatives with the unorthodox supply-side economics produced the campaign budget document of Nov. 9, 1980, in which steep cuts in the budget were combined with the big tax cuts to achieve budget balance by 1984.
It was like trying to square the circle. From the beginning, such traditionalists as Mr. Greenspan expressed grave doubts ab out the taxcuts and the sudden economic surge that was supposed to follow. The true signific ance of the tax cuts, Mr. Greenspan said, was not the promised spur to business, but rather the cuts in Federal spending that would ha ve to follow, to keep the budget in balance.
It was also an effort to reassure the monetarists of the financial world - disciples of the belief, most forcefully promulgated by Prof. Milton Friedman, that slowing the growth of the money supply is the only true way to stop inflation - that led Mr. Reagan to appoint both monetarists and supply-siders to his Administration. He named a monetarist, Beryl Sprinkel, a close Friedman disciple, to be Under Secretary of the Treasury for Monetary Policy, and a supply-sider, Norman Ture, to be the Under Secretary for Tax Policy. Regan Named Treasury Head
Indeed, Mr. Reagan named a Wall Streeter, Donald T. Regan, the former chairman of Merrill Lynch, Inc., to be his Secretary of the Treasury, to yoke these contradictory theories and theorists together.
Yet Wall Street was unconvinced. By May the markets had made clear that they found the President's design for restoring budget balance and reducing interest rates incredible. Despite the President's demonstration that he could win Congressional approval for his deep cuts in nonmilitary spending - a showing his supporters said would strengthen the markets - long-term bond prices plunged, short-term interest rates climbed and equity markets weakened.
For a while, Mr. Reagan's top economic officials argued before Congress that the prospective deficits did not matter; only the money supply mattered. Mr. Regan, the Treasury Secretary, told the Senate Finance Committee in mid-May not to worry that the Administration's tax bill would be inflationary, because ''inflation can be controlled through the money supply.''
Whatever effect this had on the Senate, Wall Street was unimpressed. President Reagan criticized the Street as unintelligent in economic matters, a truth he said he had picked up from Secretary Regan. Response From Wall Street
But one of the top Wall Streeters, Peter G. Peterson, chairman of Lehman Brothers Kuhn Loeb Inc., who had been Secretary of Commerce in the Nixon Administration, responded on June 25:
''Wall Street has been told once again, at the highest levels, that it does not offer good advice,'' Mr. Peterson said. ''Yet, because the Street i s not a message, but only a mediu m, the concept of Wall Street advice, like the concept of a Wall Str eet spokesman, is a kind of contradiction. The Street speaks only on tape - in prices andspreads - and these signals come from all ove r the world.
''Blaming us for the implicit message,'' Mr. Peterson concluded, ''is like the fat man blaming his obesity on the waiter.'' Though such criticism by the Wall Street establishment annoyed the White House, President Reagan sought to oblige by reducing the fiscal stimulus in his budget. This led him into one of his few political blunders: the hasty effort to cut an additional $46 billion from Social Security benefits over the next five years. Tax Cut Scaled Down
The President again sought to appease Wall Street by scaling down his proposed tax cut from 30 percent over three years to 25 percent, and this proposal stuck. But in the bidding war with the Democrats over the tax bill in Congress, sufficient additional cuts were added to make the tax cuts at least as big as Mr. Reagan had originally proposed.
Mr. Reagan's advisers fully expected that, once the tax bill, with its benefits to business and the financial institutions, was in place, Wall Street would celebrate. It certainly had got most of what it wanted, both directly in lower tax rates and indirectly through the impact on after-tax corporate earnings and the encouragement to individual as well as corporate savers and investers. Though it did not get a shorter holding period for long-term capital gains, this seemed only a small part of its persistent distress, which is linked primarily to budget deficits and high interest rates.
What Wall Street now wants is a stricter budget and fiscal policy, which would remove some of the burden from tight money and high interest rates. The traditional conservatives of Wall Street, including many pragmatic monetarists, are calling for major cuts in the military budget, amounting to $30 billion or more, by fiscal 1984, as well as further cuts in nonmilitary programs.
Although Mr. Reagan has indicated his willingness to trim his military budget, he is still struggling to minimize the military cuts or even to insist that he will meet his aim of 7 percent annual increases in military spending, adjusted for inflation. And he has renewed his promises to cut nonmilitary spending as well.
His current aim is to reduce the fiscal 1982 budget by an ad ditional $1 0 billion to $15 billion, and to cut $75 billion more from the budg ets for fiscal years 1983 and 1984. But how this is to be done is st ill to be decided, and Wall Street, betting its own as well as its c ustomers' money, is not yet convinced.

GERMAN URGES U.S. TO BATTLE INFLATION WITH FISCAL POLICY

Author: LEONARD SILK, Special to the New York Times

Publication info: New York Times , Late Edition (East Coast); New York, N.Y. [New York, N.Y]22 July 1981: D.19.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/424137962?accountid=11752

Abstract: If the United States has not changed the Europeans' attitude here, Secretary [Donald T. Regan] declared that, on the other hand, the Europeans had not changed what he described as the Reagan Administration's ''strength and determination'' - but what he granted might seem to them ''stubborn or foolish'' policies. Mr. Regan, former chairman of Merrill Lynch, the stockbrokers, said he had told Count Lambsdorff's chief, Chancellor Helmut Schmidt, that there was ''something screwy'' about the financial market's reaction to efforts by the central bank to make more reserves available to curb the rise in interest rates. ''If we pump reserves in now,'' Mr. Regan said, ''we'll blow rates sky high.'' 'Anxiety' in the Markets He added that these were matters for argument among the finance and economic ministers, not for debate among ''heads of state.'' He said it would be ''an offense to the President'' to try to explore such ''sophisticated'' issues as what he regards as a primitive form of monetarism on the American side.

Links: http://findit.library.jhu.edu/resolve?url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Anytimes&amp;atitle=GERMAN+URGES+U.S.+TO+BATTLE+INFLATION+WITH+FISCAL+POLICY&amp;title=New+York+Times&amp;issn=03624331&amp;date=1981-07-22&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=D.19&amp;au=LEONARD+SILK%2C+Special+to+the+New+York+Times&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=New+York+Times&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text: Otto von Lambsdorff, the West German Minister of Economics, expressed sharp disagreement today with the contention of top United States officials that the West European governments had offered no alternatives to the monetary, fiscal and foreign exchange rate policies pursued by the Reagan Administration.
In an interview by telephone at Chateau Montebello, Count Lambsdorff stressed that the West German concern was not over the goal of bringing inflation down but rather over the way the United States was going about it.
Voicing the same misgivings expressed by other Europeans and by the Canadians, he asked: ''Is there a justified mix between United States monetary and fiscal policy?''
The West German official contended that the answer was no - that the United States Government was overloading the burdens of fighting inflation on the monetary side.
Overloading monetary policy, he said, was driving interest rates in the United States and Europe higher than needed. The remedy, he thought, was for United States fiscal policy - that is, changes in taxes, government spending and the budget deficit - to be used more heavily to control inflation. U.S. Tries Persuasion
President Reagan and Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan have sought here to persuade the Europeans that they were wrong in their appraisal of United States fiscal policy.
Mr. Regan, interviewed at the Skyline Hotel in Ottawa, said he had asked the Europeans, in meeting after meeting: ''Do you realize what we are doing in the area of budget cutting?''
He stressed that over the next five years, the Reagan Administration would be cutting a cumulative total of $275 billion from President Jimmy Carter's budget projections.
But Secretary Regan and other Americans appear to have had little success in changing the Europeans' attitude that American fiscal policy was too loose. Mr. Regan said he had been successful only with Sir Geoffrey Howe, Britain's Chancellor of the Exchequer, but conceded that he might have needed little convincing, given the like approaches of the Reagan and Thatcher Governments. 'Strength and Determination'
If the United States has not changed the Europeans' attitude here, Secretary Regan declared that, on the other hand, the Europeans had not changed what he described as the Reagan Administration's ''strength and determination'' - but what he granted might seem to them ''stubborn or foolish'' policies.
Count Lambsdorff also expressed the view that the United States was conducting its monetary policy in too rigid and doctrinaire a way, trying to control the money supply on a week-to-week basis. He said West Germany had managed to control its money supply without forcing interest rates to such ''extraordinary'' levels.
But Mr. Regan, former chairman of Merrill Lynch, the stockbrokers, said he had told Count Lambsdorff's chief, Chancellor Helmut Schmidt, that there was ''something screwy'' about the financial market's reaction to efforts by the central bank to make more reserves available to curb the rise in interest rates. ''If we pump reserves in now,'' Mr. Regan said, ''we'll blow rates sky high.'' 'Anxiety' in the Markets
Count Lambsdorff insisted, nevertheless, that the efforts of the Federal Reserve, spurred by the Administration, to keep control of the money supply on a continuous basis had led to ''unnecessary unrest and anxiety'' in financial markets.
He added that these were matters for argument among the finance and economic ministers, not for debate among ''heads of state.'' He said it would be ''an offense to the President'' to try to explore such ''sophisticated'' issues as what he regards as a primitive form of monetarism on the American side.
However, the West German official added that a debate among finance ministers had been conducted in the presence of Edwin Meese 3d, counselor to the President, whom he described as ''an interested listener.''
At a news conferences, Mr. Meese was explicit in denying that the Europeans had offered criticism or counterproposals to the American policy mix. ''They didn't offer any alternatives or criticize what we are doing,'' he said, asserting that there was ''not any suggestion that we change our tax cut, particularly as they understood the facts of the tax cut, and as they recognize the fact that we have to improve saving and improve investment.'' U.S. Tax Policies Doubted
In the interview, Count Lambsdorff said: ''I am doubtful that the tax cut will mean revitalizing capital expenditures, and I asked the Secretary where he got the evidence that it would generate savings and investment and not consumption.'' He said he did not share the belief of the Administration that the tax cuts would bring up the savings rate.
The Economics Minister was also critical of the United States for its unwillingness to intervene in foreign exchange markets to prevent erratic movements disturbing to other countries.
Count Lambsdorff said the notion of nonintervention in the foreign exchange markets simply ''fits into the textbook of monetarism.'' He was critical of Beryl Sprinkel, United States Under Secretary of the Treasury for Monetary Affairs, for pushing his belief in monetarism so rigidly and aggressively. But he added: ''At least it is our impression that he has started to listen.''

DON'T LET THIS SUMMER BE THE LAST

Author: Owen, Henry; Henry Owen was President Carter's Ambassador at Large and was in charge of the White House coordinating teams for the London, Bonn, Tokyo and Venice economic summit meetings.

Publication info: New York Times , Late Edition (East Coast); New York, N.Y. [New York, N.Y]19 July 1981: A.4.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/424139367?accountid=11752

Abstract: T HE Ottawa economic summit meeting could be the most important summit yet. Links: http://findit.library.jhu.edu/resolve?url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Anytimes&amp;atitle=DON%27T+LET+THIS+SUMMER+BE+THE+LAST&amp;title=New+York+Times&amp;issn=03624331&amp;date=1981-07-19&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=A.4&amp;au=Owen%2C+Henry%3BHenry+Owen+was+President+Carter%27s+Ambassador+at+Large+and+was+in+charge+of+the+White+House+coordinating+teams+for+the+London%2C+Bonn%2C+Tokyo+and+Venice+economic+summit+meetings.&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=New+York+Times&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text: T HE Ottawa economic summit meeting could be the most important summit yet. The heads of government of the seven main industrial countries will meet to address not only the usual specific issues - macro-economic policy, energy, trade, etc. -but also the future of economic summitry itself, and, thus, of the cooperation among the heads of government that has enabled them to confront serious and unsolved domestic economic problems in the later 1970's without relapsing into the beggar-thy-neighbor economic policies with which their predecessors reacted to such problems in the 1930's.
When Ottawa convenes tomorrow, France, the United States, Britain West Germany, Japan, Italy and Canada, in that order, will each have played host to a summit meeting. At Ottawa they will have to decide whether a new cycle should be started and, if so, under what ground rules. The central question will be whether summit meetings should be converted from decision-making meetings into forums for general conversation about strategy, beginning with Ottawa itself. At first glance, this seems like an issue of less-than-shattering importance, but a review of past summit meetings suggests that a good deal is at stake.
Economic summitry began in 1975 when the leaders of major industrial countries were confronted by a new set of international economic problems in the wake of the first oil shock. Chancellor Helmut Schmidt of West Germany and President Valery Giscard d'Estaing of France concluded that these problems could only be resolved if the heads of government met. A series of lower-level meetings had failed to make progress.
The most serious of these disagreements was that between France and the United States on international monetary policy. The Bretton Woods system of fixed exchange rates had broken down; French failure to accept the shift to flexible rates endangered efficient functioning of the world monetary system.
At the Rambouillet summit meeting in November 1975, the French President accepted the move to flexible exchange rates in return for an agreement from the other leaders that national macro-economic policies should be coordinated, so as to narrow the resulting monetary fluctuations. But the bargain was not fulfilled.
When the leaders met a year later in Puerto Rico, they found that, although there had been improvement on the international monetary front, ''needed stability has not yet been restored'' -that is, coordination of domestic economic policies had not been achieved. To make good this failure, they pledged to give top priority to fighting inflation, even if this meant slowing the rate of economic recovery in some of their countries.
That agreement was short-lived. President Carter came to office committed to an early acceleration in economic growth. The British Government also favored higher growth, particularly by West Germany, whose expansion it thought would help other European countries increase their exports to the Federal Republic. The German and Japanese reactions were unenthusiastic, to put it mildly.
After some fairly sharp argument in preparatory meetings, the London meeting agreed that countries with stronger economies - Germany, Japan and the United States - should seek higher rates of growth, while the other countries should concentrate on fighting inflation.
T HE fact that only the United States fulfilled the growth target pledged at London should not obscure the fact that Germany and Japan took additional expansionist actions that they would not otherwise have adopted. Indeed, their actions, which significantly helped their trading partners without generating increased inflation at the time, were a more beneficial result of this summit meeting than the United States expansionist measures, which clearly reflected an underestimate of the inflationary threat in America.
Media emphasis on the London summit meeting's macro-economic decisions overshadowed what may have been its more lasting achievement - reviving the Multilateral Trade Negotiations, in which prospects for movement then seemed poor to zero.
At London, the heads of government committed themselves to achieve major progress toward substantial reductions in tariff and nontariff barriers, in agriculture as well as industry, before the end of the year. This commitment settled the question of whether the outcome of these negotiations should be a minipackage, as favored by the French, or the deeper cuts in trade barriers and wider coverage proposed by President Carter.
Without this high-level agreement on goals and timing, the Multilateral Trade Negotiations would almost certainly not have been concluded successfully, in the judgment of Robert Strauss, President Carter's chief trade negotiator, and others close to them. And, without a trade agreement, a reversion to protectionism, with consequent higher inflation and unemployment, might well have followed.
Pressed for still further stimulus measures at the Bonn summit meeting in July 1978, Chancellor Schmidt shrewdly perceived his bargaining power. He widened the agenda and insisted that any German economic stimulus should depend on action to reduce United States oil consumption, which he and the other leaders considered a major cause of rising oil prices.
After hard bargaining, a deal was struck - Mr. Schmidt promised to adopt a stimulus equal to 1 percent of Germany's gross national product, and Mr. Carter promised to decontrol oil prices by the end of 1980 - a move that both his immediate predecessors in the White House had considered politically infeasible. The German commitment was punctiliously fulfilled when the Bundestag reconvened. The United States decision to decontrol oil took longer to carry out, but it was probably the most useful (and the most politically painful) economic decision President Carter made.
It led to a substantial and growing reduction in American oil consumption and imports, which proved much more sensitive to price changes than many of his advisers had expected. If some of Germany's trading partners benefited from the economic expansion that it pledged at Bonn (which Mr. Schmidt has since argued contributed to later German inflation), oil importing nations benefited even more from United States decontrol, which marked a decisive turning point in American energy policy.
At the June 1979 Tokyo summit meeting, energy again came to the fore, as a result of a marginal excess of global oil demand over supply, which had generated a catastrophic run-up in oil spot prices, followed by a large increase in the official prices of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries. To limit the damage, i.e., prevent the main industrial countries from bidding against each other for scarce oil supplies, the United States proposed national oil import ceilings. But the European Economic Community leaders, who had begun the practice of fixing E.E.C. positions shortly before each annual economic summit, had just decided on an overall community ceiling instead. The United States was unimpressed. It argued that so long as the power to enforce ceilings resided in the national governments, national ceilings were essential.
After bitter argument throughout the first day at Tokyo on this point between President Carter and the four European heads, President Giscard d'Estaing broke with the E.E.C. position, which had been adopted over his objections, and accepted national oil import ceilings. The other European heads of government had little choice but to follow suit, albeit reluctantly.
In their anxiety to protect each of their national economies, the leaders could only agree on ceilings whose aggregate total exceeded the amount of oil exports available.
Nonetheless, acceptance of the principle of oil import ceilings proved useful. In subsequent ministerial meetings of the International Energy Agency, the summit conference participants and other I.E.A. members agreed on lower current import ceilings than those fixed at Tokyo and on procedures for fixing future import targets that could be converted into national ceilings whenever ministers agreed that the imbalance between oil supply and demand made this necessary.
The industrial countries were finally getting their energy act together, offering hope, not yet perceived by Americans who waited in long gasoline lines that summer, and an alternative to the divisive competition for scarce oil imports that might have otherwise followed.
At Japanese and United States initiative, North-South issues were also discussed at Tokyo. The London and Bonn summit meetings had already given a push to needed replenishment of the World Bank, its soft loan affiliate the International Development Association, and the regional development banks - which provided, among them, much of the aid going to developing countries.
At Tokyo, the need to help developing countries increase food production was emphasized, and an American proposal to double the resources of the program for international agricultural research coordinated by the World Bank was adopted. This made few headlines, but it greatly strengthened the work of international agricultural research institutions, which had pioneered the green revolution and, thus, have probably done as much for the human condition as any international activity since World War II.
Energy and North-South relations again dominated the 1980 summit meeting in Venice, and once more the emphasis was on specific decisions -not general conversation.
After the disastrous experience of the 1979 oil price run-up, the heads of government had little trouble agreeing that their countries should increase their production of alternative energy sources by the equivalent of 15 million to 20 million barrels of oil a day by 1990. Recognizing that the greater part of this increase had to come from coal, the leaders called on coal exporting nations - notably the United States - and coal importers in Europe and Japan, to take specific actions to double the use of coal by 1990.
To insure that these and other energy pledges were fulfilled, a special seven-nation group was set up to report at Ottawa on what each country was doing to fulfill its pledge.
T HE Venice summit meeting's discussion of North-South issues converged with its consideration of energy. The heads of government were anxious that the developing countries produce more energy, not only to help these countries, but to insure that pressure on world prices, which would hobble the industrial countries' growth, did not revive when world economic growth resumed. They urged the World Bank to explore means of increasing aid to developing countries for energy production, including the possibility of creating a new World Bank affiliate or facility for this purpose. Since Venice, most summit countries - the United States excepted -have come to support creation of this.
Against the background of this record, it is doubtful that the leaders at Ottawa will decide to give up summit meetings. Too much has been accomplished in past meetings, and too many unsolved international economic problems remain. They may well conclude, however, that Ottawa and future economic summit meetings should eschew specific decisions. Press reports suggest that the Reagan Administration leans toward this view. If so, that view will prevail. Without United States leadership, difficult and painful decisions to meet international economic problems are unlikely.
There is one area in which avoiding decisions and confining summits to a general exchange of views makes sense: macro-economic policy. At Ottawa, the European countries will press the United States to moderate its tax cuts, so that there will be less American reliance on high interest rates to control inflation. All countries will urge the new French Government not to fuel inflation and cut productivity with too much intervention in the economy.
But there will be no early changes in national policies by either Government as a result, since both are bound by commitments to powerful domestic constituencies. Over the longer term, this summit pressure may have a useful effect; but in the main, macro-economic policy will continue to be shaped by domestic pressure.
I N other areas of economic policy, however, discussion of trade, energy, and North-South policy that does not yield specific decisions will leave important concrete problems unresolved, and it will leave the media and the interested public unimpressed.
But will it be feasible to make specific decisions at Ottawa? On energy, the report of the monitoring group set up at Venice should lead the summit participants to agree that they will remove existing obstacles to increased coal trade.
The chief offender here is the United States. Our ports need dredging to accommodate the larger ships that will be increasingly used in coal trade. This function is reserved by law for the Federal Government, which is now no longer able to finance it. Failure of Congress and the executive branch to agree on legislation to transfer this function to individual states, some of which are willing and able to fill the gap, is both slowing the world shift from oil to coal and doing considerable changes to the United States coal industry. Administration leadership is needed in trying to develop a compromise bill that will accommodate the divergent interests of different states in sufficient degree to pass.
Canada's Prime Minister, Pierre Elliott Trudeau, is reported to believe that Ottawa is also a good place to give a push to the Venice proposal for a World Bank energy affiliate, which would provide more resources (particularly from OPEC and the private sector) to help developing countries increase their energy production and, thus, improve the balance between energy supply and demand.
The Reagan Administration is skeptical, and budgetary obstacles to even a modest United States appropriation for a new international program are evident.
A compromise may be found in a recent proposal that the World Bank's callable capital - the capital that its member nations agree to provide in case there is a default on World Bank loans - be increased without any requirement for back-up paid-in capital, since there has never been such a default. A rise in callable capital would not require a United States appropriation; yet, it would enable the World Bank to raise its energy lending.
The summit meeting could pave the way for agreement on this proposal by urging the new World Bank management to work out with member countries the best way to increase its energy lending without cutting down on other important World Bank programs (e.g., to increase developing countries' food production). It could also make clear that it did not expect increased World Bank lending for energy to replace private investment, so as to meet the Reagan Administration's concerns on this point.
The Ottawa participants should also agree on the need to fulfill their countries' existing pledges for financing of the multilateral development banks. In appraising the United States' failure in this respect, other leaders will not be impressed by our fiscal problems. They have had similar problems, and yet they have fulfilled their countries' World Bank pledges. Nothing less than the future of the World Bank Group and the International Monetary Fund, which could not long survive a drastic reduction in World Bank hard and soft lending to its customers, is at stake.
One of the reasons the Great Depression of the 1930's was so much worse than any of its predecessors was the absence of a lender of last resort to help countries in distress. The Bretton Woods agreement setting up the World Bank and the I.M.F. was designed to fill this gap. If the Ottawa meeting does nothing more than agree that preserving this system is essential, if we are not to sink back into a world depression, it will have more than justified itself.
An Ottawa outcome that thus focused on energy and North-South decisions would maintain the tradition of summit meetings that do something about international economic problems, instead of merely talking.
There will always be a healthy element of skepticism in press (as in public) attitudes toward summitry. In part, this reflects the inevitable gap between what public opinion wants a summit meeting to accomplish, and what it can accomplish. This gap is inherent in the fact that the summit countries' market economies are not in control of their governments, and that in one important area - macro-economic policy - domestic forces clearly overshadow international discussion in shaping decisions.
These facts should be taken into account in setting the agenda and goals of summit meetings. Exaggerated rhetoric about their purpose and effects should be avoided, in favor of the kinds of practical business that past summit conferences have been able to achieve - reaching specific economic decisions in areas where this is feasible, and offering a forum for general exchange of views where it is not.
If Ottawa follows and confirms this approach, it will have served us well.

Business Forum; ECONOMIC AFFAIRS: IN THE C.P.I. WE CANNOT TRUST

Author: Nordhaus, William

Publication info: New York Times , Late Edition (East Coast); New York, N.Y. [New York, N.Y]12 July 1981: A.3.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/424133537?accountid=11752

Abstract: Recent price behavior raises several important questions for the near-term outlook for the economy: Why has inflation slowed over the past few months? More specifically, do recent events reflect a change in the underlying inflation rate or a temporary reprieve? Why are financial markets still nervous in the face of the ''good news'' on both the inflation and political fronts? In analyzing inflation, we must distinguish ''underlying inflation'' from the actual inflation experience. Although there are several ways of measuring underlying inflation, perhaps the most useful is the movement in unit labor costs. Unit labor costs are a key element because they form three-quarters of all input costs in national output. The central point for the prognosis on inflation, however, is that movements in oil or food prices lead to one-shot, or transient, declines in inflation. We simply cannot count on a progressive fall in the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Country's selling price. Until and unless these transient elements affect the underlying inflation rate, there is little hope that a decline in inflation below the underlying 8 to 10 percent range will be durable.

Links: http://findit.library.jhu.edu/resolve?url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Anytimes&amp;atitle=Business+Forum%3B+ECONOMIC+AFFAIRS%3A+IN+THE+C.P.I.+WE+CANNOT+TRUST&amp;title=New+York+Times&amp;issn=03624331&amp;date=1981-07-12&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=A.3&amp;au=Nordhaus%2C+William&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=New+York+Times&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text: T HE United States has received very good, and quite surprising, news on the inflation front in the last three months. After rising at rates of around 13 percent annually since 1978, consumer price inflation has slowed to an annual rate of 7 percent over the last three months.
This good news has been cheered by the Administration. But the financial markets have not received the surprise with the hoped-for fall in interest rates and boom in stock prices.
Recent price behavior raises several important questions for the near-term outlook for the economy: Why has inflation slowed over the past few months? More specifically, do recent events reflect a change in the underlying inflation rate or a temporary reprieve? Why are financial markets still nervous in the face of the ''good news'' on both the inflation and political fronts?
In analyzing inflation, we must distinguish ''underlying inflation'' from the actual inflation experience. Although there are several ways of measuring underlying inflation, perhaps the most useful is the movement in unit labor costs. Unit labor costs are a key element because they form three-quarters of all input costs in national output.
Underlying inflation is a useful tool because it removes the influence of volatile transient phenomena, such as one-shot changes in oil prices or interest rates. By focusing on unit labor costs, that is, the movement in labor cost per unit of output produced in the nonfarm business economy, we can unmask the longer-term trends in the key element determining price movements. The accompanying chart illustrates that while there has been an enormous slowdown in the actual rate of consumer inflation, the slowdown has come entirely from the volatile components. Underlying inflation has actually risen almost continuously since 1976.
Put differently, the recent slowdown in inflation has not arisen from slower wage increases or more rapid productivity growth. Rather, it has arisen entirely from the more volatile, non-labor components.
What are these nonunderlying components of the slowdown? The most important, of course, was the enormous deceleration in energy prices. In early 1980, energy prices, which have a 10 percent direct weight in the C.P.I., were rising at a rate of 40 to 50 percent over a 12-month period. Over the last two months, energy prices have risen only one-half of 1 percent. Similar but less dramatic contributions have come from food and housing prices. Finally, the rise in the dollar has made internationally traded goods cheaper.
Economists will argue forever about the exact causal force leading to the favorable trend in oil, food, housing prices and the dollar. While the drop in oil prices is a response to the enormous price increase in earlier years, the favorable movements in the others have been the result of economic policy in the last two years.
The central point for the prognosis on inflation, however, is that movements in oil or food prices lead to one-shot, or transient, declines in inflation. We simply cannot count on a progressive fall in the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Country's selling price. Until and unless these transient elements affect the underlying inflation rate, there is little hope that a decline in inflation below the underlying 8 to 10 percent range will be durable.
We should no more think that the recent experience is permanent than we should have thought that the 13 to 14 percent inflation rates of 1979 and 1980 were permanent. The last two years witnessed a bout of incredibly bad luck; the last few months have seen a string of unpredicted good luck.
W HAT then is the inflation outlook? Given the current sogginess in world oil and commodity markets, it seems a good bet that the volatile commodity component of inflation will remain on good behavior for a year or so - or until the next fruit fly invasion. Thus for a while inflation should continue below the underlying rate.
What is the outlook for the underlying rate? Insofar as the wage half is concerned, there is no evidence yet of slowing. Results of contract negotiations from the coal fields and among newspapers like The New York Times show annual increases over the next three years averaging around 12 percent.
The Administration's theory is that, once the private sector recognizes that Reaganomics is here to stay, wage settlements will decline rapidly. But the recent stubbornness of wage behavior raises questions about whether the Administration's expectational theories are realistic. Admittedly, it is unlikely that coal miners have fully digested the Reagan economic theory and have adapted their behavior to the new economic policies. But when Times reporters, surely well informed and rational economic agents, win a hefty wage package, the Administration should regroup its theorists.
Such inertial wage behavior suggests that the decline in wage increases will be glacial. Nor is there yet any evidence of a marked upturn in productivity. Thus, it appears that the underlying inflation rate is still stuck in the 8 to 10 percent range.
The stickiness of wage behavior makes an effective policy for restraining wages a key ingredient in any anti-inflation policy over the coming years. Aside from the dubious expectational theories, however, there is little in the victorious Reagan fiscal program that would have a marked impact on wage behavior.
In light of the inflation outlook and monetary policy, the continuation of high interest rates and depressed stock prices is no surprise. One simple view holds that interest rates are merely a fixed premium, say 1 or 2 percentage points, over the inflation rate. Under this view, interest rates in the 10 to 12 percent range are consistent with the current underlying inflation rate.
A more realistic view augments such a theory to reflect the relative tightness of monetary policy. As monetary growth targets are very low relative to most projections of the growth of real gross national product, this suggests that interest rates will remain high until the economy collapses or until the Federal Reserve caves in.
In this realistic view of interest rates, there has been no major change in the medium-run outlook for financial markets to cheer about. The underlying rate of inflation is unchanged; the Reagan fiscal victory will not markedly affect the economic outlook, and the Federal Reserve is as determined as ever to maintain monetary tightness.
Under these conditions, it would be the most irrational of expectations for investors to bid up stock prices or down interest rates in light of recent transient behavior of inflation. --------------------------------------------------------------------- William Nordhaus is John Musser Professor of Economics at Yale and a former member of President Carter's Council of Economic Advisers.
Illustration graph of the C.P.I. compared with underlying inflation

DIVERGING ON THE SUMMIT

Author: Rattner, Steven

Publication info: New York Times , Late Edition (East Coast); New York, N.Y. [New York, N.Y]12 July 1981: A.1.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/424132503?accountid=11752

Abstract: ''Employment is falling everywhere, trade is suffering and there is no industrial investment,'' said Claude Cheysson, France's new Foreign Minister, at a recent meeting of the O.E.C.D. High American interest rates have sent the dollar ''floating in the stratosphere,'' he added, concluding that American policies represent ''a third oil shock in the making.'' ''T HE recovery is on the way in Europe,'' said Arnold Simkin, an economist with Merrill Lynch Economics in London. ''I sense it will be fairly apparent to most people by the fourth quarter.'' Mr. Simkin also believes that the [Francois Mitterrand] program will raise the French growth rate in 1982 to 4 percent from 2.6 percent previously projected. But inflation is also likely to accelerate, he said, to 15.1 percent from the 9.8 percent he had been forecasting. ''This policy was successful in reducing the inflationary effects of the oil price increases,'' the O.E.C.D. reported this week. ''While nominal income growth has accelerated, it has done so by less than would have been expected from past evidence.''

Links: http://findit.library.jhu.edu/resolve?url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Anytimes&amp;atitle=DIVERGING+ON+THE+SUMMIT&amp;title=New+York+Times&amp;issn=03624331&amp;date=1981-07-12&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=A.1&amp;au=Rattner%2C+Steven&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=New+York+Times&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text: WHEN the leaders of the industrialized world gather in Ottawa just a week from now - four for their first economic summit - they will be confronting an unusual divergence of economic conditions, of beliefs on what policy should be, and of opinion on what, if anything, can or should be endorsed at this annual gathering.
On the eve of the summit, President Reagan is riding a tremendous popular rush toward tax and budget cutting while keeping one foot heavily on the monetary brakes in a continuing effort to get rid of inflation. His political opposite, newly elected Francois Mitterrand, chose the pre-summit week to announce a radical economic program, startling in its faithfulness to campaign rhetoric, that emphasizes job creation above all and would involve the nationadization of major sectors of the French economy, including large American holdings.
Of the other two new faces, Zenko Suzuki of Japan faces pressing trade problems that threaten his export-dependent economy while Italy's Giovanni Spadolini tries to hold together a nation torn by racing inflation and economic stagnation.
The three familiar faces have problems of their own. In Britain, ultra-conservative Margaret Thatcher continues doggedly down the monetarist road, drawing increasing fire as the economy wilts. In West Germany, Socialist Democrat Helmut Schmidt faces hot attacks for the generous fiscal policies that critics charge have swelled the national deficit and fed inflation in a nation emotionally wedded to stable prices. In Canada, Pierre Elliott Trudeau is feuding with his southern neighbor over energy policies.
Especially in the cases of Mr. Reagan and Mr. Mitterrand, the picture is one of new leaders single-mindedly pursuing policies to which they are deeply committed, leaving moderation for later.
In such an atmosphere, the likelihood of reaching any agreement on macroeconomic policy at Ottawa seems extremely dim. One problem, as a European diplomat in Paris put it, is that ''The margins of maneuvering in economic policy for country leaders are remarkably limited in today's world. New administrations have to learn that lesson.''
Underlying all the political divergence is an array of economic problems, each special to the region involved.The United States, despite all the predictions of a slump, has continued to show signs of economic growth and, perhaps most importantly, has not experienced rising unemployment. Europe, by contrast, remains mired in a slump that has led to steadaly rising unemployment across the continent and few signs of brightening prospects. A further complexity is Japan, fearful of growing protectionist sentiments in other countries.
The divergence so apparent this summer is in substantial contrast to the circumstances just a year ago, when the leaders were glued together by a common external problem. The lingering effects of the 1979 oil price runup left the group - of somewhat different political persuasions then as well -more certain of the need to lean hard against the inflationary effects of that shock.
''We reached agreement last year because of a common problem, the enormous increase in oil prices,'' said a senior official at the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development in Paris. ''This year we knew it would be much more difficult because once we absorbed the oil price increase there would be the possibility of different policies.''
Last week, the Paris-based O.E.C.D. said in its semiannual economic assessment that the recovery in economic activity in the industrialized world, expected late last year to occur in the first half of 1981, would now be delayed by six months or more. Meanwhile, unemployment in the 24 member countries was projected to rise throughout the next 18 months, reaching some 26 million people, or nearly 7 1/2 percent of the labor force, by the second half of 1982.
But that overall assessment masks substantial differences in economic prospects. Members of the European Economic Community are likely to post a collective decline in gross national product of nine-tenths of 1 percent in 1981, after adjustment for inflation, according to Chase Econometrics, a forecasting concern. As for jobs, Europe will show a decline in employment of 1 percent in 1981, following no growth in 1980, according to the O.E.C.D.
Meanwhile, the United States, whose economy grew at a record pace in the first quarter, is expected to continue healthy expansion through the year while employment grows about 1.5 percent in 1981, after a small increase of three-tenths of 1 percent in 1980, the O.E.C.D. reported.
And both Japan and Canada will be barreling along, at a substantially faster rate, in terms of both G.N.P. and employment. These varying outlooks help to explain the highly publicized recent differences between the United States and Europe over monetary policy. In the United States, despite a few good price figures, inflation remains the principal concern. Slower monetary growth - despite the record interest rates that have been the consequence - remains the principal tool.
For Europe, the growing feeling is that interest rates - which were at least a major cause of Europe's economic malaise - need to be lower rather than higher, a goal that the American policy stance puts further from reach. Even in Britain, which has the most conservative government in Europe, pressures had been growing for a cut in the key minimum lending rate, now 12 percent. By comparison, American rates are more than 20 percent.
Bolstered by the high interest rates, the United States dollar has been soaring against all the European currencies. To the European mind, that means trouble - more expensive imports from the United States and higher payments for oil, which is priced in dollars. In other words, inflation.
''Employment is falling everywhere, trade is suffering and there is no industrial investment,'' said Claude Cheysson, France's new Foreign Minister, at a recent meeting of the O.E.C.D. High American interest rates have sent the dollar ''floating in the stratosphere,'' he added, concluding that American policies represent ''a third oil shock in the making.''
The dollar's strength, however, has another important side - encouraging European exports - and many economists feel Europe will gain in the end, for increasing exports just as surely produces jobs as increasing domestic consumption.
''T HE recovery is on the way in Europe,'' said Arnold Simkin, an economist with Merrill Lynch Economics in London. ''I sense it will be fairly apparent to most people by the fourth quarter.'' Mr. Simkin also believes that the Mitterrand program will raise the French growth rate in 1982 to 4 percent from 2.6 percent previously projected. But inflation is also likely to accelerate, he said, to 15.1 percent from the 9.8 percent he had been forecasting.
Often forgotten in the United States is the emphasis in Europe on jobs as a goal of economic policy. Europe, which has traditionally had low unemployment rates, is hurting hard, in its terms. In France, for example, unemployment has risen each year since 1973. In May, joblessness totaled 7.5 percent, or 1.79 million people, up 21.9 percent from a year earlier. One of the new Government's first acts was to propose direct creation of 150,000 public-sector jobs.
This problem may be intensified in coming years by a reversal of demographic trends from the 1970's, according to figures developed by the O.E.C.D. From 1980 to 1985, the rate of growth in working-age population in Europe is projected to rise sharply while that of the United States, historically high, will fall.
The job predicament has compounded for Europe the difficulty of getting control of public spending and borrowing. Government deficits are large - in West Germany, the gap may exceed 4 percent of gross domestic product, one-third higher than two years ago and four times the United States level.
On the other hand, Europe has traditionally had higher inflation than the United States and with the exception of Germany, is less worried about it. Thus in Britain, for example, when the inflation rate fell to around 10 percent from a peak of 23 percent it did no more than set off large calls for economic stimulus, even from many business executives. In France, the commitment to reflation, as stimulus is called here, comes despite an expected inflation rate of 14.2 percent in 1981, according to the Bankers Trust Company.
Despite the worries in Europe, the industrialized world has by nearly all accounts survived the 1979-80 oil shock better than the previous one. Learning from the 1973-74 experience, the industrialized countries moved almost uniformly to limit the spillover effect of oil price increases into the wage arena.
''This policy was successful in reducing the inflationary effects of the oil price increases,'' the O.E.C.D. reported this week. ''While nominal income growth has accelerated, it has done so by less than would have been expected from past evidence.''
To some degree, the inflation improvement has resulted from developments in oil, which is, ironically, the one issue not likely to spark much concern or discussion at this week's meeting. At the moment, with a substantial excess of output and a larger amount of production capacity disused, the oil price pressure is off.

MONETARISM IS CITED AS THREAT

Author: PAUL LEWIS, Special to the New York Times

Publication info: New York Times , Late Edition (East Coast); New York, N.Y. [New York, N.Y]15 June 1981: D.1.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/424118840?accountid=11752

Abstract: The report conveys concern that because inflation has become ''a way of life'' in today's world, it will take a monetary squeeze of intolerable severity to halt inflation. Such a squeeze, in the bank's view, risks setting off a political backlash not just against tightmoney policies but against the Western world's commitment to making inflation-fighting its top economic priority. The bank pointedly recalls that habits of economic cooperation built up since World War II represent ''the most effective bulwark against a repetition of the kind of events witnessed in the 1930's, which ultimately resulted in the disintegration of the world economy.'' The report concludes ominously. ''The warning signs are written clearly on the wall,'' it says. ''The Western world is already paying a high price for having tolerated too high an inflation rate for too long. If, in the present decisive phase, confidence in the effectiveness of international cooperation were to be shaken, the price would be greater still.'' Reflects a Broad View

Links: http://findit.library.jhu.edu/resolve?url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Anytimes&amp;atitle=MONETARISM+IS+CITED+AS+THREAT&amp;title=New+York+Times&amp;issn=03624331&amp;date=1981-06-15&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=D.1&amp;au=PAUL+LEWIS%2C+Special+to+the+New+York+Times&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=New+York+Times&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text: The Reagan Administration's stringent monetarist strategy aimed at curbing inflation in the United States is causing serious difficulties for other countries and could lead to a breakdown of economic cooperation that would spell disaster, the Bank for International Settlements warns in its latest annual report.
The annual statement by the bank, which is owned by the world's central banks, traditionally sets out in forthright language the bankers' views on the major economic problems of the day. The report was issued today in conjunction with the meeting of central bankers this week.
The message this year is that the United States and other countries are relying too heavily on monetary policy in their fight against inflation.
Ripple Effect of High Rates
America's high interest rates are forcing other countries to defend their currencies by raising their own rates to damagingly high levels at a time of recession, the bank says. Such defense is needed because the high returns available on dollar holdings draw funds from other currencies.
Business investment is suffering as a result, and with it, the West's chances of reducing unemployment through industrial development. Meanwhile, the developing world's economies are being crushed by the soaring cost of servicing its debt and by slack demand for its exports in the depressed economies of the West.
The bank would like the United States and other industrial countries to take some of the upward pressure off interest rates by doing more to fight inflation by fiscal means: cutting budget deficits, loosening economic bottlenecks and persuading trade unions to limit wage demands by subscribing to voluntary incomes policies. Dangers of a Backlash
The report conveys concern that because inflation has become ''a way of life'' in today's world, it will take a monetary squeeze of intolerable severity to halt inflation. Such a squeeze, in the bank's view, risks setting off a political backlash not just against tightmoney policies but against the Western world's commitment to making inflation-fighting its top economic priority.
If the worldwide monetary squeeze continues, the bank fears a breakdown in international economic cooperation, as European countries rebel against the prolonged recession that the Reagan Administration's tight-money policy is seen as imposing on them.
The bank pointedly recalls that habits of economic cooperation built up since World War II represent ''the most effective bulwark against a repetition of the kind of events witnessed in the 1930's, which ultimately resulted in the disintegration of the world economy.''
The report concludes ominously. ''The warning signs are written clearly on the wall,'' it says. ''The Western world is already paying a high price for having tolerated too high an inflation rate for too long. If, in the present decisive phase, confidence in the effectiveness of international cooperation were to be shaken, the price would be greater still.'' Reflects a Broad View
Although the bank insists that Washington is not the only culprit, its thinly veiled attack on the Reagan Administration's monetarist approach to inflation-fighting echoes the increasingly strident complaints now coming from virtually all other Western countries except Britain.
In recent weeks, European governments have told the United States that soaring American interest rates are spreading stagflation around the world, killing off hopes of an economic recovery in the West this year and raising the cost of oil and other imported raw materials that must be paid for in increasingly expensive dollars.
Europe and the Bank for International Settlements want the United States instead to reduce inflation by cutting its budget deficit, stimulating competition and restraining pay claims, thus making room for a coordinated reduction in world interest rates that would revive the world economy. Demands Due at O.E.C.D. Meeting
These demands will certainly be repeated by foreign and finance ministers at Tuesday's annual ministerial meeting of the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development in Paris. But so far, the Reagan Administration has turned a deaf ear to such pleas, saying that world interest rates would come down as soon as American inflation subsided and not before.
But some Western officials already fear that the O.E.C.D. meeting will provide the first signs of the kind of revolt against the West's inflation-fighting commitment that the bank fears. France's new Socialist Government, for example, has already started to stimulate the economy mildly, and several smaller European countries are starting to say that unemployment is a more serious problem than inflation.
Besides being unduly deflationary, the bank says, a purely monetary assault on inflation is increasingly difficult to carry out, a point made frequently by Paul A. Volcker, the chairman of the Federal Reserve Board.
Bankers continually thwart efforts to control the growth of the money supply by devising new forms of credit. In the view of the bank, the Federal Reserve's new policy of concentrating on control of the monetary base has led to wild swings in interest rates and exchange rates without making the growth of the monetary aggregates noticeably more stable.
While acknowledging that a restrictive monetary policy is essential if inflation is to be beaten, the bank wants it to be supplemented first and foremost by a general drive to reduce government deficits.
