DOllAR'S THREAT TO U.S. EXPORTS

Author: Hayes, Thomas C

Publication info: New York Times , Late Edition (East Coast); New York, N.Y. [New York, N.Y]09 June 1981: D.1.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/424126798?accountid=11752

Abstract: ''The basic goal of the Reagan Administration is to lick inflation,'' said Otto Eckstein, president of Data Resources Inc., an economic consulting concern. ''A strong dollar helps, but it doesn't help the exporter. The bloom is going to be off the export market.'' How Dollar Affects Trade ''We expect U.S. exporters will lose market share in the second half of this year and into 1982, particularly against the Germans,'' Mrs. [Helen B. Junz] said. ''You will see it first in a falloff in orders.'' ''It may take two or three years for negative impacts of a stronger dollar to be reflected in sales,'' Donald H. Straszheim, chief economist for the Weyerhaeuser Company, said. ''Meanwhile, a strong dollar is going to increase the oil import bill of many of our competing countries. That will aggravate their inflation problem, which would tend to make the dollar even stronger.'' Inflation Rates a Factor

Links: http://findit.library.jhu.edu/resolve?url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Anytimes&amp;atitle=DOllAR%27S+THREAT+TO+U.S.+EXPORTS&amp;title=New+York+Times&amp;issn=03624331&amp;date=1981-06-09&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=D.1&amp;au=Hayes%2C+Thomas+C&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=New+York+Times&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text: American exports, aided by the falling dollar in 1977 and 1978 and more aggressive sales efforts, have grown handsomely in the last three years, bolstering profits and creating new jobs.
But the dollar's sharp rise this year on currency markets, along with a comparatively high inflation rate in the United States, is likely to dampen, if not reverse, the mounting export prowess displayed by American companies in the last few years, according to many economists.
High interest rates have pushed the dollar to its most recent peaks against key European currencies. Since the beginning of the year alone, the dollar has risen 22.1 percent against the West German mark, 19.6 percent against the Swiss franc and 24.3 percent against the British pound.
''The basic goal of the Reagan Administration is to lick inflation,'' said Otto Eckstein, president of Data Resources Inc., an economic consulting concern. ''A strong dollar helps, but it doesn't help the exporter. The bloom is going to be off the export market.'' How Dollar Affects Trade
Generally, a stronger dollar makes American-made goods more expensive abroad, while imports into the United States become better bargains. And even though it typically takes six months or more before a big shift in exchange rates makes its mark in exports, the United States trade deficit is already showing signs of widening.
In April, the trade gap jumped to a seasonally adjusted $3.46 billion from an unusually slim $451.4 million deficit in March, in large part because of a sharp rise in petroleum imports. During the month, exports fell 7.5 percent after a strong gain in March.
Government officials, citing the dollar's strength, anticipate that the 1981 trade deficit will will be wider than last year's $36.36 billion gap. The deficit was $40.37 billion in 1979 and a record $42.36 billion in 1978.
''As we go along, the effect of the dollar's rise will become stronger and stronger,'' said Helen B. Junz, an international economist with Townsend-Greenspan & Company, an economic consulting concern.
''It's hard to imagine that U.S. exports can grow as rapidly in the period ahead,'' said Lawrence Chimerine, president of Chase Econometrics Inc., an economic consulting concern.
''We expect U.S. exporters will lose market share in the second half of this year and into 1982, particularly against the Germans,'' Mrs. Junz said. ''You will see it first in a falloff in orders.''
The American industries that compete with foreigners primarily on price, making them most vulnerable to a rising dollar, are consumer electronics, such as televisions and calculators; textiles; automobiles, and steel. Steel Imports Up Sharply
Steel imports, for example, have risen sharply in recent months. Moreover, four large European producers have asked the Commerce Department for permission to sell their steel below the fair price of steel imports established last year by the Commerce Department. The rising dollar has reduced their production costs, they said, and the price they require to sell at a profit.
Although American exporters in general expect rougher seas, companies selling products with superior quality, service and technology will probably be little affected by lower prices from foreign competitors.
These include such major exporters as the International Business Machines Corporation, the Boeing Company and the Caterpillar Tractor Company, according to Mr. Eckstein.
At Caterpillar, which sells heavy road construction equipment through distributors in more than 140 countries, management is counting on durability, low maintenance, 48-hour parts service and financing packages for buyers to overcome any problems with higher prices, a spokesman said.
Caterpillar exported $3.1 billion worth of equipment last year, or 36 percent of its total sales of $8.6 billion. Half of its 62,000 American employees worked in jobs closely tied to exports. For now, Caterpillar is not suffering an exchange-rate disadvantage against its major competitor, Komatsu of Japan. The dollar has risen 3 percent against the Japanese yen in the last 12 months. OPEC Oil Priced in Dollars
Also favoring American exporters is the fact that, although competitors in Western Europe will benefit from the rising dollar, the Europeans have been hit by a sharp jump in the price of oil imported from members of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries. OPEC prices its oil in dollars. As the dollar has risen against the European currencies, petroleum-based industries have paid dearly in higher oil bills. This will blunt some of the negative effect of the dollar's rise on trade in the United States economy.
''The Germans, in effect, have just had a 25 percent increase in petroleum prices,'' said Walter Joelson, chief economist of the General Electric Company. G.E. recorded the country's second-highest volume of export sales in 1980, after Boeing.
The jolt from the dollar's climb also will be partially offset by long-term contracts that are common in international commerce, especially on expensive capital goods.
''It may take two or three years for negative impacts of a stronger dollar to be reflected in sales,'' Donald H. Straszheim, chief economist for the Weyerhaeuser Company, said. ''Meanwhile, a strong dollar is going to increase the oil import bill of many of our competing countries. That will aggravate their inflation problem, which would tend to make the dollar even stronger.'' Inflation Rates a Factor
The relationship of the dollar to foreign currencies is important in setting the price of American goods of abroad. Comparative inflation rates also play a fundamental role. If the rate of inflation continues to decline in the United States, as it did in April and May, it will offset some of the disadvantages that American exporters face as potential customers tally exchange rates.
But that is not of much help at this time, especially when American companies go head to head with German competitors. In the 12 months ended last Friday, the dollar climbed 35.9 percent against the German mark. Average wage settlements in Germany of 5 percent have been about half the 10 percent rate in the United States, giving the Germans an edge in labor costs.
Then, too, the German economy has been weaker, making it easier for Germans to sell in the United States than for Americans in Germany. ''There is also a greater effort by foreign companies to sell in the United States,'' Mrs. Junz of Townsend-Greenspan said.
The dollar has recovered most of the losses it suffered against major foreign currencies since 1977. But, while it is expected to advance further, some economists cautioned against putting too much weight on its role as determinant of the fate of American exporters.

SPENDING BY MILITARY IS DEFENDED

Author: EDWARD COWAN, Special to the New York Times

Publication info: New York Times , Late Edition (East Coast); New York, N.Y. [New York, N.Y]04 May 1981: D.1.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/424104578?accountid=11752

Abstract: ''When you build up procurement fast, you tend to build up a huge backlog of obligated but unspent funds that actually get spent at times that you can't predict,'' Mr. [W. Bowman Cutter] said in an interview. ''It adds a factor of uncontrollability to the entire budget.'' Mr. Cutter said Mr. [Murray L. Weidenbaum] was right in arguing that fiscal and monetary policy are more restrained now than during Vietnam. But, he said, ''Where you could get into trouble is in particular industries.'' For example, he said, construction of the MX missile system ''could drive up the price of cement - almost certainly would.'' ''You cannot do both,'' Mr. [Seymour Melman] said in a telephone interview, ''It is out of the question.'' This view is diametrically opposed to the White House's prediction that [Reagan] supply-side policies would lead to major increases in labor supply, the quality of work, savings, investment, productivity and the economy's capacity to product.

Links: http://findit.library.jhu.edu/resolve?url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Anytimes&amp;atitle=SPENDING+BY+MILITARY+IS+DEFENDED&amp;title=New+York+Times&amp;issn=03624331&amp;date=1981-05-04&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=D.1&amp;au=EDWARD+COWAN%2C+Special+to+the+New+York+Times&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=New+York+Times&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text: President Reagan's chief economic adviser, Murray L. Weidenbaum, says there is no reason to expect the planned build-up of military spending in the next several years to cause a new surge of inflation.
This assertion by the chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers, in an interview earlier last week, is part of what appears to be a widening debate about the Reagan proposition that Congress can pass a three-year tax cut, vote for bigger defense appropriations and still be confident that inflation will slow appreciably in the next few years.
So far, the debate has been couched largely in terms of aggregates such as total spending, the size of a tax cut and the size of the economy. But a second line of criticism is also emerging: that any shift of resources from civilian to military use tends to drive up costs and the general price level. Some Reagan economists heatedly dispute this view.
The Situation Then and Now
Mr. Weidenbaum, citing his analysis of inflation during the Vietnam War, took issue with critics who have charged that the Reagan Administration's plans for more ships, aircraft and other materiel - and for a higher state of military readiness - are likely to touch off a rerun of the late 1960's, when the current inflation took root.
Circumstances then and now are markedly different, according to Mr. Weidenbaum. The military build-up will be slower this time and the defense budget will account for a smaller fraction of the economy, an economy the White House assumes will be growing rapidly, he said.
Among the critics have been two economists, Lester Thurow of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology and Henry Kaufman of Salomon Brothers, the Wall Street investment banking house. They contend that the Reagan policy, overall, is too stimulative for an economy already experiencing a persistent 10 percent inflation.
Two officials of the Carter Administration, W. Bowman Cutter, an economist who had a senior job at the Office of Management and Budget, and R. James Woolsey, a lawyer who was Under Secretary of the Navy, have joined the debate. Both agree with the Congressional budget office that the Reagan Administration has understated probable future military spending, especially in the fiscal year 1984, the target for balancing the budget. Comments From Economist
''When you build up procurement fast, you tend to build up a huge backlog of obligated but unspent funds that actually get spent at times that you can't predict,'' Mr. Cutter said in an interview. ''It adds a factor of uncontrollability to the entire budget.''
Mr. Cutter said Mr. Weidenbaum was right in arguing that fiscal and monetary policy are more restrained now than during Vietnam. But, he said, ''Where you could get into trouble is in particular industries.'' For example, he said, construction of the MX missile system ''could drive up the price of cement - almost certainly would.''
The proposition that price surges in particular industries will bring about a rise in the overall level of prices is heatedly rejected by those Administration economists who take a monetarist view of inflation. ''If you restrain growth of the money supply and some individual prices go up, other individual prices have to come down,'' said Lawrence A. Kudlow, chief economist of the Office of Management and Budget.
This view, that inflation is caused only by excessive expansion of the money supply, is an overarching principle of Reagan economic policies but is much debated within the economics profession. Pattern Over the Years
In an analysis done in mid-April, Mr. Kudlow examined the growth of military spending and inflation in the years 1962-80. ''Overall, no direct association was found'' between military spending and two broad measures of inflation, the Consumer Price Index and the deflator for the gross national product, he concluded.
Seymour Melman, professor of industrial engineering at Columbia University and a long-time critic of military spending under several Presidents, argues that the Reagan military budget would claim the very resources needed for an expansion of private investment in machines and plants, which is also a Reagan policy goal.
''You cannot do both,'' Mr. Melman said in a telephone interview, ''It is out of the question.'' This view is diametrically opposed to the White House's prediction that Reagan supply-side policies would lead to major increases in labor supply, the quality of work, savings, investment, productivity and the economy's capacity to product.
Mr. Melman also argues that military procurement is inflationary because it encourages the use of high-cost production techniques and that such methods become widespread and entrenched. For example, he said, American producers of numerically controlled machine tools are stuck with a high-cost technology that they developed for the Air Force. Response by Weidenbaum
Mr. Weidenbaum, replying to Mr. Kaufman and Mr. Thurow, made these points:
- The build-up of military spending will lift the total to 6 percent of the G.N.P. by 1984, still below the 8.9 percent during the Vietnam War. Moreover, the rise from 1980 will amount to only one percentage point, against a rise of 1.8 points in 1965-67. Mr. Weidenbaum said these ratios assumed the strong economic expansion predicted in the Reagan budget.
- In constant dollars, the 1965-67 rise in defense spending was 36 percent. The rise projected for 1980-84 is the same.
- There is more unused manufacturing capacity and more unemployed labor now than in 1965-67. That means less risk of bottlenecks that drive up costs. In aerospace, backlogs of unfilled orders have been dropping.

DEMOCRATS BUDGET TOPS REAGAN FIGURE ON SOCIAL PROGRAMS

Author: Tolchin, Martin

Publication info: New York Times , Late Edition (East Coast); New York, N.Y. [New York, N.Y]07 Apr 1981: A.1.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/424089673?accountid=11752

Abstract: Speaker Thomas P. O'Neill Jr. said at a news conference that the Democratic alternative budget was ''designed to address the needs of the 'struggling class' of Americans who are unable to keep up with rising prices, and who find it harder and harder to get by.'' ''It's a plan that's been well thought out, and reflects the art of compromise,'' the Speaker said. ''A lot of work went into it from every segment of our party.'' Mr. [David A. Stockman] said the Democrats' proposed economies, to offset roughly their increases in the [Reagan] nonmilitary budget, were ''questionable, soft or nonexistent.'' He took issue with purported economies for payments to veterans, revenue sharing and the strategic oil reserve. He labeled as ''absolutely artificial'' what he said was the Democrats' contemplated recovery of $1.3 billion from oil companies to settle charges of having violated price controls.

Links: http://findit.library.jhu.edu/resolve?url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Anytimes&amp;atitle=DEMOCRATS+BUDGET+TOPS+REAGAN+FIGURE+ON+SOCIAL+PROGRAMS&amp;title=New+York+Times&amp;issn=03624331&amp;date=1981-04-07&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=A.1&amp;au=Tolchin%2C+Martin&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=New+York+Times&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text: House Democrats today proposed a $713.5 billion budget for the fiscal year 1982 and recommended more funds than the Administration sought for social programs and what would seem to be more money for military needs as well, although the Democrats said it was actually less than the Administration has proposed.
The Democrats also said that their budget total was $4.3 billion less than proposed by President Reagan in March. They based that statement on their calculation that President Reagan's $695 billion budget used an incorrect projection for inflation and that, when the Reagan budget is adjusted for higher inflation, the total is really $717.8 billion. The Democrats also endorsed a smaller tax cut than the one proposed by the President and urged that the Administration's proposed deficit, which the Administration calculates at $45 billion but which the Democrats estimate at $50.5 billion, be cut to $24.6 billion. They also projected a balanced budget by the fiscal year 1983, a year earlier than the Administration projected.
Saving Based on Barring Fraud
The House Democrats outbid the Administration in commitment to fiscal austerity by relying upon some budgetary strategms that will surely be questioned. In one case, a saving of $4.8 billion was ascribed to eliminating fraud, waste and abuse. This was in addition to a $4.3 billion reduction from the Democrats' estimate of the Reagan figure for military spending and a $1.5 billion reduction in money for the Strategic Petroleum Reserve.
The Democrats' economic assumptions put the inflation rate near 10 percent, compared with the Administration's projection of 8.3 percent. The House Democrats also assumed interest rates of 12 percent on Federal borrowing, compared with the 9 percent projected by the Administration. Stockman Counterattacks
Counterattacking within hours, David A. Stockman, Director of the Office of Management and Budget, charged that the Democrats would cut military programs that were essential to national security and that their purported economies in other areas were ''questionable, soft or nonexistent.''
Mr. Stockman and Donald T. Regan, Secretary of the Treasury, objected to the Democrats' proposal for a smaller and apparently later tax cut than Mr. Reagan's. Mr. Stockman, harking back to a Reagan campaign theme, called that ''balancing the budget on the backs of the taxpayers.''
In a rare show of unity, 17 of the 18 Democrats on the House Budget Committee, ranging from urban liberals to rural conservatives, supported the package in the Democrats' caucus. The one holdout was Representative Phil Gramm of Texas. House Democratic leaders predicted that the package would have the overwhelming support of party members when it reached the floor after the Easter recess.
Speaker Thomas P. O'Neill Jr. said at a news conference that the Democratic alternative budget was ''designed to address the needs of the 'struggling class' of Americans who are unable to keep up with rising prices, and who find it harder and harder to get by.''
''It's a plan that's been well thought out, and reflects the art of compromise,'' the Speaker said. ''A lot of work went into it from every segment of our party.''
The Democrats said that they were not abandoning the needs of the poor. They proposed a reduction of 10 to 12 percent in money for many social programs, instead of the 25 percent reduction they calclate that the Administration has urged.
The Democrats sought $4.3 billion less than the $194 billion that they calculated the Reagan Administration recommended for military needs, although it is just under a billion dollars more than the $188.8 billion that Mr. Reagan said would be needed for the military. But Representative James R. Jones, Democrat of Oklahoma, chairman of the Budget Committee, said that even with what the Democrats calculate as a cut, ''This is the largest peacetime increase in defense spending in the history of our nation.'' The current military spending level is $173.9 billion.
The Democrats were able to cut the Reagan deficit by providing a tax cut of $38 billion for the fiscal year 1982, instead of the $54 billion proposed by the Administration. Mr. Jones said that the proposal was approved by Representative Daniel Rostenkowski, Democrat of Illinois, chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee.
''The minority has some real problems with the economic assumptions,'' said Representative Jack Kemp, Republican of upstate New York.
The House Democrats would save several programs marked for extinction, including the Economic Development Administration and the Legal Services Corporation, while restoring funds for dozens of programs, including food stamps, low income energy assistance, child nutrition and mass transit operating subsidies. Solarz Says New York Will Like It
''I think the people of New York City will be quite pleased with this budget, in contrast with the President's budget,'' said Representative Steven J. Solarz, Democrat of Brooklyn, who is a member of the committee.
Some of the House Democrats' restorations, all of which are based on Administration figures as they have been adjusted by the Democrats, are these:
- For food stamps, $650 million would be restored of the $1.6 billion recommended cut by the Administration.
- For education, the cut would be 10 percent, compared with the 25 percent sought by the Administration in a $30 billion program.
- For low-income energy assistance, a reduction of $650 million is sought instead of the $1.6 billion recommended by the President.
- In Social Security, the $122 a month minimum benefit would be eliminated, but only for new beneficiaries in the fiscal year 1982, and for all beneficiaries the next year. The Administration would eliminate the minimum benefit in the fiscal year 1982.
- For Medicaid, the President's proposal to cap Medicaid expenses is rejected and Democrats would provides $1.15 billion to meet the additional cost.
- Child nutrition would be reduced by $1 billion, half of the $2 billion reduction proposed by the Administration. Stockman Details Criticism
Mr. Stockman said the Democrats' proposed economies, to offset roughly their increases in the Reagan nonmilitary budget, were ''questionable, soft or nonexistent.'' He took issue with purported economies for payments to veterans, revenue sharing and the strategic oil reserve. He labeled as ''absolutely artificial'' what he said was the Democrats' contemplated recovery of $1.3 billion from oil companies to settle charges of having violated price controls.
As for Democratic cuts in military spending, Mr. Stockman said they were unwise. He specifically criticized the Democrats' proposal to skip a July 1981 pay rise for the military and to delay the MX missile and the Democrats' contention that expansion of the Defense Department's civilian payroll was unnnecessary.

MEXICO'S ECONOMIC IMBALANCES

Publication info: New York Times , Late Edition (East Coast); New York, N.Y. [New York, N.Y]06 Apr 1981: D.1.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/424091057?accountid=11752

Abstract: At the heart of the problem of course, is inflation. But in many sectors the impact of high prices has been aggravated by the Government's determination to maintain the Mexican peso's parity with the dollar. Last year, for example, while prices rose by 29.8 percent, almost double the United States inflation rate, the peso "floated" downward by only 1.9 percent, to 23.25 pesos to the dollar from 22.8 pesos. This year, the "floating" downward has increased so that a dollar now costs 23.9 pesos. But foreign bankers estimate the peso's "real" value at around 30 units to the dollar. "Oil is being used to cover up all the cracks," said one Mexican economist who is critical of Government policy, "so we're becoming more and more dependent on oil to stay afloat at all. The currency policy is particularly harmful to the tourist industry, with Acapulco reporting its lowest winter season occupancy in 15 years. Officials argue publicly that this is the result of the economic recession in the United States, but many hotels, restaurants and nightclubs here have virtually priced themselves out of the market. A single room in a first-class hotel in Mexico City, for example, now costs around $100 a night, compared with about $35 four years ago. "The main political problem is inflation," one official noted, "so the Government is paying the economic price of holding it down." Oil Production Limits Imposed

Links: http://findit.library.jhu.edu/resolve?url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Anytimes&amp;atitle=MEXICO%27S+ECONOMIC+IMBALANCES&amp;title=New+York+Times&amp;issn=03624331&amp;date=1981-04-06&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=D.1&amp;au=&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=New+York+Times&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text: A full-page advertisement for a jewelry sale in San Antonio looked strangely out of place in the pages of the Mexico City daily, Excelsior, a few days ago. But the Joske Department Store had made no mistake: its largest clientele is Mexican.
Attracted by prices that are frequently half those prevailing here, more and more middle-class Mexicans are flying to San Antonio and other United States cities near the Mexican border to shop.
In reality, the momentum of Mexico's economic boom - its gross domestic product grew by 7.4 percent in 1980 - is such that commerce here is still barely able to keep up with local demand. But the flight of consumers is nevertheless symptomatic of the economic imbalances that oil is bringing to Mexico.
At the heart of the problem of course, is inflation. But in many sectors the impact of high prices has been aggravated by the Government's determination to maintain the Mexican peso's parity with the dollar. Last year, for example, while prices rose by 29.8 percent, almost double the United States inflation rate, the peso "floated" downward by only 1.9 percent, to 23.25 pesos to the dollar from 22.8 pesos. This year, the "floating" downward has increased so that a dollar now costs 23.9 pesos. But foreign bankers estimate the peso's "real" value at around 30 units to the dollar.
The exchange rate situation encourages Mexicans to buy abroad and travel abroad, while it translates high domestic prices into high dollar prices for foreigners wanting to visit Mexico or buy its products. The bottom line last year was a current-account payments deficit of $6.6 billion, the highest in the country's history and a 36 percent increase over 1979.
"Oil is being used to cover up all the cracks," said one Mexican economist who is critical of Government policy, "so we're becoming more and more dependent on oil to stay afloat at all. The currency policy is particularly harmful to the tourist industry, with Acapulco reporting its lowest winter season occupancy in 15 years. Officials argue publicly that this is the result of the economic recession in the United States, but many hotels, restaurants and nightclubs here have virtually priced themselves out of the market. A single room in a first-class hotel in Mexico City, for example, now costs around $100 a night, compared with about $35 four years ago.
In contrast, Mexicans, who traditionally spend three times more per person abroad than visitors here, are being indirectly encouraged by the currency situation to spend vacations in the United States, Western Europe or even the Caribbean. Last year, while the number of visitors to Mexico remained unchanged and their spending grew by only 15 percent, Mexicans spent 41 percent more abroad than in 1979.
Not surprisingly, with the domestic prices of labor and raw materials rising annually by around 30 percent, Mexico's nonoil exports have also faltered against the products of countries with flexible exchange rates. Last year, the value of its manufactured exports rose by only 15 percent, which, at constant prices, implied a drop.
Calls by some industrialists for a devaluation of the peso, however, have been repeatedly rebuffed by the Government.
"If industrialists argue that it would give them a competitive edge in foreign markets," Industry Minister Jose Andres de Oteyza noted recently, "we should first analyze the fact that there are no products to export, that all of production is consumed on the domestic market and therefore a devaluation is in no way justified.
Fed by high Government expenditure, consumer spending has soared over the past three years and, after the slump in private investment that marked the controlversial administration of President Luis Echeverria Alvarez between 1970 and 1976, many factories are still struggling to expand their capacity to catch up with domestic demand.
Further, with both Government and the private sector importing a great deal for the industrial projects, some officials have said that a devaluation would merely increase the peso cost that must eventually be passed on to the public.
"The main political problem is inflation," one official noted, "so the Government is paying the economic price of holding it down." Oil Production Limits Imposed
Eager to avoid the pitfalls common to oil-exporting developing nations, such as foreign exchange revenues that the local economy cannot absorb, Mexico has in fact decided to level off oil production when a target "platform" of 2.75 million barrels a day is reached later this year. But the administration of President Jose Lopez Portillo has nevertheless decided on a policy of high economic growth, arguing that increased employment opportunities more than compensate for current inflation.
For ordinary Mexicans, though, the arrival of Mexico's oil boom has meant a reduction in their purchasing power, with the price of such basic products as corn, beans, eggs, milk, clothes and shoes all registering increases greater than the official inflation rate announced by the Government.
"A simple pair of shoes costs over 1,000 pesos ($42.50)," one young secretary said as she asked for a raise.
The "loaded gun" of the economy, as one financial analyst put it, remains the current exchange policy, with many officials privately recognizing the danger of a flight of capital as President Lopez Portillo approaches the end of his term in December 1982.
The last major devaluation of the peso took place Aug. 31 1976, just three months before President Echeverria left office, and was followed by economic chaos as the currency was allowed to float - or, in fact, sink - down from its fixed parity of 12.50 pesos to the dollar, reaching at one point 29 pesos to the dollar.
After President Lopez Portillo took power in December 1976, business confidence quickly returned and the peso stabilized around 22 pesos to the dollar, although the Government insisted at the time that the currency would continue to "float" to prevent the kind of economic convulsion provoked by the previous devaluation.
Illustration Photo of Mexican Peso Graph of Mexico's Inflation Rate

By SIR GEOFFREY HOWE

Publication info: New York Times , Late Edition (East Coast); New York, N.Y. [New York, N.Y]25 Jan 1981: A.3.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/424040659?accountid=11752

Abstract: Like the United States, after a long postwar period of growth, with relatively low inflation, we have seen serious inflation establish itself in our economy over the last decade or so. In Britain we have seen the inflationary paraphernalia of automatic indexation, wage claims at least in line with price movements, discussion of cost increases ''in real terms'' as if the general rise in the price level were unimportant, and so on. The task of defeating inflation is immeasurably easier if fiscal policy is consistent with the monetary stance. If the government's demand for credit is excessive, the result is high interest rates crowding out private investors, and proper monetary control itself becomes much more difficult. But again, reducing the government's borrowing requirement takes time. In Britain, we are sometimes constrained by our membership in the European Community; in the United States your administrations are sometimes constrained by the division of powers within the Congress. The difficulties of tackling these problems, particularly when the world outlook is so clouded, should not be underestimated. Yet, they are problems that must be tackled vigorously if we are to restore the health of our economies. --------------------------------------------------------------------- Sir Geoffrey Howe is Britain's Chancellor of the Exchequer.

Links: http://findit.library.jhu.edu/resolve?url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Anytimes&amp;atitle=By+SIR+GEOFFREY+HOWE&amp;title=New+York+Times&amp;issn=03624331&amp;date=1981-01-25&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=A.3&amp;au=&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=New+York+Times&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text: I N recent weeks I have been struck by a number of articles in the United States press advising President Reagan on the main problems that would face him on taking office and the main steps the authors felt he should take.
What was particularly interesting to me was the close parallel between the problems identified, and the prescriptions made, in some of those articles, and my own view of the British economy. Indeed, there are close parallels with many of the industrialized countries around the world. We are all suffering from the effects of the severe rise in oil prices since 1979, which has sent the world economy into recession and added to inflationary fires.
But the parallels went further than the joint experience of recession. The articles highlighted the problems of inflation and how to tackle it, government spending and borrowing, and government over-regulation of the private sector. On all these, the authors raised issues that are important to the British economy as well.
Like the United States, after a long postwar period of growth, with relatively low inflation, we have seen serious inflation establish itself in our economy over the last decade or so. In Britain we have seen the inflationary paraphernalia of automatic indexation, wage claims at least in line with price movements, discussion of cost increases ''in real terms'' as if the general rise in the price level were unimportant, and so on.
Successive governments have played a part in our inflationary process, through excessive spending and borrowing, and the pretense that they can solve problems that can only be mastered by changes in economic behavior. In some cases, they have taken over tasks better performed privately.
In others, the problem has been the establishment of a level of entitlement, or standard of provision, that assumes substantial economic growth, which it is then difficult to scale down if the growth does not materialize. Thus, public spending has acquired a momentum divorced from the realities of the productive economy, which has had to bear an increasing burden. The productive sector has been further hampered by levels of personal taxation frustrating to enterprise and effort, and by an excessive number of government regulations. I find echoes of all these phenomena in descriptions of American experience as well.
These are problems which have developed over many years, and they will not be solved overnight. But I now find near universal agreement among my fellow finance ministers that inflation must be cut to restore stable conditions for growth and new employment.
There is agreement, too, that monetary control is a necessary condition for the reduction of inflation, and that this control needs to be sustained. Indeed, a responsible attitude to the money supply needs to become a permanent feature if the deeply ingrained inflationary mentality is to be eradicated. The right method of monetary control will vary from country to country according to the nature of the financial institutions in each.
But no method of control, in our highly sophisticated modern economies, can work instant miracles. So far as Britain is concerned, I do not believe there can be any doubt that monetary conditions have been tight, despite the fact that the broader monetary aggregates have been growing rather faster than the Government's target would indicate. The narrower aggregates have been growing much slower than the rate of inflation.
We have succeeded in reducing our year-on-year inflation rate from a peak of 22 percent last May to just over 15 percent, while the annualized six-month rate is much lower - well below the rates in the United States and France, for example. Meanwhile, short-term interest rates have been reduced by 3 percent since last summer. And there is increasing evidence in the labor market of the sort of realism we need to insure adequate control over domestic costs. Many wage settlements have now come down to single-figure increases. And strikes have been at an all-time low.
The task of defeating inflation is immeasurably easier if fiscal policy is consistent with the monetary stance. If the government's demand for credit is excessive, the result is high interest rates crowding out private investors, and proper monetary control itself becomes much more difficult. But again, reducing the government's borrowing requirement takes time.
I HAVE already mentioned the built-in momentum of many spending programs. It takes time to reverse this. Further, at a time of recession there is upward pressure on the fiscal deficit from higher benefit payments and lower revenues. These are often regarded as automatic stabilizers, mitigating the effects of a recession, and we have judged that we should not try to counteract their effect altogether.
Nevertheless, we are reversing inexorable growth of public expenditure, and our plans now provide for a reduction in real terms of about 1 percent a year in 1981-82 and subsequent years as compared with the previous Government's plans for a 2 percent increase.
This has enabled us also to make a start on cutting the high personal taxes that were a uniquely foolish disincentive in the British economy. This objective of cutting personal taxes is potentially in short-run conflict, as a matter of simple arithmetic, with the objective of reducing Government borrowing. The long-term answer is planned cuts in spending, and extra revenue will be derived as the economy grows.
In the meantime, we have chosen to strike a prudent balance between the two goals, and have increased revenue from indirect taxation to offset reductions in income tax. But the fact remains that in my first budget I cut income taxes across the board and reduced the top rate of tax on earnings to 60 percent from 83 percent, thus substantially increasing the rewards successful managers are able to earn.
Reducing the burden of unnecessary regulation on industry and commerce is the other supply-side policy. The first stages have been quickly achieved. I have removed a battery of controls in Britain; on prices, pay, dividends and movements of capital across foreign exchanges. But not all deregulation is as simple as we should wish. We all have to take account of legitimate anxieties about such matters as health and safety, protection of the consumer and the environment. We need to allow for our institutional constraints.
In Britain, we are sometimes constrained by our membership in the European Community; in the United States your administrations are sometimes constrained by the division of powers within the Congress. The difficulties of tackling these problems, particularly when the world outlook is so clouded, should not be underestimated. Yet, they are problems that must be tackled vigorously if we are to restore the health of our economies. --------------------------------------------------------------------- Sir Geoffrey Howe is Britain's Chancellor of the Exchequer.
Illustration photo of Margaret Thatcher and Sir Geoffrey Howe

INFLATION OUTPACED GAINS IN INCOME IN SECOND QUARTER

Author: AP

Publication info: New York Times , Late Edition (East Coast); New York, N.Y. [New York, N.Y]09 Nov 1980: A.33.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/424018699?accountid=11752

Abstract: Nineteen states registered declines or only small increases in nonfarm income. The largest single factor was a drop in payrolls for industries making durable goods, especially cars, steel and lumber products. Eight states showed comparatively large increases in nonfarm income, attributed mainly to increases in mining, manufacturing and construction payrolls. The eight states - Oklahoma, Florida, Louisiana, Texas, California, Arizona, New Mexico and Wyoming - historically have been affected relatively little by national recessions, the report said. The Southwestern region led the nation with an overall 2.5 percent improvement in nonfarm income for the April-to-June quarter. The Far West was second, with an increase of 1.9 percent. The Middle Atlantic states had a 1.5 percent increase; New England, the Rocky Mountain states and the Southeast, a 1.3 percent increase; the Plains states, a 1 percent increase, and the Great Lakes states, a 0.6 percent increase.

Links: http://findit.library.jhu.edu/resolve?url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Anytimes&amp;atitle=INFLATION+OUTPACED+GAINS+IN+INCOME+IN+SECOND+QUARTER&amp;title=New+York+Times&amp;issn=03624331&amp;date=1980-11-09&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=A.33&amp;au=AP&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=New+York+Times&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text: American working men and women saw their personal income gains in the second quarter outstripped by prices that increased more than twice as fast, the Commerce Department said today.
Total personal income in the April-to-June period, including farm income, rose an average of 1.1 percent nationwide over the first three months of the year as a severe recession gripped the economy and choked off expansion that began in 1975.
At the same time, the department's Bureau of Economic Analysis said, inflation rose 2.6 percent, more than wiping out the improvement in income.
The most striking aspect of the report was the pervasiveness of inflation. Income increased in 34 states and the District of Columbia, but in every case was overcome by the increase in prices.
Two States Nearly Broke Even
Florida and Louisiana came closest to breaking even in the threemonth period, registering 2.4 percent increases in total personal income, including farm income.
Worst off was Michigan, with its depressed automobile industry, which registered a 1.1 percent decline in income. Idaho showed a 1 percent drop.
New York and New Jersey each showed an increase in income of 1.6 percent over the first quarter of the year, while Connecticut showed an increase of 1.5 percent.
Most of the report deals with nonfarm personal income, which department analysts view as a more stable measure of the economy because of the volatility of farm income.
Before adjustment for inflation, nonfarm income rose in 44 states and the District of Columbia in the second quarter. The nation as a whole showed a 1.4 percent increase after an improvement of 2.9 percent in the first three months.
Oklahoma Ahead After Adjustment
When farm income is taken into account and measured against the 2.6 percent inflation of the second quarter, only Oklahoma, with a 3 percent increase in income, stayed ahead of inflation. Florida stayed even.
Oklahoma's second-quarter increase in income matched its firstquarter rate. But in every other state, the second quarter - when the recession was at its worst - brought less growth than the first.
Nineteen states registered declines or only small increases in nonfarm income. The largest single factor was a drop in payrolls for industries making durable goods, especially cars, steel and lumber products.
Most of those 19 states, concentrated in the Great Lakes region, New England and the Southeast, also were severely affected by the 1974-5 recession.
Comparatively Large Increases
Eight states showed comparatively large increases in nonfarm income, attributed mainly to increases in mining, manufacturing and construction payrolls. The eight states - Oklahoma, Florida, Louisiana, Texas, California, Arizona, New Mexico and Wyoming - historically have been affected relatively little by national recessions, the report said.
The Southwestern region led the nation with an overall 2.5 percent improvement in nonfarm income for the April-to-June quarter. The Far West was second, with an increase of 1.9 percent. The Middle Atlantic states had a 1.5 percent increase; New England, the Rocky Mountain states and the Southeast, a 1.3 percent increase; the Plains states, a 1 percent increase, and the Great Lakes states, a 0.6 percent increase.
The nation's nonfarm income in the second quarter rose at a rate that, if continued for a full year, would result in a total of $2.057 trillion, up 10.8 percent from the same period in 1979.

BUSINESS COUNTS ON REAGAN

Author: Lohr, Steve

Publication info: New York Times , Late Edition (East Coast); New York, N.Y. [New York, N.Y]06 Nov 1980: D.1.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/424017333?accountid=11752

Abstract: ''We're enjoying a Reagan rally right now,'' said James M. Davin, manager of corporate bond trading for the First Boston Corporation, yesterday. ''The market is and should be buoyed by the Reagan victory and the conservative sweep across the country.'' Moreover, Chrysler executives take comfort from Mr. [Ronald Reagan]'s complete turnabout on legislation to aid the auto maker. A year ago, when asked about Chrysler, Mr. Reagan replied, ''What's wrong with bankruptcy?'' But last September, standing in the humming assembly plant where renovation was financed by Government-guaranteed loans, he characterized the rescue program as the ''proper answer.'' Energy ''Mr. Reagan will continue to embrace the general principles of free trade,'' said Leif H. Olsen, chairman of Citibank's economic policy committee. ''He will also place a high priority on counteracting dumping and other violations of fair trade.''

Links: http://findit.library.jhu.edu/resolve?url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Anytimes&amp;atitle=BUSINESS+COUNTS+ON+REAGAN&amp;title=New+York+Times&amp;issn=03624331&amp;date=1980-11-06&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=D.1&amp;au=Lohr%2C+Steve&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=New+York+Times&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text: Wall Street and the business community welcomed the election of Ronald Reagan yesterday, amid predictions that the President-elect would oversee the most pro-business administration since that of Dwight D. Eisenhower.
''This conservative landslide should provide considerable encouragement for the private sector, resulting in increased economic activity and increased business investment for plant and equipment in 1981,'' said Reginald H. Jones, chief executive of the General Electric Company and chairman of the Business Council, an organization of top corporate executives.
Martin Feldstein, a Harvard economist and president of the National Bureau of Economic Research, the official arbiter of business cycles, observed: ''The Reagan election is quite promising for business and the economy because it shows broad support for what is seen as a strong inflation-fighting program.''
Indeed, the consensus among economists, corporate managers and Wall Street executives is that a Reagan administration should strengthen the economy by improving the likelihood of controlling inflation and interest rates, cutting taxes and increasing incentives for saving and investment.
Defense and Nuclear Development
They expect sharply increased defense spending, with the nation's strategic weapons program receiving a strong push. In energy, fewer Federal restraints and a new impetus for the development of nuclear power is foreseen. The steel industry expects a Government posture that should enhance its profitability and productivity, as well as increase the chances for Congress to grant a two-year delay of pollution-control requirements.
In Detroit, auto executives say that regulatory and tax relief, begun under President Carter, should accelerate under Mr. Reagan. Wall Street analysts foresee continued strength in the stock market rally in response to the Reagan victory. The widely followed Dow Jones industrial average could pierce the 1000 barrier toward the end of this year, they say.
Bond traders, too, view a Reagan Presidency favorably, as one likely to install the conservative fiscal policies that they regard as long overdue.
Some Reservations Expressed
Still, those interviewed do not, by any means, expect the economy to show new vitality overnight, nor do they anticipate revolutionary policy shifts.
''The changes aren't going to be radical or violent,'' said Albert T. Sommers, chief economist of the Conference Board, a nonprofit business research group. ''Just about everyone in the business community recognizes that.''
Several business leaders and economists expressed reservations about some of Mr. Reagan's campaign positions, which they characterized as extreme or simplistic. In particular, they are concerned that his pledges to raise military spending significantly and slice personal income taxes sharply at the same time could worsen inflation.
But for the most part, those interviewed believe that, as President, Mr. Reagan will be more moderate and balanced than his campaign rhetoric might suggest; they think his extreme proposals will be reformulated both by his senior advisers and Congress.
In sum, the business community believes that, once in office, Mr. Reagan will be pragmatic, not dogmatic, and that the general drift of his conservative philosophy is precisely what the American business needs.
Bonds
''We're enjoying a Reagan rally right now,'' said James M. Davin, manager of corporate bond trading for the First Boston Corporation, yesterday. ''The market is and should be buoyed by the Reagan victory and the conservative sweep across the country.''
However, Mr. Davin and others speculated that after an initial period of euphoria, investors in fixed-income securities are likely to focus again on the prospect of higher interest rates as the economy comes out of recession. In addition, they point to the Federal Reserve Baord's willingness to raise short-term interest rates if necessary to slow the growth of money supply.
At present, it appears that a tight monetary policy is needed, since the money supply grew an alarming 15 1/2 percent annual rate in the latest quarter. In fact, some analysts expect a tightening move soon, probably an increase in the discount rate.
Still, if Mr. Reagan's programs include a hefty dose of tight-money fiscal conservatism, as Wall Street hopes, the long-term effect ''would be tremendously beneficial to the bond markets,'' said Richard Hoey, an economist at Bache Halsey Stuart.
Stocks
As yesterday's performance indicated, the stock market is advancing, at least in the short run. Historically, the market rallies after a Republican victory. Such rises can be sharp and generally last a month or two.
William M. LeFevre, investment strategist for Purcell, Graham & Company, said the Reagan rally would reach ''something on the order of 1000, or a shade more, between late November 1980 and mid-January 1981.''
According to analysts, industry categories most likely to advance are domestic oil, high technology, aerospace and other defense suppliers. The outlook for such basic industries as steel and autos also seem brighter.
Should the Reagan administration show signs of success in bringing down inflation, the interest-rate-sensitive sector, including home building, finance and retailing, will benefit, said Howard J. Abner, senior vice president of Laidlaw Adams & Peck.
However, the longer-term outlook for the market is uncertain, analysts acknowledge. And Mr. LeFevre noted: ''Not since Calvin Coolidge, in 1925, has the stock market advanced during the first year of any Republican administration.''
Defense
Mr. Reagan has committed his administration to a major rearmament of America. Yesterday, investors certainly took him at his word, with the buying demand for defense stocks so heavy that several issues could not open until after noon.
According to Michael Derchin, an analyst for Oppenheimer & Company, the election of many conservative candidates in Congress is also seen as crucial to the defense industry. ''Recent Congresses have tilted toward butter when they weighed the guns-or-butter issue,'' said Mr. Derchin. ''But this one will tilt toward guns.''
Under the Reagan Administration, the defense industry expects a major buildup of strategic weapons, including a speedup of the MX missile program, which is expected to cost $60 billion to $70 billion over several years.
A replacement for the 20-year-old B-52 bomber, either the so-called Stealth bomber or a derivative of the canceled B-1, is likely to have high priority. And production of cruise missiles and Trident submarines is expected to be stepped up.
Defense experts say that the aerospace industry should get a lift from the export of sophisticated fighter aircraft, reversing the ban of the Carter years.
Boeing and Martin Marietta are considered likely to be among the leading beneficiaries of the defense buildup. Boeing is the prime contractor for the air-launched cruise missile and would also likely be the lead concern for the Stealth bomber. Martin Marietta would get nearly a third of the revenues from the MX missile program.
Among the other companies expected to reap handsome rewards from the Reagan arms buildup: General Dynamics, maker of the Trident, and Northrup, which builds fighter planes that should be popular exports.
Steel
''I see the election results as the start of a whole new era of greater productivity and profitability for the steel industry,'' said William J. DeLancey, chief executive of the Republic Steel Corporation and chairman of the American Iron and Steel Institute, the industry trade group.
Yet the new era, in Mr. DeLancey's view, is a gradual, long-term proposition, resulting from an expected shift in Government policy toward less regulation and more encouragement for investment in capital-intensive industries, such as steel.
''There won't be instantaneous results,'' he said, ''but in time the steel industry will benefit.'' Specifically, steel executives expect that a recommended two-year delay on some pollution strictures will be approved. Moreover, they anticipate the continuation of the trigger-price system, reinstituted last month, which provides the domestic industry with some protection from dumping of low-cost foreign production.
David M. Roderick, chairman of the United States Steel Corporation, said that he expected the new Reagan appointees to maintain the policies already in place and ''continue to broaden our support.''
Autos
It is the antiregulatory and tax-cutting side of the Reagan agenda that is most attractive to Detroit executives. Thus, in a Reagan Administration, they see lower costs and incentives for raising the huge amounts of capital the industry needs to convert its production to the smaller, fuel-thrifty cars. The total cost of that retooling is estimated at $80 billion through 1985.
Perhaps the most immediate advantage of a Reagan Administration for car and truck makers, executives say, should be a change in attitude at such regulatory agencies as the Department of Trade and the Environmental Protection Agency.
Mr. Reagan has proposed relief on the Federal fuel economy standards and eliminating requirements for ''passive restraints'' - air bags or automatic seat belts. Dropping the passive restraint requirement alone could save the industry hundreds of millions of dollars, estimates a legislative analyst for one of the Big Three auto makers.
One point of uncertainty among Detroit executives is what Mr. Reagan will do about car shipments from Japan. Mr. Reagan has said he would talk to the Japanese about voluntary restraint but expressed reservations about imposing definite import restrictions.
Moreover, Chrysler executives take comfort from Mr. Reagan's complete turnabout on legislation to aid the auto maker. A year ago, when asked about Chrysler, Mr. Reagan replied, ''What's wrong with bankruptcy?'' But last September, standing in the humming assembly plant where renovation was financed by Government-guaranteed loans, he characterized the rescue program as the ''proper answer.'' Energy
With Mr. Reagan in the White House and a more conservative Congress, energy executives and analysts foresee a much greater emphasis on energy production and the development of nuclear power, with the breeder reactor pushed harder.
On the other hand, less emphasis will be placed on conservation, energy-related environmental issues, developing renewable resources and equity for consumer groups, according to energy experts.
In some respects, they say, much of the fundamental energy debate will now change. No longer will the basic dynamic of energy politics be consumer states versus producer states. Consumer-oriented liberals were battered in this election.
''This is cataclysmic for energy policy,'' said James Bishop Jr., an aide to former Energy Secretary James R. Schlesinger and now a consultant and writer. ''The production ethic will now be predominant, and the debates over price control and equity questions will be gone.''
Despite Mr. Reagan's campaign threats to scrap the Department of Energy, some observers say the department may actually be enlarged since two-thirds of its budget is related to national security. ''Those weapons labs have got to be pouring champagne right now,'' Mr. Bishop said.
An early test for the Reagan team will be in its treatment of smaller producers in the face of ultimate price decontrol next October. Without special Federal provisions, these smaller producers are expected to be endangered. If the Reagan team allows that to occur, it will be viewed by analysts as an indication that the new administration is taking an ideological course in energy. If it somehow shields the smaller producers, it will be taken as a sign of a more pragmatic, moderate approach.
Still, energy development is a long-term endeavor, cautioned Douglas Perry, a Gulf executive. ''It takes years to get out, do your studies and get oil onto the market,'' said Mr. Perry.
Moreover, while a more favorable climate for energy development may well increase supply somewhat, industry analysts stress that it will not eradicate ''the energy problem'' by any means.
Trade
There should be ''relatively minor changes'' in international economic policy under a Reagan administration, said Richard W. Rahn, chief economist of the Chamber of Commerce of the United States.
One of the real strengths of American trade policy is that it traditionally has been bipartisan, observed Robert D. Hormats, a United States trade representative who has served in both Democratic and Republican administrations. And Mr. Hormats, like others, foresees no major changes in trade policy under the Reagan team.
''Mr. Reagan will continue to embrace the general principles of free trade,'' said Leif H. Olsen, chairman of Citibank's economic policy committee. ''He will also place a high priority on counteracting dumping and other violations of fair trade.''

PREMIER'S COALITION TRAILS IN AUSTRALIA

Author: UPI

Publication info: New York Times , Late Edition (East Coast); New York, N.Y. [New York, N.Y]13 Oct 1980: 1.11.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/423992853?accountid=11752

Abstract: Australia's national election campaign entered its final week today with Prime Minister Malcolm Fraser's coalition trailing slightly in the polls. He also has offered a naval base at Cockburn Sound near Perth in Western Australia to the United States Navy as a home port. The Labor Party has said it would allow the United States to use Australia for a staging area for the B-52 bombers provided they did not carry nuclear weapons. Mr. [William Hayden]'s party is opposing American use of the Cockburn Sound facility because many of the warships in the United States Navy are nuclear powered.

Links: http://findit.library.jhu.edu/resolve?url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Anytimes&amp;atitle=PREMIER%27S+COALITION+TRAILS+IN+AUSTRALIA&amp;title=New+York+Times&amp;issn=03624331&amp;date=1980-10-13&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=1.11&amp;au=UPI&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=New+York+Times&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text: Australia's national election campaign entered its final week today with Prime Minister Malcolm Fraser's coalition trailing slightly in the polls.
About 9 million people are eligible to vote in the elections next Saturday in which Australia's military relationship with the United States has become an important issue.
In the latest Gallup poll, published yesterday, Mr. Fraser's conservative coalition, consisting of the Liberal and National Country parties, trailed Labor by 2 percentage points, 49 to 51. This represented a gain for the 50-year-old Prime Minister, who was behind by a wider margin earlier.
Mr. Fraser's coalition, in its campaign, has emphasized tight economic management and lowering of the current 10-percent inflation rate.
Labor Party Favors Tax Cut
The Labor Party, led by William Hayden, 47, says that if it is elected it will spend federal money to reduce the current 6 percent unemployment rate, immediately cut income taxes and freeze the price of gasoline for 12 months.
Mr. Fraser, who was first elected in 1975, has been an outspoken critic of the Soviet intervention in Afghanistan and nearly ordered Australian athletes to boycott the Moscow Olympic Games.
His Government has increased defense spending nearly 18 percent to $4.1 billion for the current fiscal year and has committed the nation to providing bases for United States military planes and warships in Australia.
The Prime Minister said he would allow American B-52 bombers, which have been flying over northern Australia on training missions from Guam, to use the Royal Australian Air Force base at Darwin as a refueling and staging area.
Use of Naval Base Offered
He also has offered a naval base at Cockburn Sound near Perth in Western Australia to the United States Navy as a home port. The Labor Party has said it would allow the United States to use Australia for a staging area for the B-52 bombers provided they did not carry nuclear weapons. Mr. Hayden's party is opposing American use of the Cockburn Sound facility because many of the warships in the United States Navy are nuclear powered.
In the current Parliament, Mr. Fraser's coalition has a majority of 48 in the 124-seat House of Representatives and an overall 6-seat majority in the Senate.
